p.s:
NEW
EXPERIMENTS
Phy&longs;ico-Mechanicall
Touching the Air.

NEW
EXPERIMENTS
Phy&longs;ico-Mechanicall,
Touching

The SPRING of the AIR,
and its EFFECTS,
(Made, for the mo&longs;t part, in a New
PNEuMATICAL ENGINE)
Written by way of LETTER

To the Right Honorable Charles
Lord Vicount of Dungarvan,
Elde&longs;t Son to the EARL of CORKE.
By the Honorable Robert Boyle E&longs;que

OXFORD:
Printed by H: Hall, Printer to the Univer&longs;ity,
for The: Robin&longs;on. 1660.
To the Reader.

ALthough the following Trea­
ti&longs;e being far more prolix
then becomes a Letter, and
then I at fir&longs;t intended it; I
am very unwilling to en­
crea&longs;e the already exce&longs;sive bulk of the
Book by a Preface, yet there are &longs;ome par­
ticulars that I think my &longs;elf oblig'd to take
notice of to the Reader, as things, that will
either concern him to know, or me to have
known.

In the fir&longs;t place then: If it be demand­
ed why I publi&longs;h to the World a Letter, which
by its Stile and diver&longs;e Pa&longs;&longs;ages, appears
to have been written as well For, as To a
particular Per&longs;on; I have chiefly the&longs;e two
things to an&longs;wer: The one, That the Ex­
periments therein related, having been ma­
ny of them try'd in the pre&longs;ence of Ingeni­
ous Men; and by that means having made
&longs;ome noi&longs;e among the Virtuo&longs;i (in&longs;omuch
that &longs;ome of them have been &longs;ent into Fo­
reign Countries, where they have had the
luck not to be de&longs;pi&longs;'d) I could not without
quite tyring more then one Amanuen&longs;is, give
out half as many Copies of them as were &longs;o
earne&longs;tly de&longs;ired, that I could not civilly
refu&longs;e them.

The other, That intelligent
Per&longs;ons in matters of this kinde per&longs;waded
me, that the publication of what I had ob­
&longs;erv'd touching the Nature of the Air,
would not be u&longs;ele&longs;s to the World; and that
in an Age &longs;o taken with Novelties as is ours,
the&longs;e new Experiments would be grateful to
the Lovers of free and real Learning: So
that I might at once comply with my grand
De&longs;ign of promoting Experimental and
U&longs;eful Philo&longs;ophy, and obtain the great &longs;a­
tisfaction of giving &longs;ome to ingenious Men;
the hope of which, is, I confe&longs;s, a tempta­
tion that I cannot ca&longs;ily re&longs;i&longs;t.

Of my being &longs;omewhat prolix in many
of my Experiments, I have the&longs;e Rea&longs;ons
to render, That &longs;ome of them being altoge­
ther new, &longs;eem'd to need the being circum­
&longs;tantially related, to keep the Reader from
di&longs;tru&longs;ting them: That divers Circum­
&longs;tances I did here and there &longs;et down for fear
of forgetting them, when I may hereafter
have occa&longs;ion to make u&longs;e of them in my o­
ther Writings: That in divers ca&longs;es I
thought it nece&longs;&longs;ary to deliver things cir­
cum&longs;tantially, that the Per&longs;on I addre&longs;&longs;ed
them to, might without mi&longs;take, and with
as little trouble as is po&longs;sible, be able to re­
peat &longs;uch unu&longs;ual Experiments: and that
after I con&longs;ented to let my Ob&longs;ervations be
made publick, the mo&longs;t ordinary Rea&longs;on of
my prolixity was, That fore&longs;eeing that &longs;uch
a trouble as I met with in making tho&longs;e try­
als carefully, and the great expence of time
that they nece&longs;&longs;arily require, (not to mention
the charges of making the Engine, and im­
ploying a man to manage it) will probably
keep mo&longs;t men from trying again the&longs;e Ex­
periments; I thought I might doe the gene­
rality of my Readers no unacceptable pece
of &longs;ervice, by &longs;o punctually relating what
I carefully ob&longs;erv'd, that they may look up­
on the&longs;e Narratives as &longs;tanding Records in
our new Pneumaticks, and need not reite­
rate them&longs;elves an Experiment to have as
di&longs;tinct an Idea of it, as may &longs;uffice them
to ground their Reflections and Speculations
upon.

And becau&longs;e &longs;ometimes 'tis the Di&longs;cour&longs;e
made upon the Experiment that makes it
appear prolix, I have commonly left a con-
&longs;picuous interval betwixt &longs;uch Di&longs;cour&longs;es,
and the Experiments whereunto they belong,
or are annexed; that they who de&longs;ire onely
the Hi&longs;torical part of the account we give
of our Engine, may read the Narra­
tives, without being put to the trouble
of reading the Reflections too: Which I
here take notice of, for the &longs;ake of tho&longs;e
that are well ver&longs;'d in the New Philo&longs;ophy,
and in the Mathematicks; that &longs;uch
may skip what was de&longs;ign'd, but for &longs;uch
Per&longs;ons as may be le&longs;s acquainted even then
I, with matters of this nature (&longs;carce &longs;o
much as mention'd by any Writer in our
Language) and not for them from whom
I &longs;hall be much more forward to learn, then
to pretend to teach them.

Of my being
wont to &longs;peak rather doubtfully, or he&longs;itant­
ly, then re&longs;olvedly, concerning matters
wherein I apprehend &longs;ome difficulty, I have
in another Treati&longs;e (which may, through
Gods A&longs;si&longs;tance, come abroad ere long)
given a particular, and I hope a &longs;atisfacto­
ry account: Wherefore I &longs;hall now defend
my Practice but by the Ob&longs;ervation of Ari­
&longs;totle, who &longs;omewhere notes, That to &longs;eem
to know all things certainly, and to &longs;peak
po&longs;itively of them, is a trick of bold and
yong Fellows: Whereas tho&longs;e that are in-
deed intelligent and con&longs;iderate, are wont to
imploy more wary and diffident Expre&longs;si­
ons, or (as he &longs;peaks) sife/ad a)ei\ to\ s,
to\ ta\xa.

There are divers Reflections, and other
Pa&longs;&longs;ages in the following Epi&longs;tle, and even
&longs;ome Experiments (occa&longs;ionally mention'd)
which may &longs;eem either impertinent or &longs;u­
perfluous, but are not &longs;o: Being purpo&longs;ely
written, either to evince &longs;ome truth oppo&longs;'d,
or di&longs;prove &longs;ome erroneous conceit main­
tain'd, by &longs;ome eminent New Philo&longs;opher,
or by &longs;ome other Ingenious Men, who, I
pre&longs;um'd, would ea&longs;ily forgive me the ha­
ving on &longs;uch occa&longs;ions purpo&longs;ely omitted
their Names; though an inqui&longs;itive Per&longs;on
will probably di&longs;cover divers of them, by
the mention of the Opinions di&longs;prov'd in
the Experiments I am excu&longs;ing.

Ever &longs;ince I di&longs;cern'd the u&longs;efulne&longs;s
of &longs;peculative Geometry to Natural Phi­
lo&longs;ophy, the unhappy Di&longs;tempers of my Eyes,
have &longs;o far kept me from being much con­
ver&longs;ant in it, that I fear I &longs;hall need the par­
doz of my Mathematical Readers, for &longs;ome
Pa&longs;&longs;ages, which if I had been deeply skill'd
in Geometry, I &longs;hould have treated more ac­
curately.

And indeed, having, for Rea&longs;ons el&longs;e­
where deduc'd, purpo&longs;ely kept my &longs;elf a
&longs;tranger to mo&longs;t of the new Hypothe&longs;es in
Philo&longs;ophy, I am &longs;en&longs;ible enough that the
Engine I treat of has prevail'd with me to
write of &longs;ome &longs;ubjects which are &longs;ufficient­
ly remote from tho&longs;e I have been mo&longs;t con­
ver&longs;ant in.

And having been reduc'd to
write the greate&longs;t part of the en&longs;uing Letter
at a di&longs;tance, not onely from my Library,
but from my own Manu&longs;cripts, I cannot
but fear that my Di&longs;cour&longs;es do not onely
want many choice things wherewith the
Learned Writings of others might have en­
riched or imbelli&longs;hed them: But that partly
for this Rea&longs;on, and partly for that touch'd
upon a little before, It is po&longs;sible I may
have mention'd &longs;ome Notions already pub­
li&longs;h'd by others, without taking notice of the
Authors, not out of any de&longs;ign to defraud
de&longs;erving Men, but for want of knowing
&longs;uch particulars to have been already pub­
li&longs;h'd by them: E&longs;pecially the Experiments
of our Engine being them&longs;elves &longs;ufficient
to hint &longs;uch Notions as we build upon
them.

The order of the Experiments every
Reader may alter, as &longs;uits be&longs;t with his own
De&longs;ign in peru&longs;ing them; For not onely all
tho&longs;e betwixt whom there is an Affinity in
Nature (by belonging to one &longs;ubject) are not
always plac'd one by another, but they are
not &longs;till &longs;et down &longs;o much as in the order
wherein they were made; but mo&longs;t common­
ly in that ca&longs;ual one wherein my occa&longs;ions in­
duc'd me to di&longs;patch them to the Pre&longs;s.

And,
which is wor&longs;e, I did u&longs;ually &longs;end quite a­
way the former Experiments, before the
later were written, or perhaps &longs;o much as
made: Whereby I lo&longs;t the advantage of cor­
recting and &longs;upplying the Imperfections of
what I had formerly written, by the light of
my &longs;ub&longs;equent Tryals and Di&longs;coveries.

Be&longs;ides all this, the di&longs;temper in my eyes
forbidding me not onely to write my &longs;elf &longs;o
much as one Experiment, but even to read
over my &longs;elf what I dictated to others.

I can­
not but fear, that be&longs;ides the Authors mi&longs;takes,
this Edition may be blemi&longs;h'd by many, that
may be properly imputed to a very unskil­
ful Writer (whom I was often times by ha&longs;te
reduc'd again&longs;t my cu&longs;tom to imploy) and
may have e&longs;caped the Diligence of that
Learned Friend, that does me the favor to
over-&longs;ee the Pre&longs;s; e&longs;pecially there being
the di&longs;tance of two days Fourney betwixt it
and me.

I need not perhaps repre&longs;ent to the equi-
table Reader, how much the &longs;trange Confu­
&longs;ions of this unhappy Nation, in the mid&longs;t
of which I have made and written the&longs;e
Experiments, are apt to di&longs;turb that calm­
ne&longs;s of Minde, and undi&longs;tractednc&longs;s of
Thoughts, that are wont to be requi&longs;ite to
Happy Speculations.

But I pre&longs;ume,
that by all the&longs;e things put together, he
will readily perceive, That I have been
&longs;o far from following the Poets prudent
Coun&longs;el touching the &longs;low Publication of
Books de&longs;ign'd to purcha&longs;e credit by,
—— Nonumque prematur in Annum

that I &longs;uffer this Treati&longs;e to come abroad
into the World with a multitude of Di&longs;ad­
vantages.

But if it be demanded, why then I did
not make it fitter for the Pre&longs;s before I &longs;ent
it thither?

my An&longs;wer mu&longs;t be, That not
at fir&longs;t imagining that this &longs;ort of Experi­
ments would prove any thing near &longs;o trouble­
&longs;ome, either to make, or to Record, as I
afterwards found them, I did, to engage
the Printer to di&longs;patch, promi&longs;e him to &longs;end
him the whole Epi&longs;tle in a very &longs;hort time:
So that although now and then the occa&longs;ional
vacations of the Pre&longs;s, by rea&longs;on of Fe&longs;ti-
vals, or the ab&longs;ence of the Corrector, gave
me the lei&longs;ure to ex&longs;paciate upon &longs;ome &longs;ub­
ject; yet being oftentimes call'd upon to di&longs;­
patch the Papers to the Pre&longs;s, my promi&longs;e,
and many unexpected Avocations, obliged
me to a ha&longs;te, which, though it have detract­
ed nothing from the Faithfulne&longs;s of the
Hi&longs;torical part of our Book, has (I fear)
been di&longs;advantageous enough to all the re&longs;t.

And I made the le&longs;s &longs;cruple to let the fol­
lowing Papers pa&longs;s out of my hands, with
all their Imperfections; becau&longs;e, as the
publick Affairs, and my own, were then
circum&longs;tanc'd, I knew not when (if at all)
I &longs;hould be again in a condition to pro&longs;ecute
Experiments of this kinde; e&longs;pecially,
&longs;ince (to omit my being almo&longs;t weary of be­
ing, as it were, confin'd to one &longs;ort of Ex­
periments) I am pre-ingag'd (if it plea&longs;e
God to vouch&longs;afe me Life and Health) to
imploy my fir&longs;t lei&longs;ure in the publication of
&longs;ome other Phy&longs;iological Papers, which I
thought 'twould make me much the &longs;itter to
take in hand, if I fir&longs;t di&longs;patch'd all that
I had at this time to write touching our
Engine.

I have this further to adde, by way
of Excu&longs;e, That as it has been my de&longs;ign
in publi&longs;hing the&longs;e Experiments to gratifie
Ingenious men; &longs;o, if I have not been
much flattered, I may hope that the vari­
ous hints to be met with in the following
Letter, will (at lea&longs;t) &longs;omewhat awaken
mens thoughts, & excite them to new &longs;pecula­
tions (&longs;uch as perhaps even inqui&longs;itive men
would &longs;carce el&longs;e light upon) and I need not
de&longs;pair, that even the examination of &longs;uch
new Su&longs;picions and Enquiries will hence al­
&longs;o, at lea&longs;t Occa&longs;ionally be facilitated: I
&longs;aid Occa&longs;ionally, becau&longs;e it being, as 'tis
proverbially &longs;aid, Facile Inventis addere.
It &longs;eems not irrational to expect, that our
Engine it &longs;elf, and divers of our Experi­
ments, will be much promoted by the Indu­
&longs;try of Inventive and Mathematical Wits,
who&longs;e contrivances may ea&longs;ily either correct
or &longs;upply, and con&longs;equently &longs;urpa&longs;s many of
tho&longs;e we have made u&longs;e of.

And, particu­
larly, if Men by skill and patience can ar­
rive both to evacuate &longs;uch Receivers as
ours, till there be no more Air left in them,
then there &longs;eems to have remain'd in the
Gla&longs;&longs;es made u&longs;e of about the Magdebur­
gick Experiment (hereafter to be mention­
ed) and to keep out the Air for a competent
while, the U&longs;efulne&longs;s and Di&longs;coveries of our
Engine, will not be a little advanc'd.

And
perhaps that may belong to it, which I re-
member Seneca &longs;peaks of Nature, Initia­
tos (&longs;ays be) nos credimus, in Ve&longs;tibulo
ejus hæremus: For being now in a place
where we are not quite de&longs;titute of moderate­
ly skilful Artificers, we have, &longs;ince the
Conclu&longs;ion of the following Letter, made
&longs;ome Additions to our Engine, by who&longs;e help
we finde (upon &longs;ome new tryals) that we
may be able, without much of new trouble,
to keep the ambient Air out of the exhau­
&longs;ted Receiver for a whole day; and perhaps
we &longs;hould be able to keep it out much longer,
if before we &longs;hall have di&longs;patch'd &longs;ome ur­
gent Affairs, and publi&longs;h'd &longs;ome Papers for
which a kinde of Promi&longs;e is thought to make
us Debtors to the Pre&longs;s, we could be at lei­
&longs;ure to pro&longs;ecute &longs;uch Experiments, as may
po&longs;sibly afford a Supplement to the follow­
ing Treati&longs;e, from which I &longs;hall now no lon­
ger detain the Reader.
I know
Friendly Reader,

I Know all Per&longs;ons
that have a publick
Spirit for the Ad­
vancement of Lear­
ning, will think much that this
piece came not out in a Lan­
guage of more general U&longs;e,
then this you &longs;ee it now attir'd
in; e&longs;pecially &longs;ince the Excel­
lent Noble Per&longs;on, who is the
Author, is known to be well a­
ble him&longs;elf (being almo&longs;t uni­
ver&longs;ally a Lingui&longs;t) to have gi­
ven it either the Old Latin, or
the newer French Dre&longs;s.

But if it be an Honor to a
Language to be preferr'd, and
this Honor breeds &longs;ometimes an
Emulation, as anciently it did
between the Greeks and Ro­
mans, it cannot be thought
unhand&longs;ome for an Engli&longs;h
Nobleman to have preferr'd
his own: And it may be a &longs;uf­
ficient Rea&longs;on for the Gentry
of Forein Parts to learn our
Speech, or keep Interpreters,
that they are &longs;ure to have for
their requital, from many of
our Engli&longs;h Writers (as here
from this piece) much curiou&longs;ly
ingenious, and profitable Lear­
ning.

But as to this particular (give
me leave to u&longs;e Words from a
Story) Since the Mountain
cannot come to Mahomet,
Mahomet will go to the
Mountain: I mean thus;
Becau&longs;e many witty Men, Per­
&longs;ons of Honor and E&longs;tate e&longs;pe­
cially, may be &longs;uppo&longs;'d to be a­
ble to make a better account, by
employing their Studies and
Time on Matter then Words,
and &longs;o are ju&longs;tly impeded from
learning Languages; And be­
cau&longs;e (as I may judge) the no­
ble Author is willing to oblige all
Men, He has already provi­
ded, that this piece &longs;hall &longs;hort­
ly be done into Latine, that &longs;o
it may come home to divers wor­
thy Per&longs;ons in its Stream, who
cannot travel to finde it out in
its fir&longs;t Origine.

Having therefore leave &longs;o
to do, I cannot forbear to give
the World the Adverti&longs;ement
of this Latine Edition, le&longs;t
&longs;ome skilful Arti&longs;t &longs;hould take
needle&longs;s pains about a Work,
which will, ere long (by Gods
furtherance) be done to his
Hands; For &longs;uch unprofitable
expences of Study have too fre­
quently happened, and too much
to the di&longs;advantage of Learn­
ing, for want of a &longs;ufficient
Corre&longs;pondence and Intercour&longs;e
between &longs;uch as are exerci&longs;ed
in the Mines of Wi&longs;dome.

This is all the trouble I &longs;hall
at pre&longs;ent give you: Nor &longs;hall I
need minde thee, if you have a
true gu&longs;t for the Book you read,
to have an honor and thankful
regard to the Per&longs;on that has
favor'd us with the Communi­
cation of the&longs;e his Tryals, & is
manife&longs;tly &longs;o great a Patron
and Friend to Experimental
Learning, and all true Wi&longs;dom;
for &longs;hould you fail in this, you
might de&longs;ervedly be depriv'd of
&longs;ome other Ob&longs;ervations on the
&longs;ame &longs;ubject, which the Au­
thor, I heare, has made &longs;ince the
fini&longs;hing of this Treati&longs;e.

I de&longs;ire to be excu&longs;ed that I
not make Excu&longs;es for the &longs;low­
ne&longs;s of the Publication, hoping
that the long expectation you
have had of it, will enhance, and
not dimini&longs;h your delight in the
enjoyment of a piece like to be,
among&longs;t the &longs;tudents in accurate
Philo&longs;ophy, of &longs;o generall accep­
tance.
Farewel.
R: Sh.

A Summary of the chief Matters treated
of in this Epi&longs;tolical Di&longs;cour&longs;e.

THe Proæmium, wherein is &longs;et down the
occa&longs;ion of this Di&longs;cour&longs;e, 1. The mo­
tives that induc'd the Author thereunto, 2 &c.
The hints he received, 5. The things where­
in this Engine excels any that have yet been
made u&longs;e of, 6 &c. The de&longs;cription of the
Engine and its parts, 8 &c. The way of pre­
paring and u&longs;ing it, 15 &c. The divi&longs;ion of
the Experiments tryable thereby into two
&longs;orts, and the difficulty of excluding the
Air. 18 &c.

The fir&longs;t Experiment, touching the man­
ner of pumping out the Air, and by what de­
grees the Receiver is emptyed, 20, &c. A di­
gre&longs;sion touching the Spring or Ela&longs;tical
power of the Air, with an attempt for a Me­
chanical Explication thereof, nece&longs;&longs;ary to be
premi&longs;'d for the explanation of the Phæno­
mena, exhibited in this and the &longs;ub&longs;equent
Experiments. 22 &c.

The &longs;econd Experiment, touching the pre&longs;­
&longs;ure of the Air again&longs;t the &longs;ides of the Bodies
it invirons, 37 &c. with a digre&longs;sive Ex­
plication of the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air included
within an ambient Body. 39 &c.

The third Experiment, touching the
force requi&longs;ite to draw down the Sucker, 42
&c. The Opinion of an eminent Modern
Naturali&longs;t examin'd. 44 &c.

The fourth Experiment, touching the
&longs;welling of a Bladder; with the degrees by
which it increa&longs;es, 45 &c. Another Opini­
on of a Learned Author examin'd. 48 &c.

The fifth Experiment, touching the break­
ing of a Bladder in the Receiver, 49 &c.
And of another by heat. 52

The &longs;ixth Experiment, of divers ways by
which the ela&longs;tical expan&longs;ion of the Air
was mea&longs;ur'd. 52 &c

The &longs;eventh Experiment, touching what
Figure does be&longs;t re&longs;i&longs;t the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air. 62 &c.

The eighth Experiment, tending to a fur­
ther Demon&longs;tration of the former, from the
breaking of gla&longs;s a Helmet inward. 64 &c.

The ninth Experiment, contains a fur­
ther confirmation from the breaking of a
Gla&longs;s outward, 66 &c. with an Experiment to
prove, that the&longs;e Phænomena proceed not
from an invincible Fuga vacui 69. A de­
&longs;cription of other &longs;mall Receivers, and their
Conveniencies, 70 &c. A Receipt for the
making of a Compo&longs;ition to Cement crackt
Gla&longs;&longs;es. 73

The tenth Experiment, touching the fla­
ming of Candles inclo&longs;ed in the Receiver. 74 &c.

The eleventh Expertment, touching the
burning of Coals, 78. And the la&longs;ting of
the excande&longs;cence of an included piece of I­
ron. 80.

The twelfth Experiment concerning the
burning of Match. 82

The thirteenth Experiment, concerning
the further pro&longs;ecution of the preceding,
tending to prove the extinction of the Fire
in the former Experiments, not to have
proceeded from the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Fire by the
Fumes, 84. Some remarkable Circum&longs;tan­
ces of it, 86. The Experiment of Match
try'd in a &longs;mall Receiver. 87

The fourteenth Experiment, touching the
&longs;triking Fire, and kindling of Powder with
the Lock of a Pi&longs;tol in the evacuated Recei­
ver. 88 &c.

The fifteenth Experiment, touching the
un&longs;ucce&longs;sfulne&longs;s of kindling included Bo­
dies with a burning Gla&longs;s, and the Au­
thors intention to pro&longs;ecute it further. 102

The &longs;ixteenth Experiment, concerning the
operation of the Load&longs;tone. 105, &c.

OF

ments to tho&longs;e I formerly
&longs;ent You over: I could not

&longs;ort of Experiments it might the mo&longs;t ac­

And at the &longs;ame
time, perceiving by Letters from &longs;ome

veral of the Virtuo&longs;i there, were very
intent upon the examination of the Inte­
re&longs;t of the Ayr, in hindring the de&longs;cent

more fit and &longs;ea&longs;onable manner, then by

cour&longs;'d of where you are, together with

Since

ment of that Experimental Philo&longs;ophy,

And I am not faintly induc'd to make

Con&longs;iderations: The one, That the Ayr

mo&longs;t other Creatures that breath, can­

And the other is, That the

our own Bodies, and mo&longs;t of the others

petually contiguous; not onely its alte-

&longs;hip, in the fir&longs;t place, with the Hint I

leave as little acce&longs;s, as po&longs;&longs;ible, to the ex­
ternal Air: And in the mid&longs;t of this cover
is left a hole (H I) of about half an inch
over, invironed al&longs;o with a ring or &longs;ocket
of the &longs;ame mettal, and fitted likewi&longs;e
with a bra&longs;s &longs;topple (K) made in the form
of the Key of a &longs;top-cock, and exactly
ground into the hole (H I) it is to fill; &longs;o
as that though it be turn'd round in the
cavity it po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;es, it will not let in the
Air, and yet may be put in or taken out
at plea&longs;ure, for u&longs;es to be hereafter men­
tioned.

In order to &longs;ome of which, it is
perforated with a little hole, (8) traver&longs;ing
the whole thickne&longs;s of it at the lower
end; through which, and a little bra&longs;s
Ring (L) fa&longs;tned to one &longs;ide, (no matter
which) of the bottom of the &longs;topple
(FG) a &longs;tring (8, 9, 10) might pa&longs;s, to

The la&longs;t thing belonging to our Recei­
ver, is the &longs;top-cock de&longs;igned in the fir&longs;t
Figure by (N.) for the better fa&longs;tening
of which to the neck, and exacter exclu&longs;i­
on of the Air, there was &longs;oder'd on to
the &longs;hank of the Cock (X) a Plate of
Tin, (MTUW) long enough to cover
the neck of the Receiver.

But becau&longs;e
the cementing of this was a matter of
&longs;ome difficulty, it will not be ami&longs;s to
mention here the manner of it, which
was, That the cavity of the tin Plate was
fill'd with a melted Cement, made of
Pitch, Ro&longs;in, and Wood-a&longs;hes, well in­
corporated; and to hinder this liquid
Mixture from getting into the Orifice (Z)
of the &longs;hank, (X) that hole was &longs;topt

whereby it might be pull'd out of the up­
per Orifice of the Receiver; and then,
the gla&longs;s neck of the Receiver being well
warm'd, was thru&longs;t into this Cement, and
over the &longs;hank whereby it was effected,
that all the &longs;pace betwixt the tin Plate and
the Receiver, and betwixt the internal
&longs;uperficies of the Receiver, and the
&longs;hanck of the Cock, was filld with the
Cement; and &longs;o we have di&longs;pach'd the
fir&longs;t and upper part of the Engine.

The undermo&longs;t remaining part con&longs;i&longs;ts
of a Frame, and of a &longs;ucking Pump, or
as we formerly call'd it, an Air Pump, &longs;up­
ported by it: The Frame is of Wood,
&longs;mall, but very &longs;trong, con&longs;i&longs;ting of three
legs, (111) &longs;o plac'd, that one &longs;ide of
it may &longs;tand perpendicular, that the free
motion of the hand may not be hindered.

In the mid&longs;t of which frame, is tran&longs;ver&longs;ly
nail'd a board, (222) which may not im­
properly be call'd a Midriff, upon which
re&longs;ts, and to which is &longs;trongly fa&longs;tned, the
main part of the Pump it &longs;elf, which is
the onely thing remaining to be de&longs;cri­
bed.

The Pump con&longs;i&longs;ts of four parts, a
hollow Cylindre, a Sucker, a handle to
move that Sucker, and a Valve.

The Cylindre was (by a pattern) ca&longs;t
of bra&longs;s; it is in length about 14 inches,
thick enough to be very &longs;trong, notwith­
&longs;tanding the Cylindrical cavity left with­
in it; this cavity is about three inches
Diameter, and makes as exact a Cylin­
dre as the Artificer was able to bore.

This hollow Cylindre is fitted with a &longs;uck­
er, (4455) con&longs;i&longs;ting of two parts, the
one (44) &longs;omewhat le&longs;s in Diameter then
the cavity of the Cylindre, upon which
is nail'd a good thick piece of tan'd &longs;hoe
Leather, which will go &longs;o clo&longs;e to the
Cylindre, that it will need to be very
forcibly knock'd and ram'd in, if at any
time it be taken out, which is therefore
done, that it may the more exactly hin­
der the Air from in&longs;inuating it &longs;elf be­
twixt it and the &longs;ides of the Cylindre
whereon it is to move.

To the mid&longs;t of this former part of the
Sucker is &longs;trongly fa&longs;tned the other,
namely a thick and narrow plate of Iron,
(55) &longs;omewhat longer then the Cylindre,
one of who&longs;e edges is &longs;mooth, but at the
other edge it is indented (as I may &longs;o
&longs;peak) with a row of teeth delineated in
the Scheme, into who&longs;e intervals are to
be fitted, the teeth of a &longs;mall Iron nut;
() (as Trade&longs;-men call it) which is fa&longs;t­
ned by two &longs;taples (22) to the under &longs;ide
of the formerly mention'd tran&longs;ver&longs;e
board (222) on which the Cylindre re&longs;ts,
and is turn'd to and fro by the third piece
of this Pump, namely, the handle or
manubrium, (7) of which the Figure gives
a &longs;ufficient de&longs;cription.

The fourth and la&longs;t part of this Cylin­
dre, is the Valve, (R) con&longs;i&longs;ting of a
hole bored through at the top of the Cy­
lindre, a little tapering towards the cavi­
ty; into which hole is ground a tapering
Peg of bra&longs;s, to be thru&longs;t in, and taken
out at plea&longs;ure.

The Engine being thus de&longs;crib'd, it
will be requi&longs;ite to adde, that &longs;omething
is wont to be done before it be &longs;et on
work, for the more ea&longs;ie moving of the
Sucker, and for the better exclu&longs;ion of
the outward Air: which when the Ve&longs;&longs;el
begins to be exhau&longs;ted, is much more dif­
ficult to be kept out then one would ea&longs;i­
ly imagine.

There mu&longs;t then be fir&longs;t powr'd in at
the top of the Receiver a little &longs;allad oyl,
partly to fill up any &longs;mall intervalls that
may happen to be betwixt the contigu­
ous &longs;urfaces of the internal parts of the
Stop-cock: And partly that it may be
the more ea&longs;ie to turn the Key (S) back­
wards and forwards.

Pretty &longs;tore of oyl
mu&longs;t al&longs;o be pour'd into the Cylindre,
both that the Sucker may &longs;lip up and
down in it the more &longs;moothly and freely,
and that the Air might be the better
hindred from getting in between them:
And for the like rea&longs;ons, a little oyl is to
be u&longs;ed al&longs;o about the Valve.

Upon
which occa&longs;ion, it would not be omitted
(for it is &longs;trange) that oftentimes, when
neither the pouring in of water, nor even
of oyl alone, prov'd capable to make the
Sucker move ea&longs;ily enough in the Cylin­
der; a mixture of both tho&longs;e Liquors
would readily (&longs;ometimes even to admi­
ration) perform the de&longs;ired effect.

And
la&longs;tly, the bra&longs;s cover of the Receiver,
being put into the bra&longs;s ring formerly de­
&longs;crib'd, that no Air may get between
them, it will be very requi&longs;ite to plai&longs;ter
over very carefully the upper edges of
both, with the plai&longs;ter formerly mention­
ed, or &longs;ome other as clo&longs;e, which is to be
&longs;pread upon the edges with a hot Iron;
that being melted, it may run into and
fill up all the crannies, or other little ca­
vities, at which the Air might otherwi&longs;e
get entrance.

All things being thus fitted, and the
lower &longs;hank (O) of the &longs;top-cock being
put into the upper Orifice of the Cylin­
der (&), into which it was exactly ground;
the Experimenter is fir&longs;t, by turning the
handle, to force the Sucker to the top of
the Cylinder, that there may be no Air
left in the upper part of it: Then &longs;hut­
ting the Valve with the Plug, and turning
the other way, he is to draw down the
Sucker to the bottom of the Cylinder;
by which motion of the Sucker, the Air
that was formerly in the Cylinder being
thru&longs;t out, and none being permitted to
&longs;ucceed in its room, 'tis manife&longs;t that the
cavity of the Cylinder mu&longs;t be empty,
in reference to the Air: So that if there­
upon the Key of the Stop-cock be &longs;o
turn'd, as that through the perforation of
it, a free pa&longs;&longs;age be opened betwixt the
Cylinder and the Receiver, part of the
Air formerly contain'd in the Receiver,
will nimbly de&longs;cend into the Cylinder.

And this Air, being by the turning back
of the Key hinder'd from the returning
into the Receiver, may, by the opening
of the Valve, and forcing up of the Suck­
er to the top of the Cylinder again, be
driven out into the open Air.

And thus
by the repetition of the motion of the
Sucker upward and downward, and by op­
portunely turning the Key, and &longs;topping
the Valve, as occa&longs;ion requires, more or
le&longs;s Air may be &longs;uck'd out of the Recei­
ver, according to the exigency of the Ex­
periment, and the intention of him that
makes it.

Your Lord&longs;hip will, perhaps, think that
I have been unnece&longs;&longs;arily prolix in this
fir&longs;t part of my Di&longs;cour&longs;e: But if you
had &longs;een how many unexpected difficul­
ties we found to keep out the externall
Air, even for a little while, when &longs;ome
con&longs;iderable part of the internal had been
&longs;uckt out; You would peradventure al­
low, that I might have &longs;et down more
circum&longs;tances then I have, without &longs;et­
ting down any, who&longs;e knowledge, he that
&longs;hall try the Experiment may not have
need of.

Which is &longs;o true, that, before we
proceed any further, I cannot think it un­
&longs;ea&longs;onable to adverti&longs;e Your Lord&longs;hip,
that there are two chief &longs;orts of Experi­
ments, which we de&longs;ign'd in our Engine
to make tryal of: The one, &longs;uch as may
be quickly di&longs;patcht, and therefore may
be try'd in our Engine, though it leak a
little; becau&longs;e the Air may be fa&longs;ter drawn
out, by nimbly plying the Pump, then
it can get in at undi&longs;cern'd leaks; I &longs;ay at
undi&longs;cern'd leaks, becau&longs;e &longs;uch as are big
enough to be di&longs;cover'd can &longs;carce be un­
ea&longs;ie to be &longs;topt.

The other &longs;ort of Ex­
periments con&longs;i&longs;ts of tho&longs;e that require
not onely that the internal Air be drawn
out of the Receiver, but that it be like­
wi&longs;e for a long time kept out of it.

Such
are the pre&longs;ervation of Animal and o­
ther Bodies therein, the germination and
growth of Vegetables, and other tryals
of &longs;everal &longs;orts, which it is apparent can­
not be well made unle&longs;s the external Air
can, for a competent while, be excluded:
Since even at a very &longs;mall leak there may
enough get in, to make the Vacuum &longs;oon
loo&longs;e that name; by which I here declare
once for all, that I under&longs;tand not a &longs;pace
wherein there is no body at all, but &longs;uch
as is either altogether, or almo&longs;t totally
void of Air.

Now this di&longs;tinction of Experiments
I thought fit to premi&longs;e to the en&longs;uing
Narratives, becau&longs;e upon tryal, we found
it &longs;o exceeding (and &longs;carce imaginable) dif-
ficult a matter, to keep out the Air from
getting at all in at any imperceptible hole
or flaw what&longs;oever, in a Ve&longs;&longs;el immedi­
ately &longs;urrounded with the compre&longs;&longs;ed At­
mo&longs;phere, that in &longs;pight of all our care
and diligence, we never were able totally
to exhau&longs;t the Receiver, or keep it when
it was almo&longs;t empty, any con&longs;iderable
time, from leaking more or le&longs;s: although
(as we have lately intimated) by unwearyed
quickne&longs;s in plying the Pump, the inter­
nall Air can be much fa&longs;ter drawn out
then the external can get in, till the Re­
ceiver come to be almo&longs;t quite empty.

And that's enough to enable men to di&longs;­
cover hitherto unob&longs;erved Phænomena of
Nature.

The Experiments therefore of the fir&longs;t
&longs;ort, will, I fear, prove the onely ones
wherewith my Avocations will allow me
to entertain Your Lord&longs;hip in this Letter.

For till your further Commands &longs;hall en­
gage me to undertake, by Gods permi&longs;­
&longs;ion, &longs;uch an Employment, and more lea­
&longs;ure &longs;hall better fit me for it, I know not
whether I &longs;hall be in a condition to try
what may be done, to enable me to give
you &longs;ome account of the other &longs;ort of
Experiments al&longs;o.

TO proceed now to the Phænomena,
exhibited to us by the Engine above
de&longs;cribed; I hold it not unfit to begin
with what does con&longs;tantly and regularly
offer it &longs;elf to our ob&longs;ervation, as depend­
ing upon the Fabrick of the Engine it &longs;elf,
and not upon the nature of this or that
particular Experiment which 'tis employ­
ed to try.

Experi­
ment 1.

Fir&longs;t, Then upon the drawing down
of the Sucker, (the Valve being &longs;hut) the
Cylindrical &longs;pace, de&longs;erted by the Sucker,
is left de void of Air; and therefore, up­
on the turning of the Key, the Air con­
tained in the Receiver ru&longs;hes into the em­
ptyed Cylinder, till the Air in both tho&longs;e
Ve&longs;&longs;els be brought to about an equal
mea&longs;ure of dilatation.

And therefore,
upon &longs;hutting the Receiver by returning
the Key, if you open the Valve, and force
up the Sucker again, you will finde, that
after this fir&longs;t ex&longs;uction you will drive
out almo&longs;t a whole Cylinder full of Air:
But at the following ex&longs;uctions, you will
draw le&longs;s and le&longs;s of Air out of the Recei­
ver into the Cylinder, becau&longs;e that there
will &longs;till remain le&longs;s and le&longs;s Air in the
Receiver it &longs;elf; and con&longs;equently, the
Particles of the remaining Air, having
more room to extend them&longs;elves in, will
le&longs;s pre&longs;s out one another.

This you will
ea&longs;ily perceive, by finding, that you &longs;till
force le&longs;s and le&longs;s Air out of the Cylin­
der; &longs;o that when the Receiver is almo&longs;t
exhau&longs;ted, you may force up the Sucker
almo&longs;t to the top of the Cylinder, be­
fore you will need to un&longs;top the Valve to
let out any Air: And if at &longs;uch time, the
Valve being &longs;hut, you let go the handle of
the Pump, you will finde the Sucker for­
cibly carryed up to the top of the Cylin­
der, by the protru&longs;ion of the external Air;
which, being much le&longs;s rarified then that
within the Cylinder, mu&longs;t have a more
forcible pre&longs;&longs;ure upon the Sucker, then
the internal is able to re&longs;i&longs;t: And by this
means you may know how far you have
emptyed the Receiver.

And to this we
may adde, on this occa&longs;ion, that con&longs;tant­
ly upon the turning of the Key to let out
the Air from the Receiver, into the em­
ptied Cylinder, there is immediately pro­
duced a con&longs;iderably brisk noi&longs;e, e&longs;peci­
ally whil'&longs;t there is any plenty of Air in
the Receiver.

For the more ea&longs;ie under&longs;tanding of the
Experiments tryable by our Engine, I
thought it not &longs;uperfluous, nor un&longs;ea&longs;on­
able in the recital of this fir&longs;t of them, to
in&longs;inuate that notion by which it &longs;eems
likely that mo&longs;t, if not all, of them will
prove explicable.

Your Lord&longs;hip will
ea&longs;ily &longs;uppo&longs;e, that the Notion I &longs;peak
of is, That there is a Spring, or Ela&longs;ti­
cal power in the Air we live in.

By which
e)latg\r or Spring of the Air, that which
I mean is this: That our Air either con­
&longs;i&longs;ts of, or at lea&longs;t abounds with, parts of
&longs;uch a nature, that in ca&longs;e they be bent or
compre&longs;&longs;'d by the weight of the incum­
bent part of the Atmo&longs;phere, or by any o­
ther Body, they do endeavor, as much as
in them lies, to free them&longs;elves from that
pre&longs;&longs;ure, by bearing again&longs;t the contigu­
ous Bodies that keep them bent; and,
a&longs;&longs;oon as tho&longs;e Bodies are remov'd or
reduced to give them way, by pre&longs;ently
unbending and &longs;tretching out them&longs;elves,
either quite, or &longs;o far forth as the con­
tiguous Bodies that re&longs;i&longs;t them will per­
mit, and thereby expanding the whole
parcel of Air, the&longs;e ela&longs;tical Bodies com­
po&longs;e.

This Notion may perhaps be &longs;ome­
what further explain'd, by conceiving the
Air near the Earth to be &longs;uch a heap of
little Bodies, lying one upon another, as
may be re&longs;embled to a Fleece of Wooll.

For this (to omit other likene&longs;&longs;es betwixt
them) con&longs;i&longs;ts of many &longs;lender and flexi­
ble Hairs; each of which, may indeed,
like a little Spring, be ea&longs;ily bent or roul­
ed up; but will al&longs;o, like a Spring, be
&longs;till endeavouring to &longs;tretch it &longs;elf out
again.

For though both the&longs;e Haires,
and the Aerial Corpu&longs;cles to which we
liken them, do ea&longs;ily yield to externall
pre&longs;&longs;ures; yet each of them (by vertue of
its &longs;tructure) is endow'd with a Power or
Principle of &longs;elf-Dilatation; by vertue
whereof, though the hairs may by a Mans
hand be bent and crouded clo&longs;er together,
and into a narrower room then &longs;uits be&longs;t
with the nature of the Body: Yet whil'&longs;t
the compre&longs;&longs;ion la&longs;ts, there is in the fleece
they compo&longs;e an endeavour outwards,
whereby it continually thru&longs;ts again&longs;t the
hand that oppo&longs;es its Expan&longs;ion.

And
upon the removall of the external pre&longs;­
&longs;ure, by opening the hand more or le&longs;s, the
compre&longs;&longs;ed Wooll does, as it were, &longs;pon­
taneou&longs;ly expand or di&longs;play it &longs;elf towards
the recovery of its former more loo&longs;e and
free condition, till the Fleece have ei­
ther regain'd its former Dimen&longs;ions, or
at lea&longs;t, approach'd them as near as the
compre&longs;&longs;ing hand (perchance not quite
open'd) will permit.

This Power of
&longs;elf-Dilatation, is &longs;omewhat more con&longs;pi­
cuous in a dry Spunge compre&longs;&longs;'d, then
in a Fleece of Wooll.

But yet we ra­
ther cho&longs;e to imploy the latter, on this
occa&longs;ion, becau&longs;e it is not like a Spunge,
an entire Body, but a number of &longs;len­
der and flexible Bodies, loo&longs;ely com­
plicated, as the Air it &longs;elf &longs;eems to
be.

There is yet another way to explicate
the Spring of the Air, namely, by &longs;uppo­
&longs;ing with that mo&longs;t ingenious Gentleman,
Mon&longs;ieur Des Cartes, That the Air is no­
thing but a Congeries or heap of &longs;mall
and (for the mo&longs;t part) of flexible Parti­
cles; of &longs;everal &longs;izes, and of all kinde of Fi­
gures which are rai&longs;'d by heat (e&longs;pecially
that of the Sun) into that fluid and
&longs;ubtle Etheriall Body that &longs;urrounds
the Earth; and by the re&longs;tle&longs;&longs;e agi­
tation of that Cele&longs;tial Matter where­
in tho&longs;e Particles &longs;wim, are &longs;o whirl'd
round, that each Corpu&longs;cle endeavours
to beat off all others from coming within
the little Sphear requi&longs;ite to its motion
about its own Center; and (in ca&longs;e any,
by intruding into that Sphear &longs;hall op­
po&longs;e its free Rotation) to expell or drive
it away: So that according to this Do­
ctrine, it imports very little, whether the
particles of the Air have the &longs;tructure re­
qui&longs;ite to Springs, or be of any other
form (how irregular &longs;oever) &longs;ince their
Ela&longs;tical power is not made to depend
upon their &longs;hape or &longs;tructure, but upon
the vehement agitation, and (as it were)
brandi&longs;hing motion, which they receive
from the fluid Ether that &longs;wiftly flows
between them, and whirling about each
of them (independently from the re&longs;t)
not onely keeps tho&longs;e &longs;lender Aërial
Bodies &longs;eparated and &longs;tretcht out (at lea&longs;t,
as far as the Neighbouring ones will per­
mit) which otherwi&longs;e, by rea&longs;on of
their flexiblene&longs;s and weight, would
flag or curl; but al&longs;o makes them hit
again&longs;t, and knock away each other, and
con&longs;equently require more room, then
that which if they were compre&longs;&longs;'d, they
would take up.

By the&longs;e two differing ways, my Lord,
may the Spring of the Air be explicated.

But though the former of them be that,
which by rea&longs;on of its &longs;eeming &longs;omewhat
more ea&longs;ie, I &longs;hall for the mo&longs;t part make
u&longs;e of in the following Di&longs;cour&longs;e: yet
am I not willing to declare peremptorily
for either of them, again&longs;t the other.

And
indeed, though I have in another Treati&longs;e
endeavoured to make it probable, that the
returning of Ela&longs;tical Bodies (if I may &longs;o
call them) forcibly bent, to their former
po&longs;ition, may be Mechanically explica­
ted: Yet I mu&longs;t confe&longs;s, that to deter­
mine whether the motion of Re&longs;titution
in Bodies, proceed from this, That the
parts of a Body of a peculiar Structure
are put into motion by the bending of the
&longs;pring, or from the endeavor of &longs;ome &longs;ub­
tle ambient Body, who&longs;e pa&longs;&longs;age may be
oppo&longs;'d or ob&longs;tructed, or el&longs;e it's pre&longs;&longs;ure
unequally re&longs;i&longs;ted by rea&longs;on of the new
&longs;hape or magnitude, which the bending of
a Spring may give the Pores of it: To
determine this, I &longs;ay, &longs;eems to me a mat­
ter of more difficulty, then at fir&longs;t &longs;ight
one would ea&longs;ily imagine it.

Wherefore
I &longs;hall decline medling with a &longs;ubject,
which is much more hard to be explica-
ted, then nece&longs;&longs;ary to be &longs;o, by him,
who&longs;e bu&longs;ine&longs;s it is not, in this Letter, to
a&longs;&longs;ign the adequate cau&longs;e of the Spring of
the Air, but onely to manife&longs;t, That the
Air has a Spring, and to relate &longs;ome of
its effects.

I know not whether I need annex that,
though either of the above-mention'd
Hypothe&longs;es, and perhaps &longs;ome others,
may afford us an account plau&longs;ible enough
of the Air-&longs;pring; yet I doubt, whether
any of them gives us a &longs;ufficient account
of its Nature.

And of this doubt, I
might here mention &longs;ome Rea&longs;ons, but
that, peradventure, I may (God permit­
ting) have a fitter occa&longs;ion to &longs;ay &longs;ome­
thing of it el&longs;ewhere.

And therefore I
&longs;hould now proceed to the next Experi­
ment, but that I think it requi&longs;ite, fir&longs;t,
to &longs;ugge&longs;t to your Lord&longs;hip what comes
into my thoughts, by way of An&longs;wer to
a plau&longs;ible Objection, which I fore&longs;ee you
may make again&longs;t our propo&longs;'d Doctrine,
touching the Spring of the Air.

For it
may be alleadged, that though the Air
were granted to con&longs;i&longs;t of Springy Par­
ticles (if I may &longs;o &longs;peak) yet thereby
we could onely give an account of the
Dilatation of the Air in Wine-Guns and
other pneumatical Engines wherein the
Air has been compre&longs;&longs;'d, and its Springs
violently bent by an apparent externall
force; upon the removall of which, 'tis
no wonder that the Air &longs;hould, by the
motion of re&longs;titution, expand it &longs;elf till
it have recovered its more natural dimen­
&longs;ions: whereas in our above-mentioned
fir&longs;t Experiment, and in almo&longs;t all others
tryable in our Engine, it appears not
that any compre&longs;&longs;ion of the Air prece­
ded its &longs;pontaneous Dilatation or Expan­
&longs;ion of it &longs;elf.

To remove this difficul­
ty, I mu&longs;t de&longs;ire Your Lord&longs;hip to take
notice, that of whatever nature the Air,
very remote from the Earth, may be, and
whatever the Schools may confidently
teach to the contrary, yet we have divers
Experiments to evince, that the Atmo&longs;­
phere we live in is not (otherwi&longs;e then
comparatively to more ponderous Bodies)
light, but heavy: And did not their
gravity hinder them, it appears not why
the &longs;teams of the Terraqueous Globe, of
which our Air in great part con&longs;i&longs;ts,
&longs;hould not ri&longs;e much higher then the Re­
fraction of the Sun, and other Stars
give men ground to think, that the At­
mo&longs;phere, even in the judgement of tho&longs;e
Recent A&longs;tronomers, who &longs;eem willing
to enlarge its bounds as much as they dare,
does reach.

But le&longs;t you &longs;hould expect my &longs;econding
this Rea&longs;on by Experience; and le&longs;t you
&longs;hould object, That mo&longs;t of the Experi­
ments that have been propo&longs;'d to prove the
gravity of the Air, have been either barely
propo&longs;'d, or perhaps not accuratly try'd; I
am content, before I pa&longs;s further, to menti­
on here, That I found a dry lambs-bladder
containing near about two thirds of a pint,
and compre&longs;&longs;'d by a packthred tyed about
it, to loo&longs;e a grain and the eighth part of
a grain of its former weight, by the rece&longs;s
of the Air upon my having prickt it: And
this with a pair of Scales, which when the
full Bladder and the corre&longs;pondent weight
were in it, would manife&longs;tly turn either
way with the 32 part of a grain.

And if
it be further objected, That the Air in
the Bladder was violently compre&longs;&longs;'d by
the Pack-thred and the &longs;ides of the
Bladder, we might probably (to wave
prolix an&longs;wers) be furni&longs;h'd with a Re­
ply, by &longs;etting down the differing weight
of our Receiver, when empty'd and when
full of uncompre&longs;&longs;'d Air, if we could here
procure &longs;cales fit for &longs;o nice an experiment;
&longs;ince we are informed, that in the German
Experiment, commended at the begin­
ning of this Letter, the Ingenious Tryers
of it found, That their Gla&longs;s Ve&longs;&longs;el, of
the capacity of 32 mea&longs;ures, was lighter
when the Air had been drawn out of it,
then before, by no le&longs;s then one ounce
and (3/10) that is, an ounce and very near a
third: But of the gravity of the Air, we
may el&longs;ewhere have occa&longs;ion to make fur­
ther mention.

Taking it then for granted that the Air
is not deyoid of weight, it will not be
unea&longs;ie to conceive, that that part of the
Atmo&longs;phere wherein we live, being the
lower part of it, the Corpu&longs;cles that com­
po&longs;e it, are very much compre&longs;&longs;'d by the
weight of all tho&longs;e of the like nature that
are directly over them, that is, of all the
Particles of Air, that being pil'd up up­
on them, reach to the top of the Atmo&longs;­
phere.

And though the height of this
Atmo&longs;phere, according to the famous
Kepler, and &longs;ome others, &longs;carce exceeds
eight common miles; yet other eminent
and later A&longs;tronomers, would promote
the confines of the Atmo&longs;phere, to ex­
ceed &longs;ix or &longs;even times that number of
miles.

And the diligent and learned
Riviolo makes it probable, that the At­
mo&longs;phere may, at lea&longs;t in divers places, be
at lea&longs;t 50 miles high.

So that according to
a moderate e&longs;timate of the thickne&longs;s of
the Atmo&longs;phere, we may well &longs;uppo&longs;e,
that a Column of Air, of many miles in
height, leaning upon &longs;ome &longs;pringy Cor­
pu&longs;cles of Air here below, may have
weight enough to bend their little &longs;prings,
and keep them bent: As, to re&longs;ume our
former compari&longs;on, if there were fleeces of
Wooll pil'd up to a mountainous height
upon one another, the Hairs that com­
po&longs;e the lowermo&longs;t locks which &longs;upport
the re&longs;t, would, by the weight of all the
Wool above them, be as well &longs;trongly
compre&longs;&longs;ed, as if a man &longs;hould &longs;queeze
them together in his hands, or imploy any
&longs;uch other moderate force to compre&longs;s
them.

So that we need not wonder, that
upon the taking off the incumbent Air
from any parcel of the Atmo&longs;phere here
below, the Corpu&longs;cles, whereof that un­
dermo&longs;t Air con&longs;i&longs;ts, &longs;hould di&longs;play them­
&longs;elves, and take up more room then be­
fore.

And if it be objected, That in Water,
the weight of the upper and of the lower
part is the &longs;ame: I an&longs;wer, That be&longs;ides
that it may be well doubted whether the
ob&longs;ervation, by rea&longs;on of the great diffi­
culty have been exactly made, there is a
manife&longs;t di&longs;parity betwixt the Air and
Water: For I have not found, that upon
an Experiment purpo&longs;ely made, (and in
another Treati&longs;e Recorded) that Water
will &longs;uffer any con&longs;iderable compre&longs;&longs;ion;
whereas we may ob&longs;erve in Wind-Guns
(to mention now no other Engines) that
the Air will &longs;uffer it &longs;elf to be crouded in­
to a comparatively very little room; in
&longs;o much, that a very diligent Examiner
of the Phænomena of Wind-Guns would
have us believe, that in one of them, by
conden&longs;ation, he reduc'd the Air into a
&longs;pace at lea&longs;t eight times narrower then it
before po&longs;&longs;e&longs;t.

And to this, if we adde
a noble Phænomenon of the Experiment
De Vacuo; the&longs;e things put together, may
for the pre&longs;ent &longs;uffice to countenance our
Doctrine.

For that noble Experimenter,
Mon&longs;ieur Pa&longs;cal (the Son) had the com­
mendable Curio&longs;ity to cau&longs;e the Torri­
cellian Experiment to be try'd at the foot,
about the middle, and at the top of that
high Mountain (in Auvergne, if I mi&longs;take
not) commonly call'd Le Puy de Domme;
whereby it was found, That the Mercury
in the Tube fell down lower, about three
inches, at the top of the Mountain then
at the bottom.

And a Learned Man a
while &longs;ince inform'd me, That a great
Virtuo&longs;o, friend to us both, has, with not
unlike &longs;ucce&longs;s, tryed the &longs;ame Experi­
ment in the lower and upper parts of a
Mountain in the We&longs;t of England: Of
which, the rea&longs;on &longs;eems manife&longs;tly enough
to be this, That upon the tops of high
Mountains, the Air which bears again&longs;t
the re&longs;tagnant Quick-&longs;ilver, is le&longs;s pre&longs;&longs;'d
by the le&longs;s ponderous incumbent Air; and
con&longs;equently is not able totally to hinder
the de&longs;cent of &longs;o tall and heavy a Cylin­
der of Quick-&longs;ilver, as at the bottom of
&longs;uch Mountains did but maintain an Æqui­
librium with the incumbent Atmo&longs;phere.

And if it be yet further Objected a­
gain&longs;t what hath been propo&longs;'d touching
the compactne&longs;s and pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Infe­
rior Air; That we finde this very Air to
yield readily to the motion of little Flies,
and even to that of Feathers, and &longs;uch o­
ther light and weak Bodies; which &longs;eems
to argue, that the particles of our Air are
not &longs;o compre&longs;&longs;'d as we have repre&longs;ented
them, e&longs;pecially, &longs;ince by our former
Experiment it appears, that the Air rea-
dily dilated it &longs;elf downward, from the
Receiver into the Pump, when 'tis plain,
that it is not the incumbent Atmo&longs;phere,
but onely the &longs;ubjacent Air in the bra&longs;s
Cylinder that has been remov'd: If this,
I &longs;ay, be objected, we may reply, That
when a man &longs;queezes a Fleece of Wool in
his hand, he may feel that the Wool in­
ce&longs;&longs;antly bears again&longs;t his hand, as that
which hinders the hairs it con&longs;i&longs;ts of, to
recover their former and more natural ex­
tent.

So each parcel of the Air about the
Earth, does con&longs;tantly endeavour to thru&longs;t
away all tho&longs;e contiguous Bodies, whe­
ther Aërial or more gro&longs;s, that keep
them bent, and hinder the expan&longs;ion of
its parts, which will dilate them&longs;elves or
flie abroad towards that part, whether up­
wards or downwards, where they finde
their attempted Dilatation of them&longs;elves
le&longs;s re&longs;i&longs;ted by the neihgboring Bodies.

Thus the Corpu&longs;cles of that Air we have
been all this while &longs;peaking of, being un­
able, by rea&longs;on of their weight, to a&longs;cend
above the Convexity of the Atmo&longs;phere,
and by rea&longs;on of the re&longs;i&longs;tance of the &longs;ur­
face of the Earth and Water, to fall down
lower, they are forced, by their own gra­
vity and this re&longs;i&longs;tance, to expand and
diffu&longs;e them&longs;elves about the Terre&longs;tial
Globe; whereby it comes to pa&longs;s, that
they mu&longs;t as well pre&longs;s the contiguous
Corpu&longs;cles of Air that on either &longs;ide op­
po&longs;e their Dilatation, as they mu&longs;t pre&longs;s
upon the &longs;urface of the Earth, and, as it
were recoyling thence, endeavor to thru&longs;t
away tho&longs;e upper particles of Air that
lean upon them.

And as for the ea&longs;ie yielding of the Air
to the Bodies that move in it, if we con­
&longs;ider that the Corpu&longs;cles whereof it con­
&longs;i&longs;ts, though of a &longs;pringy nature, are yet
&longs;o very &longs;mall, as to make up (which 'tis
manife&longs;t they doe) a fluid Body, it will
not be difficult to conceive, that in the
Air, as in other Bodies that are fluid, the
little Bodies it con&longs;i&longs;ts of are in an almo&longs;t
re&longs;tle&longs;s motion, whereby they become
(as we have more fully di&longs;cour&longs;ed in ano­
ther Treati&longs;e) very much di&longs;po&longs;ed to
yield to other Bodies, or ea&longs;ie to be di&longs;­
plac'd by them, and that the &longs;ame Cor­
pu&longs;cles are likewi&longs;e &longs;o variou&longs;ly mov'd, as
they are intire Corpu&longs;cles, that if &longs;ome
&longs;trive to pu&longs;h a Body plac'd among them
towards the right hand (for in&longs;tance)
others, who&longs;e motion has an oppo&longs;ite de­
termination, as &longs;trongly thru&longs;t the &longs;ame
Body towards the left; whereby neither
of them proves able to move it out of
its place, the pre&longs;&longs;ure on all hands being
reduced as it were to an Æquilibrium: &longs;o
that the Corpu&longs;cles of the Air mu&longs;t be as
well &longs;ometimes con&longs;idered under the no­
tion of little Springs, which remaining
bent, are in their entire bulk tran&longs;ported
from place to place; as under the notion
of Springs di&longs;playing them&longs;elves, who&longs;e
parts flie abroad whil&longs;t as to their entire
bulk they &longs;carce change place: As the
two ends of a Bow, &longs;hot off, fly from one
another, whereas the Bow it &longs;elf may be
held fa&longs;t in the Archers hand; and that it
is the equal pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air on all &longs;ides
upon the Bodies that are in it, which cau­
&longs;es the ea&longs;ie Ce&longs;&longs;ion of its parts, may be
argu'd from hence: That if by the help
of our Engine the Air be but in great
part, though not totally drawn away
from one &longs;ide of a Body without being
drawn away from the other; he that &longs;hall
think to move that Body too and fro, as
ea&longs;ily as before, will finde him&longs;elf much
mi&longs;taken.

In a Di&longs;­
cour&longs;e
touching
&longs;luidity
and firm­
ne&longs;s.

In verification of which we will, to di­
vert your Lord&longs;hip a little, mention here
a Phænomenon of our Engine, which even
to divers ingenious per&longs;ons has at fir&longs;t
&longs;ight &longs;eem'd very wonderful.

THe thing that is wont to be admired,
and which may pa&longs;s for our &longs;econd
Experiment is this, That if, when the
Receiver is almo&longs;t empty, a By-&longs;tander
be de&longs;ired to lift up the bra&longs;s Key (former­
ly de&longs;cribed as a &longs;topple in the bra&longs;s Co­
ver) he will finde it a very difficult thing
to do &longs;o, if the Ve&longs;&longs;el be well exhau&longs;ted;
and even when but a moderate quantity of
Air has been drawn out, he will, when he
has lifted it up a little, &longs;o that it is &longs;ome­
what loo&longs;e from the &longs;ides of the lip or
&longs;ocket, which (with the help of a little
oyl) it exactly filled before, he will (I &longs;ay)
finde it &longs;o difficult to be lifted up, that
he will imagine there is &longs;ome great weight
fa&longs;tned to the bottom of it.

And if (as
&longs;ometimes has been done for merriment)
onely a Bladder be tyed to it, it is plea­
&longs;ant to &longs;ee how men will marvail that &longs;o
light a Body, filled at mo&longs;t but with Air,
&longs;hould &longs;o forcibly draw down their hand
as if it were fill'd with &longs;ome very ponder­
ous thing: whereas the cau&longs;e of this pret­
ty Phænomenon &longs;eems plainly enough to
be onely this, That the Air in the Recei­
ver, being very much dilated, its Spring
mu&longs;t be very much weakn'd, and con&longs;e­
quently it can but faintly pre&longs;s up the
lower end of the &longs;topple, whereas the
Spring of the external Air being no way
debilitated, he that a little lifts up the
&longs;topple mu&longs;t with his hand &longs;upport a pre&longs;­
&longs;ure equal to the di&longs;proportion betwixt
the force of the internal expanded Air, and
that of the Atmo&longs;phere incumbent upon
the upper part of the &longs;ame key or &longs;topple:
And &longs;o men being unu&longs;'d to finde any re­
&longs;i&longs;tance, in lifting things up, from the
free Air above them, they are forward to
conclude that that which depre&longs;&longs;es their
hands mu&longs;t needs be &longs;ome weight, though
they know not where plac'd, drawing be­
neath it.

Experi­
ment 2.

And that we have not mi&longs;-a&longs;&longs;ign'd the
cau&longs;e of this Phænomenon &longs;eems evident
enough by this; That as Air is &longs;uffer­
ed by little and little to get into the Re­
ceiver, the weight that a man fancies his
hand &longs;upports is manife&longs;tly felt to decrea&longs;e
more and more, the internal Air by this
recruit approaching more to an Æquili­
brium with the external, till at length the
Receiver growing again full of Air, the
&longs;topple may be lifted up without any dif­
ficulty at all.

By &longs;everal other of the Experiments
afforded us by our Engine, the &longs;ame no­
tion of the great and equal pre&longs;&longs;ure of the
free Air upon the Bodies it environs,
might be here manife&longs;ted, but that we
think it not &longs;o fit to anticipate &longs;uch Ex­
periments: And therefore &longs;hall rather
employ a few lines to clear up a difficulty
touching this matter, which we have ob­
&longs;erv'd to have troubled &longs;ome even of the
Philo&longs;ophical and Mathematical Specta­
tors of our Engine, who have wonder'd
that we &longs;hould talk of the Air exqui&longs;itely
&longs;hut up in our Receiver, as if it were all
one with the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Atmo&longs;phere;
whereas the thick and clo&longs;e body of the
Gla&longs;s, wholly impervious to the Air, does
manife&longs;tly keep the incumbent Pillar of
the Atmo&longs;phere from pre&longs;&longs;ing in the lea&longs;t
upon the Air within the Gla&longs;s, which it
can no where come to touch.

To eluci­
date a little this matter, let us con&longs;ider,
That if a man &longs;hould take a fleece of
Wool, and having fir&longs;t by compre&longs;&longs;ing it
in his hand reduc'd it into a narrower com­
pa&longs;s, &longs;hould nimbly convey and &longs;hut it
clo&longs;e up into a Box ju&longs;t fit for it, though
the force of his hand would then no lon­
ger bend tho&longs;e numerous &longs;pringy Body's
that compo&longs;e the Fleece, yet they would
continue as &longs;trongly bent as before, be­
cau&longs;e the Box they are inclo&longs;'d in would
as much re&longs;i&longs;t their re-expanding of
them&longs;elves, as did the hand that put them
in.

For thus we may conceive, that the
Air being &longs;hut up, when its parts are bent
by the whole weight of the incumbent
Atmo&longs;phere, though that weight can no
longer lean upon it, by rea&longs;on it is kept
off by the Gla&longs;s, yet the Corpu&longs;cles of
the Air within that Gla&longs;s continue as
forcibly bent as they were before their in­
clu&longs;ion, becau&longs;e the &longs;ides of the Gla&longs;s
hinder them from di&longs;playing or &longs;tretch­
ing out them&longs;elves.

And if it be ob­
jected that this is unlikely, becau&longs;e ev'n
Gla&longs;s bubles, &longs;uch as are wont to be
blown at the flame of a Lamp, exceeding
thin and Hermetically &longs;eal'd will not
break; whereas it cannot be imagin'd
that &longs;o thin a Pri&longs;on of Gla&longs;s could re­
&longs;i&longs;t the Ela&longs;tical force of all the included
Air, if that Air were &longs;o compre&longs;&longs;'d as we
&longs;uppo&longs;e.

It may be ea&longs;ily reply'd, That
the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the inward Air again&longs;t the
Gla&longs;s, is countervail'd by the equal pre&longs;-
&longs;ure of the outward again&longs;t the &longs;ame Gla&longs;s.

And we &longs;ee in bubles, that by rea&longs;on of
this an exceeding thin film of Water is
often able, for a good while, to hinder the
eruption of a pretty quantity of Air.

And
this may be al&longs;o more con&longs;picuous in
tho&longs;e great Spherical bubles that boyes
&longs;ometimes blow with Water, to which
Sope has given a Tenacity.

But that, if the
pre&longs;&longs;ure of the ambient Air were remov'd,
the internal Air may be able to break
thicker Gla&longs;&longs;es then tho&longs;e lately men­
tion'd, will appear by &longs;ome of the follow­
ing Experiments; to which we &longs;hall there­
fore now ha&longs;ten, having, I fear, been but
too prolix in this Excur&longs;ion, though we
thought it not ami&longs;s to annex to our fir&longs;t
Experiments &longs;ome general Con&longs;iderati­
ons touching the Spring of the Air, be­
cau&longs;e (this Doctrine being yet a &longs;tranger
to the Schools) not onely we finde not
the thing it &longs;elf to be much taken notice
of; but of tho&longs;e few that have heard of it,
the greater part have been forward to re­
ject it, upon a mi&longs;taken Per&longs;wa&longs;ion, that
tho&longs;e Phænomena are the effects of natures
abhorrency of a Vacuum, which &longs;eem to
be more fitly a&longs;cribeable to the weight
and Spring of the Air.

WE will now proceed to ob&longs;erve that
though, by the help of the handle,
the Sucker be ea&longs;ily drawn down to the
bottom of the Cylinder; yet, without
the help of that Leaver, there would be
required to the &longs;ame effect, a force or
weight great enough to &longs;urmount the
pre&longs;&longs;ure of the whole Atmo&longs;phere: Since
otherwi&longs;e the Air would not be driven out
of its place, when none is permitted to
&longs;ucceed into the place de&longs;erted by the
Sucker.

This &longs;eems evident, from the
known Torricellian Experiment, in which,
if the inverted Tube of Mercury be but
25 Digits high, or &longs;omewhat more, the
Quick-&longs;ilver will not fall but remain &longs;u&longs;­
pended in the Tube; becau&longs;e it cannot
pre&longs;s the &longs;ubjacent Mercury with &longs;o great
a force, as does the incumbent Cylinder
of the Air reaching thence to the top of
the Atmo&longs;phere: Whereas, if the Cy­
linder of Mercury were three or four digits
longer, it would over-power that of the
external Air, and run out into the Ve&longs;&longs;el'd
Mercury, till the two Cylinders came to
an Æquilibrium, and no further.

Hence
we need not wonder, that though the
Sucker move ea&longs;ily enough up and down
in the Cylinder by the help of the Manu­
brium; yet if the Manubrium be taken off,
it will require & con&longs;iderable &longs;trength to
move it either way.

Nor will it &longs;eem
&longs;trange, that if, when the Valve and
Stop-cock are well &longs;hut, you draw down
the Sucker, and then let go the Manubri­
um; the Sucker will, as it were of it &longs;elf,
re-a&longs;cend to the top of the Cylinder, &longs;ince
the &longs;pring of the external Air findes no­
thing to re&longs;i&longs;t its pre&longs;&longs;ing up the Sucker.

And for the &longs;ame rea&longs;on, when the Re­
ceiver is almo&longs;t evacuated, though, ha­
ving drawn down the Sucker, you open
the way from the Receiver to the Cylin­
der, and then intercept that way again by
returning the Key; the Sucker will, up­
on the letting go the Manubrium, be
forcibly carried up almo&longs;t to the top of
the Cylinder: Becau&longs;e the Air within the
Cylinder, being equally dilated and weak­
ned with that of the Gla&longs;s, is unable to
with&longs;tand the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the external Air,
till it be driven into &longs;o little &longs;pace, that
there is an Æquilibrium betwixt its force
and that of the Air without.

And con­
gruou&longs;ly hereunto we finde, that in this
ca&longs;e, the Sucker is drawn down with little
le&longs;s difficulty, then if the Cylinder, be­
ing devoid of Air, the Stop-cock were
exactly &longs;hut: We might take notice of
&longs;ome other things, that depend upon the
Fabrick of our Engine it &longs;elf; but to &longs;hun
prolixity, we will, in this place, content
our &longs;elves to mention one of them, which
&longs;eems to be of greater moment then the
re&longs;t, and it is this; that when the Sucker
has been impell'd to the top of the Cylin­
der, and the Valve is &longs;o carefully &longs;topp'd,
that there is no Air left in the Cylinder a­
bove the Sucker: If then the Sucker be
drawn to the lower part of the Cylinder,
he that manages the Pump findes not any
&longs;en&longs;ibly greater difficulty to depre&longs;s the
Sucker, when it is nearer the bottom of the
Cylinder, then when it is much further off.

Which circum&longs;tance we therefore think fit
to take notice of, becau&longs;e an eminent Mo­
dern Naturali&longs;t hath taught, that, when the
Air is &longs;ucked out of a Body, the violence
wherewith it is wont to ru&longs;h into it again,
as &longs;oon as it is allow'd to re-enter, pro­
ceeds mainly from this; That the pre&longs;&longs;ure
of the ambient Air is &longs;trengthned upon
the acce&longs;&longs;ion of the Air &longs;uck'd out; which,
to make it &longs;elf room, forces the neighbor­
ing Air to a violent-&longs;ubingre&longs;&longs;ion o&longs; its
parts: which, i&longs; it were true, he that draws
down the Sucker, would finde the re&longs;i&longs;t­
ance of the external Air increa&longs;'d as he
draws it lower, more of the di&longs;placed Air
being thru&longs;t into it to compre&longs;s it.

But, by
what has been di&longs;cour&longs;'d upon the fir&longs;t
Experiment, it &longs;eems more probable, that
without any &longs;uch &longs;trengthning of the pre&longs;­
&longs;ure of the outward Air, the taking quite
away or the debilitating of the re&longs;i&longs;tance
from within, may &longs;uffice to produce the
effects under con&longs;ideration.

But this will
perhaps be illu&longs;trated by &longs;ome or other of
our future Experiments, and therefore
&longs;hall be no longer in&longs;i&longs;ted on here.

Experi­
ment 3.

HAving thus taken notice of &longs;ome of
the con&longs;tant Phænomena of our En­
gine it &longs;elf, let us now proceed to the Ex­
periments tryable in it.

Experi­
ment 4.

We took then a Lambs Bladder large,
well dry'd, and very limber, and leaving in
it about half as much Air as it could con­
tain, we cau&longs;'d the neck of it to be &longs;trong­
ly ty'd, &longs;o that none of the included Air,
though by pre&longs;&longs;ure, could get out.

This
Bladder being convey'd into the Receiver,
and the Cover luted on, the Pump
was &longs;et awork, and after two or three
ex&longs;uctions of the ambient Air (where­
by the Spring of that which remain'd in
the Gla&longs;s was weaken'd) the Impri&longs;on'd
Air began to &longs;well in the Bladder, and as
more and more of the Air in the Recei­
ver was, from time to time, drawn out; &longs;o
did that in the Bladder more and more ex­
pand it &longs;elf, and di&longs;play the folds of the
formerly flaccid Bladder: &longs;o that before we
had exhau&longs;ted the Receiver near &longs;o much
as we could, the Bladder appear'd as full
and &longs;tretched, as if it had been blown up
with a Quill.

And that it may appear that this plump­
ne&longs;s of the Bladder proceeded from the
&longs;urmounting of the debilitated Spring of
the ambient Air remaining in the Ve&longs;&longs;el,
by the &longs;tronger Spring of the Air remain­
ing in the Bladder; we Return'd the Key
of the Stop-cock, and by degrees allow'd
the external Air to return into the Recei­
ver: Whereupon it happen'd, as was ex­
pected, that as the Air came in from with­
out, the di&longs;turb'd Air in the Bladder, was
proportionably compre&longs;&longs;'d into a narrow­
er room, and the &longs;ides of the Bladder
grew flaccid, till the Receiver having re­
admitted its wonted quantity of Air, the
Bladder appear'd as full of wrinkles and
cavities as before.

This Experiment is much of the &longs;ame
nature with that which was &longs;ome years
agoe &longs;aid to be made by that eminent Ge­
ometrician Mon&longs;ieur Roberval, with a
Carps Bladder empty'd and convey'd into
a Tube, wherein the Experiment De Va­
cuo was afterwards try'd, which ingeni­
ous Experiment of his ju&longs;tly de&longs;erves the
thanks of tho&longs;e that have been, or &longs;hall be
&longs;olicitous to di&longs;cover the nature of the
Air.

But to return to our Experiment, we
may take notice of this Circum&longs;tance in
it, That after the Receiver has been in
&longs;ome mea&longs;ure empty'd, the Bladder do's,
at each ex&longs;uction, &longs;well much more con­
&longs;picuou&longs;ly then it did at any of the fir&longs;t
Ex&longs;uctions; in&longs;omuch that towards the
end of the pumping, not onely a great
fold or cavity in the &longs;urface of the Blad­
der may be made, even by the &longs;tretching
of the inward &longs;elf-expanding Air: But
we have &longs;ometimes &longs;een, upon the turn­
ing of the Key to let the ambient Air
pa&longs;s out of the Receiver into the Cylin­
der, we have &longs;een (I &longs;ay) the Air in the
Bladder &longs;uddenly expand it &longs;elf &longs;o much
and &longs;o briskly, that it manife&longs;tly lifted up
&longs;ome light Bodies that lean'd upon it,
and &longs;eem'd to lift up the Bladder it
&longs;elf.

Now becau&longs;e it has by very Learned
Men been doubted whether the &longs;welling
of the Bladder may not have proceeded
from the Dilatation of the included Air,
but from the Texture of the Fibres,
which, being wont to keep the Bladder
extended when the Animal to whom it
belong'd was alive, may be &longs;uppo&longs;'d in
our Experiment to have return'd, like &longs;o
many Springs to their wonted extent, up­
on the removal of the Ambient Air that
compre&longs;&longs;'d and bent them: becau&longs;e this,
I &longs;ay, has been doubted, we thought fit
to make this further tryall.

We let down into the Receiver with
the fore-mentioned Bladder two other
much &longs;maller, and of the &longs;ame kinde of
Animal; the one of the&longs;e was not ty'd
up at the neck that there might be liberty
left to the Air that was not &longs;queez'd out
(which might amount to about a fifth
part of what the Bladder held before) to
pa&longs;s out into the Receiver: The other had
the &longs;ides of it &longs;tretch'd out and pre&longs;&longs;'d to­
gether, almo&longs;t into the form of a Cup,
that they might intercept the le&longs;s Air be­
twixt them, and then was &longs;trongly ty'd
up at the neck: This done, and the Air
being in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure &longs;uck'd out of the
Pneumatical Gla&longs;s (if I may &longs;o call it)
the Bladder, mention'd at the beginning
of our Experiment, appear'd extended e­
very way to its full Dimen&longs;ions; whereas
neither of the two others did remarkably
&longs;well, and that who&longs;e neck was not ty'd
&longs;eem'd very little, if at all le&longs;s wrinkl'd
then when it was put in.

We made likewi&longs;e a &longs;trong Ligature a­
bout the middle of a long Bladder part­
ly empty'd, and upon the drawing the
Air out of the Receiver, could ob&longs;erve
no &longs;uch &longs;welling betwixt the Ligature and
the Neck of the Bladder, which had been
purpo&longs;ely left open, as betwixt the &longs;ame
Ligature and the bottom of the Bladder,
whence the included Air could no way
get out.

But a further and &longs;ufficient manife&longs;tati­
on whence the intume&longs;&longs;ence of the Blad­
der proceeds, may be deduc'd from the
following Experiment.

TO try then at once both what it was
that expanded the Bladder, and what
a powerful Spring there is ev'n in the Air
we are wont to think uncompre&longs;&longs;'d, we
cau&longs;'d a Bladder dry, well ty'd and blown
moderately full, to be hung in the Recei­
ver by one end of a &longs;tring, who&longs;e other
end was fa&longs;tned to the in&longs;ide of the Co­
ver: and upon drawing out the ambient
Air, that pre&longs;&longs;'d on the Bladder; the in­
ternal Air not finding the wonted re&longs;i&longs;t­
ance, fir&longs;t &longs;well'd and di&longs;tended the Blad­
der, and then broke it, with &longs;o wide and
crooked a rent, as if it had been forcibly
torn a&longs;&longs;under with hands.

After which a
&longs;econd Bladder being convey'd in, the Ex­
periment was repeated with like &longs;ucce&longs;s:
And I &longs;uppo&longs;e it will not be imagin'd that
in this ca&longs;e the Bladder was broken by its
own Fibres, rather then by the Impri­
&longs;on'd Air.

Experi­
ment 5.

And of this Experiment the&longs;e two Phæ­
nomena may be taken notice of: The one,
that the Bladder at its breaking gave a
great report, almo&longs;t like a Craker: And
the other, That the Air contain'd in the
Bladder, had the power to break it with
the mention'd Impetuo&longs;ity, long before
the ambient Air was, all or near all, drawn
out of the Receiver.

But, to verifie what we &longs;ay in another
Di&longs;cour&longs;e, where we &longs;how, That even
true Experiments may, by rea&longs;on of
the ea&longs;ie mi&longs;take of &longs;ome unheeded
Circum&longs;tance, be un&longs;ucce&longs;sfully try'd;
we will Adverti&longs;e, on this occa&longs;ion,
that we did oftentimes in vain try the
breaking of Bladders, after the manner
above-mention'd: Of which the cau&longs;e
appear'd to be this, That the Bladders we
could not break, having been brought us
ready blown from tho&longs;e that &longs;old them,
were grown dry before they came to our
hands: whence it came to pa&longs;s, that, if
we afterwards ty'd them very hard, they
were apt to fret and &longs;o become un&longs;ervice­
able; and if we ty'd them but moderate­
ly hard, their &longs;tiffne&longs;s kept them from be­
ing clo&longs;'d &longs;o exactly, but that when the
included Air had in the exhau&longs;ted Recei­
ver di&longs;tended them as much as ea&longs;ily it
could, it would in part get out between
the little wrinkles of the Sphincter of the
Neck: Whence al&longs;o it u&longs;ually happen'd,
that, upon the letting in the Air from
without, the Bladders appear'd more flac­
cid and empty then before they were put
in; whereas when the Bladders were
brought us moi&longs;t from the Butchers, we
could, without injuring them, tye their
necks &longs;o clo&longs;e, that none of the Air once
blown in, could get out of them, but by
violently breaking them.

It will not be ami&longs;s on this occa&longs;ion to
point at &longs;omething which may de&longs;erve a
more deliberate Speculation then we can
now afford it; namely that the Ela&longs;tical
Power of the &longs;ame Quantity of Air may
be as well Encrea&longs;'d by the Agitation of
the Aërial Particles (whether onely mo­
ving them more &longs;wiftly and &longs;cattering
them, or al&longs;o extending or &longs;tretching
them out, I determine not) within an
every way inclo&longs;ing and yet yielding Bo­
dy; as Di&longs;play'd by the withdrawing of
the Air that pre&longs;&longs;'d it without.

For we
found that a Bladder, but moderately
fill'd with Air and &longs;trongly ty'd, being
a while held near the Fire, not onely grew
exceeding turgid and hard, but after­
wards, being approach'd nearer to the
Fire, &longs;uddenly broke with &longs;o loud and ve­
hement a noi&longs;e, as &longs;tony'd tho&longs;e that were
by, and made us, for a while after, almo&longs;t
deaf.

HAving thus &longs;een that the Air has an
Ela&longs;tical Power, we were next de&longs;i­
rous to know in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure how far a
parcel of Air might by this its own Spring
be dilated.

And though we were not pro­
vided of In&longs;truments fit to mea&longs;ure the
dilatation of the Air any thing accurately,
yet becau&longs;e an imperfect mea&longs;ure of it was
more de&longs;ireable then none at all, we de­
vi&longs;'d the following Method as very ea&longs;ily
practicable.

Experi­
ment 6.

We took a limber Lambs Bladder
which was thorowly wetted in fair Water,
that the &longs;ides of it being &longs;queez'd roge­
ther, there might be no Air left in its
folds: (as indeed we could not afterwards
upon tryal di&longs;cern any) The neck of this
Bladder was &longs;trongly tyed about that of
a &longs;mall Gla&longs;s, (capable of holding five
full drachmes of Water) the Bladder be­
ing fir&longs;t &longs;o compre&longs;&longs;'d, that all the inclu­
ded Air was onely in the Gla&longs;s, without
being pre&longs;&longs;'d there; then the Pump be­
ing &longs;et awork after a few ex&longs;uctions, the
Air in the little Viol began to dilate it
&longs;elf and produce a &longs;mall Tumor in the
Neck of the Bladder; and as the ambi­
ent Air was more and more drawn away,
&longs;o the included Air penetrated further and
further into the Bladder, and by degrees
lifted up the &longs;ides and di&longs;play'd its folds,
