till at length it &longs;eem'd to have blown it
up to its full extent: whereupon the ex­
ternal Air, being permitted to flow back
into the Reciver, repul&longs;'d the Air that
had fill'd the Bladder into its former nar­
row receptacle, and brought the Bladder
to be again flaccid and wrinkled as before:
Then taking out the Bladder, but with­
out &longs;evering it from the Gla&longs;s, we did by
a hole made at the top of the Bladder fill
the Ve&longs;&longs;el they both made up with Wa­
ter, who&longs;e weight was five Ounces five
Drachmes and an half: Five Drachmes
whereof were above-mention'd to be the
contents of the Bottle.

So that in this Ex­
periment, when the Air had mo&longs;t extend­
ed the Bladder, it po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;'d in all above
nine times as much room as it did when it
was put into the Receiver.

And it would
probably have much inlarg'd its bounds,
but that the Bladder by its weight and the
&longs;ticking together of its &longs;ides did &longs;ome­
what re&longs;i&longs;t its expan&longs;ion: And which was
more con&longs;iderable, the Bladder appear'd
tumid enough, whil&longs;t yet a pretty deal of
Air was left in the Receiver, who&longs;e ex­
&longs;uction would, according to our former
Ob&longs;ervation, probably have given way
to a further expan&longs;ion of the Air, e&longs;peci-
ally &longs;uppo&longs;ing the dilatation not to be re­
&longs;train'd by the Bladder.

SInce we wrote the other day the former
Experiment, we have met with &longs;ome
Gla&longs;&longs;es not very unfit for our purpo&longs;e;
by means of which we are now able, with
a little more trouble, to mea&longs;ure the ex­
pan&longs;ion of the Air a great deal more ac­
curately then we could by the help of the
above-mention'd Bladder, which was
much to narrow to allow the Air its ut­
mo&longs;t di&longs;tention.

We took then fir&longs;t a Cylindrical Pipe
of Gla&longs;s, who&longs;e bore was about a quarter
of an Inch in Diameter: this Pipe was &longs;o
bent and doubled, that, notwith&longs;tanding
its being about two foot in length, it
might have been &longs;hut up into a &longs;mall Re­
ceiver, not a Foot high: But by mi&longs;­
fortune it crack'd in the cooling, whereby
we were reduced to make u&longs;e of one part
which was &longs;traight and intire, but exceed­
ed not &longs;ix or &longs;even Inches.

This little
Tube was open at one end; and at the
other, where it was Hermetically &longs;eal'd,
had a &longs;mall Gla&longs;s bubble to receive the
Air who&longs;e dilatation was to be mea&longs;ur'd.

Along the &longs;ide of this Tube was pa&longs;t­
ed a &longs;traight narrow piece of Parchment,
divided into twenty &longs;ix equal parts, mark­
ed with black Lines and Figures, that by
them might be mea&longs;ur'd both the inclu­
ded Air and its dilatation.

Afterwards
we fill'd the Tube with Water almo&longs;t to
the top, and &longs;topping the open end with
a Finger, and inverting the Tube, the
Air was permitted to a&longs;cend to the above­
mention'd Gla&longs;s bubble.

And by rea­
&longs;on this a&longs;cent was very &longs;low, it gave us
the opportunity to mark how much more
or le&longs;s then one of the twenty &longs;ix divi&longs;i­
ons this Air took up.

By this means, af­
ter a tryal or two, we were inabled to con­
vey to the top of the Gla&longs;s a bubble of
Air equal enough, as to &longs;ight, to one
of tho&longs;e Divi&longs;ions: Then the open end
of the Tube being put into a &longs;mall Viol,
who&longs;e bottom was cover'd with Water
about half an Inch high; we included
both Gla&longs;&longs;es into a &longs;mall and &longs;lender Re­
ceiver, and cau&longs;ed the Pump to be &longs;et a­
work.

The event was, That at the fir&longs;t
ex&longs;uction of the Air there appear'd not
any expan&longs;ion of the bubble, comparable
to what appear'd at the &longs;econd, and that
upon a very few ex&longs;uctions the bubble
reaching as low as the &longs;urface of the &longs;ub­
jacent Water, gave us cau&longs;e to think
that if our Pipe had not been broken it
would have expanded it &longs;elf much fur­
ther: Wherefore we took out the little
Tube, and found that be&longs;ides the twenty
&longs;ix divi&longs;ions formerly mention'd, the
Gla&longs;s bubble and &longs;ome part of the Pipe
to which the divided Parchment did not
reach, amounted to &longs;ix divi&longs;ions more.

Whereby it appears that the air had taken
up one and thirty times as much room as
before, and yet &longs;eem'd capable of a much
greater expan&longs;ion, if the Gla&longs;s would
have permitted it.

Wherefore, after the
former manner, we let in another bubble,
that by our gue&longs;s was but half as big as
the former, and found, that upon the ex­
&longs;uction of the Air from the Receiver, this
little bubble did not onely fill up the
whole Tube, but (in part) break through
the &longs;ubjacent Water in the Viol, and
thereby manife&longs;t it &longs;elf to have po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;ed
&longs;ixty and odde times its former room.

The&longs;e two Experiments are mention'd
to make way for the more ea&longs;ie belief of
that which is now to follow.

Finding
then that our Tube was too &longs;hort to &longs;erve
our turn, we took a &longs;lender Quill of Gla&longs;s
which happen'd to be at hand, though it
were not &longs;o fit for our purpo&longs;e as we
could have wi&longs;hed, in regard it was three
or four times as big at one end as the o­
ther.

This Pipe which was thirty Inches
long, being Hermetically &longs;eal'd at the
&longs;lender end, was almo&longs;t filled with Wa­
ter; and after the above-related manner
a bubble was convey'd to the top of it,
and the open extream was put into a Viol
that had a little fair Water at the bottom:
Then the Cover, by means of a &longs;mall hole
purpo&longs;ely made in it for the Gla&longs;s Pipe to
&longs;tand out at, was cemented on to the Re­
ceiver, and the Pump being &longs;et awork,
after &longs;ome ex&longs;uctions, not onely the Air
manife&longs;tly appear'd extended below the
&longs;urface of the &longs;ubjacent Water; but one
of the By-&longs;tanders affirms, that he &longs;aw
&longs;ome bubbles come out at the bottom of
the Pipe and break through the Water
This done, we left off Pumping, and ob­
&longs;erv'd how at the unperceiv'd leaks of the
Receiver the Air got in &longs;o fa&longs;t, thatit
very quickly impell'd up the Water to
the top of the Tube, excepting a little
&longs;pace whereinto that bubble was repul&longs;'d,
which had &longs;o lately po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;'d the whole
Tube; this Air at the &longs;lender end ap-
pear'd to be a Cylinder of 5/6 parts of an
Inch in length; but when the Pipe was
taken out and turn'd up&longs;ide down, it ap­
pear'd at the other end inferior in bulk to a
Pea.

The&longs;e things being thus done we took
(to make the Experiment the more ex­
actly) a &longs;mall pair of Scales, &longs;uch as Gold­
Smiths u&longs;e to weigh Gold Coyn in; and
weighing the Tube and Water in it, we
found them to amount to one Ounce thir­
ty Grains and an half: Then we pour'd in
as much Water as &longs;erv'd to fill up the
Tube, wherein before we had left as much
&longs;pace unfill'd up as was po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;'d by the
bubble; and weighing again the Pipe and
Water, we found the weight increa&longs;'d
onely by one Grain.

La&longs;tly, pouring out
the Water, and carefully freeing the Pipe
from it (which yet we could not perfectly
doe) we weighed the Gla&longs;s alone, and
found it to want two Drachmes and thirty
two Grains of its former weight: So
that the bubble of Air taking up the room
but of one Grain in weight of Water, it
appear'd that the Air by its own e)lith\r
was &longs;o rarified, as to take up one hundred
fifty two times as much room as it did be­
fore: though it were then compre&longs;&longs;'d by
nothing but the ordinary pre&longs;&longs;ure of the
contiguous Air.

I know not whether it
be requi&longs;ite to take notice, that this Ex­
periment was made indeed in a moi&longs;t
Night, but in a Room, in who&longs;e Chim­
ney there was burning a good Fire, which
did perhaps &longs;omewhat rarifie the Air of
which the bubble con&longs;i&longs;ted.

It has &longs;eem'd almo&longs;t incredible which is
related by the Indu&longs;trious Mer&longs;ennus, That
the Air by the violence of heat, though
as great as our Ve&longs;&longs;els can &longs;upport with­
out fu&longs;ion, can be &longs;o dilated as to take up
&longs;eventy times as much room as before:
Wherefore becau&longs;e we were willing to
have a confirmation of &longs;o &longs;trange a Phæno­
menon; we once more convey'd into the
Tube a bubble of the bigne&longs;s of the for­
mer, and pro&longs;ecuting the Experiment as
before with the &longs;ame Water, we ob&longs;erved
that the Air did manife&longs;tly &longs;tretch it &longs;elf
&longs;o far, as to appear &longs;everal times a good
way below the &longs;urface of the Water in the
Viol, and that too with a &longs;urface very
convex toward the bottom of the Pipe.

Nay, the Pump being ply'd a little lon­
ger, the Air did manife&longs;tly reach to that
place where the bottom of the Tube
lean'd upon the bottom of the Viol, and
&longs;eem'd to knock upon it and rebound
from it: Which Circum&longs;tances we adde,
partly that the Phænomenon we have been
relating may not be imputed to the
bare &longs;ub&longs;iding of the Water that fill'd
the Tube, upon the taking off the pre&longs;­
&longs;ure of the ambient Air.

And partly al­
&longs;o that it may appear that if our Expe­
riments have not been as accurately made
as with fitter In&longs;truments might perhaps
be po&longs;&longs;ible; yet the expan&longs;ion of the
Air is likely to be rather greater then
le&longs;&longs;er then we have made it: Since the
Air was able to pre&longs;s away the Water at
the bottom of the Pipe, though that were
about two Inches below the &longs;urface of the
Water that was then in the Viol, and
would have been at lea&longs;t as high in the
Pipe, if the Water had onely &longs;ub&longs;ided and
not been depre&longs;&longs;ed: So that it &longs;eems not
unlikely that if the Experiment could be
&longs;o made, as that the expan&longs;ion of the Air
might not be re&longs;i&longs;ted by the Neighboring
Bodies, it would yet inlarge its bounds,
and perhaps &longs;tretch it &longs;elf to two hundred
times its former bulk, if not more.

How­
ever, what we have now try'd will, I hope,
&longs;uffice to hinder divers of the Phænomena
of our Engine from being di&longs;tru&longs;ted:
Since in that part of the Atmo&longs;phere we
live in, that which we call the free Air (and
pre&longs;ume to be &longs;o uncompre&longs;&longs;'d) is crouded
into &longs;o very &longs;mall a part of that &longs;pace,
which if it were not hindred it would po&longs;­
&longs;e&longs;s.

We would gladly have tryed al&longs;o
whether the Air at its greate&longs;t expan&longs;ion
could be further rarified by heat; but do
what we could, our Receiver leak'd too
fa&longs;t to let us give our &longs;elves any &longs;atisfacti­
on in that particular.

TO di&longs;cover likewi&longs;e by the means of
that pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air, both the
&longs;trength of Gla&longs;s, and how much inte­
re&longs;t the Figure of a Body may have in its
greater or le&longs;&longs;er Re&longs;i&longs;tance to the pre&longs;&longs;ure
of other Bodys, we made the&longs;e further
tryals.

Experi­
ment 7.

We cau&longs;'d to be blown with a Lamp a
round Gla&longs;s bubble, capable of contain­
ing, by gue&longs;s, about five Ounces of Wa­
ter, with a &longs;lender neck about the bigne&longs;s
of a Swans Quill, and it was purpo&longs;ely
blown very thin, as Viols made with
Lamps are wont to be, that the thinne&longs;s
of the matter might keep the roundne&longs;s
of the Figure from making the Ve&longs;&longs;el too
&longs;trong.

Then having moderately empty­
ed the Receiver, and taken it out of the
Pump, we &longs;peedily applyed to the Ori­
fice of the bottom of it the Neck of the
newly mention'd Gla&longs;s, carefully &longs;topping
the Crannys with melted Plai&longs;ter, that no
Air might get in at them: And after
turning the Key of the Stop-cock, we
made a free pa&longs;&longs;age for the Air to pa&longs;s out
of the bubble into the Receiver: which it
did with great celerity, leaving the bub­
ble as empty as the Receiver it &longs;elf; as ap­
pear'd to us by &longs;ome Circum&longs;tances not
now to be in&longs;i&longs;ted on.

Notwith&longs;tanding
all which, the Ve&longs;&longs;el, continuing as intire
as before, gave us cau&longs;e to wonder that
the bare Roundne&longs;s of the Figure &longs;hould
inable a Gla&longs;s, almo&longs;t as thin as Paper, to
re&longs;i&longs;t &longs;o great a pre&longs;&longs;ure as that of the
whole incumbent Atmo&longs;phere.

And ha­
ving reiterated the Experiment, we found
again that the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the ambient
Body, thru&longs;ting all the parts inwards,
made them, by rea&longs;on of their arched Fi­
gure, &longs;o &longs;upport one another, that the
Gla&longs;s remain'd as whole as at fir&longs;t.

Now that the Figure of the Gla&longs;s is
of great moment in this matter, may be
evinced by this other Experiment.

WE took a Gla&longs;s Helmet or Alem­
bick (delineated by the &longs;eventh
Figure) &longs;uch as Chymi&longs;ts u&longs;e in Di&longs;tilla­
tions, and containing by conjecture be­
tween two and three Pints: The Ro&longs;trum
or No&longs;e of it mark'd with (c) was Herme­
tically clo&longs;ed; and at the top of it was a
hole, into which was fitted and cemented
one of the Shanks of a middle-&longs;iz'd Stop­
cock; &longs;o that the Gla&longs;s being turn'd up­
&longs;ide-down, the wide Orifice (which in
common Gla&longs;s-Helmets is the onely one)
was upwards; and to that wide Orifice
was fitted a ca&longs;t-Cover of Lead, which
was carefully cemented on to the Gla&longs;s:
Then the other Shank of the Stop-cock
being with Cement likewi&longs;e fa&longs;ten'd into
the upper part of the Pump, the ex&longs;ucti­
on of the Air was endeavoured.

But it
was not long before, the remaining Air
being made much too weak to ballance
the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the ambient Air, the Gla&longs;s
was not without a great noi&longs;e crack'd al­
mo&longs;t half round, along that part of it
where it began to bend inwards: As if
in the Figure the crack had been made ac­
cording to the Line (ab); and upon an
endeavour to pump out more of the Air,
the crack once began, appear'd to run on
further; though the Gla&longs;s where it was
broken &longs;eem'd to be by conjecture above
ten, &longs;ome thought above twenty times as
thick as the bubble mention'd in the fore­
going Experiment.

Experi­
ment 8.

This will perhaps make it &longs;eem &longs;trange,
that having taken another Gla&longs;s bubble
blown at the &longs;ame time, and like for
ought we di&longs;cern'd for &longs;ize, thickne&longs;s
and Figure to that thin one formerly
mention'd; and having &longs;eal'd it up Her­
metically, and &longs;u&longs;pended it in the Recei­
ver, the ex&longs;uction of the ambient Air did
not enable the impri&longs;oned Air to break, or
in the lea&longs;t to crack the bubble; though
the Experiment were laboriou&longs;ly try'd,
and that &longs;everal times with bubbles of o­
ther &longs;izes: But that perhaps the heat of
the Candle or Lamp wherewith &longs;uch
Gla&longs;&longs;es are Hermetically &longs;eal'd, (not to
mention the warmth of his hands that
&longs;eal'd it) might &longs;o rarifie the contained
Air, as much to weaken its Spring, may
&longs;eem probable by the following Expe­
riments.

WE took a Gla&longs;s Viol able to hold
three or four Ounces of Water,
and of the thickne&longs;s u&longs;ual in Gla&longs;&longs;es of
that &longs;ize; into the Neck of this was put
a moderately &longs;lender Pipe of Gla&longs;s, which
was carefully fa&longs;ten'd with a mixture of e­
qual parts of Pitch and Ro&longs;in to the Neck
of the Viol, and which reach'd almo&longs;t to
the bottom of it, as the &longs;ixth Figure de­
clares.

Experi­
ment 9.

This Viol being upon a particular de­
&longs;ign fill'd with Water, till that came up in
it a pretty deal higher then the lower end
of the Pipe, was put into one of our &longs;mall
Receivers, (containing between a Pint
and a Quart) in &longs;uch manner as that the
Gla&longs;s Pipe, pa&longs;&longs;ing through a hole made
purpo&longs;ely for it in the Leaden-Cover of
the Receiver, was for the mo&longs;t part of it
without the Ve&longs;&longs;el, which being exactly
clo&longs;ed, the Pump was &longs;et awork: But at
the very fir&longs;t ex&longs;uction, and before the
Sucker was drawn to the bottom of the
Cylinder, there flew out of the Viol a
piece of Gla&longs;s half as broad as the Palm
of a Mans Hand, and it was thrown out
with &longs;uch violence, that hitting again&longs;t
the Neighboring &longs;ide of the Receiver, it
not onely dafh'd it &longs;elf to pieces, but
crack'd the very Receiver in many places,
with a great noi&longs;e that much &longs;urpri&longs;ed all
that were in the Room.

But it &longs;eem'd
that in &longs;o little a Receiver, the Air about
the Viol being &longs;uddenly drawn out, the
Air Impri&longs;on'd in the Ve&longs;&longs;el, having on
it the whole pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Atmo&longs;phere
(to which by the Pipe open at both ends,
It and the Water were expo&longs;'d) and not
having on the other &longs;ide the wonted pre&longs;­
&longs;ure of the Ambient Air to ballance that
other pre&longs;&longs;ure, the re&longs;i&longs;tance of the Gla&longs;s
was finally &longs;urmounted, and the Viol once
beginning to break where it was weake&longs;t,
the external Air might ru&longs;h in with vio­
lence enough to throw the crack'd parcel
&longs;o forcibly again&longs;t the Neighboring &longs;ide
of the Receiver, as to break that too.

And this may be pre&longs;umed &longs;ufficient to
verifie what we delivered in that part of
our Appendix to the fir&longs;t Experiment,
where we mention'd the almo&longs;t equal
pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air on either &longs;ide of a
thin Gla&longs;s Ve&longs;&longs;el, as the cau&longs;e of its not
being broken by the forcible Spring of
the contain'd Air.

But yet that it be not
&longs;u&longs;pected that chance had an intere&longs;t in &longs;o
odde an Experiment as we have been Re­
lating, we will adde that for farther &longs;ati&longs;­
faction we reiterated it in a round Gla&longs;&longs;e
containing by gue&longs;&longs;e about &longs;ix ounces
of water: this violl we put into &longs;uch a
&longs;mall Receiver as was lately mention'd,
in &longs;uch manner as that the bottome of
it re&longs;ted upon the lower part of the Pneu­
maticall Gla&longs;&longs;e, and the Neck came out
through the Leaden-Cover of the &longs;ame
at a hole made purpo&longs;ely for it.

But be­
ing made circum&longs;pect by the foregoing
mi&longs;chance, we had put the violl into a
Bladder, before we put it into the Re­
ceiver to hinder this la&longs;t named Gla&longs;&longs;e
from being endanger'd by the breaking
of the other.

Then the Pneumaticall
ve&longs;&longs;ell being clos'd &longs;o that no way was
left for the outward Air to get into it,
but by breaking through the Viol, into
who&longs;e cavity it had free acce&longs;&longs;e by the
mouth of it, (which was purpo&longs;ely left
open,) the Sucker being nimbly drawn
down, the external Air immediatly pre&longs;&longs;'d
forcibly as well upon the Leaden-Co­
ver as the Violl; and the Cover hap­
pening to be in one place a little narrow­
er then the edge of the Pneumatical Gla&longs;s,
was depre&longs;&longs;'d, and thru&longs;t into it &longs;o vio-
lently by the incumbent Air, that get­
ting a little within the tapering Lip of the
Gla&longs;s, it did like a kinde of Wedge, thru&longs;t
out that &longs;ide where it was depre&longs;&longs;'d, &longs;o as,
though the Receiver was new, to &longs;plit it.

This accident being thus mention'd upon
the by to confirm what we formerly &longs;aid
touching the fitne&longs;s or unfitne&longs;s of Gla&longs;&longs;es
of &longs;ome Figures to re&longs;i&longs;t the pre&longs;&longs;ure of
the Atmo&longs;phere; We will proceed to
relate the remaining part of the Experi­
ment, namely, That having fitted on a
wider Cover to the &longs;ame Receiver, and
clo&longs;ed both that and the crack with Ce­
ment, we pro&longs;ecuted the Experiment in
the manner above related, with this &longs;uc­
ce&longs;s: That upon the quick depre&longs;&longs;ing of
the Sucker, the external Air bur&longs;t the
Body of the Viol in above a hundred pie­
ces, many of them exceeding &longs;mall, and
that with &longs;uch violence that we found a
wide rent, be&longs;ides many holes, made in
the Bladder it &longs;elf.

And to evince that the&longs;e Phænomena
were the effects of a limited and even
moderate force, and not of &longs;uch an ab­
horrency of a Vacuum as that to avoid it,
many have been plea&longs;ed to think that Na­
ture mu&longs;t, upon occa&longs;ion, exerci&longs;e an al-
mo&longs;t boundle&longs;s power; we afterwards pur­
po&longs;ely try'd this Experiment with &longs;everal
Gla&longs;&longs;es &longs;omewhat thicker then tho&longs;e Vi­
ols, and found the event to verifie our con­
jecture, that it would not &longs;ucceed: for
the Gla&longs;&longs;es were taken out as intire as they
were put in.

And here, My Lord, I hold it not un­
fit, upon occa&longs;ion of the mention that
has been made of our having employ'd
&longs;mall Receivers, and one of them, not­
with&longs;tanding its being crack'd, to annex
the&longs;e two Adverti&longs;ements.

Fir&longs;t then, be&longs;ides the great Pneuma­
tical Gla&longs;s &longs;o often mention'd, and the
proportionate Stop-cock, we thought fit
to provide our &longs;elves of &longs;ome &longs;mall Recei­
vers blown of Cry&longs;talline Gla&longs;s, of &longs;eve­
rall Shapes, and furni&longs;hed with &longs;maller
Stop-cocks purpo&longs;ely made; and this we
did upon hopes that when we had &longs;ur­
mounted the difficulties to be met with in
Cementing the Gla&longs;&longs;es to the Stop­
cocks, and the Pneumatical Ve&longs;&longs;els to the
Pump &longs;o exqui&longs;itely as is requi&longs;ite for our
purpo&longs;e, we &longs;hould from the &longs;malne&longs;s of
our Receivers receive a four-fold Advan­
tage.

The fir&longs;t, that by rea&longs;on of the
&longs;lenderne&longs;s of the Ve&longs;&longs;els, and their be-
ing made of much purer and clearer me­
tall, as the Gla&longs;s-men &longs;peak, then the
great Receiver, we might have a more
perfect view of every thing happening
within them.

The next, that &longs;uch &longs;mall
Ve&longs;&longs;els might be empty'd with le&longs;s la­
bour and in much le&longs;&longs;e time.

The third,
that this nimble ex&longs;uction of the ambient
Air would make many changes in the
Bodies &longs;hut up in the&longs;e gla&longs;&longs;es more &longs;ud­
den and con&longs;picuous then otherwi&longs;e they
would prove.

And the la&longs;t, that we &longs;hould
be able to draw and keep out the Air much
more perfectly from &longs;uch &longs;mall Ve&longs;&longs;els
then from our large Receiver.

But though
we were not much di&longs;-appointed in the
expectation of the three fir&longs;t advantages,
yet we were in our hopes of the fourth.

For be&longs;ides the great difficulty we found
in fitting together the Gla&longs;&longs;es, the Stop­
cocks and the Covers; be&longs;ides this I &longs;ay,
we found our &longs;elves &longs;eldom able to draw,
and keep out the Air &longs;o far as to make the
remaining Air in the&longs;e Receivers weaker
then the remaining Air in our great Recei­
ver.

For though &longs;ometimes the Leaks
of &longs;ome of the&longs;e little Receivers may be
much either fewer or &longs;maller then tho&longs;e
of the larger Ve&longs;&longs;el; yet a little Air get-
ting into one of the&longs;e, wherein it had but
little room to expand and di&longs;play it &longs;elf,
might pre&longs;s as much upon all parts of the
internal &longs;urface of the Ve&longs;&longs;el, and upon
the included Bodies, as a greater quan­
tity of Air in a Ve&longs;&longs;el in who&longs;e capacity
it might finde more room to expand it
&longs;elf.

The other thing that we were to ad­
verti&longs;e, is, That 'tis not every &longs;mall crack
that can make &longs;uch a Receiver as is of a
roundi&longs;h Figure altogether u&longs;ele&longs;s to our
Experiment, in regard that upon the ex­
&longs;uction of the internal Air, the ambient
Air on all &longs;ides pre&longs;&longs;ing the Gla&longs;s inwards
or towards the middle, does con&longs;equent­
ly thru&longs;t the Lips of the crack clo&longs;er, and
&longs;o rather clo&longs;e then increa&longs;e it.

This I mention partly becau&longs;e Recei­
vers fit for our turn are more ea&longs;ily
crack'd then procur'd, and therefore ought
not to be unnece&longs;&longs;arily thrown away as
un&longs;erviceable: And partly becau&longs;e I think
it becomes one that profe&longs;&longs;es him&longs;elf a
faithful Relator of Experiments, not to
conceal from Your Lord&longs;hip, that after a
few of the foregoing Experiments were
made, there happen'd in the great Recei­
ver a crack of about a Span long, begin-
ning at the upper Orifice, and occa&longs;ion'd,
as it &longs;eem'd, by the exce&longs;&longs;ive heat of too
large an Iron that was employ'd to melt
the Cement about that Orifice.

But ha­
ving laid upon this crack a broad Plai&longs;ter,
which in one of our E&longs;&longs;ays written &longs;ome
years &longs;ince to your ingenious and hopeful
Cou&longs;in Fones, we extoll for the mending
of crack'd Receivers, and other Chymi­
cal Gla&longs;&longs;es; and having afterwards thick­
ly over-laid this Plai&longs;ter with Diachylon,
we neither could then, nor can yet per­
ceive that the Ve&longs;&longs;el leaks &longs;en&longs;ibly at that
crack.

The Plai&longs;ter was made of good quick
Lime finely poudred, and nimbly ground
with a Pe&longs;tle in a Morter, with a quantity
(I know not how much preci&longs;ely, not ha­
ving tho&longs;e E&longs;&longs;ays in this place) of &longs;cra­
pings of Chee&longs;e and a little fair Water,
no more then is ju&longs;t nece&longs;&longs;ary to bring the
mixture to a &longs;omewhat &longs;oft Pa&longs;te, which
when the Ingredients are exqui&longs;itely in­
corporated, will have a &longs;trong and
&longs;tincking &longs;mell: Then it mu&longs;t be im­
mediately &longs;pread upon a Linnen Cloath
three or four fingers breadth, and pre&longs;ently
apply'd, le&longs;t it begin to harden.

But if
Your Lord&longs;hip had &longs;een how we mended
with it Receivers even for the mo&longs;t &longs;ub­
tle Chymical Spirits, You would &longs;carce
wonder at the &longs;ervice it has done in our
Pneumatical Gla&longs;s.

WE took a Tallow-Candle of &longs;uch
a &longs;ize that eight of them make
about a pound, and having in a very com­
modious Candle&longs;tick let it down into the
Receiver, and &longs;o &longs;u&longs;pended it that the
Flame burnt almo&longs;t in the middle of the
Ve&longs;&longs;el, we did in &longs;ome two minutes ex­
actly clo&longs;e it up: and, upon Pumping ve­
ry nimbly, we found that within little
more then half a minute after the Flame
went out, though the Snuff had been
purpo&longs;ely left of that length we judged
the mo&longs;t convenient for the la&longs;ting of
the Flame.

Experi­
ment 10.

But the &longs;econd time having put in the
&longs;ame Candle into the Receiver, (after it
had by the bla&longs;ts of a pair of Bellows
been freed from Fumes) the Flame la&longs;ted
about two minutes from the time the
Pumper began to draw out the Air; up­
on the fir&longs;t ex&longs;uction whereof, the Flame
&longs;eem'd to contract it &longs;elf in all its Dimen­
&longs;ions.

And the&longs;e things were further ob-
&longs;ervable, that after the two or three fir&longs;t
ex&longs;uctions of the Air, the Flame (except
at the very top) appear'd exceeding blew,
and that the Flame &longs;till receded more and
more from the Tallow, till at length it
appear'd to po&longs;&longs;e&longs;s onely the very top of
the Week, and there it went out.

The &longs;ame Candle being lighted again
was &longs;hut into the Receiver, to try how it
would la&longs;t there without drawing forth
the Air, and we found that it la&longs;ted much
longer then formerly; and before it went
out receded from the Tallow towards the
the top of the Week, but not near &longs;o
much as in the former Experiment.

And having an intention to ob&longs;erve par­
ticularly what the motion of the &longs;moak
would be in the&longs;e Experiments: We
took notice that when the Air was not
drawn out, there did upon the extinction
of the Flame a con&longs;iderable part of the
Week remain kindled, which (probably
by rea&longs;on of the Circulation of the Air
in the Ve&longs;&longs;el, occa&longs;ion'd by the heat) e­
mitted a Steam, which a&longs;cended &longs;wiftly
and directly upwards in a &longs;lender and unin­
terrupted Cylinder of &longs;moke, till it came
to the top, whence it manife&longs;tly recoyl'd
by the &longs;ides to the lower part of the Ve&longs;-
&longs;el.

Whereas when the Flame went out
upon the ex&longs;uction of the Air one time
(when the Flame retir'd very lea&longs;urely
to the top) we perceived it not to be fol­
low'd by any &longs;moke at all.

And at an
other time the upper part of the Week
remaining kindled after the extinction
of the Flame, the &longs;lender &longs;team of Fumes
that did ari&longs;e a&longs;cended but a very little
way, and then after &longs;ome uncertain mo­
tions this and that way, did, for the mo&longs;t
part, &longs;oon fall downwards.

Being de&longs;irous al&longs;o to try whether
there would be any difference as well in
our Receiver as there is wont to be el&longs;e­
where betwixt Candles made of Wax and
tho&longs;e made of Tallow, as to their dura­
tion; we took &longs;lender Tapers of white
Wax, (commonly called Virgins Wax)
that being found to burn with much le&longs;s
&longs;moke then common yellow Wax: Six
of the&longs;e of like bigne&longs;s, and each of them
of about the thickne&longs;s of a Swans Quill,
we pre&longs;&longs;'d together into one Candle: And
having lighted all the Weeks, we let in
the above-mention'd Wax into the Re­
ceiver, and made what ha&longs;te we could to
clo&longs;e it up with Cement.

But though in
the mean while we left open the Valve
of the Cylinder, the hole of the Stop­
cock and that in the Cover of the Re­
ceiver, that &longs;ome Air might get in to
cheri&longs;h the Flame and the &longs;moke might
have a vent; Yet for &longs;o great a Flame
the Air &longs;ufficed not &longs;o much as till the
Cover could be perfectly luted on: So
that before we were quite ready to imploy
the Pump, the Candle was extingui&longs;hed.

Wherefore we took but one of the a­
bove mention'd Tapers, and having
lighted it, clo&longs;'d it up in the Receiver, to
try how long a &longs;mall Flame with a pro­
portionable &longs;moke would continue in
&longs;uch a quantity of Air: But we found
upon two &longs;everal tryals, that from the
beginning of pumping, the Flame went
out in about a minute of an hour.

It
appear'd indeed to us that the &longs;winging
of the Wier to and fro (in the Engine
&longs;haken by pumping) ha&longs;ten'd the vani&longs;h­
ing of the Flame, which &longs;eem'd by that
motion to be ca&longs;t &longs;ometimes on one &longs;ide
of the Week and &longs;ometimes on the o­
ther; But though once we purpo&longs;ely
refrain'd pumping after a very few ex­
&longs;uctions of the Air, that the Flame might
not be agitated, yet it la&longs;ted not much
longer then the newly mention'd time.
And la&longs;tly, clo&longs;ing up the &longs;ame Taper,
lighted again, to di&longs;cover how long it
would la&longs;t without drawing out of the
Air, we found that it burn'd for a while
vividly enough, but afterwards began to
be le&longs;&longs;en'd more and more in all its Di­
men&longs;ions.

And we ob&longs;erv'd that the
Flame did not, as before, retire it &longs;elf by
little and little towards the top, but to­
wards the bottom of the Week (from
which yet it did a little withdraw upwards
ju&longs;t before it went out) &longs;o that the upper
part of the Week appear'd for a pretty
while manife&longs;tly above the top of the
Flame, which having la&longs;ted about five
minutes, was &longs;ucceeded by a directly a&longs;­
cending &longs;tream of Smoak.

THere was taken a Wier, which being
bent almo&longs;t in the form of a Screw,
con&longs;tituted &longs;uch an In&longs;trument to contein
Coals and leave them every way acce&longs;&longs;i­
ble to the Air, as the tenth Figure de­
clares; the breadth of this Ve&longs;&longs;el was no
le&longs;s then that it might with ea&longs;e be con­
vey'd into the Receiver: And having filld
it to the height of about five Inches with
throughly kindled Wood-coals, we let
it down into the Gla&longs;s; and &longs;peedily clo­
&longs;ing it, we cau&longs;'d the Pumper to ply
his work, and ob&longs;erv'd that upon the ve­
ry fir&longs;t ex&longs;uction of the Air (though per­
haps not becau&longs;e of that onely) the Fire
in the Coals began to grow very dim, and
though the agitation of the Ve&longs;&longs;el did
make them &longs;wing up and down (which in
the free Air would have retarded the ex­
tinction of the Fire) yet when we could
no longer di&longs;cern any redne&longs;s at all in any
of them; ca&longs;ting our eyes upon a Minute­
Watch we kept by us on this occa&longs;ion, we
found that from the beginning of the
Pumping (which might be about two mi­
nutes after the Coals had been put in
glowing) to the total di&longs;-appearing of
the Fire, there had pa&longs;&longs;ed but three mi­
nutes.

Experi­
ment 11.

Whereupon, to try the Experiment a
little further, we pre&longs;ently took out the
Coals, in which it &longs;eems there had re­
mained &longs;ome little parcels of Fire, rather
cover'd then totally quench'd: For in the
open Air the Coals began to be re-kind­
led in &longs;everal places, wherefore having by
&longs;winging them about in the Wier,
throughly lighted them the &longs;econd time,
welet them down again into the Receiver,
and clo&longs;'d it &longs;peedily as before; and then
waiting till the Fire &longs;eem'd totally ex­
tinct without medling with the Pump, we
found that from the time the Ve&longs;&longs;el was
clo&longs;'d till that no Fire at all could be per­
ceiv'd there had pa&longs;&longs;ed about four mi­
nutes: Whereby it &longs;eem'd to appear that
the drawing away of the ambient Air
made the Fire go out &longs;ooner then other­
wi&longs;e it would have done; though that part
of the Air that we drew out left the more
room for the &longs;tifling &longs;teams of the Coals
to be received into.

La&longs;tly, Having taken out the Wier
and put other Coals into it, we did, in the
&longs;ame Room where the Engine &longs;tood, let it
hang quietly by a &longs;tring in the open Air,
to try how long the Fire would la&longs;t with­
out agitation when no Air was kept from
it.

And we found that the Fire began to
go out fir&longs;t at the top and out-&longs;ides of the
Coals; but inwards and near the bottom
the Fire continu'd vi&longs;ible for above half
an hour, a great part of the Coals, e&longs;pe­
cially tho&longs;e next the bottom, being burnt
to a&longs;hes before the Fire went out.

We cau&longs;'d likewi&longs;e a piece of Iron to
be forg'd, of the bigne&longs;s of a middle &longs;iz'd
Char-coal, and having made it red hot
throughout; we cau&longs;'d it in the lately
mention'd Wier, to be &longs;peedily convey'd
and &longs;hut up into the Receiver, being de­
&longs;irous to try what would become of a
glowing Body, by rea&longs;on of its texture
more vehemently hot then a burning
Coal of the &longs;ame bigne&longs;s, & yet unlike to
&longs;end forth &longs;uch copious & &longs;tifling Fumes:
But we could not ob&longs;erve any manife&longs;t
change upon the ex&longs;uction of the Air.

The Iron began indeed to lo&longs;e its Fiery
redne&longs;s at the top, but that &longs;eem'd to be
becau&longs;e it was it the upper end &longs;omewhat
more &longs;lender then at the lower: The red­
ne&longs;s, though it were in the day time, con­
tinued vi&longs;ible about four minutes; and
then, before it did quite di&longs;-appear, we
turn'd the Key of the Stop-cock but
could not di&longs;cern any change of the Iron
upon the ru&longs;hing in of the Air.

Yet &longs;ome
little remainders of Wax that &longs;tuck to
the Wier, and were turn'd into Fumes by
the heat of the neighboring Iron, &longs;eem'd
to afford a more plentiful, or at lea&longs;t a
much more free expanded &longs;moke when
the Air was &longs;uck'd out, then afterwards;
though allowance was made for the de­
crea&longs;ing heat of the Iron.

And la&longs;tly,
notwith&longs;tanding a con&longs;iderable ex&longs;uction
of the ambient Air, though not by far &longs;o
great a one as might have been made by
the Engine; and notwith&longs;tanding the in­
con&longs;iderable di&longs;&longs;ipation of the parts of the
Iron, the &longs;urrounding &longs;ides of the Recei­
ver were &longs;en&longs;ibly, and almo&longs;t offen&longs;ively
heated by it; in&longs;omuch that a pretty while
after the Iron was taken out, the &longs;ides of
the Gla&longs;s manife&longs;tly retain'd a warmth:
which would not be unfit to be con&longs;ider'd
by a Per&longs;on at more lea&longs;ure then I am
now.

BEing willing to try after this &longs;ome­
thing that would not cheri&longs;h much
Fire at once, and would keep Fire much
longer then a Coal.

We took a piece of
Match, &longs;uch as Souldiers u&longs;e, of the thick­
ne&longs;s of a Mans little Finger, or &longs;omewhat
thicker; and this being well lighted at
one end, was by a &longs;tring &longs;u&longs;pended with
that end downwards in the cavity of the
Receiver which was immediately clo&longs;'d:
And yet by that time it could well be &longs;o,
the copious Fumes of the Match had neer
fill'd and darken'd the Receiver.

Where­
fore, le&longs;t the Ve&longs;&longs;el &longs;hould be endanger'd,
the Pump was nimbly ply'd, and a great
deal of Air and Smoke mixt together was
drawn out, whereby the Receiver grow­
ing more clear, we could di&longs;cern the Fire
in the Match to burn more and more lan­
guidly: And notwith&longs;tanding that by the
diligence u&longs;'d in Pumping, it &longs;eem'd to
have room enough allow'd it to throw
out Fumes; yet after no long time it
cea&longs;'d from being di&longs;cernable either by its
Light or its Smoke.

And though by
that we were invited to &longs;uppo&longs;e it quite
extingui&longs;hed, yet we continu'd pumping
a while, in pro&longs;ecution of another Expe­
riment we were trying at the &longs;ame time:
And this we did the more willingly be­
cau&longs;e of a &longs;u&longs;picion the Experiment a­
bout the Coals might ea&longs;ily &longs;ugge&longs;t, and
which the event declar'd not to have been
altogether groundle&longs;s.

For upon the
Admi&longs;&longs;ion of the external Air, the Fire,
that &longs;eem'd to have gone out a pretty
while before, did pre&longs;ently revive; and
being as it were refre&longs;h d by the new Air,
and blown by the Wind made by that
Air in ru&longs;hing in, it began again to &longs;hine
and di&longs;&longs;ipate the neighboring Fuel into
Smoke as formerly.

Experi­
ment 12.

A While after we let down into
the Receiver together with a ligh­
ted piece of Match, a great Bladder well
tyed at the Neck, but very lank, as not
containing actually much (if any thing) a­
bove a Pint of Air, but being capable of
containing ten or twelve times as much.

Experi­
ment 13.

Our &longs;cope in this Experiment was
partly to try whether or no the &longs;moke of
the Match, repleni&longs;hing the Receiver,
would be able to hinder the Dilatation of
the inward Air, upon the ex&longs;uction of the
Ambient.

And partly to di&longs;cover whe­
ther the extinction of the Fire in the
Match did proceed from want of Air, or
barely from the pre&longs;&longs;ure of its own
Fumes, which for want of room to ex­
pand them&longs;elves in, might be &longs;uppo&longs;'d
to Recoyl upon the Fire, and &longs;o to
&longs;tifle it.

The event of our tryal was, That
at the beginning of our Pumping the
Match appear'd well lighted, though
it had almo&longs;t fill'd the Receiver with
its plentiful Fumes: But by degrees it
burnt more and more dimly, notwith­
&longs;tanding that by the nimble drawing
out the Air and Smoke, the Ve&longs;&longs;el
were made le&longs;s opacous, and le&longs;s full of
compre&longs;&longs;ing matter; as appeard by this,
That the longer we pump'd, the le&longs;&longs;er
Air and Smoke came out of the Cylin­
der at the opening the Valve, and con&longs;e­
quently the le&longs;s came into it before; yet
the Fire in the Match went but &longs;lowly
out.

And when afterwards, to &longs;atisfie
our &longs;elves of its expiration, we had dar­
ken'd the Room, and in vain endeavored
to di&longs;cover any &longs;park of Fire, as we could
not for &longs;ome time before by the help of
Candles di&longs;cern the lea&longs;t ri&longs;ing of Smoke,
we yet continued pumping &longs;ix or &longs;even
times; and after all that letting in the
Air, the &longs;eemingly dead Fire quickly
revived, and manife&longs;ted its recovery by
Light and &longs;tore of Smoke, with the
latter of which it quickly began to re­
pleni&longs;h the Receiver.

Then we fell
to pumping afre&longs;h, and continued that
labour &longs;o long till the re-kindled
Match went out again: and thinking
it then fit not to cea&longs;e from Pum­
ping &longs;o &longs;oon as before, we found that
in le&longs;s then half a quarter of an hour the
Fire was got out for good and all,
and pa&longs;t the po&longs;&longs;ibility of being recover'd
by the re-admitted Air.

Some Circum&longs;tances, be&longs;ides tho&longs;e al­
ready mention'd, occurr'd in the making
of the Experiment, of which the&longs;e are
the principal.

Fir&longs;t, when the Receiver was full of
Smoke, if the Cylinder were emptied,
immediately upon the turning of the
Stop-cock, the Receiver would appear
manife&longs;tly darken'd to his eye that look'd
upon the light through it: and this dark­
ne&longs;s was much le&longs;s when the Receiver was
much le&longs;s fill'd with Fumes: It was al&longs;o
in&longs;tantaneous, and &longs;eem'd to proceed from
a &longs;udden change of place and &longs;cituation
in the exhalations, upon the vent &longs;ud­
denly afforded them and the Air they
were mixt with, out of the Receiver into
the Cylinder.

The next thing we ob&longs;erv'd was, a kinde
of Halo that appear'd a good while about
the Fire, and &longs;eem'd to be produced by
the &longs;urrounding Exhalations.

And la&longs;tly, it is remarkable, That even
when the Fumes &longs;eemed mo&longs;t to reple­
ni&longs;h the Receiver, they did not &longs;en&longs;ibly
hinder the Air included in the Bladder
from dilating it &longs;elf after the &longs;ame manner
(for ought we could di&longs;cern) as it would
have otherwi&longs;e done: So that before the
Fire or the Match was quite extinct, the
Bladder appear'd &longs;well'd at lea&longs;t to &longs;ix or
&longs;even times its former capacity.

Since the writing of the&longs;e la&longs;t Lines,
we took a &longs;mall Receiver, capable of
containing (by gue&longs;s) about a pound and
a half of Water; and in the mid&longs;t of it
we &longs;u&longs;pended a lighted Match, but though
within one minute of an hour (or there­
abouts) from the putting in of the Match,
we had cemented on the Cover, yet we
could not make &longs;uch ha&longs;te, but that before
we began to pump, the Smoke had &longs;o
fill'd that &longs;mall Receiver, as for ought we
di&longs;cern'd, to choke the Fire.

And having
again and again reiterated the Experi­
ment, it &longs;eem'd &longs;till as at fir&longs;t, that we
could not clo&longs;e up the Ve&longs;&longs;el and pump
out all the Fumes time enough to re&longs;cue
the Fire from Extinction; whereupon we
made u&longs;e of this Expedient.

A&longs;&longs;oon as
we had pump'd once or twice, we &longs;udden­
ly turn'd the Key, and thereby gave acce&longs;s
to the excluded Air, which ru&longs;hing vio­
lently in, as if it had been forced thorow
a pair of Bellows, did both drive away
the a&longs;hes, fill the Gla&longs;s with fre&longs;h Air, and
by blowing the almo&longs;t extingui&longs;h'd Fire,
re-kindl'd it, as appear'd by the Matches
beginning again to &longs;moke, which before it
had cea&longs;'d to do; we having by this
means obtain'd a lighted Match in the
Receiver, without being reduc'd to &longs;pend
time to clo&longs;e it up, commanded the Air
to be immediatly pump'd out, and found
that upon the ex&longs;uction of it, the Match
quickly left &longs;mokeing, as it &longs;eem'd, by
rea&longs;on of the ab&longs;ence of the Air; and
yet if &longs;ome urgent occa&longs;ions had not hin­
der'd us, we would for greater &longs;ecurity
have try'd, whether or no the Match re­
kindled as formerly, would &longs;moke much
longer, in ca&longs;e of no ex&longs;uction of the am­
bient Air.

TO try diver&longs;e things at once,
and particularly whether Fire,
though we found it would not long la&longs;t,
might not yet be produced in our eva­
cuated Receiver: We took a Pi&longs;tol of
about a Foot in length, and having
firmly tyed it to a &longs;tick almo&longs;t as long as
the Cavity of the Receiver, we very
carefully prim'd it with well dry'd Gun­
powder, and then cocking it, we ty'd to
the Tricker one end of a &longs;tring, who&longs;e
other end was fa&longs;ten'd to the Key former­
ly mention'd to belong to the Cover of
our Receiver.

This done, we convey'd
the Pi&longs;tol, together with the annexed
Staff, into the Ve&longs;&longs;el: which being clo&longs;'d
up, and empty'd after the u&longs;ual man­
ner, we began to turn the Key in the
Cover; and thereby &longs;hortning the &longs;tring
that reach'd from it to the Pi&longs;tol, we
pull'd a&longs;ide the Tricker, and ob&longs;erv'd,
that according to our expectation the
force of the Spring of the Lock was
not &longs;en&longs;ibly abated by the ab&longs;ence of
the Air. (from who&longs;e impetus yet &longs;ome
Modern Naturali&longs;ts would derive the
cau&longs;e of the motion of Re&longs;titution in
&longs;olid Bodies) For the Cock falling
with its wonted violence upon the Steel,
&longs;truck out of it as many and as con&longs;pi­
cuous parts of Fire, as, for ought we
could perceive, it would have done in
the open Air.

Repeating this Experi­
ment divers times, we al&longs;o ob&longs;erved
whether or no there would appear
any con&longs;iderable Diver&longs;ity in the
Motion of the &longs;hining Sparks in a
place where the remaining Aire was
&longs;o much rarified, but could not perceive
but that they moved &longs;ome of them up­
wards, as well as &longs;ome of them down­
wards, and &longs;ome of them &longs;ide-ways, as
they are wont to do, when upon &longs;uch col­
li&longs;ions they fly out in the open Air.

Experi­
ment 14.

We likewi&longs;e cau&longs;'d a piece of Steel to
be made of the form and bigne&longs;s of the
Flint, in who&longs;e place we put it, and then
the Pi&longs;tol being cock'd and conveyed in­
to the Receiver, the Trigger was pull'd
after the Air was drawn out: And though
the place were purpo&longs;ely &longs;omewhat dar­
ken'd, yet there appear'd not upon the
&longs;triking of the two Steels again&longs;t each o­
ther the lea&longs;t &longs;park of Fire: Nor did we
expect any (having before in vain attem­
pted to &longs;trike Fire this way in the open
Air) though we thought fit to make the
Experiment to undeceive tho&longs;e who fan­
cy in rarified Air, I know not what &longs;trange
di&longs;po&longs;ition, to take Fire upon a much
&longs;lighter occa&longs;ion then this Experiment
afforded.

We have indeed found, that
by the dextrous Colli&longs;ion of two har­
den'd pieces of Steel, &longs;tore of &longs;parks
may be &longs;truck out: But that was done with
&longs;uch vehement percu&longs;&longs;ion of the edges of
the two Steels, as could not well be com­
pa&longs;&longs;'d in our Receiver.

But the chief thing we de&longs;ign'd to do
with our Pi&longs;tol, was, To ob&longs;erve whe­
ther Gun-powder would take Fire in our
empty'd and clo&longs;ely &longs;top'd Gla&longs;s?

Whe­
ther the expan&longs;ion of the Flame would be
con&longs;iderably varied by the ab&longs;ence of &longs;o
much of the ambient Air as was drawn
out of the Receiver?

and whether the
Flame would diffu&longs;e it &longs;elf upward, as it is
wont, notwith&longs;tanding its not having a­
bout it the u&longs;ual proportion of Air to
force it up?

And though mo&longs;t of our at­
tempts to fire the Gun-powder in the
Pan of the Pi&longs;tol &longs;ucceeded not, becau&longs;e
we were fain to let it hang almo&longs;t perpen­
dicular in the Receiver; whereby the
Powder was &longs;haken down before the
&longs;parks could reach it: yet once the Ex­
periment &longs;ucceeded, and the kindled
Powder &longs;eem'd to make a more expanded
Flame then it would have done in the
open Air, but mounted upwards accord­
ing to its wont, whether by rea&longs;on of that
little portion of Air, which in &longs;pight of
our pumping remained in the Receiver, or
for any other cau&longs;e, we have not now the
lei&longs;ure to con&longs;ider.

But we mu&longs;t not for­
get, that upon the extinction of the Flame
the Receiver appear'd darken'd with
&longs;moke, which &longs;eem'd to move freely up
and down, and upon the letting in the Air
at the Stop-cock began to circulate much
fa&longs;ter then before.

We wonld have made
more ob&longs;ervations concerning this Flame,
but that of two or three attempts we
afterwards made to repeat the kindling of
Powder, not any one &longs;ucceeded; and
we have not the lea&longs;ure to dwell long up­
on one kinde of Tryals.

TO the&longs;e Experiments concerning Fire
we added another, which, though it &longs;uc­
ceded not, may perhaps without imper­
tinency be recorded: partly becau&longs;e that
(as we have in another Treati&longs;e amply de­
clar'd) it is u&longs;efull to recite what Experi­
ments mi&longs;carry as well as what &longs;ucceed.

And partly al&longs;o becau&longs;e it is very po&longs;&longs;ible
that what we endeavored in vaine, may be
performed by Your Lord&longs;hip, or &longs;ome
other Virtuo&longs;o that &longs;hall have &longs;lancker
Ve&longs;&longs;ells then we had, and more Sunny
dayes then the pre&longs;ent Winter allows
us.

Experi­
ment 15.

We convey'd then into one of our &longs;mall
Receivers a piece of matter combu&longs;tible,
dry and black (experience declaring things
of that colour to be mo&longs;t ea&longs;ily kindled)
& carefully clo&longs;ing the Ve&longs;&longs;el we brought
it to a Window at which the Sun, not very
faire from the Meridian, &longs;hone in very free­
ly: then drawing out the Aire with &longs;peed
united the Sun-beames with a burning
Gla&longs;s upon the combu&longs;tible matter which
began immediatly to &longs;end forth a Smoke
that quickly darkned the Receiver, but
notwith&longs;tanding all our care and diligence
the externall Aire got in &longs;o fa&longs;t that after
diver&longs;e tryals we were fayne to leave off
the Experiment in that Gla&longs;&longs;e and induc'd
to make tryall of it in our great Re­
ceiver.

Haveing then after &longs;ome difficulty
lodg'd the combu&longs;tible matter in the ca­
vity of this Ve&longs;&longs;ell in &longs;uch manner as that
it was almo&longs;t contiguous to that &longs;ide
thereof that was next the Sun, we did en­
deavor with a pretty large burning Gla&longs;s
to kindle it, but found, as we fear'd,
That by rea&longs;on of the thickne&longs;s of the
Gla&longs;s, (which was al&longs;o of a le&longs;s pure and
le&longs;s Diaphanous matter then the o­
ther) the Sun-beams thrown in by the
burning Gla&longs;s, were in their pa&longs;&longs;age
&longs;o Di&longs;located and Scattered (not now to
mention tho&longs;e many that being reflected,
I could not pierce into the cavity of the
Receiver) that we could not po&longs;&longs;ibly u­
nite enough of them to kindle the matter,
nor &longs;o much as to make it &longs;en&longs;ibly &longs;moke.

Yet we hope that the &longs;eeing whether Bo­
dies (other then Gun-powder) may be
kindled, and what would happen to them
when &longs;et on fire, in a place in great mea­
&longs;ure devoid of Air, may prove &longs;o Lucife­
rous an Experiment, that when the Sea­
&longs;on is more favorable we &longs;hall, God per­
mitting, make further tryal of it, and ac­
quaint Your Lord&longs;hip with the Event, if
it prove pro&longs;perous.

In the mean time
we &longs;hall pa&longs;s on to other Experiments,
a&longs;&longs;oon as we have adverti&longs;'d Your Lord­
&longs;hip that we have forborn to make &longs;uch
Reflections upon the &longs;everal Experiments
we have &longs;et down concerning Fire, as the
matter would have ea&longs;ily enough afford­
ed, and Your Lord&longs;hip may perhaps have
expected.

But I made the le&longs;s &longs;cruple to
forbear the annexing of Speculations to
the&longs;e Recitals, becau&longs;e Carneades & Eleu­
therius have in &longs;ome Dialogues concern­
ing Heat and Flame, which were la&longs;t year
&longs;een by &longs;ome Friends, and may be, when
you plea&longs;e, commanded by You, men-
tion'd divers of my Thoughts and Expe­
riments concerning Fire.

WE de&longs;igned to try whether or no
divers Magnetical Experiments
would exhibit any unu&longs;ual Phænomena,
being made in our Evacuated Receiver
in&longs;tead of the open Air: But for want of
lei&longs;ure and conveniency to pro&longs;ecute &longs;uch
Tryals, we were induced to re&longs;erve the
re&longs;t for an other time, and to content our
&longs;elves with making that which follows.

We convey'd into the Receiver a little
Pede&longs;tal of Wood, in the mid&longs;t of which
was perpendicularly erected a &longs;lender
Iron, upon who&longs;e &longs;harp point an excited
Needle of Steel purpo&longs;ely made, and of
about five Inches long, was &longs;o placed
that hanging in an Æquilibrium it could
move freely towards either hand.

Then
the Air being after the u&longs;ual manner
pumped out, we apply'd a Load-&longs;tone
moderately vigorous to the out-&longs;ide of
of the Gla&longs;s, and found that it Attracted
or Repell'd the ends of the Needle, accor­
ding to the Laws Magnetical, without
any remarkable difference from what the
&longs;ame Load-&longs;tone would have done had
none of the Air been drawn away from a­
bout the Needle, which when the Load­
&longs;tone was removed, after &longs;ome tremu­
lous Vibrations to and fro, re&longs;ted in a po­
&longs;ition wherein it look'd North and
South.

Experi­
ment 16

PRoceed we now to the mention of
that Experiment, whereof the &longs;ati&longs;­
factory tryal was the principal Fruit I
promi&longs;'d my &longs;elf from our Engine.

It
being then &longs;ufficiently known, that, in
the Experiment De Vacuo, the Quick­
&longs;ilver in the Tube is wont to remain ele­
vated, above the &longs;urface of that whereon
it leans, about 27 digits: I con&longs;idered,
that, if the true and onely rea&longs;on why the
Quick-&longs;ilver falls no lower, be, that at
that Altitude, the Mercurial Cylinder in
the Tube, is an Æquilibrium with the
Cylinder of Air, &longs;uppo&longs;'d to reach from
the adjacent Mercury to the top of the
Atmo&longs;phere: If this Experiment could
be try'd out of the Atmo&longs;phere, the
Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube would fall
down to a levell with that in the Ve&longs;&longs;el,
&longs;ince then there would be no pre&longs;&longs;ure up­
on the Subjacent, to re&longs;i&longs;t the weight of
the Incumbent Mercury.

Whence I in­
ferr'd (as ea&longs;ily I might) that, if the Ex­
periment could be try'd in our Engine, the
Quick-&longs;ilver would &longs;ub&longs;ide below 27 Di­
gits, in proportion to the ex&longs;uction of
Air, that &longs;hould be made out of the Re­
ceiver.

For, as when the Air is &longs;hut in­
to the Receiver, it does (according to
what hath above been taught) continue
there as &longs;trongly compre&longs;&longs;'d, as it did
whil'&longs;t all the incumbent Cylinder of the
Atmo&longs;phere lean'd immediatly upon it;
becau&longs;e the Gla&longs;s, wherein it is pent up,
hinders it to deliver it &longs;elf, by an expan&longs;i­
on of its parts, from the pre&longs;&longs;ure where­
with it was &longs;hut up.

So, if we could per­
fectly draw the Air out of the Receiver,
it would conduce as well to our purpo&longs;e,
as if we were allow'd to try the Experi­
ment beyond the Atmo&longs;phere.

Experi­
ment 17.

Wherefore (after having &longs;urmounted
&longs;ome little difficulties which occurr'd at
the beginning) the Experiment was made
after this manner.

We took a &longs;lender and
very curiou&longs;ly blown Cylinder of Gla&longs;s,
of near three Foot in length, and who&longs;e
bore had in Diameter a quarter of an Inch,
wanting a hairs breadth: This Pipe being
Hermetically &longs;eal'd at one end, was, at
the other, fill'd with Quick-&longs;ilver, care
being taken in the filling, that as few
bubles as was po&longs;&longs;ible &longs;hould be left in the
Mercury: Then the Tube being &longs;topt
with the Finger and inverted, was open'd,
according to the manner of the Experi­
ment, into a &longs;omewhat long and &longs;lender
Cylindrical Box (in&longs;tead of which we now
are wont to u&longs;e a Gla&longs;s of the &longs;ame form)
half fill'd with Quick-&longs;ilver: And &longs;o, the
liquid metal being &longs;uffered to &longs;ub&longs;ide, and
a piece of Paper being pa&longs;ted on levell
with its upper &longs;urface, the Box and Tube
and all were by &longs;trings carefully let down
into the Receiver, and then, by means of
the hole formerly mention'd to be left in
the Cover, the &longs;aid Cover was &longs;lip't along
as much of the Tube as reach'd above the
top of the Receiver; And the Interval,
left betwixt the &longs;ides of the Hole and
tho&longs;e of the Tube, was very exqui&longs;itely
fill'd up with melted (but not over hot)
Diachylon; and the round chink, betwixt
the Cover and the Receiver, was likewi&longs;e
very carefully clo&longs;'d up: Upon which clo­
&longs;ure there appear'd not any change in the
height of the Mercurial Cylinder; no
more, then if the interpo&longs;'d Gla&longs;s Recei­
ver did not hinder the immediate pre&longs;&longs;ure
of the ambient Atmo&longs;phere upon the
inclo&longs;ed Air; which hereby appears to
bear up on the Mercury, rather by virtue
of its &longs;pring, then of its weight: &longs;ince its
weight cannot be &longs;uppo&longs;'d to amount to
above two or three Ounces, which is in­
con&longs;iderable in compari&longs;on of &longs;uch a Cy­
linder of Mercury as it would keep from
&longs;ub&longs;iding.

All things being thus in a readine&longs;s, the
Sucker was drawn down; and, immedi­
ately upon the egre&longs;s of a Cylinder of
Air out of the Receiver; the Quick-&longs;ilver
in the Tube did, according to expectati­
on, &longs;ub&longs;ide: and notice being carefully
taken (by a mark fa&longs;ten'd to the out&longs;ide)
of the place where it &longs;topt, we cau&longs;'d him
that manag'd the Pump to pump again,
and mark'd how low the Quick-&longs;ilver fell
at the &longs;econd ex&longs;uction; but continuing
this work, we were quickly hindred from
accurately marking the Stages made by
the Mercury in its de&longs;cent, becau&longs;e it &longs;oon
&longs;unk below the top of the Receiver; &longs;o
that we could thenceforward mark it no
other ways then by the eye.

And thus,
continuing the labor of pumping for a­
bout a quarter of an hour, we found our
&longs;elves unable to bring the Quick-&longs;ilver in
the Tube totally to &longs;ub&longs;ide; becau&longs;e,
when the Receiver was con&longs;iderably em­
pty'd of its Air, and con&longs;equently that
little that remain'd grown unable to re&longs;i&longs;t
the Irruption of the external, that Air
would (in &longs;pight of whatever we could
do) pre&longs;s in at &longs;ome little Avenue or
other; and though much could not there­
at get in, yet a little was &longs;ufficient to coun­
terballance the pre&longs;&longs;ure of &longs;o &longs;mall a Cy­
linder of Quick-&longs;ilver, as then remain'd
in the Tube.

Now (to &longs;atisfie our &longs;elves further, that
the failing of the Quick-&longs;ilver in the
Tube to a determinate height, proceeds
from the Æquilibrium, wherein it is at
that height with the external Air, the one
gravitating, the other pre&longs;&longs;ing with equal
force upon the &longs;ubjacent Mercury) we Re­
turned the Key and let in &longs;ome new Air;
upon which the Mercury immediatly be­
gan to a&longs;cend (or rather to be impell'd up­
wards) in the Tube, and continu'd a&longs;cend­
ing, till having Return'd the Key it im­
mediatly re&longs;ted at the height which it had
then attain'd: And &longs;o, by Turning and
Returning the Key, we did &longs;everal times
at plea&longs;ure impel it upwards, and check its
a&longs;cent.

And la&longs;tly, having given a free
egre&longs;s at the Stop-cock to as much of the
external Air as would come in, the Quick­
&longs;ilver was impell'd up almo&longs;t to its fir&longs;t
height: I &longs;ay almo&longs;t, becau&longs;e it &longs;topt
near a quarter of an Inch beneath the Pa­
per mark formerly mention'd; which we
a&longs;crib'd to this, That there was (as is u­
&longs;ual in this Experiment) &longs;ome little Parti­
cles of Air engag'd among tho&longs;e of the
Quick-&longs;ilver; which Particles, upon the
de&longs;cent of the Quick-&longs;ilver, did manife&longs;t­
ly ri&longs;e up in Bubbles towards the top of
the Tube, and by their pre&longs;&longs;ure, as well
as by le&longs;&longs;ening the Cylinder by as much
room as they formerly took up in it, hin­
der'd the Quick-&longs;ilver from regaining its
fir&longs;t height.

This Experiment was a few days after
repeated in the pre&longs;ence of tho&longs;e excellent
and de&longs;ervedly Famous Mathematick
Profe&longs;&longs;ors, Dr. Wallis, Dr. Ward, and Mr.
Wren, who were plea&longs;ed to Honor it with
their Pre&longs;ence: And whom I name, both
as ju&longs;tly counting it an Honor to be
known to them, and as being glad of &longs;uch
Judicious and illu&longs;trious Witne&longs;&longs;es of our
Experiment; and 'twas by their gue&longs;s that
the top of the Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube
was defin'd to be brought within an Inch
of the &longs;urface of that in the Ve&longs;&longs;el.

And here, for the Illu&longs;tration of the
foregoing Experiment, it will not be a­
mi&longs;s to mention &longs;ome other particulars
relating to it.

Fir&longs;t then, When we endeavor'd to
make the Experiment with the Tube
clo&longs;'d at one end with Diachylon in&longs;tead
of an Hermetical Seal; we perceiv'd, that
upon the drawing of &longs;ome of the Air out
of the Receiver, the Mercury did indeed
begin to fall, but continu'd afterwards to
&longs;ub&longs;ide, though we did not continue pum­
ping.

Whence it appear'd, that though
the Diachylon that &longs;topt the end of the
Tube were &longs;o thick and &longs;trong, that the
external Air could not pre&longs;s it in (as expe­
rience taught us that it would have done,
if there had been but little of it) yet the
&longs;ubt'ler parts of it were able (though
&longs;lowly) to in&longs;inuate them&longs;elves through
the very body of the Plai&longs;ter, which it
&longs;eems was of &longs;o clo&longs;e a Texture, as that
which we mention'd our &longs;elves to have
&longs;ucce&longs;sfully made u&longs;e of in the Experi­
ment De Vacuo &longs;ome years ago.

So that
now we begin to &longs;u&longs;pect, that perhaps one
Rea&longs;on, why we cannot perfectly pump
out the Air, may be, that when the Ve&longs;&longs;el
is almo&longs;t empty, &longs;ome of the &longs;ubtler
parts of the external Air may, by the
pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Atmo&longs;phere, be &longs;train'd
through the very body of the Diachylon
into the Receiver.

But this is onely con­
jecture:

Another Circum&longs;tance of our Expe­
riment was this, That, if (when the
Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube was fallen low)
too much ingre&longs;s were, at the hole of the
Stop-cock, &longs;uddenly permitted to the ex­
ternal Air; it would ru&longs;h in with that vio­
lence, and bear &longs;o forcibly upon the &longs;ur­
face of the &longs;ubjacent Quick-&longs;ilver, that
it would impel it up into the Tube rudely
enough to endanger the breaking of the
Gla&longs;s.

We formerly mention'd, that the
Quick-&longs;ilver did not in its de&longs;cent fall as
much at a time after the two or three fir&longs;t
ex&longs;uctions of the Air, as at the beginning:
For, having mark'd its &longs;everal Stages up­
on the Tube, we found, that at the fir&longs;t
&longs;uck it de&longs;cended an Inch and 3/8, and at the
&longs;econd an Inch and 1/8; and when the Ve&longs;­
&longs;el was almo&longs;t empty'd, it would &longs;carce at
one ex&longs;uction be drawn down above the
breadth of a Barly-corn.

And indeed we
found it very difficult to mea&longs;ure in what
proportion the&longs;e decrements of the Mer­
curial Cylinder did proceed: partly be­
cau&longs;e (as we have already intimated) the
Quick &longs;ilver was &longs;oon drawn below the
top of the Receiver: and partly becau&longs;e,
upon its de&longs;cent at each ex&longs;uction, it
would immediatly rea&longs;cend a little up­
wards; either by rea&longs;on of the leaking of
the Ve&longs;&longs;el at &longs;ome imperceptible hole or
other, or by rea&longs;on of the motion of
Re&longs;titution in the Air, which, being &longs;ome­
what compre&longs;t by the fall as well as weight
of the Quick &longs;ilver, would repell it a lit­
tle upwards, and make it vibrate a little up
and down, before they could reduce each
other to &longs;uch an Æquilibrium as both
might re&longs;t in.

But though we could not
hitherto make ob&longs;ervations accurate e­
nough concerning the mea&longs;ures of the
Quick-&longs;ilver's de&longs;cent, to reduce them in­
to any Hypothe&longs;is, yet would we not di&longs;­
courage any from attempting it: &longs;ince, if it
could be reduc'd to a certainty, tis proba­
ble that the di&longs;covery would not be un­
u&longs;eful.

And, to illu&longs;trate this matter a little
more, we will adde, That we made a &longs;hift
to try the Experiment in one of our above
mention'd &longs;mall Receivers, not containing
a Quart; but that (agreeably to what we
formerly ob&longs;erved) we found it as difficult
to bring this to be quite empty as to eva­
cuate the greater; the lea&longs;t external Air
that could get in (and we could not po&longs;&longs;i­
bly keep it all perfectly out) &longs;ufficing in &longs;o
&longs;mall a Ve&longs;&longs;el to di&longs;play a con&longs;iderable
pre&longs;&longs;ure upon the &longs;urface of the Mercury,
and thereby hinder that in the Tube from
falling to a level with it.

But this is remark­
able, that having two or three times try'd
the Experiment in that &longs;mall Ve&longs;&longs;el, upon
the very fir&longs;t Cylinder of Air that was
drawn out of the Receiver, the Mercury
fell in the Tube 18 Inches and a half, and
at another 19 Inches and a half.

But, on this occa&longs;ion, I hold it not un­
fit to give Your Lord&longs;hip notice that I
hop'd, from the de&longs;cent of the Quick­
&longs;ilver in the Tube upon the fir&longs;t &longs;uck, to
derive this advantage: that I &longs;hould thence
be enabled to give a near gue&longs;s at the pro­
portion of force betwixt the pre&longs;&longs;ure of
the Air (according to its various &longs;tates, as
to Den&longs;ity and Rarefaction) and the gra­
vity of Quick-&longs;ilver, then hitherto has
been done.

For in our Experiment there
are diver&longs;e things given, that may be
made u&longs;e of towards &longs;uch a di&longs;covery.
For fir&longs;t we may know the capacity of the
Receiver wherein the Experiment is
made, &longs;ince, by filling it with water, we
may ea&longs;ily compute how many Quarts, or
Mea&longs;ures of any other denomination, it
contains of Air; which Air, when &longs;hut
up in the Ve&longs;&longs;el, may be &longs;uppo&longs;'d to have
a pre&longs;&longs;ure equal to that of the Atmo­
&longs;phere; &longs;ince it is able to keep the Quick­
&longs;ilver in the Tube from falling any lower
then it did in the free and open Air.

Next
here is given us the capacity of the bra&longs;s
Cylinder empty'd by the drawing down
of the Sucker (its bore and height being
mention'd in the de&longs;cription of our Pump)
whereby we may come to know how
much of the Air contain'd in the Recei­
ver is drawn out at the fir&longs;t &longs;uck.

And
we may al&longs;o ea&longs;ily define, either in weight
or cubick mea&longs;ures the Cylinder of
Quick-&longs;ilver that an&longs;wers to the Cy­
linder of Air lately mention'd (that
Mercuriall Cylinder being in our En­
gine computable by deducting from
the entire altitude or that Cylinder of
Quick-&longs;ilver, the altitude at which it re&longs;ts
upon the fir&longs;t ex&longs;uction.) But though, if
this Experiment were very watchfully
try'd in Ve&longs;&longs;els of &longs;everal &longs;izes, and the
various de&longs;cents of the Quick-&longs;ilver com­
par'd among them&longs;elves, 'tis not impro­
bable that &longs;ome &longs;uch thing as we hop'd for
may thereby be di&longs;cover'd.

Yet becau&longs;e
not onely the &longs;olid contents of as much
of the Gla&longs;s-tube as remains within the
concave &longs;urface of the Receiver, and
(which is more difficult) the varying con­
tents of the Ve&longs;&longs;el containing the Mer­
cury, and of as much of the Mercury it
&longs;elf as is not in the Tube, mu&longs;t be dedu­
cted out of the capacity of the Receiver;
but there mu&longs;t al&longs;o an allowance be made
for this, that the Cylinder that is empty'd
by the drawing down of the Sucker, and
comes to be fill'd upon the letting of the
Air out of the Receiver into it, is not &longs;o
repleni&longs;h'd with Air as the Receiver it &longs;elf
at fir&longs;t was: becau&longs;e there pa&longs;&longs;es no more
Air out of the Receiver into the Cylin­
der, then is requi&longs;ite to reduce the Air in
the cavity of the Cylinder, and in that of
the Receiver to the &longs;ame mea&longs;ure of dila­
tation: Becau&longs;e of the&longs;e (I &longs;ay) and &longs;ome
other difficulties that require more skill in
Mathematicks then I pretend to, and much
more lea&longs;ure then my pre&longs;ent occa&longs;ions
would allow me, I was willing to refer the
nicer con&longs;ideration of this matter to &longs;ome
of our Learned and Acurate Mathema­
ticians, thinking it enough for me to have
given the Hint already &longs;ugge&longs;ted.

For further confirmation of what hath
been delivered, we likewi&longs;e tryed the Ex­
periment in a Tube of le&longs;s then two foot
long: and, when there was &longs;o much Air
drawn out of the Ve&longs;&longs;el, that the remain­
ing Air was not able to counterballance
the Mercurial Cylinder, the Quick-&longs;ilver
in the Tube &longs;ub&longs;ided &longs;o vi&longs;ibly, that (the
Experiment being try'd in the little Ve&longs;­
&longs;el lately mention'd) at the fir&longs;t &longs;uck it
fell above a &longs;pan, and was afterwards
drawn lower and lower for a little while;
and the external Air being let in upon it,
impell'd it up again almo&longs;t to the top of
the Tube: So little matters it how heavy
or light the Cylinder of Quick &longs;ilver to
&longs;ub&longs;ide is, provided its gravity over­
power the pre&longs;&longs;ure of as much external
Air as bears upon the &longs;urface of that Mer­
cury into which it is to fall.

La&longs;tly we al&longs;o ob&longs;erv'd, That if (when
the Mercury in the Tube had been drawn
down, and by an Ingre&longs;s permitted to the
external Air, impell'd up again to its for­
mer height) there were &longs;ome more Air
thru&longs;t up by the help of the Pump into
the Receiver, the Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube
would a&longs;cend much above the wonted
height of 27 digits, and immediatly up­
on the letting out of that Air would fall a­
gain to the height it re&longs;ted at before.

Your Lord&longs;hip will here perhaps expect,
that as tho&longs;e who have treated of the Tor­
ricellian Experiment, have for the mo&longs;t
part maintaind the Affirmative, or the Ne­
gative of that famous Que&longs;tion, Whether
or no that Noble Experiment infer a Va­
cuum? &longs;o I &longs;hould on this occa&longs;ion inter­
po&longs;e my Opinion touching that Contro­
ver&longs;ie, or at lea&longs;t declare whether or no, in
our Engine, the ex&longs;uction of the Air do
prove the place de&longs;erted by the Air &longs;uck'd
out, to be truly empty, that is, devoid of
all Corporeal Sub&longs;tance.

But be&longs;ides that,
I have neither the lei&longs;ure, nor the ability,
to enter into a &longs;olemn Debate of &longs;o nice a
Que&longs;tion; Your Lord&longs;hip may, if you
think it worth the trouble, in the Dia­
logues not long &longs;ince referr'd to, finde the
Difficulties on both &longs;ides repre&longs;ented;
which then made me yield but a very wa­
vering a&longs;&longs;ent to either of the parties con­
tending about the Que&longs;tion: Nor dare I
yet take upon me to determine &longs;o difficult
a Controver&longs;ie.

For on the one &longs;ide it appears, that not­
with&longs;tanding the ex&longs;uction of the Air, our
Receiver may not be de&longs;titute of all Bo­
dies, &longs;ince any thing placed in it, may be
&longs;een there; which would not be, if it
were not pervious to tho&longs;e Beams of
Light which rebounding from the &longs;een
Object to our eyes, affect us with the &longs;en&longs;e
of it: And that either the&longs;e Beams are
Corporeal Emanations from &longs;ome lucid
body, or el&longs;e at lea&longs;t the light they convey
doth re&longs;ult from the brisk Motion of &longs;ome
&longs;ubtle Matter, I could, if I mi&longs;take not,
&longs;ufficiently manife&longs;t out of the Dialogues
above-mention'd, if I thought your Lord­
&longs;hip could &longs;eriou&longs;ly imagine that Light
could be convey'd without, at lea&longs;t, having
(if I may &longs;o &longs;peak) a Body for its Ve­
hicle.

By the &longs;ixteenth Experiment, it al&longs;o
appears that the clo&longs;ene&longs;s of our Receiver
hinders it not from admitting the Efflu­
via of the Load-&longs;tone; which makes it
very probable that it al&longs;o freely admits
the Magnetical &longs;teams of the Earth; con­
cerning which, we have in another Trea­
ti&longs;e endeavour'd to manife&longs;t that numbers
of them do always permeate our Air.

But on the other &longs;ide it may be &longs;aid,
That as for the &longs;ubtle Matter which makes
the Objects enclo&longs;ed in our evacuated Re­
ceiver, vi&longs;ible, and the Magnetical Efflu­
via of the Earth that may be pre&longs;um'd to
pa&longs;s thorow it, though we &longs;hould grant
our Ve&longs;&longs;el not to be quite devoyd of
them, yet we cannot &longs;o rea&longs;onably affirm
it to be repleni&longs;h'd with them, as we may
&longs;uppo&longs;e, that if they were gather'd toge­
ther into one place without Intervals be­
tween them, they would fill but a &longs;mall
part of the whole Receiver.

As in the
thirteenth Experiment, a piece of Match
was incon&longs;iderable for its bulk, while&longs;t its
parts lay clo&longs;e together, that afterwards
(when the Fire had &longs;catter'd them into
&longs;moke) &longs;eem'd to repleni&longs;h all the Ve&longs;&longs;el.

For (as el&longs;ewhere our Experiments have
demon&longs;trated) both Light and the Efflu­
via of the Load-&longs;tone, may be readily ad­
mitted into a Gla&longs;s, Hermetically &longs;eal'd,
though before their Admi&longs;&longs;ion, as full of
Air as hollow Bodies here below are wont
to be, &longs;o that upon the ex&longs;uction of the
Air, the large &longs;pace de&longs;erted by it, may
remain empty, notwith&longs;tanding the pre­
tence of tho&longs;e &longs;ubtle Corpu&longs;cles, by
which Lucid and Magnetical Bodies pro­
duce their effects.

And as for the Allegations above
mention'd, they &longs;eem to prove but that
the Receiver devoy'd of Air, May be re­
pleni&longs;h'd with &longs;ome &longs;uch Etherial Matter,
as &longs;ome Modern Naturali&longs;ts write of; but
not that it really is &longs;o.

And indeed to me
it yet &longs;eems, that as to tho&longs;e &longs;paces which
the Vacui&longs;ts would have to be empty, be­
cau&longs;e they are manife&longs;tly devoid of Air;
and all gro&longs;&longs;er Bodies, the Pleni&longs;ts (if I
may &longs;o call them) do not prove that &longs;uch
&longs;paces are repleni&longs;h'd with &longs;uch a &longs;ubtle
Matter as they &longs;peak of, by any &longs;en&longs;ible
effects, or operations of it (of which di­
vers new Tryals purpo&longs;ely made, have not
yet &longs;hown me any) but onely conclude
that there mu&longs;t be &longs;uch a Body, becau&longs;e
there cannot be a Void.

And the rea&longs;on
why there cannot be a Void, being by
them taken, not from any Experiments,
or Phænomena of Nature, that clearly and
particularly prove their Hypothe&longs;is, but
from their notion of a Body, who&longs;e Na­
ture, according to them, con&longs;i&longs;ting one­
ly in exten&longs;ion (which indeed &longs;eems the
property mo&longs;t e&longs;&longs;ential to, becau&longs;e in&longs;epa­
rable from a Body) to &longs;ay a &longs;pace devoid
of Body, is to &longs;peak in the School-mens
Phra&longs;e, a Contradiction in Adjecto: This
rea&longs;on, I &longs;ay, being thus de&longs;um'd, &longs;eems
to make the Controver&longs;ie about a Vacu­
um, rather a Metaphy&longs;ical, then a Phy&longs;io­
logical Que&longs;tion; which therefore we &longs;hall
here no longer debate, finding it very dif­
ficult either to &longs;atisfie Naturali&longs;ts with
this Carte&longs;ian Notion of a Body, or to
manife&longs;t wherein it is erroneous, and &longs;ub­
&longs;titute a better in its &longs;tead.

But though we are unwilling to exa­
mine any further the Inferences wont to
be made from the Torricellian Experi­
ment, yet we think it not impertinent to
pre&longs;ent Your Lord&longs;hip with a couple of
Adverti&longs;ements concerning it.

Fir&longs;t, then if in trying the Experiment
here or el&longs;ewhere, you make u&longs;e of the
Engli&longs;h mea&longs;ures that Mathematicians
and Trade&longs;men are here wont to imploy,
You will, unle&longs;s you be forewarn'd of it,
be apt to &longs;u&longs;pect that tho&longs;e that have writ­
ten of the Experiment have been mi&longs;ta­
ken.

For whereas men are wont gene­
rally to talk of the Quick-&longs;ilver's remain­
ing &longs;u&longs;pended at the heighth of between
&longs;ix or &longs;even and twenty Inches; we com­
monly ob&longs;erv'd, when divers years &longs;ince
we fir&longs;t were &longs;ollicitous about this Expe­
riment, that the Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube
re&longs;ted at about 29 Inches & an half above
the &longs;urface of the Re&longs;tagnant Quick-&longs;ilver
in the Ve&longs;&longs;el, which did at fir&longs;t both amaze
and perplex us, becau&longs;e though we held it
not improbable that the difference of the
gro&longs;&longs;er Engli&longs;h Air, and that of Italy and
France, might keep the Quick-&longs;ilver from
falling quite as low in this colder, as in
tho&longs;e warmer Climates; yet we could
not believe that that difference in the Air
&longs;hould alone be able to make &longs;o great a one
in the heights of the Mercurial Cylinders;
and accordingly upon enquiry we found,
that though the various den&longs;ity of the
Air be not to be over-look'd in this Ex­
periment, yet the main Rea&longs;on why we
found the Cylinder of Mercury to con&longs;i&longs;t
of &longs;o many Inches, was this, That our
Engli&longs;h Inches are &longs;omewhat inferior in
length to the digits made u&longs;e of in Fo­
