rein Parts, by the Writers of the Expe­
riment.

The next thing I de&longs;ire Your Lord&longs;hip to
take notice of, is, That the heigth of the
Mercurial Cylinder is not wont to be found
altogether &longs;o great as really it might
prove, by rea&longs;on of the negligence or in­
cogitancy of mo&longs;t that make the Experi­
ment.

For often times upon the opening
of the inverted Tube into the Ve&longs;&longs;ell'd
Mercury, you may ob&longs;erve a bubble of
Air to a&longs;cend from the bottom of the
Tube through the &longs;ub&longs;iding Quick-&longs;ilver
to the top; and almo&longs;t always you may,
if you look narrowly, take notice of a
multitude of &longs;mall bubbles all along the
in&longs;ide of the Tube betwixt the Quick­
&longs;ilver & the gla&longs;s: (not now to mention the
Particles of Air that lye conceal'd in the
very Body of the Mercury) Many of
which, upon the Quick-&longs;ilvers for&longs;aking
the upper part of the Tube, do break in­
to that de&longs;erted &longs;pace where they finde
little or no re&longs;i&longs;tance to their expanding
of them&longs;elves.

Whether this be the rea­
&longs;on that upon the Application of warm
Bodies to the emptyed part of the Tube,
the &longs;ubjacent Mercury would be depre&longs;&longs;'d
&longs;omewhat lower, we &longs;hall not determine;
though it &longs;eem very probable, e&longs;pecially
&longs;ince we found that upon the application
of Linnen cloaths dipped in Water, to
the &longs;ame part of the Tube, the Quick­
&longs;ilver would &longs;omewhat a&longs;cend, as if the
cold had conden&longs;'d the Impri&longs;on'd Air,
that pre&longs;&longs;'d upon it, into a le&longs;&longs;er room.

But that the de&longs;erted &longs;pace is not wont to
be totally devoid of Air, we were induc'd
to think by &longs;everal Circum&longs;tances.

For
when an eminent Mathematician, and ex­
cellent Experimenter, had taken great
pains and &longs;pent much time in accuratly fil­
ling up a Tube of Mercury, we found
that yet there remain'd &longs;tore of incon&longs;pi­
cuous bubbles, by inverting the Tube,
letting the Quick-&longs;ilver fall to its wonted
heighth; and by approaching (by de­
grees) a red hot Iron to the out-&longs;ide of the
Tube, over again&longs;t the upper part of the
Mercurial Cylinder, for hereby the little
unheeded bubbles, being mightily expan­
ded, a&longs;cended in &longs;uch numbers, and &longs;o fa&longs;t
to the de&longs;erted &longs;pace, that the upper part
of the Quick-&longs;ilver &longs;eem'd, to our wonder,
to boyl.

We further ob&longs;erv'd, That in
the tryals of the Torricellian Experiment
we have &longs;een made by others, and (one
excepted) all our own, we never found that
upon the inclining of the Tube the Quick­
&longs;ilver would fully reach to the very top of
the &longs;eal'd end: which argued, that there
was &longs;ome Air retreated thither that kept
the Mercury out of the unrepleni&longs;h'd
&longs;pace.

If Your Lord&longs;hip &longs;hould now demand
what are the be&longs;t expedients to hinder the
intru&longs;ion of the Air in this Experiment;
we mu&longs;t an&longs;wer, That of tho&longs;e which are
ea&longs;ily intelligible without ocular demon­
&longs;tration, we can at pre&longs;ent &longs;ugge&longs;t upon
our own tryals no better then the&longs;e.

Fir&longs;t,
at the open end of the Tube the Gla&longs;s
mu&longs;t not onely be made as even at the ed­
ges as you can, but it is very conveni­
ent (e&longs;pecially if the Tube be large) that
the bottom be every way bent inwards,
that &longs;o the Orifice, not much exceeding a
quarter of an Inch in Diameter, may be
the more ea&longs;ily and exactly &longs;topp'd by the
Experimenter's finger; between which
and the Quick-&longs;ilver, that there may be
no Air intercepted (as very often it hap­
pens that there is) it is requi&longs;ite that the
Tube be fill'd as full as po&longs;&longs;ibly it can be,
that the finger which is to &longs;top it, pre&longs;&longs;ing
upon the accumulated and protuberant
Mercury, may rather throw down &longs;ome,
then not finde enough exactly to keep out
the Air.

It is al&longs;o an u&longs;eful and compen­
dious way not to fill the Tube at fir&longs;t
quite ful of Mercury, but to leave near the
top about a qnarter of an Inch empty; for
if you then &longs;top the open end with your
finger, and invert the Tube that quarter
of an Inch of Air will a&longs;cend in a great
bubble to the top, and in its pa&longs;&longs;age thi-
ther, will gather up all the little bubbles,
and unite them with it&longs;elf into one great
one, &longs;o that if by reinverting the Tube
you let that bubble return to the open
end of it, you will have a much clo&longs;er Mer­
curial Cylinder then before, and need but
to adde a very little Quick-&longs;ilver more to
fill up the Tube exactly.

And la&longs;tly, as for
tho&longs;e le&longs;&longs;er and incon&longs;picuous parcels of
Air which cannot this way be gleaned up,
You may endeavor before you invert the
Tube, to free the Quick-&longs;ilver from them
by &longs;haking the Tube, and gently knock­
ing on the out-&longs;ide of it, after every little
parcel of Quick-&longs;ilver which you pour in;
and afterwards, by forcing the &longs;mall la­
titant bubbles of Air to di&longs;clo&longs;e them­
&longs;elves and break, by imploying a hot Iron
in &longs;uch manner as we lately mention'd.

I
remember that by carefully filling the
Tube, though yet it were not quite free
from Air, we have made the Mercurial
Cylinder reach to 30 Inches and above an
eighth, and this in a very &longs;hort Tube:
which we therefore mention, becau&longs;e we
have found, by experience, that in &longs;hort
Tubes a little Air is more prejudicial to
the Experiment then in long ones, where
the Air having more room to expand it
&longs;elf, does le&longs;s potently pre&longs;s upon the &longs;ub­
jacent Mercury.

And &longs;ince we are fallen upon the con&longs;i­
deration of the Altitude of the Mercurial
Cylinder, I mu&longs;t not conceal from Your
Lord&longs;hip an Experiment relating thereun­
to, which perhaps will &longs;et both You and
many of your Friends the Virtuo&longs;i a think­
ing; and, by di&longs;clo&longs;ing &longs;ome things a­
bout the Air or Atmo&longs;phere that have
&longs;carce hitherto been taken notice of, may
afford you &longs;ome hints conducive to a fur­
ther di&longs;covery of the &longs;ubject of this E­
pi&longs;tle.

WE took a Gla&longs;s Tube, which,
though it were not much above
three Foot long, we made choice of be­
cau&longs;e it was of a more then ordinarily
even thickne&longs;s.

This we fill'd with Mer­
cury, though not with as much care as we
could, yet with &longs;omewhat more then is
wont to be u&longs;ed in making the Torricellian
Experiment.

Then, having according to
the manner inverted the Tube, and open'd
the mouth of it beneath the &longs;urface of
&longs;ome other Quick-&longs;ilver, that in the Tube
fell down to the wonted heigth, leaving,
as is u&longs;ual, &longs;ome little Particles of Air in
the &longs;pace it de&longs;erted, as we ghe&longs;t by ob­
&longs;erving, that upon the Application of hot
Bodies to the upper part of the Tube, the
Quick-&longs;ilver would be a little depre&longs;&longs;'d.

La&longs;tly, having put both the Tube and the
Ve&longs;&longs;el it lean'd on into a convenient
Wooden Frame, to keep them from mi&longs;­
chances: we plac'd that Frame in a Win­
dow within my Bed-chamber, that I might
both keep the Mercury from being &longs;tirr'd,
and have opportunity to watch from time
to time the Phænomena it was to exhibit.

For the better di&longs;covery of which, when
the Quick-&longs;ilver both in the Tube and
&longs;ubjacent Ve&longs;&longs;el was perfectly at re&longs;t, we
took notice, by a mark made on the out­
&longs;ide of the Gla&longs;s, how high the included
Liquor then reach'd.

Experi­
ment 18.

During &longs;everal Weeks that the Tube
was kept in that Window (which was very
rarely open'd) I had the opportunity to
ob&longs;erve, that the Quick-&longs;ilver did &longs;ome­
times faintly imitate the Liquor of a
Weather-gla&longs;s, &longs;ub&longs;iding a little in warm,
and ri&longs;ing a little in cold Weather, which
we a&longs;cribed to the greater or le&longs;&longs;er pre&longs;&longs;ure
of that little Air that remain'd at the top
of the Tube, expanded or conden&longs;'d by
the heat or cold that affected the ambient
Air.

But that which I was chiefly careful
to ob&longs;erve, was this, That oftentimes the
Quick-&longs;ilver did ri&longs;e and fall in the Tube,
and that very notably, without conforming
it &longs;elf to what is u&longs;ual in Weather-gla&longs;&longs;es,
who&longs;e Air is at the top, nay quite contrary
thereunto: for &longs;ometimes I ob&longs;erv'd it in
very cold weather (&longs;uch as this Winter has
already afforded us good &longs;tore of) to fall
down much lower then at other times,
when by rea&longs;on of the ab&longs;ence of both
Fro&longs;t, Snow, and &longs;harp Winds, the Air was
comparatively much warmer.

And I fur­
ther ob&longs;erv'd, That &longs;ometimes the Quick­
&longs;ilver would for &longs;ome days together re&longs;t
almo&longs;t at the &longs;ame height; and at other
times again it would in the compa&longs;s of the
&longs;ame day con&longs;iderably vary its altitude,
though there appear'd no change either in
the Air abroad, or in the temper of the Air
within the Room (wherein was con&longs;tantly
kept a good Fire) nor in any thing el&longs;e, to
which either I, or &longs;ome eminently Learned
Men whom I then acquainted with the
Experiment, could rea&longs;onably impute
&longs;uch a change: E&longs;pecially con&longs;idering that
the &longs;pace wherein the Mercury wandred up
and down, within about five Weeks, a­
mounted to full two Inches, of which we
found by our &longs;everal marks whereby we
had taken notice of its &longs;everal removes, that
it had de&longs;cended about (9/16) of an Inch from the
place where it fir&longs;t &longs;etled, & the other Inch
and (7/16) it had a&longs;cended.

And it &longs;eems pro­
bable that the height of the Mercurial Cy­
linder would have varied yet more, if the
Experiment had been made in the open
Air and in a long Tube, where the Parti­
cles of the Impri&longs;on'd Air, by having
more room to di&longs;play them&longs;elves in,
might not have had &longs;o &longs;trong a Spring to
work upon the Quick-&longs;ilver with.

But for
want both of time and of a competent
quantity of Mercury (which was not to be
procur'd where we then happen'd to be)
we were unable to make any further try­
als: which therefore chiefly troubled us,
becau&longs;e we would gladly have try'd an in­
genious Experiment which was &longs;ugge&longs;ted
unto us by that excellent Mathematician
Mr. Wren, who being invited to name any
thing he would have us try touching the
pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air, de&longs;ired us to ob&longs;erve
whether or no the Quick-&longs;ilver in a long
Tube would not a little vary its height ac­
cording to the Tides, e&longs;pecially about the
New and Full Moon, about which times
Mariners ob&longs;erve tho&longs;e great Flowings
and Ebbs of the Sea, that they call the
Spring-Tides.

For he &longs;agaciou&longs;ly and
plau&longs;ibly conjectur'd that &longs;uch ob&longs;ervati­
ons accurately made, would di&longs;cover the
truth or erroneou&longs;ne&longs;s of the Carte&longs;ian
Hypothe&longs;is concerning the Ebbing and
Flowing of the Sea: which Des Cartes
a&longs;cribes to the greater pre&longs;&longs;ure made upon
the Air by the Moon, and the Intercur­
rent Ethereal Sub&longs;tance at certain times
(of the Day, and of the Lunary Moneth)
then at others.

But in regard we found
the Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube to move up
and down &longs;o uncertainly, by rea&longs;on, as it
&longs;eems, of accidental mutation in the Air;
I &longs;omewhat doubt whether we &longs;hall finde
the Altitude of the Quick-&longs;ilver to vary
as regularly as the Experiment is ingeni­
ou&longs;ly propo&longs;'d.

The &longs;ucce&longs;s we &longs;hall (God
permitting us to make tryal of it) acquaint
Your Lord&longs;hip with; and in the mean
time take notice, that when we had occa­
&longs;ion to take the Tube out of the Frame
(after it had &longs;taid there part of November
and part of December) a good Fire being
then in the room, becau&longs;e it was a Snowy
day, we found the Quick-&longs;ilver in the
Tube to be above the upper &longs;urface of
the &longs;ubjacent Mercury 29 Inches three
quarters.

If Your Lord&longs;hip &longs;hould now ask me
what are the true cau&longs;es of this varying al­
titude of the Mercurial Cylinder; I &longs;hould
not undertake to an&longs;wer &longs;o difficult a que­
&longs;tion, and &longs;hould venter to &longs;ay no more,
then that among divers po&longs;&longs;ible cau&longs;es to
which it may be a&longs;cribed, it would not be,
perhaps, ab&longs;urd to reckon the&longs;e that fol­
low.

Fir&longs;t then we may con&longs;ider, that the Air
in the upper part of the Tube is much
more rarified, and therefore more weak
then the external Air, as may appear by
this among other things, That upon the in­
clining of the Tube the Quick-&longs;ilver will
readily a&longs;cend almo&longs;t to the very top of
it, and &longs;o take up eight or nine tenth parts,
and perhaps more of that &longs;pace which it
de&longs;erted before: which would not happen
if that whole &longs;pace had been full of unra­
rified Air, &longs;ince that (as tryal may ea&longs;ily
&longs;atisfie you) would not have &longs;uffer'd it
&longs;elf to be thru&longs;t into &longs;o narrow a room by
&longs;o weak a pre&longs;&longs;ure.

So that although in
our Tube when the included Air was
heated, the Quick-&longs;ilver was &longs;omewhat
depre&longs;&longs;'d: Yet there is this difference be­
twixt &longs;uch a Tube and common Weather­
Gla&longs;&longs;es, that in the&longs;e the included and the
ambient Air are in an Æquilibrium as to
pre&longs;&longs;ure, and the weight of the Water
that keeps them &longs;eparate is &longs;carce con&longs;i­
derable.

Whereas in &longs;uch a Tube as we
are &longs;peaking of, the Air within is very
much more dilated then that without; and
'tis not &longs;o much the &longs;pring or re&longs;i&longs;tance
of the included Air, as the weight of the
Mercurial Cylinder it &longs;elf that hinders the
Quick-&longs;ilver from a&longs;cending higher; for
if we &longs;hould &longs;uppo&longs;e that de&longs;erted part of
the Tube perfectly devoid of Air, yet
would the Quick-&longs;ilver ri&longs;e but a little
higher in it, and be far from filling it, in
regard the outward Air would not be
able to impel up &longs;uch a weight much
higher: whereas it may, by our former
Experiments appear, that if all the Air in
the upper part of a Weather-Gla&longs;s were
away, the Water would be impell'd up to
the very top of it, though the Pipe were
above thirty Foot long.

We may next con&longs;ider, that this ra­
rified Air at the upper part of our Tube
being exactly &longs;hut up betwixt the Gla&longs;s
and the Quick-&longs;ilver, it was &longs;carce &longs;ubject
to any di&longs;cernable alterations, &longs;ave tho&longs;e
it receiv'd from heat and cold.

And we may further con&longs;ider that yet
the external Air or Atmo&longs;phere is &longs;ubject
to many alterations, be&longs;ides them that
proceed from either of tho&longs;e Quali­
ties.

For the Experiment that occa&longs;ion'd
this Di&longs;cour&longs;e, &longs;eems to make it proba­
ble enough that there may be &longs;trange
Ebbings and Flowings, as it were, in the
Atmo&longs;phere; or at lea&longs;t, that it may ad­
mit great and &longs;udden Mutations, either as
to its Altitude or its Den&longs;ity, from cau&longs;es,
as well unknown to us, as the effects are
unheeded by us.

And that You may not
think that there is nothing in Nature but
our Experiment that agrees with this our
conjecture, we might put Your Lord&longs;hip
in minde of the Pains and Aches that are
often complain'd of by tho&longs;e that have
had great Wounds or Brui&longs;es, and that
doe pre&longs;age great Mutations in the Air
oftentimes, whil&longs;t to &longs;trong and healthy
Per&longs;ons no &longs;ign of any &longs;uch thing appears.

And that is al&longs;o very memorable to this
purpo&longs;e, which I remember I have &longs;ome­
where read in a Book of the Ingenious
Kircherus, who giving a pertinent admoni­
tion concerning the various refractions
that may happen in the Air, relates, That
during his &longs;tay in Malta, he often &longs;aw
Mount Ætna, though the next day, not­
with&longs;tanding its being extreamly clear, he
could not &longs;ee it; adding, that Vintemillius,
a very Learned Per&longs;on, did oftentimes,
from a Hill he names, behold the whole
I&longs;land he calls Luprica protuberant above
the Sea, though at other times, notwith­
&longs;tanding a clear Sky, he could not &longs;ee it.

And though perhaps this may be in part a­
&longs;cribed to the various light & po&longs;ition of
the &longs;un, or to the various di&longs;po&longs;ition of the
Spectators eye, or peradventure to &longs;ome
other cau&longs;e; yet the mo&longs;t probable cau&longs;e
&longs;eems to be the differing Den&longs;ity of the
Air, occa&longs;ion'd by Exhalations capable to
increa&longs;e the refraction, and con&longs;equently
bring Beams to the Eye, which otherwi&longs;e
would not fall on it.

We have likewi&longs;e
in another Treati&longs;e mention'd our having
often ob&longs;erv'd with Tele&longs;copes a plenty
of Steams in the Air, which without &longs;uch
a help would not be taken notice of, and
which as they were not at all times to be
&longs;een even through a Tele&longs;cope, &longs;o they
did &longs;ometimes, e&longs;pecially after a &longs;hower of
Rain, ha&longs;tily di&longs;appear: and when we
have vi&longs;ited tho&longs;e places that abound with
Mines, we have &longs;everal times been told
by the Diggers, that even when the Sky
&longs;eem'd clear, there would not &longs;eldom &longs;ud­
denly ari&longs;e, and &longs;ometimes long continue,
a certain Steam (which they u&longs;ually call a
damp) &longs;o gro&longs;s and thick, that it would
oftentimes put out their very Candles, if
they did not &longs;ea&longs;onably prevent it.

And
I think it will ea&longs;ily be granted, that the
a&longs;cen&longs;ion of &longs;uch Steams into this or that
part of the Air, and their mixing with it,
are very like to thicken it; as on the o­
ther &longs;ide either heat or the &longs;udden conden­
&longs;ation of the Air in another part of the At­
mo&longs;phere (to mention now no other cau­
&longs;es) are capable of rarifying it.

Nor will it very much import the main
&longs;cope of our Di&longs;cour&longs;e, whether it be
&longs;uppo&longs;'d that the copious Steams the
earth &longs;ends into the air, thicken that part
of the Atmo&longs;phere that receives them,
and make it more heavy: Or that &longs;ome­
times the Fumes may a&longs;cend with &longs;uch ce­
lerity, that though the Air be thicken'd
yet they rather dimini&longs;h then encrea&longs;e its
gravitation, in regard that the quickne&longs;s
of their a&longs;cent, not onely keeps them
from gravitating them&longs;elves, but may
hinder the pre&longs;&longs;ing downwards of many
Aërial Corpu&longs;cles that they meet with in
their way upwards.

This, I &longs;ay, is of
no great importance to our pre&longs;ent Di&longs;­
cour&longs;e, &longs;ince either way the Terre&longs;trial
Steam may here and there con&longs;iderably
alter the gravity or pre&longs;&longs;ure of the At­
mo&longs;phere.

Your Lord&longs;hip may al&longs;o be plea&longs;ed to
remember, That by our &longs;eventeenth Ex­
periment it appear'd that as when the Air
in the Receiver was expanded more then
ordinarily, the Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube
did proportionably &longs;ub&longs;ide; &longs;o when the
Air in the &longs;ame Receiver was a little more
then ordinarily compre&longs;&longs;'d, it did impell
up the Quick-&longs;ilver in the Tube above
the wonted height of betwixt &longs;ix and &longs;e­
ven and twenty digits.

And if to the&longs;e things we annex, that
for ought we can finde by tryals purpo&longs;e­
ly made, the degree of rarity or den&longs;ity
of the Air, &longs;hut up into our Receiver, does
not &longs;en&longs;ibly alter its temperature as to
cold or heat.

It will not, I hope, appear
ab&longs;urd to conceive, That &longs;ince the Air,
included in the Tube, could but very faint­
ly hinder the a&longs;cent of the Quick-&longs;ilver,
or pre&longs;s it downwards, &longs;ince too that inclu­
ded Air could &longs;carce immediately receive
any &longs;en&longs;ible alteration, &longs;ave either by heat
or cold.

And &longs;ince al&longs;o that according to
the bare den&longs;ity or rarity of the Air in­
cumbent on the &longs;ubjacent Quick-&longs;ilver in
the Ve&longs;&longs;el, that in the Tube was impell'd
more or le&longs;s high; &longs;uch changes happen­
ing in the neighboring part of the out­
ward Air, either by the a&longs;cen&longs;ion of gro&longs;s
or copious exhalations, or by any other
cau&longs;e (of which there may be divers) as
were capable to make con&longs;iderable altera­
tions in the con&longs;i&longs;tence of the Air, as to
rarity and den&longs;ity, may be able propor­
tionably to alter the heighth of the
Quick-&longs;ilver: I rather &longs;ay, that &longs;uch alte­
rations may be, then that they are the
cau&longs;es of our Phænomenon, becau&longs;e I think
it &longs;ufficient, if I have propo&longs;'d conje­
ctures not altogether irrational about a
new My&longs;tery of Nature, touching which,
the chief thing I pretend to, is to give oc­
ca&longs;ion to the Curious to inquire further
into it then I have been yet able to do.

THe &longs;ame Rea&longs;on that mov'd us to
conclude, that by the drawing of the
Air out of the Receiver, the Mercury
would de&longs;cend in a Tube &longs;horter then &longs;ix
and twenty digits, induc'd us al&longs;o to ex-
pect, that by the &longs;ame means Water
might be brought to &longs;ub&longs;ide in Gla&longs;s
Tubes of a moderate length, though by
the noble Experiment, &longs;aid to have been
accurately made in France by Mon&longs;ieur
Pa&longs;chal, we are informed that a Tube of
no le&longs;s then about two and thirty Foot,
was found requi&longs;ite to make the Experi­
ment De Vacuo &longs;ucceed with Water in­
&longs;tead of Quick-&longs;ilver: &longs;o tall a Cylinder
of that lighter Liquor, being, it &longs;eems,
requi&longs;ite to equal the weight of a Mercu­
rial Cylinder of &longs;ix or &longs;even and twenty
digits, and &longs;urmount the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the
Atmo&longs;phere.

Experi­
ment 19.

We took then a Tube of Gla&longs;s, Her­
metically &longs;eal'd at one end, of about four
foot in length, and not very &longs;lender: This
at the open end we fill'd with common
Water, and then &longs;topt that end till we
had inverted the Tube, and open'd it be­
neath the &longs;urface of a quantity of the like
Water, contain'd in a &longs;omewhat deep and
&longs;lender Ve&longs;&longs;el.

This Ve&longs;&longs;el, with the
Tube in it, was let down into the Recei­
ver, and the Receiver being clo&longs;'d up af­
ter the accu&longs;tom'd manner, the Pump was
&longs;et awork.

As much of the event as concerns our
pre&longs;ent purpo&longs;e, was this, That till a con­
&longs;iderable part of the Air was drawn out
of the Receiver, the Tube continu'd top­
full of Water as when it was put in, it be­
ing requi&longs;ite that a great part of the Air
formerly contain'd in the Receiver, &longs;hould
be drawn out, to bring the remaining
Air to an Æquilibrium with &longs;o &longs;hort and
light a Cylinder of Water.

But when
once the Water began to fall in the Tube,
then each ex&longs;uction of Air made it de­
&longs;cend a little lower, though nothing near
&longs;o much as the Quick-&longs;ilver at the begin­
ning did in the Experiment formerly men­
tion'd.

Nor did there appear &longs;o much
inequality in the &longs;paces tran&longs;mitted by
the Water in its de&longs;cent, as there did in
tho&longs;e ob&longs;erv'd in the fall of the Quick­
&longs;ilver, of which the cau&longs;e will &longs;carce &longs;eem
ab&longs;tru&longs;e to him that &longs;hall duly reflect up­
on what has been already deliver'd.

And
whereas we drew down the Quick-&longs;ilver
in the Tube &longs;o far as to bring it within an
Inch of the &longs;urface of the other Quick­
&longs;ilver into which it was to fall; the lowe&longs;t
we were able to draw down the Water
was, by our conjecture, to about a Foot
or more above the &longs;urface of that in the
Ve&longs;&longs;el; of which I know not whether it
will be needful to a&longs;&longs;ign &longs;o obvious a cau&longs;e
as that, though the little Air remaining
in the Receiver could not hinder a Cylin­
der of above an Inch high of Quick-&longs;ilver
from &longs;ub&longs;iding; yet it might very well
be able, by its pre&longs;&longs;ure, to countervail the
weight of a Cylinder of a Foot long or
more, of a Liquor &longs;o much le&longs;s ponderous
then Quick-&longs;ilver, as Water is.

And in
fine, to conclude our Experiment, when
the Water was drawn down thus low, we
found, that by letting in the outward Air,
it might be immediately impell'd up a­
gain to the higher parts of the Tube.

We will adde no more concerning this
Experiment, &longs;ave that having try'd it in
one of our &longs;mall Receivers, we ob&longs;erv'd,
That upon the fir&longs;t ex&longs;uction of the Air
the Water did u&longs;ually &longs;ub&longs;ide divers In­
ches, and at the &longs;econd (ex&longs;uction) fall
down much lower, &longs;ub&longs;iding &longs;ometimes
near two Foot; as al&longs;o that upon the let­
ting in of the Air from without, the Wa­
ter was impell'd up with very great ce­
lerity.

THat the Air has a notable Ela&longs;tical
power (whence&longs;oever that proceeds)
we have, I &longs;uppo&longs;e, abundantly evinc'd,
and it begins to be acknowledg'd by the
eminente&longs;t Modern Naturali&longs;ts.

But whe­
ther or no there be in Water &longs;o much as
a languid one, &longs;eems hitherto to have been
&longs;carce con&longs;ider'd, nor has been yet, for
ought I know, determin'd either way by
any Writer, which invited us to make the
following Experiment.

Experi­
ment 20.

There was taken a great Gla&longs;s-bubble,
with a long neck; (&longs;uch as Chymi&longs;ts are
wont to call a Philo&longs;ophical Egg) which
being fill'd with common Water till the
Liquor reach'd about a &longs;pan above the
bubble, and a piece of Paper being there
pa&longs;ted on, was put un&longs;top'd into the Re­
ceiver, and then the Air was &longs;uck'd out
after the wonted manner.

The event was
this, That a con&longs;iderable part of the Air,
pent up in the Receiver, was drawn out
before we di&longs;cern'd any expan&longs;ion of the
Water; but, continuing the labor of
pumping, the Water manife&longs;tly began to
a&longs;cend in the &longs;tem of the Gla&longs;s, and di­
vers bubbles loo&longs;ening them&longs;elves from
the lower parts of the Ve&longs;&longs;el, made their
way through the Body of the Water, to
the top of it, and there brake into the
Receiver: And after the Water once ap­
pear'd to &longs;well, then at each time the Stop­
cock was turn'd to let out the air from the
Receiver into the Pump, the Water in the
Neck of the Gla&longs;s did &longs;uddenly ri&longs;e a­
bout the breadth of a Barly-corn in the
Neck of the Gla&longs;s, and &longs;o attain'd, by
degrees, to a con&longs;iderable height above
the mark formerly mention'd.

And at
length (to make the expan&longs;ion of the Wa­
ter more evident) the outward Air was
&longs;uddenly let in, and the Water immedi­
ately &longs;ub&longs;ided and de&longs;erted all the &longs;pace it
had newly gain'd in the Gla&longs;s.

And, on this occa&longs;ion, it will not per­
haps be ami&longs;s to acquaint Your Lord&longs;hip
here (though we have already mention'd
it in another Paper, to another purpo&longs;e)
with another Expedient that we made u&longs;e
of two or three years ago, to try whether
or no Water had a Spring in it.

About
that time then, That Great and Learned
Promoter of Experimental Philo&longs;ophy
Dr. Wilkins, doing me the Honor to
come him&longs;elf, and bring &longs;ome of his in­
qui&longs;itive Friends to my Lodging, we
there had in readine&longs;s a round and hollow
Ve&longs;&longs;el of Pewter, great enough to con­
tain two pounds of Water, and exactly
clo&longs;e every where, but at one little hole
where it was to be fill'd; then partly by
&longs;ucking out the Air, and partly by inject­
ing Water with a Syringe, it was (not
without &longs;ome difficulty) fill'd up to the
top; and that hole being plac'd directly
upwards, there was a little more Water
lei&longs;urely forc'd in by the Syringe.

Upon
which, though the Ve&longs;&longs;el were permitted
to re&longs;t, and the hole kept in its former po­
&longs;ture, yet the compre&longs;&longs;'d Water lei&longs;urely
&longs;well'd above the Orifice of the hole, and
divers drops ran over along the &longs;ides of the
Ve&longs;&longs;el.

After this, we cau&longs;'d a skilful Pew­
terer (who had made the Globe) to clo&longs;e
it up in our pre&longs;ence with Soder &longs;o exqui­
&longs;itely, that none &longs;u&longs;pected there was any
thing left in it be&longs;ides Water.

And la&longs;t­
ly, the Ve&longs;&longs;el thus &longs;oder'd up, was wari­
ly and often &longs;truck in divers places with a
Wooden Mallet, and thereby was mani­
fe&longs;tly compre&longs;&longs; d, whereby the inclo&longs;ed
Water was crouded into le&longs;s room then it
had before: And thereupon when we took
a Needle, and with it and the Mallet per­
forated the Ve&longs;&longs;el, and drew out the
Needle again; the Water (but in a very
&longs;lender Stream) was &longs;uddenly thrown af­
ter it into the Air, to the height of two
or three Feet.

As for the other Phænome­
na of this Experiment, &longs;ince they belong
not to our pre&longs;ent purpo&longs;e, and are partly
mention'd in another of our Papers, we
&longs;hall, in&longs;tead of recording them here, give
this Adverti&longs;ement: That as evidently
as this Experiment, and that made in our
Receiver, &longs;eem to prove a power in the
Water to expand and re&longs;tore it &longs;elf after
compre&longs;&longs;ion; yet for a rea&longs;on to be met
with ere long, I judged it not &longs;afe to in­
fer that Conclu&longs;ion from the&longs;e Premi&longs;es,
till I had made &longs;ome of the following try­
als, to the mention of which I will there­
fore ha&longs;ten.

TO di&longs;cover whether the Expan&longs;ion
of the Water really proceeded
from an Ela&longs;tical power in the parts of
the Water it &longs;elf, we thought it requi&longs;ite
to try two things: The one, Whether or no
the Atmo&longs;phere gravitates upon Bodies
under Water; and the other, Whether
in ca&longs;e it do gravitate, the Intume&longs;cence
of the Water may not be a&longs;cribed to &longs;ome
&longs;ub&longs;tance &longs;ubtler then it &longs;elf, re&longs;iding m­
it.

In order to the &longs;atisfying my &longs;elf about
the fir&longs;t of the&longs;e, I intended to let down
into the Receiver a Ve&longs;&longs;el of Water,
wherein &longs;hould be immer&longs;'d a very &longs;mall
oyl'd Bladder, almo&longs;t devoid of Air, but
&longs;trongly ty'd up at the Neck with a &longs;tring,
and detain'd a little under Water by &longs;uch
a weight fa&longs;ten'd to that &longs;tring, as &longs;hould
ju&longs;t be able to keep the Bladder from
&longs;wimming, and no more.

For I &longs;uppo&longs;'d,
that if when all things were thus order'd,
the Receiver were empty'd, in ca&longs;e there
were any &longs;uch pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Atmo&longs;phere
upon Water, as I was inclin'd to believe,
the Air within the Bladder, being upon the
ex&longs;uction of the Air within the Receiver,
freed from that pre&longs;&longs;ure, and being pre&longs;&longs;'d
onely by the &longs;mall weight of the in­
cumbent Water, would con&longs;iderably ex­
pand it &longs;elf; but whil'&longs;t we were prepa­
ring Bladders for this Experiment, there
occurr'd an ea&longs;ie way for the making at
once both the Di&longs;coveries I de&longs;ir'd.

Experi­
ment 21.

We took then a Gla&longs;s Viol, containing
by ghe&longs;s a pound and &longs;ome ounces of
Water, this we fill'd top full, and then
we put into the Neck of it a Gla&longs;s Pipe
a pretty deal bigger then a Goo&longs;e Quill,
open at both ends, and of divers Inches
in length: One end of this Pipe was &longs;o
put into the Neck of the Viol, as to reach
a little below it, and then was carefully
cemented thereto that no Air might get
into the Viol, nor no Water get out of
it, otherwi&longs;e then through the Pipe; and
then the Pipe being warily fill'd, about
half way up to the top, with more Wa­
ter, and a mark being pa&longs;ted over again&longs;t
the upper &longs;urface of the Liquor; the Viol
thus fitted with the Pipe, was, by &longs;trings
let down into the Receiver, and according
to the wonted manner exqui&longs;itely clo&longs;'d
up in it.

This done, we began to Pump out the
Air, and when a pretty quantity of it had
been drawn away, the Water in the Pipe
began to ri&longs;e higher in the Pipe, at the
&longs;ides of which &longs;ome little bubbles di&longs;co­
ver'd them&longs;elves.

After a little while
longer, the Water &longs;till &longs;welling, there
appear'd at the bottom of the Pipe a bub­
ble about the bigne&longs;s of a &longs;mall Pea,
which a&longs;cending through the Pipe to the
top of the Water, &longs;taid there awhile and
then broke; but the Pump being nimbly
ply'd, the expan&longs;ion of the Water &longs;o en­
crea&longs;'d, that quickly, getting up to the
top of the Pipe &longs;ome drops of it be­
gan to run down along the out-&longs;ide of it,
which oblig'd us to forbear pumping a­
while, and give the Water leave to &longs;ub­
&longs;ide within le&longs;s then two Inches of the
bottom of the Pipe.

After this the
Pump being again &longs;et at work, the bub­
bles began to a&longs;cend from the bottom
of the Pipe, being not all of a &longs;ize, but yet
&longs;o big, that e&longs;timating one with another,
they appear'd to be of the &longs;ize of the &longs;mal­
ler &longs;ort of Peas; and of the&longs;e we reckon'd
about &longs;ixty which came up one after ano­
ther, be&longs;ides &longs;tore of &longs;maller ones, of which
we made no reckoning: And at length,
growing weary of reckoning and pumping
too (becau&longs;e we found, that in &longs;pight
of all our pains and indu&longs;try, &longs;ome un­
di&longs;cern'd Leak or other in the Recei­
ver hinder'd us from being able to empty
it altogether) we thought fit to de&longs;i&longs;t for
that time.

After tryal made of what o­
peration the external Air, being let in
upon the expanded Water, would have;
and accordingly turning the Key to let in
the Air, we &longs;aw, as we expected, that
the Water in the Pipe in a moment fell
down almo&longs;t to the bottom of it.

Now of this Experiment there are two
or three Circum&longs;tances yet to be men­
tion'd, which are no le&longs;s then tho&longs;e alrea­
dy recited, pertinent to our pre&longs;ent pur­
po&longs;e.

In the fir&longs;t place then, when the great­
er part of the Air had been pump'd out of
the Receiver, the ri&longs;ing bubbles a&longs;cend­
ed &longs;o very &longs;lowly in the Pipe, that their
Progre&longs;s was &longs;carce di&longs;cernable; which
&longs;eem'd to proceed from this, That their
bigne&longs;s was &longs;uch, That they could not
&longs;ufficiently extend them&longs;elves in the
cavity of the Gla&longs;s, without pre&longs;&longs;ing
on both hands again&longs;t the &longs;ides of it,
whereby they became of more difficult
extru&longs;ion to the Water.

And though it
may &longs;eem &longs;trange the&longs;e bubbles &longs;hould
be of any con&longs;iderable bulk, &longs;ince 'tis
like they con&longs;i&longs;ted of le&longs;&longs;er parcels of
the Air lurking in the Water, then tho&longs;e
that were vigorous enough to make their
way through long before them: yet they
were commonly much larger then before,
&longs;ome of them being equal in quantity to
four or five Peas: Whether this their in­
crea&longs;e of bulk proceeded from the greater
decrement of the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air,
or from the Union of two or three of
tho&longs;e numerous bubbles which were then
generated below the bottom of the Pipe,
where we could not &longs;ee what was done a­
mong them.

Another thing we noted in our bubbles
was, That whereas in ordinary ones the
Air, together with the thin film of Water
that inve&longs;ts and detains, is wont to &longs;well
above the &longs;urface of the Water it &longs;wims
on, and commonly to con&longs;titute Hemi&longs;­
pherical Bodies with it, the little parcels
of Air that came up after the Receiver
was pretty well empty'd, did not make
protuberant bubbles, but &longs;uch who&longs;e up­
per &longs;urface was either level with or be­
neath that of the Water, &longs;o that the up­
per &longs;urface being u&longs;ually &longs;omewhat con­
vex, the le&longs;s protuberant parts of it had
a pretty quantity of Water remaining a­
bove them.

We al&longs;o further ob&longs;erv'd, That where­
as in the bubbles that fir&longs;t appear'd in
the Pipe, the a&longs;cending Air did, as in o­
ther common bubbles, make its way up­
wards, by dividing the Water through
which it pa&longs;&longs;'d, in tho&longs;e bubbles that ap­
pear'd at the latter end of our Experi­
ment, when the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the little ex-
ternal Air, remaining in the Receiver,
was grown incon&longs;iderable, the a&longs;cending
parcels of Air having now little more
then the weight of the incumbent Water
to &longs;urmount, were able both &longs;o to expand
them&longs;elves as to fill up that part of the
Pipe which they pervaded, & by pre&longs;&longs;ing
every way again&longs;t the &longs;ides of it, to lift
upwards with them what Water they
found above them, without letting any
con&longs;iderable quantity glide down along
the &longs;ides of the Gla&longs;s: So that &longs;ometimes
we could &longs;ee a bubble thru&longs;t on before it
a whole Cylinder of Water of perhaps
an Inch high, and carry it up to the top
of the Pipe; though as we formerly no­
ted, upon the letting in the external Air,
the&longs;e tumid bubbles &longs;uddenly relap&longs;'d to
their former incon&longs;picuou&longs;ne&longs;s.

All the&longs;e things laid together &longs;eem'd
&longs;ufficiently to confirm that, which the
con&longs;ideration of the thing it &longs;elf would
ea&longs;ily enough per&longs;wade, namely, That
the Air, and &longs;uch like Bodies being under
Water, may be pre&longs;&longs;'d upon as well by
the Atmo&longs;phere, as by the weight of the
incumbent Water it &longs;elf.

Hence likewi&longs;e we may verifie what we
ob&longs;erv'd at the clo&longs;e of the foregoing
Experiment, namely, That from the &longs;ole
&longs;welling of Water there recorded, it can­
not be &longs;o &longs;afely concluded that Water,
when freed from compre&longs;&longs;ion, is endowd
with an Ela&longs;tical power of expanding it
&longs;elf, &longs;ince thereby it appears that the In­
tume&longs;cence produc'd by that Experiment,
may (at lea&longs;t in great part) be a&longs;crib'd to
the numerous little bubbles which are
wont to be produc'd in Water, from
which the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Atmo&longs;phere is
in great mea&longs;ure taken off.

So apt are we
to be mi&longs;-led, even by Experiments them­
&longs;elves, into Mi&longs;takes, when either we con­
&longs;ider not that mo&longs;t Effects may proceed
from various Cau&longs;es, or minde onely tho&longs;e
Circum&longs;tances of our Experiment, which
&longs;eem to comply with our preconceiv'd
Hypothe&longs;is or Conjectures.

And hence it &longs;eems al&longs;o probable, that
in the Pores or invi&longs;ible little rece&longs;&longs;es of
Water it &longs;elf there lie commonly inter­
&longs;per&longs;'d many parcels of either Air, or at
lea&longs;t &longs;omething Analogous thereunto, al­
though &longs;o very &longs;mall that they have not
been hitherto &longs;o much as &longs;u&longs;pected to
lurk there.

But if it be demanded how it
appears that there is inter&longs;per&longs;'d through
the Body of Water any &longs;ub&longs;tance thinner
then it &longs;elf, and why that which produc'd
the bubbles above mention'd &longs;hould not
be re&longs;olutely &longs;aid to be nothing el&longs;e then
a more active and &longs;pirituous part of the

was formerly deliver'd the following Ex­
periment.

WE recited in our nineteenth Ex­
periment, how by drawing mo&longs;t
of the Air out of the Receiver, we made
the Water &longs;ub&longs;ide by degrees in a Gla&longs;s
not four Foot long: We &longs;hall now adde,
that in the like Experiment made in &longs;uch
a Tube, or a greater, it may be ob&longs;erv'd,
That when the Water begins to fall, there
will appear &longs;tore of bubbles fa&longs;ten'd all a­
long to the &longs;ides of the Gla&longs;s; of which
bubbles, by the agitation of the Ve&longs;&longs;el
con&longs;equent upon pumping, there will ari&longs;e
good numbers to the top of the Water,
and there break; and as the Cylinder of
Water is brought to be lower and lower,
&longs;o the bubbles will appear more numerous
in that part of the Tube which the Water
yet fills; and the nearer the &longs;urface of the

bubbles, the greater they will grow, be­

upon them, the Expan&longs;ion of that Air

by the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the incumbent Water

that upon the letting in a little external

It may indeed, as we lately intimated,

&longs;tent in the Water, and lurking in the

&longs;ion allow'd them upon the dimini&longs;h'd

And indeed, I am not
yet &longs;o well &longs;atisfied that bubbles may not

&longs;topt in its a&longs;cent near an Inch beneath

And &longs;ince, if the upper part of

then &longs;uch Ethereal matter as was &longs;ubtle

which, being collected into one place and
hinder'd by the top of the Gla&longs;s from re­

of the outward Air.

As we &longs;ee that if
never &longs;o little Air remain in the Tube up­
on the making the Experiment De Vacuo
with Quick-&longs;ilver, no inclining of the

But in order to a further Di&longs;covery what

&longs;ion, inform Your Lord&longs;hip that we try'd

was not thereby impell'd to the top of the

tle more then half an Inch.

And whe­
ther or no it were Air that po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;'d that
&longs;pace at the top of the Tube which was
not fill'd with Water, we took this cour&longs;e
to examine.

We drew the &longs;econd time
the Air out of the Receiver, and found,
that by rea&longs;on of the body that po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;'d
the top of the Tube, we were able not

&longs;on of its own weight, argued that the Wa­

And
this further tryal (to adde that upon
the by) we made at the &longs;ame time, That
when the Water in the Pipe was drawn

from pumping) by the bare application

ed part of the Tube, the remaining Wa­

pre&longs;&longs;'d.

And having for a while held a
kindled Coal to the out&longs;ide of the Tube,

divers Inches beneath the &longs;urface of the

Whereby it appears (by
the &longs;ame way by which we formerly mea­
&longs;ur'd the dilatation of the Air) that the
Air, even when it is expanded to between
90 and 100 times, its extent will yet rea­
dily admit of a much further rarifaction
by heat.

I con&longs;ider'd al&longs;o that in ca&longs;e the Bub­

duc'd by the parcels of Air latitant in the
Water, that Air being now got together
to the top of the Tube, though the Air
were again drawn out of the Receiver,

clo&longs;e bubbles as before; and accordingly,
the Air being again pump'd out, the Wa­
ter in the Tube de&longs;cended as formerly:
but for a great while we &longs;carce &longs;aw one
bubble appear, onely when the Receiver
had been very much exhau&longs;ted, and the

near the bottom of the Tube, certain
little bubbles, which &longs;eem'd to con&longs;i&longs;t of
&longs;uch parcels of Air as had not, by rea&longs;on
of their &longs;malne&longs;s, got up to the top of
the Water, with the more bulkie and vi­
gorous ones.

And that which is not in­
con&longs;iderable, is, That having, by letting
in the Air, forc'd up the Water into the
Tube, we could not perceive that it a&longs;­
cended nearer the top, though we per­
mitted the Engine to remain unimploy'd
for two or three Nights together, and
watch'd whether the Water would &longs;well
up and fill the Tube.

And on this occa­
&longs;ion I remember, that having try'd &longs;uch an
Experiment as this with Quick-&longs;ilver in­
&longs;tead of Water, in a Tube of about a Foot
and a half long, wherein it might &longs;eem
more hopeful to e&longs;cape bubbles; yet up­
on the drawing down the Quick-&longs;ilver as
low as we could, and letting in the exter­
nal Air upon it, we found that &longs;ome lurk­
ing particles of Air were got up to the top
of the Tube, and hinder'd the Quick­
&longs;ilver from being forc'd up again &longs;o high.
And though the Quick-&longs;ilver were by
this means brought to appear a very clo&longs;e
and lovely Metalline Cylinder, not inter­
rupted by inter&longs;per&longs;'d bubbles as before;
yet having cau&longs;'d the Air to be again
drawn out of the Receiver, I could per­
ceive &longs;everal little bubbles to di&longs;clo&longs;e
them&longs;elves, fa&longs;ten'd to the in&longs;ide of the
Tube, near the bottom of it; and having
purpo&longs;ely watch'd one or two of the chief­
e&longs;t, I had the plea&longs;ure to ob&longs;erve, that
though they grew bigger and bigger as
the &longs;urface of the Mercurial Cylinder fell
nearer and nearer to them, &longs;o as that at
length they &longs;well'd into a con&longs;picuous
bulk; yet upon the wary letting in the
Air upon them, they did not break, but
pre&longs;ently &longs;hrunk up into a littlene&longs;s that
render'd them incon&longs;picuous.

Whence it &longs;eems very probable, if not
certain, that even in the clo&longs;e&longs;t and mo&longs;t
ponderous Liquors, and therefore much
more in Water, there may lurk undi&longs;cern­
able parcels of Air, capable, upon the
removal of the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the ambient

Liquor wherein it lurks, to produce con­
&longs;picuous bubbles.

And con&longs;equently, if
it &longs;eem inconvenient to admit an Ela&longs;tical

the &longs;welling of the compre&longs;&longs;'d Water in

the &longs;pringing up of the Water at the hole
made by the Needle, were not the effects
of any internal Elater of the Water, but

of Air di&longs;per&longs;'d through that Water, and
acting upon it in their &longs;udden recovering
them&longs;elves to a greater extent, then that
to which a violent compre&longs;&longs;ion had re­
duc'd them.

But though, from all the&longs;e particulars,
it &longs;eems manife&longs;t that the bubbles we have
been all this while treating of, were pro­
duc'd by &longs;uch a &longs;ub&longs;tance as may be pro­
perly enough call'd Air; yet till we &longs;hall
have had the opportunity of making
&longs;ome further tryals concerning the nature
of the Air, we &longs;hall not re&longs;olutely deter­
mine whether or no Air be a Primogenial
Body (if I may &longs;o &longs;peak) that cannot
now be generated or turn'd either into
Water or any other Body.

Yet in the
mean while (becau&longs;e it is an important
Que&longs;tion, and if rightly determin'd, may
much conduce to the knowledge of the
nature of the Air) We think it not unfit
to make a brief mention of &longs;ome of the
particulars which at pre&longs;ent occur to our
thoughts in favor of either part of the
Que&longs;tion.

Fir&longs;t then, divers Naturali&longs;ts e&longs;teem the
Air (as well as other Elements) to be in­
generable and incorruptible.

And rea&longs;ons
plau&longs;ible enough may be drawn to coun­
tenance this Opinion from the con&longs;idera­
tion of that permanency that ought to
belong to the corporeal Principles of o­
ther Bodies.

Next, Experience may be pleaded to
the &longs;ame purpo&longs;e, for I have read of &longs;ome
who have in vain attempted to turn Air
into Water, or VVater into Air.

The diligent Schottus tells us, That a­
mong&longs;t the other rarities to be met with
in that great Repo&longs;itory of them, the
Mu&longs;æum Kercherianum, there is a round
Gla&longs;s with a tapering Neck near half full
(as one may gue&longs;s by the Scheme he an­
nexes) of ordinary Spring-water, which
having been Hermetically &longs;hut up there
by Clavius the famous Geometrician,
The included water is to this day pre­
&longs;erv'd, not onely clear and pure, as if
it were but newly put in: But (as it &longs;eems)
without (in the lea&longs;t) turning into Air,
notwith&longs;tanding its having been kept

That the Water hath continued there all

Nor does it appear in tho&longs;e Gla&longs;&longs;es,
which for Chymical Experiments we u&longs;u­
ally clo&longs;e with Hermes his Seal (as they
call it) that the included Air does, during
its long Impri&longs;onment, notwith&longs;tanding

Whereas we plainly perceive in our Dige­
&longs;tions and Di&longs;tillations, that though it
may be rarified into invi&longs;ible Vapors, yet
it is not really chang'd into Air, but onely

minute parts, which meeting together in

&longs;ently return into &longs;uch Water as they con­
&longs;tituted before.

And we al&longs;o &longs;ee, that
ev'n Spirit of Wine, and other &longs;ubtle and

to the Air, and mingle with it, do yet in

the di&longs;gui&longs;e of Air, and re&longs;ume the deve­
&longs;ted form of Liquors.

And &longs;o volatile
Salts, as of Urine, Harts-horn, &c. though
they will readily di&longs;per&longs;e them&longs;elves
through the Air, and play up and down in
the capacity of an Alembick or a Recei­

them&longs;elves to the in&longs;ides of &longs;uch Gla&longs;&longs;es
in the form of Salts.

Be&longs;ides, &longs;ince Air is confe&longs;&longs;edly en­
dow'd with an Ela&longs;tical power that proba­
bly proceeds from its Texture, it appears
not what it is that in &longs;uch light alterations

pable of turning it into Air, can be rea­
&longs;onably &longs;uppo&longs;'d &longs;o to contrive the Parti­

permanently, the &longs;tructure requi&longs;ite to a
Spring.

I adde the word, Permanently,
becau&longs;e the newly mention'd ob&longs;ervations
&longs;eem to argue the Corpu&longs;cles of Air to
be irreducible into Water, whereas the
Aqueous Particles may perhaps for a

Air.

La&longs;tly, The Experiment formerly made

&longs;eems to evince, that even tho&longs;e light and
&longs;ubtle Fumes (for the mo&longs;t part not aque­
ous neither) into which the Fire it &longs;elf
&longs;hatters dry Bodies, have no &longs;uch Spring
in them as the Air, &longs;ince they were unable
to hinder or repre&longs;s the expan&longs;ion of the
Air included in the Bladder they &longs;urroun­

I remember indeed that the Learned
Fo&longs;ephus Aco&longs;ta, in his Hi&longs;tory of the
We&longs;t Indies, tells us, That he &longs;aw in tho&longs;e
parts &longs;ome Grates of Iron &longs;o ru&longs;ted and
con&longs;um'd by the Air, that the Metal be­
ing pre&longs;&longs;'d between the Fingers, di&longs;&longs;olv'd
(to u&longs;e his words) to powder, as if it had
been Hay or parched Straw.

And I re­
member too, that the accurate Varenius
tells us, That in the I&longs;lands commonly
called Azores, the Air (and Wind) is &longs;o
&longs;harp, that in a &longs;hort time it frets not only

du&longs;t.

And I have el&longs;ewhere mention'd
&longs;ome recent Ob&longs;ervations of this kinde.

But it may be &longs;aid, That the above-men­

&longs;aline Corpu&longs;cles di&longs;per&longs;'d through the

And that
&longs;uch volatile Salts may copiou&longs;ly a&longs;cend
into the Air, and yet retain their Nature,
as doth the more fixt Salt in the Sea Wa­
ter, the &longs;ublimations of Sal-Armoniack
may &longs;ufficiently evince.

Not to mention
that I have &longs;hown &longs;ome Friends a &longs;ecret
kinde of &longs;aline Sub&longs;tance incomparably
&longs;ubtler then Sal-Armoniack, which did

&longs;ubtle exhalations, which did afterwards

We remember al&longs;o,
that to try whether Water could be turn'd
into Air, we once took an Æolipile, into
which we had before convey'd &longs;ome Wa­

when the heat forc'd out a vehement
&longs;tream of aqueous Vapors; we ty'd about
the neck of it, that of a Bladder, which
we had before empty'd of Air; and find­
ing the Æolipile after a while to blow up
the Bladder, we carefully ty'd it again
that the included &longs;ub&longs;tance might not get
away.

Then &longs;lipping it off from the Æo­
lipile we convey'd it into our Receiver, to
try whether or no that which in part di­
&longs;tended the Bladder would appear by its
Spring to be true Air: whereby we found

Air, the included &longs;ub&longs;tance expanded it
&longs;elf and the Bladder to a very much great­
er bulk then it was of before.

And for
further &longs;atisfaction, having again taken
out the Bladder, we &longs;uffer'd it to remain
ty'd up till next morning, to try whether
time, and the coldne&longs;s of the night, would
make the contain'd &longs;ub&longs;tance relap&longs;e in­
to Water: But the next Morning we
found it little le&longs;s tumid then before.

I
remember, I &longs;ay, that I once made this
Experiment; but I might &longs;ay in an&longs;wer
to it, that the chief rea&longs;on of my men­

how requi&longs;ite it is to be circum&longs;pect and

For though
I may &longs;eem to have u&longs;ed &longs;ufficient cauti­

&longs;elf that the Æolipile I had imploy'd was
a very large one, and that it required much

that the di&longs;ten&longs;ion of the Bladder in our

tinent to &longs;ubjoyn a notable Experiment

as ever, in&longs;omuch as none of the various
