&longs;eem'd to abound more with Aerial Parti­
cles then did this Oyl.

In which it was
further remarkable, that between the time
it was &longs;et into the Receiver, and that at
which we could get ready to Pump, it &longs;ub­
&longs;ided notably (by ghe&longs;s about half an
Inch) below the mark it reach'd before it
was put in.

Experi­
ment 24.

After this expre&longs;&longs;'d Oyl, we made tryal
of a di&longs;till'd one, and for that purpo&longs;e
made choice of the common Oyl or Spi­
rit (for in the Shops where it is &longs;old, the
&longs;ame Liquor is promi&longs;cuou&longs;ly call'd by ei­
ther name) of Turpentine; becau&longs;e 'twas
onely of that Chymical Oyl, we had a
&longs;ufficient quantity: which, being put in­
to a &longs;mall Gla&longs;s bubble with a &longs;lender
Neck, &longs;o as to fill it to about two Inches
from the top, did, upon the evacuating
of the Receiver, pre&longs;ent us with great
&longs;tore of bubbles; mo&longs;t of which ri&longs;ing
from the bottom, expanded them&longs;elves
exceedingly in their a&longs;cent, and made the
Liquor in the Neck to &longs;well &longs;o much by
degrees, that at length it divers times ran
over at the top: by which means, we
were hindred from being able to di&longs;cern
upon the letting in of the Air, how much
the &longs;ub&longs;idence of the Oyl below the fir&longs;t
mark was due to the rece&longs;s of the bub­
bles.

Having likewi&longs;e a minde to try whe­
ther as &longs;trong a &longs;olution of Salt of Tartar
in fair Water as could be made (we ha­
ving then no Oyl of Tartar per deliqui­
um at hand) though it be accounted,
Quick-&longs;ilver excepted, the heavie&longs;t of
Liquors would afford us any bubbles; we
put in a Gla&longs;s Egge full of it at the &longs;ame
time, with other Liquors, and found that
they did long yield &longs;tore of bubbles be­
fore any di&longs;covered them&longs;elves in the
Liquor of Tartar; and having pur&longs;ued
the Experiment, it appear'd, That of all
the Liquors we made tryal of, this afford­
ed the fewe&longs;t and the &longs;malle&longs;t Bubbles.

Spirit of Vinager being try'd after the
&longs;ame manner, exhibited a moderate num­
ber of bubbles, but &longs;carce any thing el&longs;e
worth the mentioning.

Nor could we in red Wine, try'd in a
Gla&longs;s Egge, take notice of any thing ve­
ry ob&longs;ervable.

For though upon the ex­
&longs;uction of the Air the bubbles a&longs;cended
in this Liquor, as it were in &longs;holes,
and &longs;hifted places among them&longs;elves in
their a&longs;cent; yet the Intume&longs;cence of the
whole bulk of the Liquor was &longs;carce at all
&longs;en&longs;ible, the bubbles mo&longs;t commonly
breaking very &longs;oon after their arrival at
the top, where during their &longs;tay, they
compo&longs;'d a kinde of &longs;hallow froth, which
alone appear'd higher in the Neck of the
Gla&longs;s, then was the Wine when it was
fir&longs;t let down.

Neither yet did Milk, con­
vey'd into our Pneumatical Ve&longs;&longs;el, pre­
&longs;ent us with any thing memorable, &longs;ave
that (as it &longs;eem'd by rea&longs;on of &longs;ome un­
ctuou&longs;ne&longs;s of the Liquor) the bubbles
not ea&longs;ily breaking at the top, and thru&longs;t­
ing up one another made the intume&longs;cence
appear much greater then that of common
Water.

We likewi&longs;e convey'd Hens Eggs into
the Receiver, but, after the ex&longs;uction of
the Air, took them out whole again.

That
which invited us to put them in, was, That
(as perhaps we mention in other Papers)
we had among other Experiments of
cold, made Eggs bur&longs;t, by freezing them
within doors with Snow and Salt: The
Ice, into which the aqueous parts of the
Egge were turned by the cold, &longs;o di&longs;tend-
ing (probably by rea&longs;on of the numerous
bubbles wont to be ob&longs;ervable in Ice) the
outward parts of the Egge, that it u&longs;ually
crack'd the &longs;hell, though the inner Mem­
brane that involv'd the &longs;everal Liquors
of the Egge, becau&longs;e it would &longs;tretch
and yield, remain d unbroken, And here­
upon we imagin'd that in our Engine it
might appear whether or no there were
any con&longs;iderable Spring, either in any of
the Liquors, or in any other more &longs;piri­
tuous &longs;ub&longs;tance included in the Egge.

We took al&longs;o &longs;ome Spirit of Urine,
carele&longs;ly enough deflegmed, and put it in­
to the &longs;ame Gla&longs;s (fir&longs;t carefully &longs;cowr'd
and clean&longs;'d) wherein we had put the Oyl­
olive above mention'd: We took al&longs;o an­
other Gla&longs;s, differing from a Gla&longs;s Egge,
onely in that its bottom was &longs;lat, and fill'd
it up to about 2/3 of the Neck (which was
wider then that of the Egge) with rectifi­
ed Spirit of Wine.

We took al&longs;o another Gla&longs;s Egge, and
having fill'd it with common Water till it
reach'd to the middle of the Neck, we
pour'd to it of the &longs;ame Spirit of Wine,
till it reach'd about an Inch higher.

The&longs;e three Gla&longs;&longs;es having marks &longs;et
on them, over again&longs;t the edges of the
contain'd Liquors were put into the Re­
ceiver, and that beginning to be evacua­
ted, the bubbles in all the three Liquors
began to appear.

The mixture of the
Spirit of Wine and Water di&longs;clo&longs;'d a
great &longs;tore of bubbles, e&longs;pecially towards
the top; but &longs;carce afforded us any thing
worth remem bring.

The Spirit of Urine
appear'd to &longs;well near an Inch and an half
above the mark; and be&longs;ides that, &longs;ent
forth &longs;tore of bubbles, which made a
kinde of froth at the upper part of it.

And
above that &longs;pume there appear'd eight or
ten great bubbles one above another, in a
very decent order, each of them con&longs;titu­
ting, as it were, a Cylinder of about half
an Inch high, and as broad as the internal
cavity of the Neck: So that all the upper
part of the Neck (for the&longs;e bubbles reach'd
to the top) &longs;eem'd to be divided into al­
mo&longs;t equal parts, by certain Diaphrag­
mes, con&longs;i&longs;ting of the coats of the bub­
bles, who&longs;e edges appear'd like &longs;o many
Rings &longs;u&longs;pended one above another.

In the Spirit of Wine there did ari&longs;e a
great multitude of bubbles, even till
wearine&longs;s did make us give over the Ex­
periment.

And in the&longs;e bubbles two or
three things were remarkable; as fir&longs;t,
That they a&longs;cended with a very notable
celerity: Next, That being arriv'd at the
top, they made no &longs;tay there, and yet,
notwith&longs;tanding the great thinne&longs;s and
&longs;pitituou&longs;ne&longs;s of the Liquor, did, before
they broke, lift up the upper &longs;urface of
it, and for a moment or two form thereof
a thin film or skin which appear'd protu­
berant above the re&longs;t of the &longs;uperficies
like a &longs;mall Hemi&longs;phere.

Thirdly, That
they a&longs;cended &longs;traight up, whereas tho&longs;e
produc'd at the lower part of the Ve&longs;&longs;el,
containing the mixture of the Water and
Spirit of Wine, a&longs;cended with a waver­
ing or wrigling motion, whereby they
de&longs;crib'd an indented Line.

La&longs;tly, It
was ob&longs;ervable in the Spirit of Wine (and
we took notice of the like in the Oyl of
Turpentine lately mention'd) that not
onely the bubbles &longs;eem'd to ri&longs;e from cer­
tain determinate places at the bottom of
the Gla&longs;s, but that in their a&longs;cen&longs;ion they
kept an almo&longs;t equal di&longs;tance from each
other, and follow'd one another in a cer­
tain order, whereby they &longs;eem'd part of
&longs;mall Bracelets, con&longs;i&longs;ting of equally lit­
tle incontiguous Beads: the lower end of
each Bracelet, being as it were, fa&longs;ten'd to
a certain point at the bottom of the Gla&longs;s.

The Air being &longs;paringly let into the
Receiver, the great bubbles formerly
mention'd as incumbent upon one ano­
ther, in that Gla&longs;s that contain'd the Spi­
rit of Urine, were by orderly degrees
le&longs;&longs;en'd, till at length they wholly &longs;ub&longs;i­
ded, notwith&longs;tanding the rece&longs;s of &longs;o ma­
ny bubbles as broke on the top of the
Spirit of Urine, during all the time of the
Experiment; yet it &longs;carcely appear'd at all
to be &longs;unk below the mark: Nor did the
mixture of Spirit of Wine and Water
con&longs;iderably &longs;ub&longs;ide.

But that is no­
thing to what we ob&longs;erv'd in the Spirit
of Wine, for not onely it con&longs;picuou&longs;ly
expanded it &longs;elf in the Neck of the
Ve&longs;&longs;el that contain'd it, notwith&longs;tand­
ing the largene&longs;s of it; and that the
bubbles were about to break at the
top of it almo&longs;t a&longs;&longs;oon as they arriv'd
there: but upon the re-admi&longs;&longs;ion of
the external Air, the Spirit of Wine
retain'd its newly acquired expan&longs;ion.

And though we let it alone for near
an hour together, in expectation that it
might &longs;ub&longs;ide; yet when we took it
out, we found it &longs;till &longs;well'd between a
quarter and half an Inch above the
mark; and although it was not ea&longs;ily
imaginable how this Phænomenon could
proceed from any mi&longs;take in trying
the Experiment, yet the &longs;trangene&longs;&longs;e
of it invited me to repeat it with fre&longs;h
Spirit of Wine; which, &longs;welling in the
Neck as formerly, I left all Night in
the Receiver, allowing free acce&longs;s to the
external Air at the Stop-cock, and the
next day found it &longs;till expanded as be­
fore, &longs;ave that it &longs;eem'd a little lower:
which decrement perhaps proceeded from
the avolation of &longs;ome of the fugitive
parts of &longs;o volatile a Liquor.

And for
better &longs;atisfaction having taken out the
Gla&longs;s, and con&longs;ider'd it in the open Air,
and at a Window, I could not finde that
there was any remaining Bubbles that
could occa&longs;ion the per&longs;evering and ad­
mir'd expan&longs;ion.

BEing de&longs;irous to di&longs;cover what diffe­
rence there might be as to gravity and
levity, between Air expanded under Wa­
ter, and it &longs;elfe before &longs;uch expan&longs;ion; we
took two very &longs;mall Viols, &longs;uch as Chy­
mical E&longs;&longs;ences (as they call them) are wont
to be kept in, and of the &longs;ize and &longs;hape ex­
pre&longs;&longs;ed by the 8th Figure: into one of the&longs;e
we put &longs;o much of a certain ponderous
Mercurial mixture (hapning to be then at
hand) that the mouth being &longs;topt with a
little &longs;oft Wax, the Gla&longs;s would ju&longs;t &longs;ink
in Water and no more; this we let fall to
the bottom of a wide-mouth'd Cry&longs;tal
Jar, fill'd with about half a pint of com­
mon Water, and into the &longs;ame Ve&longs;&longs;el we
&longs;unk the other E&longs;&longs;ence Gla&longs;s un&longs;topp'd,
with as much Water in it as was more
then &longs;ufficient to make it &longs;ub&longs;ide.

Both
the&longs;e &longs;unk with their mouthes downward,
the former being about three quarters full
of Air, the latter containing in it a bub­
ble of Air that was ghe&longs;&longs;'d to be of the
bigne&longs;s of half a Pea: This done, the
wide-mouth'd Gla&longs;s was let down into
the Receiver, and the way of imploy­
ing the Engine was carefully made u&longs;e
of.

Experi­
ment 25.

The &longs;ucce&longs;s was, That having drawn
out a pretty quantity of Air, the bubbles
began to di&longs;clo&longs;e them&longs;elves in the Wa­
ter, as in the former Experiments; and
though for a good while after the bubbles
a&longs;cended in &longs;warms from the lower parts
of the Water, and ha&longs;tily broke at the
top; yet we pro&longs;ecuted the Experiment
&longs;o long without &longs;eeing any effect wrought
upon the E&longs;&longs;ence: Bottles, that we began
to di&longs;pair of &longs;eeing either of them ri&longs;e, but
continuing to ply the Pump, that little
Gla&longs;s, who&longs;e mouth was open'd, came to
the top of the Water, being, as it were,
boy'd up thither by a great number of
bubbles that had fa&longs;tned them&longs;elves to
the &longs;ides of it; &longs;wimming thus with the
mouth downward, we could ea&longs;ily per­
ceive that the internal Air above men­
tion'd had much delated it &longs;elf, and there­
by &longs;eem'd to have contributed to the e­
merging of the Gla&longs;s, which remain'd
floating, notwith&longs;tanding the breaking
and vani&longs;hing of mo&longs;t of the contiguous
bubbles: being hereby incouraged to per­
&longs;i&longs;t in pumping, we ob&longs;erved with &longs;ome
plea&longs;ure, that at each time we turn'd the
Key, the Air in the little Gla&longs;s did mani­
fe&longs;tly expand it &longs;elf and thru&longs;t out the wa­
ter, generally retaining a very protuberant
&longs;urface where it was contiguous to the re­
maining Water.

And when after divers
ex&longs;uctions of the Air in the Receiver,
that in the little Viol &longs;o dilated it &longs;elf as
to expel almo&longs;t all the Water, it turn'd
up its mouth towards the &longs;urface of the
Water in the Jar, and there deliver'd a
large bubble, and then relap&longs;ed into its
formér floating po&longs;ture: And this Expe­
riment taught us, among other things,
that it was a work of more time and la­
bor then we imagin'd, to exhau&longs;t our En­
gine as much as it may be exhau&longs;ted: for
although before the emerging of the &longs;mall
Viol, we did (as has been touch'd alrea­
dy) think we had very con&longs;iderably em­
ptyed the Receiver, becau&longs;e there &longs;eem'd
to come out but very little or almo&longs;t
no &longs;en&longs;ible Air at each ex&longs;uction into
and out of the Cylinder; yet after­
wards, at each drawing down the Suc­
ker, the Air included in the Viol did
manife&longs;tly dilate it &longs;elf, &longs;o long, that
it did no le&longs;s then nine times turn its
mouth upwards, and di&longs;charge a bub­
ble by conjecture about the bigne&longs;s of
a Pea, after the manner newly recited.

But as for that Violl which had the
weight in it, it ro&longs;e not at all.

So
that being not able by quick pumping
to gain another bubble from the Air
in the &longs;wimming Gla&longs;s, which proceed­
ed from &longs;ome &longs;mall leak in the Ve&longs;&longs;el,
though it held in this Experiment more
&longs;tanch then was u&longs;ual, we thought fit
to let in lea&longs;urely the Air from with­
out, upon who&longs;e admi&longs;&longs;ion that with-
in the Viol &longs;hrinking into a very nar­
row compa&longs;s, the Gla&longs;s did, as we expe­
cted, fall down to the bottom of the
Jar.

But being de&longs;irous before we proceed­
ed to any new.

Experiment, to try once
more whether the little Gla&longs;s that had
the weight in it might not al&longs;o be rai&longs;'d.

After we had &longs;uffer'd the Engine to re­
main clo&longs;'d as it was, for five or &longs;ix
hours, the Pump was again ply'd with
&longs;o much ob&longs;tinacy, that not onely a­
bout the upper part of the Jar there ap­
pear'd a good number of bubbles (but
very much &longs;maller then tho&longs;e we &longs;aw
the fir&longs;t time) but afterwards there
came from the bottom of the Jar, bub­
bles about the bigne&longs;s of &longs;mal Peas: which
the Pump being &longs;till kept going, fol­
low'd one another, to the number of forty,
coming from the &longs;topp'd Violl; who&longs;e
mouth, it &longs;eems, had not been &longs;hut &longs;o
&longs;trongly and clo&longs;ely, but that the included
Air, dilating it &longs;elf by its own &longs;pring, made
it&longs;elf &longs;ome little pa&longs;&longs;age betwixt the Wall
and the Gla&longs;s, and got away in the&longs;e bub­
bles; after which, the un&longs;topp'd Gla&longs;s be­
gan to float again, the Air &longs;hut up in it
being manife&longs;tly &longs;o dilated as to expel a
good part of the Water, but not &longs;o much
as to break quite thorow.

And at length,
when our expectation of it was almo&longs;t ti­
red out, the heavier of the two Viols be­
gan to come aloft, and immediately to
&longs;ub&longs;ide again, which appear'd to be oc­
ca&longs;ion'd by the Air within it, who&longs;e bulk
and &longs;pring being weaken'd by the rece&longs;s
of the forty bubbles before-mention'd, it
was no longer able, as formerly, to break
forcibly through the incumbent Water;
but forming a bubble at the mouth of the
Gla&longs;s, boyed it up towards the top, and
there getting away, left it to &longs;ink again
till the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air in the Recei­
ver being further taken off, the Air in the
Viol was permitted to expand it &longs;elf fur­
ther, and to create another bubble, by
which it was again for a while carried up.

And it was remarkable, that though after
having emptyed the Receiver as far as
well we could, we cea&longs;'d from pumping;
yet the Ve&longs;&longs;el continuing more &longs;tanch
then it was wont, this a&longs;cent and fall of
the Viol was repeated to the ninth time;
the included Air, by rea&longs;on of the &longs;mal­
ne&longs;s of the vent at which it mu&longs;t pa&longs;s out,
being not able to get away otherwi&longs;e then
little by little; and con&longs;equently, in divers
&longs;uch parcels as were able to con&longs;titute
bubbles, each of them big enough to
rai&longs;e the Viol and keep it aloft until the
avolation of that bubble.

Whereby it
may appear, that the grand rule in Hy­
dro&longs;taticks, That a Body will &longs;wim in the
Water, in ca&longs;e it be lighter then as much
of that Water that equals it in bulk, will
hold likewi&longs;e when the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the At­
mo&longs;phere is in very great mea&longs;ure, if not
when it is totally taken off from the Li­
quor and the Body: though it were worth
inquiring what it is that &longs;o plentifully
concurs to fill the bubbles made in our
Experiment by the &longs;o much expanded
Air, for to &longs;ay with the old Peripatetick
Schools, That the Air, in Rarefaction,
may acquire a new extent, without the
admi&longs;&longs;ion of any new &longs;ub&longs;tance, would
be an account of the Phænomenon very
much out of date, and which, I &longs;uppo&longs;e,
our Modern Naturali&longs;ts would neither
give, nor acquie&longs;s in.

I know not whether it may be requi&longs;ite
to adde, that in this Experiment, as in
the former, the outward Air being let in
did &longs;oon precipitate the floating Viol.

But
I think it will not be ami&longs;s to note, that
(congruou&longs;ly to what hath been above
recorded of the va&longs;t expan&longs;ion of the Air)
the Water which in the heavier Viol &longs;uc­
ceeded in the room of tho&longs;e forty odde, if
not fifty great bubbles of Air, which at
&longs;everal times got out of it, amounted but
to a very incon&longs;iderable bigne&longs;s.

IT having been ob&longs;erv'd by tho&longs;e that
have con&longs;ider'd what belongs to Pendu­
lums (a Speculation that may, in my
poor judgement, be highly u&longs;eful to the
Naturali&longs;ts) that their Vibrations are
more &longs;lowly made, and that their moti­
on la&longs;ts le&longs;s in a thicker, then in a thinner
Medium: We thought it not ami&longs;s to
try if a Pendulum would &longs;wing fa&longs;ter, or
continue &longs;winging longer in our Receiver,
in ca&longs;e of the ex&longs;uction of the Air, then
otherwi&longs;e.

Wherefore we took a couple
of round and poli&longs;h'd Pendulums of Iron
or Steel, of equal bigne&longs;s, as near as we
could get the Artificer to make them, and
weighing each of them twenty Dragmes,
wanting as many Grains.

One of the&longs;e
we &longs;u&longs;pended in the cavity of the Recei­
ver by a very &longs;lender &longs;ilken &longs;tring, of a­
bout &longs;even Inches and a half in length
from the cover of the Receiver to which
it was fa&longs;ten'd.

Then (by inclining the
Engine) we made the Pendulum &longs;wing too
and fro in it, and de&longs;crib'd as long Arches
as in the capacity of &longs;o brittle a Ve&longs;&longs;el we
thought &longs;afe and convenient.

And one of
the A&longs;&longs;i&longs;tants telling the recur&longs;ions of the
other Pendulum hanging in the free Air,
by a &longs;tring of about the &longs;ame length, we
&longs;horten'd and lengthen'd this other Pen­
dulum, till it appear'd to keep the &longs;ame
pace in its Vibrations, with that &longs;hut up in
the Receiver.

Then having carefully
drawn away the Air, we did again &longs;et the
Pendulum in the Receiver a vibrating;
and giving the other Pendulum &longs;uch a mo­
tion as made it de&longs;cribe an Arch, accord­
ing to ones ghe&longs;s, equal to that of the in­
cluded Pendulum; we reckon'd, one of
us, the Recur&longs;ions of that Pendulum which
was &longs;winging within the Receiver; and
another of us that which was moving in
(that which one would think a much more
re&longs;i&longs;ting medinm) the Air.

But once, one
of us reckon'd near two and twenty Re­
cur&longs;ions of the included Pendulum, whil&longs;t
the other reckon'd but twenty of the Pen­
dulum that vibrated without.

And an­
other time al&longs;o, the former of the&longs;e Pen-
dula was reckon'd to have made one and
twenty Recur&longs;ions, wherein the other
made but twenty: Yet this Experiment
&longs;eem'd to teach us little, &longs;ave that the dif­
ference betwixt the motion of &longs;uch a Pen­
dulum in the common Air, and in one ex­
ceedingly rarified, is &longs;carce &longs;en&longs;ible in
Ve&longs;&longs;els no bigger then our Receiver; e­
&longs;pecially &longs;ince though during this Expe­
riment it held very well, yet we could
not &longs;uppo&longs;e it to be altogether devoid of
Air.

We ob&longs;erv'd al&longs;o, that when the
Receiver was full of Air, the included
Pendulum continu'd its Recur&longs;ions about
fifteen minutes (or a quarter of an hour)
before it left off &longs;winging; and that after
the ex&longs;uction of the Air, the Vibration
of the &longs;ame Pendulum (being fre&longs;h put in­
to motion) appear'd not (by a minutes
Watch) to la&longs;t &longs;en&longs;ibly longer.

So that
the event of this Experiment being other
then we expected, &longs;carce afforded us any
other &longs;atisfaction, then that of our not
having omitted to try it.

And whether
in ca&longs;e the tryal be made with a Pendulum
much le&longs;s di&longs;proportionate to the Air then
Steel is, the event will much better an­
&longs;wer expectation, experience may be con­
&longs;ulted.

Experi­
ment 26.

THat the Air is the medium whereby
&longs;ounds are convey'd to the Ear, has
been for many Ages, and is yet the com­
mon Doctrine of the Schools.

But this
Received Opinion has been of late op­
po&longs;'d by &longs;ome Philo&longs;ophers upon the ac­
count of an Experiment made by the
Indu&longs;trious Kircher, and other Learned
Men, who have (as they a&longs;&longs;ure us) ob­
&longs;erv'd, That if a Bell, with a Steel Clap­
per, be &longs;o fa&longs;ten'd to the in&longs;ide of a Tube,
that upon the making the Experiment De
Vacuo with that Tube, the Bell remain'd
&longs;u&longs;pended in the de&longs;erted &longs;pace at the up­
per end of the Tube: And if al&longs;o a vi­
gorous Load-&longs;tone be apply'd on the out­
&longs;ide of the Tube to the Bell, it will at­
tract the Clapper, which upon the Remo­
val of the Load-&longs;tone falling back, will
&longs;trike again&longs;t the oppo&longs;ite &longs;ide of the
Bell, and thereby produce a very audible
&longs;ound, whence divers have concluded,
That 'tis not the Air, but &longs;ome more &longs;ub­
tle Body that is the medium of &longs;ounds.

But becau&longs;e we conceiv'd that, to invali­
date &longs;uch a con&longs;equence from this ingeni­
ous Experiment (though the mo&longs;t lucife-
rous, that could well be made without
&longs;ome &longs;uch Engine as ours) &longs;ome things
might be &longs;peciou&longs;ly enough alleadg'd; we
thought fit to make a tryal or two, in or­
der to the Di&longs;covery of what the Air does
in conveying of &longs;ounds, re&longs;erving divers
other Experiments tryable in our Engine
concerning &longs;ounds, till we can obtain more
lea&longs;ure to pro&longs;ecute them.

Conceiving it
then the be&longs;t way to make our tryal with
&longs;uch a noi&longs;e as might not be loud enough
to make it difficult to di&longs;cern &longs;lighter va­
riations in it, but rather might be, both
la&longs;ting, that we might take notice by what
degrees it decrea&longs;'d; and &longs;o &longs;mall, that
it could not grow much weaker with­
out becoming imperceptible.

We took
a Watch, who&longs;e Ca&longs;e we open'd, that
the contain'd Air might have free egre&longs;s
into that of the Receiver.

And this Watch
was &longs;u&longs;pended in the cavity of the Ve&longs;&longs;el
onely by a Pack-thred, as the unlikelie&longs;t
thing to convey a &longs;ound to the top of the
Receiver: And then clo&longs;ing up the Ve&longs;­
&longs;el with melted Plai&longs;ter, we li&longs;ten'd near
the &longs;ides of it, and plainly enough heard
the noi&longs;e made by the ballance.

Tho&longs;e al­
&longs;o of us, that watch'd for that Circum­
&longs;tance, ob&longs;erv'd, that the noi&longs;e &longs;eem'd to
come directly in a &longs;traight Line from the
Watch unto the Ear.

And it was ob&longs;erva­
ble to this purpo&longs;e, that we found a mani­
fe&longs;t di&longs;parity of noi&longs;e, by holding our Ears
near the &longs;ides of the Receiver, and near the
Cover of it: which difference &longs;eem'd to
proceed from that of the Texture of the
Gla&longs;s, from the &longs;tructure of the cover (and
of the Cement) through which the &longs;ound
was propagated from the Watch to the
Ear.
But let us pro&longs;ecute our Experiment.

The Pump after this being imployd, it
&longs;eemd that from time to time the &longs;ound
grew fainter and fainter; &longs;o that when the
Rec iver was empty'd as much as it u&longs;'d
to be for the foregoing Experiments, nei­
ther we, nor &longs;ome &longs;trangers that chanc'd
to be then in the room, could, by applying
our Ears to the very &longs;ides, hear any noi&longs;e
from within; though we could ea&longs;ily per­
ceive that by the moving of the hand
which mark'd the &longs;econd minutes, and by
that of the ballance, that the Watch nei­
ther &longs;tood &longs;til, nor remarkably varied from
its wonted motion.

And to &longs;atisfie our
&longs;elvs further that it was indeed the ab&longs;ence
of the Air about the Watch that hinder'd
us from hearing it, we let in the external
Air at the Stop-cock, and then though we
turn'd the Key and &longs;topt the Valve, yet we
could plainly hear the noi&longs;e made by the
ballance, though we held our Ears &longs;ome­
times at two Foot di&longs;tance from the out­
&longs;ide of the Receiver.

And this Experi­
ment being reiterated in another place,
&longs;ucceded after the like manner.

Which
&longs;eems to prove, that whether or no the
Air be the onely, it is at lea&longs;t, the princi­
pal medium of Sounds.

And by the way
it is very well worth noting, that in a Ve&longs;­
&longs;el &longs;o well clo&longs;'d as our Receiver, &longs;o weak
a pul&longs;e as that of the ballance of a Watch
&longs;hould propagate a motion to the Ear in a
Phi&longs;ically &longs;traight Line, notwith&longs;tanding
the interpo&longs;ition of &longs;o clo&longs;e a Body as
Gla&longs;s, e&longs;pecially Gla&longs;s of &longs;uch thickne&longs;s
as that of our Receiver; &longs;ince by this it
&longs;eems that the air impri&longs;on'd in the Gla&longs;s,
mu&longs;t, by the motion of the ballance, be
made to beat again&longs;t the concave part of
the Receiver, &longs;trongly enough to make
its convex part beat upon the contiguous
Air, and &longs;o propagate the motion to the
Li&longs;tners ears.

I know this cannot but
&longs;eem &longs;trange to tho&longs;e, who, with an emi­
nent Modern Philo&longs;opher, will not allow
that a Sound, made in the cavity of a
Room, or other place &longs;o clo&longs;'d, that there
is no intercour&longs;e betwixt the external and
internal Air, can be heard by tho&longs;e with­
out, unle&longs;s the &longs;ounding Body do imme­
diately &longs;trike again&longs;t &longs;ome part of the in­
clo&longs;ing Body.

But not having now time
to handle Controver&longs;ies, we &longs;hall onely
annex, That after the foregoing Experi­
ment, we took a Bell of about two Inches
in Diameter at the bottom, which was
&longs;upported in the mid&longs;t of the cavity of
the Receiver by a bent &longs;tick, which by
rea&longs;on of its Spring pre&longs;&longs;'d with its two
ends again&longs;t the oppo&longs;ite parts of the in­
&longs;ide of the Ve&longs;&longs;el: in which, when it was
clo&longs;'d up, we ob&longs;erv'd that the Bell &longs;eem'd
to &longs;ound more dead then it did when ju&longs;t
before it &longs;ounded in the open Air.

And
yet, when afterwards we had as formerly
emptyed the Receiver, we could not di&longs;­
cern any con&longs;iderable change (for &longs;ome
&longs;aid they ob&longs;erv'd a &longs;mall one) in the loud­
ne&longs;s of the &longs;ound, whereby it &longs;eem'd that
though the Air be the principal medium
of &longs;ound, yet either a more &longs;ubtle mat­
ter may be al&longs;o a medium of it, or el&longs;e an
ambient Body that contains but very
few particles of Air, in compari&longs;on of
tho&longs;e it is ea&longs;ily capable of, is &longs;ufficient
for that purpo&longs;e.

And this, among o-
ther things, invited us to con&longs;ider, whether
in the above-mention'd Experiment made
with the Bell and the Load-&longs;tone, there
might not in the de&longs;erted part of the Tube
remain Air enough to produce a &longs;ound:
&longs;ince the Tubes for the Experiment De
Vacuo (not to mention the u&longs;ual thin­
ne&longs;s of the Gla&longs;s) being &longs;eldom made
greater then is requi&longs;ite, a little Air might
bear a not incon&longs;iderable proportion to
the de&longs;erted &longs;pace.

And that al&longs;o, in the
Experiment De Vacuo, as it is wont to be
made, there is generally &longs;ome little Air
that gets in from without, or at lea&longs;t &longs;tore
of bubbles that ari&longs;e from the Body of
the Quick-&longs;ilver, or other Liquor it &longs;elf,
Ob&longs;ervations heedfully made have fre­
quently informed us: And it may al&longs;o
appear, by what has been formerly deli­
vered concerning the Torricellian Experi­
ment.

Experi­
ment 27.

On the occa&longs;ion of this Experiment
concerning &longs;ounds, we may adde in this
place, That when we try'd the Experiment
formerly mention'd, of firing Gun-pow­
der with a Pi&longs;tol in our evacuated Recei­
ver, the noi&longs;e made by the &longs;triking of the
Flint again&longs;t the Steel, was exceeding
languid in compari&longs;on of what it would
have been in the open Air.

And on di­
vers other occa&longs;ions it appear'd that the
&longs;ounds created within our exhau&longs;ted
Gla&longs;s, if they were not lo&longs;t before they
reach'd the Ear, &longs;eem'd at lea&longs;t to arrive
there very much weaken'd.

We intended
to try whether or no the Wire-&longs;tring of an
In&longs;trument &longs;hut up into our Receiver,
would, when the ambient Air was &longs;uck'd
out, at all tremble, if in another In&longs;trument
held clo&longs;e to it, but without the Receiver
a &longs;tring tun'd (as Mu&longs;icians &longs;peak, how
properly I now examine not) to an Uni&longs;on
with it, were briskly toucht, and &longs;et a Vi­
brating.

This, I &longs;ay, we purpo&longs;'d to try
to &longs;ee how the motion made in the Air
without, would be propagated through the
cavity of our evacuated Receiver.

But
when the In&longs;trument wherewith the tryal
was to be made came to be imploy'd, it
prov'd too big to go into the Pneumatical
Ve&longs;&longs;el, and we have not now the conveni­
ency to have a fitter made.

We thought likewi&longs;e to convey into
the Receiver a long and &longs;lender pair of
Bellows, made after the fa&longs;hion of tho&longs;e
u&longs;ually employ'd to blow Organs, and fur­
ni&longs;h'd with a &longs;mall Mu&longs;ical in&longs;tead of an
ordinary Pipe.

For we hop'd, that by
means of a &longs;tring fa&longs;tned to the upper
part of the Bellows, and to the moveable
&longs;topple that makes a part of the Cover
of our Receiver, we &longs;hould, by frequent­
ly turning round that &longs;topple, and the an­
nexed &longs;tring, after the manner already
often recited, be able to lift up and di&longs;tend
the Bellows; and by the help of a com­
petent weight fa&longs;ten'd to the &longs;ame upper
part of the Bellows, we &longs;hould likewi&longs;e
be able, at plea&longs;ure, to compre&longs;s them:
and by con&longs;equence, try whether that
&longs;ubtler matter then Air (which, accord­
ing to tho&longs;e that deny a Vacuum, mu&longs;t be
&longs;uppo&longs;'d to fill the exhau&longs;ted Receiver)
would be able to produce a &longs;ound in the
Mu&longs;ical Pipe; or in a Pipe like that of or­
dinary Bellows, to beget a Wind capable
to turn or &longs;et a moving &longs;ome very light
matter, either &longs;hap'd like the Sails of a
Wind-Mill, or of &longs;ome other conveni­
ent form, and expo&longs;'d to its Orifice.

This
Experiment, I &longs;ay, we thought to make,
but have not yet actually made it for want
of an Artificer to make us &longs;uch a pair of
Bellows as it requires.

We had thoughts al&longs;o of trying whe­
ther or no, as Sounds made by Bodies in
our Receiver become much more languid
then ordinary, by rea&longs;on of the want of
Air, &longs;o they would grow &longs;tronger, in ca&longs;e
there were an unu&longs;ual quantity of Air
crouded and &longs;hut up in the &longs;ame Ve&longs;&longs;el,
which may be done (though not without
&longs;ome difficulty) by the help of the Pump,
provided the Cover and Stopple be &longs;o
firmly fa&longs;ten'd (by binding and Cement,
or otherwi&longs;e) to the Gla&longs;s; and to each
other, that there be no danger of the
conden&longs;'d Airs blowing of either of them
away, or its breaking through the jun­
ctures.

The&longs;e thoughts, My Lord, as I
was &longs;aying, we entertain'd; but for want
of lea&longs;ure, as, of as good Receivers as
ours, to &longs;ub&longs;titute in its place, in ca&longs;e we
&longs;hould break it before we learn'd the skill
of condencing the Air in it, we dur&longs;t not
put them in practice: Yet, on this occa­
&longs;ion, give me leave to adverti&longs;e Your
Lord&longs;hip once for all, That though for
the rea&longs;ons newly intimated, we have,
Onely in the &longs;eventeenth Experiment,
taken notice, that by the help of our En­
gine the Air may be conden&longs;'d as well as
rarified; yet there are divers other of our
Experiments, who&longs;e Phænomena it were
worth while to try to vary, by means of
the compre&longs;&longs;ion of the Air.

WE taught, among divers other
things, when we di&longs;cour&longs;'d of our
fir&longs;t Experiment, That the Air &longs;hut up in
our Receiver, pre&longs;&longs;eth as &longs;trongly upon
the Bodies &longs;hut up with it, as if they
were expo&longs;'d to the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the whole
Atmo&longs;phere.

That this was not incon­
&longs;iderately propounded, we hope Your
Lord&longs;hip has gather'd from divers of the
things already recited: But yet perhaps it
will not be ami&longs;s to &longs;ubjoyn, by way of
further confirmation of the &longs;ame truth, the
following Experiment, which &longs;hould have
accompanied the 20th, but the Paper where
in the one was written chanc'd not to beat
hand, when the other was &longs;ent away.

Experi­
ment 28.

We convey'd into the Receiver a new
Gla&longs;s Viol, capable of holding about 6 or
7 ounces of Water, into which we had
before put 2 or 3 Spoon-fulls of that Li­
quor, and &longs;topt it clo&longs;e with a fit Cork.

The Pneumatical Ve&longs;&longs;el being empty'd,
there appear'd not any change in the in­
clo&longs;'d Water, the Air impri&longs;on'd with it,
not having the force to blow out the &longs;top-
ple, which event, though it were no other
then we expected, was differing from what
we de&longs;ir'd.

For we would gladly have &longs;een
what change would have appear'd in the
Water upon the Bottles being &longs;uddenly
un&longs;topp'd, in a place where the ambient
Body was &longs;o differing from our common
Air.

Wherefore we did again put in the
Viol, but le&longs;s &longs;trongly clo&longs;'d then for­
merly, though as &longs;trongly &longs;topt as &longs;eem'd
requi&longs;ite on ordinary occa&longs;ions: But when
the Air was pump'd out of the Receiver,
that within the Viol did quickly, as we
expected, find or make it &longs;elf little pa&longs;&longs;a­
ges to get out at: as we argu'd, from this,
That whereas when the Viol was put in
the time before, the Water remain'd all
the while perfectly free from bubbles; at
this time the bottom of the Gla&longs;s ap­
pear'd all cover'd with them, and they,
upon the regre&longs;s of the excluded Air into
the Receiver, did pre&longs;ently flag and &longs;hrink
up.

From the&longs;e tryals it &longs;eem'd deducible
enough, that whil'&longs;t the Viol continu'd
to be well &longs;topt, the included Water
did, from the Air, &longs;hut up with it,
&longs;u&longs;tain a pre&longs;&longs;ure equal to that of the
Atmo&longs;phere; &longs;ince till the Air could get
out of the Gla&longs;s, there appear'd no bub­
bles in the Water, notwith&longs;tanding the
want of pre&longs;&longs;ure in the ambient Body.

But to be &longs;ure to reach the chief end of
our Experiment, we made u&longs;e of this o­
ther expedient: We cau&longs;'d a convenient
quantity of Water to be put, and Her­
metically &longs;hut up into a Gla&longs;s Egge, to
who&longs;e long Neck (which was purpo&longs;ely
made of an unequal thickne&longs;s) was fa­
&longs;ten'd to one end of a &longs;tring, who&longs;e o­
ther end was ty'd to the Cover of our
Receiver, after the manner el&longs;ewhere men­
tion'd already: Then the Egge being
convey'd into the Pneumatical Ve&longs;&longs;el,
and that being evacuated, we did, by
turning the bra&longs;s Stopple formerly de­
&longs;crib'd among&longs;t the parts of our En­
gine, &longs;o &longs;horten the &longs;tring as to break the
Gla&longs;s; whereby liberty being given to
the Air impri&longs;on'd in the Egge, to pa&longs;s
into the capacity of the Receiver, the &longs;ud­
den rece&longs;s of the Air made the bubbles in
a trice appear &longs;o numerous, and a&longs;cend
&longs;o &longs;wiftly in the Water, that their motion
look'd like that of a violent &longs;hower of
Rain; &longs;ave that the bubbles did not, like
the drops of Rain, tend downwards, but
upwards, which made me re&longs;emble this
Phænomenon to what I have &longs;een happen
in the di&longs;&longs;olution of Seed-Pearl in &longs;ome
acid Men&longs;truum, in which, if a good quan­
tity of the little Pearls be ca&longs;t whole, they
will at fir&longs;t, if the Men&longs;truum be &longs;harp e­
nough, be carryed in &longs;warms from the
bottom to the top of the Liquor.

We
will adde, that without &longs;ealing up the
Gla&longs;s, this Experiment may be try'd in
one of our &longs;malle&longs;t Receivers, for there
the ex&longs;uction of the ambient Air may be
perform'd &longs;o nimbly, that immediately
the bubbles lurking in the Water are al­
low'd to di&longs;play them&longs;elves, and a&longs;cend
in throngs; in&longs;omuch, as having in &longs;uch
a Receiver try'd the Experiment with
Wine (as a more &longs;pirituous Liquor) in­
&longs;tead of Water, the Red-Wine appear'd
all cover'd, with a copious, but vani&longs;hing
white Froth, almo&longs;t as if a Ve&longs;&longs;el full of
bottl'd drink had been unwarily open'd.

IT may not a little conduce to the clear­
er explication of divers Points in the
Doctrine of Meteors, and perhaps of
&longs;ome other Phy&longs;iological difficulties, to
di&longs;cover what the Air does to the motion
of tho&longs;e Steams or Exhalations that a&longs;-
cend into it, namely, Whether they mount
upwards by vertue of any &longs;uch po&longs;itive le­
vity (as &longs;ome Peripateticks &longs;peak) ac­
quir'd together with their Aërial nature,
as inables them to pierce through part of
the Atmo&longs;phere, and over-come its re­
&longs;i&longs;tance.

Or el&longs;e, whether the&longs;e &longs;teams
being once rai&longs;'d above the Earth by their
agitation, have their a&longs;cent and &longs;u&longs;tenta­
tion aloft, rather promoted then hindred
by the Air: as the inferior parts of that,
being thicker and heavier then the &longs;upe­
rior, the &longs;teams can more ea&longs;ily continue
for a while their agitation upwards then
downwards; And afterwards are by the
&longs;ame fluidity and thickne&longs;s of the Air,
carried to and fro in it, and kept from re­
lap&longs;ing to the Earth, as in the Sea water
the &longs;aline parts are kept from &longs;ub&longs;iding by
tho&longs;e aqueous ones wherewith they are
a&longs;&longs;ociated.

Experi­
ment 29

We hop'd to illu&longs;trate this matter, by
ob&longs;erving the motion of the &longs;moke, pro­
ceeding from kindled or flaming Bodies in
our exhau&longs;ted Receiver.

But as we for­
merly noted, upon the ex&longs;uction of the
Air, the &longs;moking of tho&longs;e Bodies pre­
&longs;ently cea&longs;'d.

We had thoughts al&longs;o of
conveying into our Pneumatical Gla&longs;s a
hot Iron, with &longs;ome Body ea&longs;ie to be
di&longs;&longs;ipated into &longs;moke &longs;et upon it, but con­
&longs;ider'd, that neither was that way free
from inconveniencies; e&longs;pecially this, that
the hot Body would make the Impri&longs;on'd
Air circulate within the Receiver, and
con&longs;equently make it que&longs;tionable whe­
ther the a&longs;cent of the &longs;teams would not
be due to the new and acquired motion of
the Air.

Wherefore I bethought my &longs;elf of an­
other way to &longs;atisfie in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure my
curio&longs;ity, to wit, by means of a certain
Liquor, which I call'd to minde that &longs;ome
years ago I had (for a de&longs;ign that belongs
not to our pre&longs;ent purpo&longs;e) prepar'd;
which, I &longs;uppo&longs;e, I &longs;hew'd Your Lord­
&longs;hip, and which had the luck to be ta­
ken notice of by divers very Ingenious
and Famous Men.

For this Liquor,
though mo&longs;t of its Ingredients be Metals,
and all of them ponderous enough, is yet
of that nature, that whil&longs;t the Viol where­
in it is kept is &longs;topt (how &longs;light a Cover
&longs;oever) both the Liquor and the Gla&longs;s
are tran&longs;parent; and &longs;o is that upper half
of the Gla&longs;s to which the Liquor reaches
not.

But a&longs;&longs;oon as ever the &longs;topple is ta­
ken out, and full acce&longs;s is given to the ex-
ternal Air, both the inward part of the
Cork, and the Liquor it &longs;elf, do pre&longs;ent­
ly &longs;end upwards, and &longs;catter abroad a
fume as thick and white, as if there were
a quantity of Alabla&longs;ter-du&longs;t thrown up
into the Air: And this &longs;moking of the
Liquor la&longs;ts till my unwillingne&longs;s to wa&longs;te
it, invites me &longs;top it again; and then the
a&longs;cen&longs;ion of the fumes &longs;uddenly cea&longs;es, till
the Viol be again un&longs;top'd.

This fuming Liquor then I thought
would much conduce to the di&longs;covery I
de&longs;ir'd to make, &longs;ince it &longs;av'd me the need
of conveying any hot Body with it into
the Receiver, and would not darken it
with fumes before the time.

Wherefore
having ty'd to the Viol a great weight of
Lead, to keep it from being lifted up by
the drawing out of the Cork; and having
ty'd to the &longs;topple one end of a &longs;tring, of
which the other end was made fa&longs;t to the
Cover of the Pneumatical Gla&longs;s, the Li­
quor was carefully clo&longs;'d up after the
wonted manner; then the Air being dili­
gently pump'd out, the Viol was un&longs;topt
in the empty'd Receiver: and though
immediately, npon the drawing out of the
Cork, there appear'd to be as it were
thrown up &longs;ome white fumes, which
&longs;eem'd to proceed from the Air before
impri&longs;on'd in the Viol, and diffu&longs;ing it
&longs;elf &longs;uddenly into the capicity of the
Receiver.

Yet we afterward ob&longs;erv'd,
as we expected, That the fumes did not
mount and di&longs;per&longs;e them&longs;elves as they
u&longs;e to do in the open Air, but that, when
by rea&longs;on of the agitation of the Cor­
pu&longs;cles of the Liquor, which could not

&longs;pace as the Viol afforded them, and were

&longs;tances the fumes were a&longs;cended to the lip

but ran down along the out-&longs;ide of the

along, a long and inclining piece of Lead,
on which the Viol re&longs;ted, like a little
Stream (not very much bigger then a

&longs;tream of Water of the &longs;ame bigne&longs;s

And this &longs;tream la&longs;ted
a pretty while, and would probably have
la&longs;ted longer, but that being loath to wa&longs;te
my Liquor, I let in at the Stop-cock a
pretty deal of the external Air; notwith­
&longs;tanding which, finding after a while the
&longs;tream did run afre&longs;h; though, as it &longs;eem'd,

&longs;moak.

Though it be now divers years
&longs;ince this Numerical Liquor was prepa­
red, after the manner mention'd either
by Carneiades or Eleutherius (for I do not

bove been mention'd.

More Circum&longs;tances concerning the&longs;e
Fumes we might have ob&longs;erv'd, had we
not been deterr'd by an Indi&longs;po&longs;ition in

that of the Ingredients of this Liquor
the&longs;e &longs;eem likely to be of.

The Reflections that may be made up­
on this Experiment, we have not now the
lea&longs;ure to pro&longs;ecute, and therefore &longs;hall

veral Circum&longs;tances of it to Your Lord­
&longs;hips &longs;erious con&longs;ideration; and to take

bient Body, or a medium thinner then
them&longs;elves, may both tend downwards,
and otherwi&longs;e emulate the nature of a
Liquor; which I therefore point at, that
it may appear the le&longs;s &longs;trange, if we &longs;ome­
times &longs;peak of the Atmo&longs;phere as of a
kinde of Liquor, in compari&longs;on of that
more thin and &longs;ubtle Cele&longs;tial Matter that
&longs;urrounds it.

And though it might perchance &longs;uf­
fice to have on this occa&longs;ion intima­
ted thus much; yet, le&longs;t this way
of &longs;peaking of the Atmo&longs;phere &longs;hould
be thought too bold and extra­
vagant, I am content to borrow an
Experiment of the Di&longs;cour&longs;e former-

&longs;uitable to the contrivance of our Engine;

might have been annext to what has been
noted either upon the fir&longs;t, or eighteenth
Experiment, but that when they were
written and &longs;ent away, it came not into

The Experiment then as we
try'd in our Engine, was as follows.

WE took one of the &longs;mall Receivers,
often mention'd already, and into it
we convey'd a piece of well lighted Match;
and letting it remain there till it had fill'd
the Receiver with &longs;moak, we took it out
and ha&longs;tily clo&longs;'d again the Receiver, that
the &longs;moak might not get away.

Then
&longs;taying awhile to let the&longs;e fumes lei&longs;urely
&longs;ub&longs;ide, we found, as we expected, that
after &longs;ome time they &longs;etled them&longs;elves in
the lower half of the Receiver, in a dark­
i&longs;h Body, leaving the upper half of the

of nought but clear Air.

Now to mani­
fe&longs;t that this &longs;moak thus &longs;etled emulated
a Liquor, we inclin'd the Engine that con­

&longs;moak to keep its &longs;urface almo&longs;t Hori­

And if by a quicker rocking of the

&longs;elf in an intire and di&longs;tinct Body from the
incumbent Air; and being permitted to
re&longs;t awhile, would &longs;oon recover its for­

the Key were turn'd and the Valve un­
&longs;topp'd, &longs;o that there was a free, though
but a narrow pa&longs;&longs;age open'd betwixt the

quantity of the outward Air, would ma­
nife&longs;tly a&longs;cend through it into the incum­

and Wine by degrees mingle with one an­
other; the one falling downe as it were in
little colour'd &longs;treames, and the other a&longs;­
cending into its room in the like curled
&longs;treames, &longs;ometimes preceded by round

tran&longs;parency, looke almo&longs;t like bubbles.

The other circum&longs;tances of this Experi­
ment, belonging not all of them to our
pre&longs;ent purpo&longs;e, we &longs;hall content our
&longs;elves with taking notice of one which
&longs;eemes the mo&longs;t important, and may illu­
&longs;trate and confirme &longs;ome things former­
ly delivered.

And it was, That if, when
the &longs;uperficies of our Smoke lay &longs;mooth
and horizontal, a hot iron were held near
the our &longs;ide of the Receiver, the Neigh­

the re&longs;t did not very much alter their for­

would readily a&longs;cend in a large Pillar of
&longs;moke to the very top of the Receiver,
yet without &longs;eeming to loo&longs;e a di&longs;tinct
&longs;uperficies, or to be confounded with Air;
below which, upon the rece&longs;s of the ad­
ventitious heat that by agitating it im­
pell'd it upward, it would againe &longs;ub­
&longs;ide.

Experi­
ment 30.

All which being added to the late Ex­
periment of the &longs;moking Liquor, and
to what may be from that which has been
el&longs;ewhere &longs;ayd, gather'd to the &longs;ame pur­
po&longs;e, will, I hope, keep it at lea&longs;t from ap­
pearing ab&longs;ur'd: If &longs;ince we &longs;ee that there
is &longs;o great an inequality in the den&longs;ity and
weight of Liquors, that water is neere 14
times thinner or lighter than Quick-&longs;ilver
of the &longs;ame bulk, and well dephlegm'd;
Spirit of Wine yet much lighter than wa­
ter; we venter to &longs;peak &longs;ometimes of the
Atmo&longs;phere, as if it were a peculiar kind
of thin and halituous Liquor (if I may &longs;o
call it) much lighter than Spirit of Wine.

To the&longs;e things I know not whether it
will be requi&longs;ite to add, that as we late­
ly took notice of con&longs;picuous waves that
appear'd upon the &longs;uperficies of our agi­

So &longs;ome &longs;uch thing may
not ab&longs;urdly be conjectur'd to happen
on the &longs;uperficies of the Atmo&longs;phere,
by tho&longs;e &longs;trange ruggedne&longs;&longs;es that ap­
peare (e&longs;pecially in the Spring and Fall,
when exhalations and vapours are wont to
a&longs;cend mo&longs;t plentifully) upon the Limb
or Edge of the Ri&longs;ing and Setting Sun.

I
&longs;peake thus diffidently upon this occa&longs;ion
becau&longs;e I know that by the Fluctuation or

ver&longs;e eminent Mathematicians have plau­
&longs;ibly enough (but how truly I leave

give an Account of it.

But if we will joine
with tho&longs;e that have a&longs;crib'd of late this
Phænomenon to the Refraction the Sun­
Beames fuffer in our vapid Air; we may,
as hath been intimated, promote their Do­

the &longs;urface Atmo&longs;phere is oftentimes (if
not alwayes) exceedingly curl'd or wav'd.

And certainly it is &longs;omewhat wonderfull

qualities in the edge of it (in&longs;omuch that

other; &longs;ave that their Motion oftentimes
&longs;eemes to be quicke&longs;t as if in that va&longs;t &longs;ea

lea&longs;t by a tide.

And this (as we el&longs;e
where note) appear's to the eye not on­

le&longs;cope upon the &longs;unne; but al&longs;o when a
large and well defin'd image of the &longs;unne
is by the &longs;ame tele&longs;cope brought into a

per.

But to in&longs;i&longs;t on this were to digre&longs;s:
and therefore I will proceed to experi­
ments of another kind.

IT has been admir'd by very ingenious
Men, that if the exqui&longs;itly poli&longs;h'd
&longs;urfaces of two flat peeces of marble be &longs;o
congruous to each other that from their
mutuall application there will re&longs;ult an
immediate contact, they will &longs;tick &longs;o fa&longs;t
together, that he that lifts up the upper­
mo&longs;t, &longs;hall, if the undermo&longs;t be not ex­
ceeding heavy, lift up that too, and &longs;u&longs;­
taine it aloft in the free aire.

A proba­
ble cau&longs;e of this &longs;o clo&longs;e adhe&longs;ion we have
el&longs;ewhere endeavour'd to deduce from the
unequall pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air upon the un­
dermo&longs;t &longs;tone; For the lower &longs;uperficies
of that &longs;tone being freely expos'd to the

&longs;uperiour &longs;tone, is thereby defended from

per, hinders it from falling, as we have
el&longs;ewhere more fully declar'd.

Upon
the&longs;e grounds we conjectur'd that in ca&longs;e
we could procure two marbles exactly
ground to one another; and in ca&longs;e we
could al&longs;o &longs;ufficiently evacuate our Re­
ceiver, the lower &longs;tone would, for want
of the wonted and &longs;u&longs;taining pre&longs;&longs;ure of
the Air, fall from the upper.

But the
further tryal of this Experiment we mu&longs;t,
unle&longs;s your Lord&longs;hip think it worth Your
making at Paris, put off till a fitter
opportunity.

For where we now are, we
cannot procure marbles &longs;o exactly ground,
that they will &longs;u&longs;taine one another in the
Air, above a minute or two, which is a
much &longs;horter time than the emptying of

We did indeed
try to make our marbles &longs;tick clo&longs;e to­
gether by moi&longs;tening their polli&longs;hed &longs;ur­

&longs;eem'd &longs;ufficient to exclude and keep out

But this we try'd to little pur­
po&longs;e, for having convey'd into the Recei-
ver two black &longs;quare marbles (the one of
two inches and a third in length or
breadth, and &longs;omewhat more than halfe

cover, we found not that the ex&longs;uction of

Experi­
ment 31,

I would gladly have the Experiment
try'd with marble &longs;o well polli&longs;h't as to
need no Liquor what&longs;oever to make them
cohere, and in a Ve&longs;&longs;el out of which the
Air may be more perfectly drawn than it
was out of ours.

But in the mean time
though we will not determin whether the
Spirit of wine did contribute to the &longs;trong

Air from getting in between them, yet it
&longs;eemed that the not falling downe of the

Air remaining in the Receiver; which as

to keep a Cylinder of water of above
a Foot in height from falling to the bot­
tom of the Tube, may well enough be
&longs;uppo&longs;'d capable of keeping &longs;o broad a flat
Marble from de&longs;cending.

And though this
may &longs;eem a &longs;trange proof of the &longs;trength of

may be made betwixt broad Bodies, one­

A notable in&longs;tance of which, I
have met with in this &longs;hort Narrative of

Fuveni (&longs;ays he)
lacertorum &longs;uorum robur: jactanti propo­
&longs;ita &longs;emel e&longs;t lamina ærea, per an&longs;am in
medio extantem apprehen&longs;am elevanda è

qui primo tanquam rem ludicr am puero
committendam contemp&longs;it: tum in&longs;tanti­
bus amicis manum utrámque admovens,
cum luctatus diu hærentem non removi&longs;&longs;et,

& potenti&longs;simi glutinis interpo&longs;itione, quo

nec vidit ab alio per tabulam facilimè lami­

actam in tran&longs;ver&longs;um inàe deportari.

But
that we may learn from our own Engine,
that two Bodies, though they touch each
other but in a &longs;mall part of their &longs;urfaces,
may be made to cohere very &longs;trongly,

more forcibly upon the inferior &longs;uperfi­

ment, though out of the order wherein

P. Nic.

Zucchius
opal Schot:
part 1.

Experi­
ment 32.

I remember I have, in a Di&longs;cour&longs;e con­
cerning Fluidity and Firmne&longs;s, made
mention of my having, by the ex&longs;uction
of the Air out of a Gla&longs;s Ve&longs;&longs;el, made
that Ve&longs;&longs;el take up, or &longs;uck up (to &longs;peak in
the common Language) a Body weighing
divers Ounces; but our Engine affording
us the opportunity of making con&longs;ider­
abler Experiments of that kinde, We
thought fit to make a further tryal of the
force of the Atmo&longs;phere's pre&longs;&longs;ure up­
wards, after the following manner.

The Receiver having been exqui&longs;itely
clo&longs;'d, as we have often taught already,
and the Air being in a good mea&longs;ure drawn
out of it, it was remov'd from off the
Pump: and to the lower Branch of the
Stop-cock, there was &longs;peedily apply'd a
tapering Valve of bra&longs;s, &longs;uch as is de&longs;crib'd
in the 9th fig: made fit to go with its nar­
rower end into the cavity of the branch,
and to fill the orifice of that cavity with
its broader part.

And that the Air might
not get in at the litle intervals, left here
and there between the convex &longs;urface of
the &longs;topple and the internall edge of the
branch, tho&longs;e intervals were &longs;top't with
a little Diachylon.

And to the doore,
or, (if you plea&longs;e) that part of the Valve
which was to move to and fro, and in
this Experiment hung perpendicular to
the Horizon, there was, at a button of
bra&longs;s belonging to the Valve fa&longs;ten'd a
broad &longs;cale wherein weights were to be
put.

This done the key of the Stop-cock
was turn'd, and the externall Air beating
like a forcible &longs;treame upon the Valve
to get in there, it did &longs;uddenly both &longs;hut
the Valve and keep it &longs;hut &longs;o &longs;trongly,
that we had time to ca&longs;t in diver&longs;e weights
one after another into the Scale; till at
length the weight overpowering the pre&longs;­
&longs;ure of the Atmo&longs;phere, drew downe the
Valve by the &longs;tringes that ty'd the Scale
to it, and gave liberty to the outward Air
to ru&longs;h into the Receiver.

Though a-
nother time, when the Valve had but lit­
tle weight hanging at it, being, by I know
not what accident, drawn down beneath its
former place, it was by the impetuous
current of the outward Air &longs;uddenly im­
pell'd up into it again, and kept there.

But in the former Experiment it is re­
markable, That though the Receiver were
not well exhau&longs;ted, and though it leak'd
whil'&longs;t the re&longs;t of the Experiment was in
pro&longs;ecution, and though the Valve
whereon the Cylinder of the Atmo&longs;phere
could pre&longs;s, were not above an Inch and
a half in Diameter, yet the weight kept
up by &longs;uction, or rather &longs;upported by the
Air, namely the Valve, the Seal and
what was ca&longs;t into it, being &longs;ent to be
weigh'd, amounted to about ten of our
common Pounds, con&longs;i&longs;ting of &longs;ixteen
Ounces apiece: So that we doubted not
but that, had the Experiment been made
with favorable Circum&longs;tances, the Air
endeavoring to pre&longs;s in at the Orifice of
the Stop-cock, would have kept a very
much greater weight from falling out of
it; I &longs;ay the Air, becau&longs;e we found, by
tryal purpo&longs;ely made, that neither the
imperfect contact of the Valve and the
Stop-cock, nor the Diachylon that was
employ'd to fill up the little Crannies left
betwixt them, were con&longs;iderable in this
Experiment; by which may among other
things appear, that I did not without
cau&longs;e in the above-nam'd Di&longs;cour&longs;e touch­
ing Fluidity and Firmne&longs;s, a&longs;cribe a great
force, ev'n to &longs;uch Pillars of Air as may
be &longs;uppo&longs;'d to begin at the top of the
Atmo&longs;phere, and recoyling from the
ground to terminate on the Bodies on
which they pre&longs;s: &longs;ince in the pre&longs;ent Ex­
periment &longs;uch a weight was &longs;upported by
&longs;o &longs;lender a Cylinder of Air, rebounding
from the Earth to the Valve whereon it
did bear.

BUt in regard we have not yet been
able to empty &longs;o great a Ve&longs;&longs;el as our
Receiver, &longs;o well as we can the Cylinder
it &longs;elf; our Pump alone may afford us a
nobler in&longs;tance of the fotce of the Air we
live in, in&longs;omuch, that by help of this
part of our Engine, we may give a pretty
near ghe&longs;s at the &longs;trength of the Atmo­
&longs;phere, computed as a weight.

And the
way may be this; Fir&longs;t, the Sucker be­
ing brought to move ea&longs;ily up and down
the Cylinder, is to be impell'd to the top
of it: Then the Receiver mu&longs;t be taken
off from the Pump, that the upper Ori­
fice of the Cylinder remaining open, the
Air may freely &longs;ucceed the Sucker, and
therefore readily yield to its motion
downward.

This done, there mu&longs;t be
fa&longs;ten'd to one of the Iron Teeth of the
Sucker, &longs;uch a weight as may ju&longs;t &longs;uffice
to draw it to the bottom of the Cylinder.

And having thus examin'd what weight is
nece&longs;&longs;ary to draw down the Sucker, when
the Atmo&longs;phere makes no other then the
ordinary re&longs;i&longs;tance of the Air again&longs;t its
de&longs;cent; the Sucker mu&longs;t be again forc'd
to the top of the Cylinder, who&longs;e upper
Orifice mu&longs;t now be exactly clo&longs;ed; and
then (the fir&longs;t weight remaining) we ea&longs;i­
ly may, by hanging a Scale to the above­
mention'd Iron (that makes part of the
Sucker) ca&longs;t in known weights &longs;o long,
till in &longs;pight of the reluctancy of the At­

For
to the&longs;e weights in the Scale, that of the

Experi­
ment 33.

According to this method we did, &longs;ince

Then to

And to &longs;atisfie our &longs;elves, and the Spe­

&longs;ently begin to impell the Sucker, with

&longs;uch accidental Impediment as we former­

its a&longs;cent to the top, to the no &longs;mall won­

And indeed it is very

And though (as hath been already ac­

E&longs;t quoddam prodire tenus, &longs;i non da­

Peradventure it will not be imperti-
nent to annex to the other Circum&longs;tances

It
might al&longs;o be try'd with Cylinders of &longs;e­

&longs;tain or lift up; and con&longs;equently, whe­

&longs;i&longs;tance of the ambient Air, can be re­

cellian Experiment, if we could get Tubes
&longs;o accurately blown and drawn, that the

To dwell upon all the &longs;everal Refle­
ctions, that a &longs;peculative Wit might
make upon this and the foregoing Expe­
riment: (I mean the thirty third and thir­
ty &longs;econd, would require almo&longs;t a Vo­
lume, whereas our occa&longs;ions will &longs;carce
allow us time to touch upon three or
four of the chief Inferences that &longs;eem de­
ducible from them, and therefore we &longs;hall
content our &longs;elves to point at tho&longs;e
few.

And fir&longs;t, as many other Phænomena
of our Engine, &longs;o e&longs;pecially, the two
lately mention'd Experiments, &longs;eem ve­
ry much to call in que&longs;tion the receiv'd
Opinion of the Nature or Cau&longs;e of Su­
ction.

For 'tis true indeed, that when men
&longs;uck, they commonly u&longs;e &longs;ome manife&longs;t
endeavour by a peculiar motion of their
Mouthes, Che&longs;ts, and &longs;ome other con&longs;pi­
ring parts, to convey to them the body
to be &longs;uckt in.

And hence perhaps they
have taken occa&longs;ion, to think that in all
Suction there mu&longs;t be &longs;ome Endeavour
or motion in the &longs;ucking to attract the
&longs;ucked Body.

But in our la&longs;t Experi­
ment it appeares not at all how the up­
per part of the empty'd Cylinder that re­
maines movele&longs;s all the while, or any
part of it, does at all endeavour to draw
to it the depre&longs;&longs;ed Sucker and the an­
nex'd weights.

And yet tho&longs;e that be­
hold the a&longs;cention of the Sucker, without
&longs;eriou&longs;ly con&longs;idering the cau&longs;e of it, doe
readily conclude it to be ray&longs;'d by &longs;ome­
thing that powerfully Sucks or attracts
it, though they &longs;ee not what that may
be or where it lurks.

So that it &longs;eemes
not ab&longs;olutely nece&longs;&longs;ary to Suction, that
there be in the Body, which is &longs;aid to &longs;uck,
an endeavor or motion in order thereun­
to, but rather that Suction may be at lea&longs;t
for the mo&longs;t part reduc'd to Pul&longs;ion, and
its effects a&longs;crib'd to &longs;uch a pre&longs;&longs;ure of
the neighboring air upon tho&longs;e Bodies
(whther aërial, or of other Natures) that
are contiguous to the Body that is &longs;ayd to
attract them, as is &longs;tronger than that Sub­
&longs;tance which po&longs;&longs;e&longs;&longs;es the cavity of that
&longs;ucking Body is able to re&longs;i&longs;t.

To ob­
ject here, that it was &longs;ome particles of
Air remaining in the empty'd Cylin-
der that attracted this weight to obviate

le&longs;s it can be cleerly made out by what li­
tle hooks, or other grappling In&longs;truments,
the internal Air could take hold of the
Sucker; how &longs;o litle of it obtain'd the

al&longs;o, upon the letting in of a litle more
Air into one of our evacuated Ve&longs;­
&longs;els, the attraction is, in&longs;tead of being
&longs;trengthen'd, much weaken'd, though,
if there were danger of a Vacuum be­
fore, it would remain, notwith&longs;tanding
this ingre&longs;s of a little Air.

For that &longs;till
there remain'd in the capacity of the ex­
hau&longs;ted Cylinder &longs;tore of little rooms,
or &longs;paces empty or devoid of Air, may
appear by the great violence wherewith
the air ru&longs;hes in, if any way be open'd to it.

And that 'tis not &longs;o much the decrement
of the Vacuum within the cavity of the
ve&longs;&longs;el that debilitates the attraction, as the
&longs;pring of the included air (who&longs;e pre&longs;ence
makes the decrement) that does it by
re&longs;i&longs;ting the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the external Air,
&longs;eems probable, partly from the Di&longs;abi­
lity of vacuities, whether greater or le&longs;&longs;er,
