ly by &longs;ome of the Phænomena of our Ex-
periments, and particularly by this Cir­
cum&longs;tance of the three and Thirtieth,
that the Sucker was by the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the
Ambient Air impell'd upwards, with its
weight hanging at it, not only when it
was at the bottome of the Cylinder, and
con&longs;equently left a great Vacuum in the
cavity of it; but when the Sucker had
been already impel'd almo&longs;t to the top of
the Cylinder, and con&longs;equently, when the
Vacuum that remain'd was become very
litle in compari&longs;on of that which preceded
the beginning of the Sucker's a&longs;cention.

In the next place, the&longs;e Experiments
may teach us, what to judge of the vul­
gar Axiom receiv'd for &longs;o many Ages
as an undoubted Truth in the Peripate­
tick Schools; That Nature abhorres
and flys a Vacuum, and that to &longs;uch a de­
gree, that no humane power (to go no
higher) is able to make one in the Uni­
ver&longs;e; wherein Heaven and Earth would
change places, and all its other Bodyes
rather act contrary to their own Nature,
than &longs;uffer it.

For, if by a Vacuum we
will under&longs;tand a place perfectly devoid
of all corporeal Sub&longs;tance, it may be in­
deed then, as we formerly noted be plau­
&longs;ibly enough maintain'd, that there is
no &longs;uch thing in the world; but that the
generality of the Pleni&longs;ts, (e&longs;pecially till
of late yeares &longs;ome of them grew more
wary) did not take a Vacuum in &longs;o &longs;trict
a Sen&longs;e, may appear by the Experiments
formerly, and ev'n to this Day imploy'd
by the Deniers of a Vacuum, to prove it
impo&longs;&longs;ible that there can be any made.

For when they alleadge (for In&longs;tance)
that when a man &longs;ucks Water through a
long Pipe, that heavy Liquor, contrary
to its Nature, a&longs;cends into the Sucker's
mouth, only, to fill up that room made
by the Dilatation of his Bre&longs;t and
Lungs, which otherwi&longs;e will in part be
empty.

And when they tell us, that the
rea&longs;on why if a long Pipe exactly
clos'd at one end be fill'd top-ful
of Water, and then inverted, no Liquor
will fall out of the open Orifice; Or, to
u&longs;e a more familiar Example, when they
teach, that the cau&longs;e why in a Gardiner's
watering Pot &longs;hap'd conically, or like a
Sugar-Loaf fill'd with Water, no Liquor
fals down through the numerous holes
at the bottome, whil&longs;t the Gardiner keeps
his Thumb upon the Orifice of the litle
hole at the top, and no longer, mu&longs;t be
that it in the ca&longs;e propo&longs;ed the Water
&longs;hould de&longs;cend, the Air being unable to
&longs;ucceed it, there would be left at the up­
per and de&longs;erted part of the Ve&longs;&longs;el a Va­
cuum, that would be avoided if the hole
at the top were open'd.

When (I &longs;ay)
they alleadge &longs;uch Experiments, the
Tendency of them &longs;eems plainly to im­
port, that they mean, by a Vacuum, any
&longs;pace here below that is not fill'd with a
vi&longs;ible body, or at lea&longs;t with Air; though
it be not quite devoy'd of all Body what­
&longs;oever.

For why &longs;hould Nature, out of
her dete&longs;tation of a Vacuum, make Bo­
dies act contrary to their own Tendency,
that a place may be fill'd with Air, if its
being &longs;o were not nece&longs;&longs;ary to the avoi­
ding of a Vacuum.

Taking then a Vacuum in this vulgar
and obvious &longs;ence, the common opinion
about it &longs;eems lyable to &longs;everal Exce­
ptions, whereof &longs;ome of the chief are
&longs;ugge&longs;ted to us by our Engine.

It will not ea&longs;ily then be intelligibly
made out, how hatred or aver&longs;ation,
which is a pa&longs;&longs;ion of the Soule, can either
for a Vacuum, or any other object, be &longs;up­
pos'd to be in Water, or &longs;uch like inani­
mate Body, which cannot be pre&longs;um'd
to know when a Vacuum would en&longs;ue; if
they did not be&longs;tirre them&longs;elves to pre­
vent it, nor to be &longs;o generous as to act
contrary to what is mo&longs;t conducive to
their own particular pre&longs;ervation for the
publique good of the Univer&longs;e.

As much
then of intelligible and probable Truth,
as is contain'd in this Metaphoricall Ex­
pre&longs;&longs;ion, &longs;eems to amount but to this;
That by the Wi&longs;e Author of Nature
(who is ju&longs;tly &longs;ayd to have made all
things in number, weight, and mea&longs;ure,)
the Univer&longs;e, and the parts of it, are &longs;o
contriv'd, that it is as hard to make a Va­
cuum in it, as if they &longs;tudiou&longs;ly con&longs;pir'd
to prevent it.

And how far this it &longs;elfe
may be granted, de&longs;erves to be further
con&longs;ider'd.

For in the next place, our Experiments
&longs;eem to teach, that the &longs;uppo&longs;ed Aver&longs;a­
tion of Nature to a Vacuum is but acci­
dental, or in con&longs;equence partly of the
Weight and Fluidity, or, at lea&longs;t, Fluxi­
lity of the Bodies here below; and partly,
and perhaps principally, of the Spring of
the air, who&longs;e re&longs;tle&longs;s endeavor to expand
it &longs;elfe every way, makes it either ruth
in it &longs;elfe, or compel the interpos'd bo­
dys into all &longs;paces, where it finds no grea­
ter re&longs;i&longs;tance than it can &longs;urmount.

And
that in tho&longs;e motions which are made ob­
fugamVacui (as the common phra&longs;e is) Bo­
dys act without &longs;uch genero&longs;ity & Con­
&longs;ideration, as is wont to be a&longs;crib'd to
them, is apparent enough in our 32d Ex­
periment, where the torrent of Air, that
&longs;eem'd to &longs;trive to get into the Empty'd
Receiver, did plainly prevent its own
De&longs;igne, by &longs;o impelling the Value, as
to make it &longs;hut the only Orifice the Air
was to get in at.

And if afterwards ei­
ther Nature, or the internal Air, had a de­
&longs;igne the external Air &longs;hould be attra­
cted, they &longs;eem'd to pro&longs;ecute very un­
wi&longs;ely by continuing to &longs;uck the Valve
&longs;o &longs;trongly, when they found that by
that Sucction the Valve it &longs;elfe could not
be drawn in: Whereas by forbearing to
&longs;uck, the Valve would by it's own weight
have fall'n down, and &longs;uffer'd the exclu­
ded Air to returne freely, and to fill
again the exhau&longs;ted Ve&longs;&longs;el.

And this minds me to take notice of
another deficiency, pointed at by our Ex­
periments in the common Doctrine of
tho&longs;e Pleni&longs;ts we rea&longs;on with; for many
of tho&longs;e unu&longs;ual motions in Bodies, that
are &longs;ayd to be made to e&longs;cape a Vacuum,
&longs;eem rather made to fill it.

For why,
to in&longs;tance in our newly mention'd Ex­
periment, a&longs;&longs;oon as the Valve was de­
pre&longs;s'd by the weight we hung at it,
&longs;hould the Air &longs;o impetuou&longs;ly and copi­
ou&longs;ly ru&longs;h into the cavity of the Receiver;
if there were before no vacant room there
to receive it?

and if there were, then all the
while the Valve kept out the Air, tho&longs;e
litle &longs;paces in the Receiver, which the
corpu&longs;cles of that Air afterwards fill'd,
may be concluded to have remain'd em­
pty.

So that the &longs;eeming violence,
imploy'd by Nature on the occa&longs;ion of
the evacuating of the Ve&longs;&longs;el, &longs;eems to
have come too late to hinder the making
of Vacuities in the Receiver, and only
to have, a&longs;&longs;oon as we permitted, fill'd
up with Air tho&longs;e that were already
made.

And as for the Care of the Publique
Good of the Univer&longs;e a&longs;crib'd to dead
and &longs;tupid Bodies, wee &longs;hall only de­
mand, why in our 19th Experiment, upon
the Ex&longs;uction of the ambient Air, the
Water de&longs;erted the upper half of the
Gla&longs;s-Tube; and did not a&longs;cend to fill
it up, till the external Air was let in upon
it: whereas by its ea&longs;y and &longs;udden regai­
ning that upper part of the Tube, it
appear'd both that there was there much
&longs;pace devoid of Air, and that the Water
might with &longs;mall or no re&longs;i&longs;tance have
a&longs;cended into it, if it could have done &longs;o
without the impul&longs;ion of the readmitted
Air; which, it &longs;eems, was nece&longs;&longs;ary to
mind the Water of its formerly neglected
Duty to the Univer&longs;e.

Nay, for ought appeares, ev'n when
the excluded Air, a&longs;&longs;oon as 'twas per­
mitted, ru&longs;ht violently into our exhau­
&longs;ted Receiver, that flowing in of the
Air proceeded rather from the deter­
minate Force of the Spring of the
neighbouring Air, then from any endea­
vour to fill up, much le&longs;s to prevent va­
cuity's.

For though when as much Air as
will, is gotten into our Receiver our pre­
&longs;ent Opponents take it for granted that
it is full of Air; yet if it be remembred
that when we made our 17th Experiment
we crouded in more Air to our Receiver
than it u&longs;ually holds; and if we al&longs;o con­
&longs;ider (which is much more) the Air of
the &longs;ame con&longs;i&longs;tence with that in our
Receiver may in wind guns, as is known,
and as we have try'd, be compre&longs;&longs;ed at
lea&longs;t into halfe its wonted room (I &longs;ay at
lea&longs;t, becau&longs;e &longs;ome affirme, that the Air
may be thru&longs;t into an 8th, or a yet &longs;maller
part of its ordinary extent) it &longs;eems ne­
ce&longs;&longs;ary to admit either a notion of conden­
&longs;ation & rarefaction that is not intelligi­
ble, or that in the capacity of our Recei­
ver when pre&longs;um'd to be full of Air, there
yet remain'd as much of &longs;pace as was ta­
ken up by all the aërial corpu&longs;cles unpo&longs;­
&longs;e&longs;&longs;ed by the Air.

Which &longs;eemes plainly,
to infer that the Air that ru&longs;h'd into our
empty'd ve&longs;&longs;el did not doe it preci&longs;ely
to fill up the Vacuities of it, &longs;ince it left &longs;o
many unfill'd, but rather was thru&longs;t in by
the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the contiguous Air; which
as it could not, but be always ready to ex­
pand it &longs;elfe, where it found lea&longs;t re&longs;i­
&longs;tance, &longs;o was it unable to fill the Recei­
ver any more, then until the Air within
was reduc'd to the &longs;ame mea&longs;ure of Com­
pactne&longs;s with that without.

We may al&longs;o from our two already of­
ten mention'd Experiments further de­
duce, that, (&longs;ince Natures hatred of a
Vacuum is but Metaphorical and Ac­
cidental, being but a con&longs;equence or re­
&longs;ult of the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air and of the
Gravity, and partly al&longs;o of the Fluxility
of &longs;ome other bodies) The power &longs;hee
makes u&longs;e of to hinder a Vacuum, is not
(as we have el&longs;e-where al&longs;o noted) any
&longs;uch boundle&longs;s thing as men have been
pleas'd to imagine.

And the rea&longs;on, why
in the former Experiments, mentioned
in favour of the Pleni&longs;ts, Bodies &longs;eem to
forget their own Natures to &longs;hun a Va­
cuum, &longs;eems to be but this; That in the
alleadged ca&longs;es the weight of that Wa­
ter that was either kept from falling or
impell'd up, was not great enough to
&longs;urmount the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the contiguous
Air; which, if it had been, the Water
would have &longs;ub&longs;ided, though no Air could
have &longs;ucceeded.

For not to repeat that
Experiment of Mon&longs;ieur Pa&longs;chal (for­
merly mention'd to have been try'd in a
Gla&longs;s exceeding 32 Foot) wherein the
inverted Pipe being long enough to con­
tain a competent weight of Water, that
Liquor freely ran out at the lower Orifice:
Not to mention this (I &longs;ay) we &longs;aw in
our nineteenth Experiment, that when
the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the ambient Air was &longs;uffi­
ciently weaken'd, the Water would fall
out apace at the Orifice even of a &longs;hort
Pipe, though the Air could not &longs;ucceed
into the room de&longs;erted by it.

And it were
not ami&longs;s if tryal were made on the tops
of very high Mountains, to di&longs;cover with
what ea&longs;e a Vacuum could be made near
the confines of the Atmo&longs;phere, where
the Air is probably but light in compari­
&longs;on of what it is here below.

But our
pre&longs;ent (three and thirtieth) Experiment
&longs;eems to manife&longs;t, not onely that the
power, exerci&longs;'d by Nature, to &longs;hun or re­
pleni&longs;h a Vacuum, is limited, but that it
may be determin'd even to Pounds and
Ounces: In&longs;omuch that we might &longs;ay,
&longs;uch a weight Nature will &longs;u&longs;tain or will
lift up to re&longs;i&longs;t a Vacuum in our Engine;
but if an Ounce more be added to that
weight, it will &longs;urmount Her &longs;o much
magnifi'd dete&longs;tation of Vacuities.

And
thus, My Lord, our Experiments may
not onely an&longs;wer tho&longs;e of the Pleni&longs;ts,
but enable us to retort their Arguments
again&longs;t them&longs;elves: &longs;ince, if that be true
which they alleadge, that, when Water
falls not down according to its nature, in
a Body wherein no Air can &longs;ucceed to fill
up the place it mu&longs;t leave, the &longs;u&longs;pen&longs;i­
on of the Liquor is made Ne detur Vacu­
um, (as they &longs;peak) it will follow, that
if the Water can be brought to &longs;ub&longs;ide
in &longs;uch a ca&longs;e, that de&longs;erted &longs;pace may be
deem'd empty, according to their own
Doctrine; e&longs;pecially, &longs;ince Nature (as
they would per&longs;wade us) be&longs;tirs her &longs;elf
&longs;o mightily to keep it from being de­
&longs;erted.

I hope I &longs;hall not need to reminde Your
Lord&longs;hip, that I have all this while been
&longs;peaking of a Vacuum, not in the &longs;trict
and Philo&longs;ophical &longs;en&longs;e, but in that more
obvious and familiar one that has been
formerly declar'd.

And therefore I &longs;hall now proceed to
ob&longs;erve in the la&longs;t place, that our 33d Ex­
periment affords us a notable proof of the
unheeded &longs;trength of that pre&longs;&longs;ure which
is &longs;u&longs;tain'd by the Corpu&longs;cles of what we
call the free Air, and pre&longs;ume to be un­
compre&longs;&longs;'d.

For, as fluid and yielding a
Body as it is, our Experiment teaches us,
That ev'n in our Climate, and without
any other compre&longs;&longs;ion then what is (at
lea&longs;t here below) Natural, or (to &longs;peak
more properly) ordinary to it, it bears &longs;o
&longs;trongly upon the Bodies whereunto it is
contiguous, that a Cylinder of this free
Air, not exceeding three Inches in Dia­
meter is able to rai&longs;e and carry up a
weight, amounting to between &longs;ixteen
and &longs;eventeen hundred Ounces.

I &longs;aid,
even in our Climate, becau&longs;e that is tem­
perate enough; and as far as my ob&longs;er­
vations a&longs;&longs;i&longs;t me to conjecture, the Air in
many other more Northern Countries
may be much thicker, and able to &longs;upport
a greater weight: which is not to be
doubted of, if there be no mi&longs;take in
what is Recorded concerning the Hollan­
ders, that were forc'd by the Ice to Win­
ter in Nova Zembla, namely, That
they found there &longs;o conden&longs;'d an Air, that
they could not make their Clock goe,
ev'n by a very great addition to the
weights that were wont to move it.

I &longs;uppo&longs;e Your Lord&longs;hip will readily
take notice, that I might very ea&longs;ily have
di&longs;cour&longs;ed much more fully and accuratly
then I have done, again&longs;t the common o­
pinion touching Suction, and touching na­
tures hatred of a Vacuum.

But I was willing
to keep my &longs;elf to tho&longs;e con&longs;iderations
touching the&longs;e matters, that might be ve­
rifi'd by our Engine it &longs;elf, e&longs;pecially, &longs;ince,
as I &longs;aid at fir&longs;t, it would take up too much
time to in&longs;i&longs;t particularly upon all the Re­
flections that may be made even upon our
two la&longs;t Experiments.

And therefore,
pa&longs;&longs;ing to the next, I &longs;hall leave it to your
Lord&longs;hip to con&longs;ider how far the&longs;e tryals
of ours will either confirm or disfavor
the new Doctrine of &longs;everal eminent Na­
turali&longs;ts, who teach, That in all motion
there is nece&longs;&longs;arily a Circle of Bodies, as
they &longs;peak, moving together; and whe­
ther the Circles in &longs;uch motion be an Ac­
cidental or Con&longs;equential thing or no.

TIs a known thing to tho&longs;e that are con­
ver&longs;ant in the Hydro&longs;taticks, That
two Bodies which in the Air are of equal
weight, but of unequal bulk, as Gold,
for in&longs;tance and Iron, being afterwards
weighed in Water, will lo&longs;e their Æqui­
librium upon the change of the ambient
Body, &longs;o that the Gold will &longs;ink lower
then the Iron; which, by rea&longs;on of its
greater bulk, has more Water to lift
or di&longs;place, that it may &longs;ink.

By Analogy
to this Experiment, it &longs;eem'd probable,
that if two weights did in our Engine
ballance each other, when the Gla&longs;s was
full of Air; upon the ex&longs;uction of a
great part of that Air, &longs;o notable a change
in the con&longs;i&longs;tence of the ambient Body,
would make them lo&longs;e their Æquili­
brium.

Experi­
ment 34.

But being de&longs;irous at the &longs;ame time to
make a tryal, for a certain De&longs;ign that
needs not here be mention'd, we took
for one of our weights a dry Bladder,
&longs;trongly tyed at the Neck, and about
half fill'd with Air (that being a weight
both &longs;light, and that would expand it
&longs;elf in the evacuated Gla&longs;s) and fa&longs;tning
that to one part of our formerly menti­
on'd exact ballance (which turns with the
32d part of a Grain) we put a Metalline
counterpoi&longs;e into the oppo&longs;ite Scale; and
&longs;o the two weights being brought to an
Æquilibrium, the ballance was convey'd
into the Receiver, and &longs;u&longs;pended from the
Cover of it.

But before we proceed further, we mu&longs;t
note, That pre&longs;ently after the laying on
of the Cover, the Bladder appear'd to
preponderate, whereupon the Scales being
taken out, and reduc'd very near to an Æ­
quilibrium, yet &longs;o, that a little advantage
remain'd on that &longs;ide to which the Metal­
line weight belong'd; they were again let
down into the Receiver, which was pre­
&longs;ently made fa&longs;t with Plai&longs;ter, and a hot
Iron: Soon after which, before the Pump
was employ'd, the Bladder &longs;eem'd again
a little to preponderate.

Afterwards
the Air in the Gla&longs;s being begun to be
drawn out, the Biadder began (according
to the formerly mention'd Ob&longs;ervations)
to expand it &longs;elf, and manife&longs;tly to out­
weigh the oppo&longs;ite weight, drawing
down the Scale to which it was fa&longs;tned
very much beneath the other, e&longs;pecially
when the Air had &longs;well'd it to its full ex­
tent.

This done, we very lei&longs;urely let in the
external Air; and ob&longs;erv'd, that upon
the flagging of the Bladder, the Scale
whereto it was fa&longs;tned, not onely by de­
grees return'd to an Æquilibrium with the
other, but at length was a little out­
weighed by it.

But becau&longs;e we &longs;u&longs;pected there
might have interven'd &longs;ome unheeded
Circum&longs;tance in this la&longs;t part of the Ex­
periment, we would not pre&longs;ently take
out the Scales, nor meddle with the Co­
ver, but leaving things as they were, we
perceiv'd, that after a little while the
Bladder began again to preponderate, and
by degrees to &longs;ink lower and lower for
divers hours; wherefore, leaving the
Ve&longs;&longs;el clo&longs;'d up all night, we repair'd to it
next Morning, and found the Bladder
fallen yet lower.

As if the very &longs;ub&longs;tance
of it, had imbibed &longs;ome of the moi&longs;ture
wherewith the Air (the Sea&longs;on being ve­
ry rainy) did then abound: As Lute­
&longs;trings, which are made likewi&longs;e of the
Membranous parts of Guts, &longs;trongly
wreath'd, are known to &longs;well &longs;o much,
oftentimes as to break in rainy and wet
weather.

Which conjecture is the more to
beregarded, becau&longs;e congruou&longs;ly unto it
one of the company having a little warm'd
the Bladder, found it then lighter then
the oppo&longs;ite weight.

But this mu&longs;t be
look'd upon as a bare conjecture, till we
can gain time to make further tryals about
it.

In the mean while we &longs;hall adde, that
without removing the Scales or the Co­
ver of the Receiver, we again cau&longs;'d the
Air to be drawn out (the weather conti­
ing very moi&longs;t) but found not any manife&longs;t
alteration in the ballance; whether be­
cau&longs;e the Æquilibrium was too far lo&longs;t to
let a &longs;mall change appear, we determine
not.

But to make the Experiment with a
Body le&longs;s apt to be altered by the tempe­
rature of the Air, then was the Bladder;
we brought the Scales again to an Æqui-
librium with two weights, whereof the
one was of Lead, the other of Cork.

And
having evacuated the Receiver, we ob&longs;er­
ved, that both upon the ex&longs;uction, and
after the return of the Air, the Cork did
manife&longs;tly preponderate, and much more
a while after the Air had been let in again,
then whil&longs;t it was kept out.

Wherefore,
in the room of the Cork, we &longs;ub&longs;tituted
a piece of Char-coal, as le&longs;s likely to im­
bibe any moi&longs;ture from the Air, but the
event proved much the &longs;ame with that
newly related: So that this Experiment
&longs;eems more liable to Ca&longs;ualties then any,
excepting one we have made in our En­
gine.

And as it is difficult to prevent
them, &longs;o it &longs;eems not very ea&longs;ie to di&longs;­
cover the cau&longs;es of them, whereof we
&longs;hall therefore at pre&longs;ent forbear mention­
ing our Conjectures.

SOme Learned Mathematicians have of
late ingenioù&longs;ly endeavored to reduce
Filters to Siphons; but &longs;till the true cau&longs;e
of the a&longs;cen&longs;ion of Water, and other Li­
quors, both in Siphons and in Filtration,
needing (for ought we have yet found) a
clearer Di&longs;covery and Explication, we
were de&longs;irous to try whether or no the
pre&longs;&longs;ure of the Air might rea&longs;onably be
&longs;uppo&longs;'d to have either the principal, or at
lea&longs;t a con&longs;iderable Intere&longs;t in the rai&longs;ing
of tho&longs;e Liquors.

But becau&longs;e we found
that we could not yet &longs;o evacuate our Re­
ceiver, but that the remaining Air,
though but little in compari&longs;on of the
exhau&longs;ted, would be able to impell the
the Water to a greater height then is
u&longs;ual in ordinary Filtrations: we re&longs;olved,
in&longs;tead of a Li&longs;t of Cotton, or the like
Filtre, to make u&longs;e of a Siphon of Gla&longs;s,
delineated in the third Figure, con&longs;i&longs;t­
ing of three pieces, two &longs;traight, and
the third crooked to joyn them toge­
ther; who&longs;e Junctures were diligently
clo&longs;'d, that no Air might finde entrance
at them.

One of the Legs of this Si­
phon was (as it &longs;hould be) &longs;omewhat
longer then the other, and was pervious
at the bottom of it onely, by a hole al­
mo&longs;t as &longs;lender as a hair, that the
Water might but very lea&longs;urely drop
out of it, le&longs;t it &longs;hould all run out
before the Experiment were compleat­
ed.

The other and &longs;horter Leg of
the Siphon was quite open at the end,
and of the &longs;ame widene&longs;&longs;e with the
re&longs;t of the Pipe, who&longs;e bore was about /4
of an Inch.

The whole Siphon made
up of the&longs;e &longs;everal pieces put together,
was de&longs;ign'd to be about a Foot and a
half long; that the remaining Air, when
the Ve&longs;&longs;el was exhau&longs;ted after the wont­
ed manner, might not be able to impell
the Water to the top of the Siphon;
which being inverted, was fill'd with Wa­
ter, and of which the Shorter leg being
let down two or three Inches deep into a
Gla&longs;s Ve&longs;&longs;el full of Water, and the up­
per parts of it being fa&longs;ten'd to the in&longs;ide
of the Cover of the Receiver, we pro­
ceeded to clo&longs;e fir&longs;t, and then to empty
the Ve&longs;&longs;el.

Experi­
ment 35.

The effect of the tryal was this, that
till a pretty quantity of Air had been
drawn out, the Water dropp'd freely out
at the lower end of the lower leg of the
Siphon, as if the Experiment had been
performed in the free Air.

But afterwards,
the Bubbles (as had been apprehended)
began to di&longs;clo&longs;e them&longs;elves in the Wa­
ter, and a&longs;cending to the top of the Si­
phon, imbodyed them&longs;elves there into
one, which was augmented little by little
by the ri&longs;ing of other bubbles that from
time to time broke into it, but much
more by its own dilatation, which en-
crea&longs;'d proportionably to the ex&longs;uction
that was made of the Air out of the Re-
ceiver.

So that at length the Water in
the &longs;horter Leg of the Siphonwas re-
duc'd partly by the extraction of the am-
bient Air, and partly by the expan&longs;ion
of the great Bubble at the upper part of
the Siphon, to be but about a Foot high,
if &longs;o much; wherby it came to pa&longs;s,
that the cour&longs;e of the Water in the Si-
phon was interrupted, and that which re-
main'd in the longer Leg of it, continu'd
&longs;u&longs;pended there without dropping any
longer.

But upon the turning of the
Stop-cock, the outward Air (being t
into the Receiver) got into the Siphon by
the little hole at which the Water former-
ly dropt out; and traver&longs;ing all the in-
cumbent Cylinder of Water, in the form
of Bubbles, joyn'd it &longs;elf with that Air

phon.

To prevent the inconveniences ari&longs;ing
from the&longs;e Bubbles, two Gla&longs;s Pipes, like
the former; were &longs;o placed; as to termi-
nate together in the mid&longs;t of the Belly of
a Gla&longs;s Viol, into who&longs;e Neck they
were carefully fa&longs;tned with Cement; and
then both the Viols and the Pipes being

ter, as formerly; and the Experiment be-

much more Air then formerly was drawn
out, before the Bubbles di&longs;closing them-
&longs;elves in the Water were able to di&longs;turb
the Experiment; becau&longs;e that in the ca-
pacity of the Viol there was room enough

the Pipes; and, during this time, the

But at
length the Receiverbeing very much em-
pty'd, the pa&longs;&longs;age of the Water through
the Siphoncea&longs;'d, the upper ends of the
Pipes beginning to appear a little above

And hereby the con-
tinuity of the Water, and &longs;o the Expe-

And though upon the whole mat-
ter there &longs;eem'd little or no cau&longs;e to

fe&longs;tly enough have appear'd that the

from Bubbles by the help of the &longs;ame
Engine.

This occa&longs;ion I have had to take notice
of Siphons, puts me in minde of an odde
kinde of Siphon that I cau&longs;'d to be made
a pretty while ago; and which has been
&longs;ince, by an Ingenious Man of Your ac-
quaintance, communicated to divers o-
thers.

This occa&longs;ion was this, An emi-
nent Mathematician told me one day, that
&longs;ome inqui&longs;itive French Men (who&longs;e
Names I know not) had ob&longs;erv'd, That,
in ca&longs;e one end of a flender and perforated
Pipe of Gla&longs;s be dipt in Water, the Li-
quor will a&longs;cend to &longs;ome height in the
Pipe, though held perpendicular to the
plain of the Water.

And, to &longs;atisfie me
that he mi&longs;-related not the Experiment,
he &longs;oon after brought two or three
&longs;mall Pipes of Gla&longs;s, which gave me the
opportunity of trying it: though I had
the le&longs;s rea&longs;on to di&longs;tru&longs;t it, becau&longs;e I re-
member I had often in the long and flen-
der Pipes of &longs;ome Weather Gla&longs;&longs;as,
which I had cau&longs;'d to be made after a
&longs;omewhat peculiar fa&longs;hion, taken notice
of the like a&longs;cen&longs;ion of the Liquor,
though (pre&longs;uming it might be ca&longs;ual) I
had made but litllereflection upon it.

But
after this tryal, beginning to &longs;uppo&longs;e, that
though the Water in the&longs;e Pipes that
were brought me, ri&longs;e not above a quar-
ter of an Inch, (if near &longs;o high) yet, if
the Pipes were made flender enough, the
water might ri&longs;e to a very much greater
height; I cau&longs;'d &longs;everal of them to be, by
a dexterous Hand, drawn out at the flame
of a Lamp, in one of which that was
almo&longs;t incredibly flender, we found that
the Water as&longs;ended (as it were of it &longs;elf)
five Inches by mea&longs;ure, to the no &longs;mall
wonder of &longs;ome famous Mathematicians,
who were Spectators of &longs;ome of the&longs;e
Experiments.

And this height the Wa-
ter reach'd to, though the Pipe were held
in as erected a po&longs;ture as we could: For if
it were inclin'd, the Water would fill a
greater part of it, though not ri&longs;e higher

And we al&longs;o found, that when the
in&longs;ide of the Pipe was wetted before-
hand, the Water would ri&longs;e much better
then otherways: But we cau&longs;'d not all
our flender Pipes to be made &longs;traight, but
&longs;ome of them crooked, like Siphons: And
having immer&longs;'d the &longs;horter Leg of one
of the&longs;e into a Gla&longs;s that held &longs;ome fair
Water, we found, as we expected, that
the Water ari&longs;ing to the top of the Si-
phon, though that were high enough, did
of it &longs;elf run down the longer Leg, and
continue running like an ordinary Siphon.

The cau&longs;e of this a&longs;cen&longs;ion of the Wa-
ter, appear'd to all that were pre&longs;ent &longs;o
difficult, that I mu&longs;t not &longs;tay to enumerate
the various Conjectures that were made
at it, much le&longs;s to examine them; e&longs;pe-
cially, having nothing but bare Conje-
ctures to &longs;ub&longs;titute in the room of tho&longs;e
I do not approve.

We try'd indeed, by
conveying a very flender Pipe and a &longs;mall
Ve&longs;&longs;el of Water into our Engine, whe-
ther or no the Ex&longs;uction of the ambient
Air would a&longs;&longs;i&longs;t us to finde the cau&longs;e of
the a&longs;cen&longs;ion we have been &longs;peaking of:
But though we imploy'd red Wine in-
&longs;tead of Water, yet we could fearce cer-

was interpo&longs;'d betwixt our Eyes and the
Liquor, what happen'd in a Pipe &longs;o flen-

&longs;carce &longs;en&longs;ible in it.

But as far as we could
di&longs;cern, there happen'd no great altera-

&longs;trange, becau&longs;e the Spring of that Air
that might depre&longs;s the Water in the Pipe,

remain'd to pre&longs;s upon the &longs;urface of the

Wherefore, in
favor of his Ingenious Conjecture who
a&longs;crib'd the Phaenomenon, under con&longs;ide-
ration to the greater pre&longs;&longs;ure made upon
the Water by the Air without the Pipe,
then by that within it, (where &longs;o much of

&longs;cles more pliant to the internal &longs;urfaces of
the Air) was contiguous to the &longs;ides) it
was &longs;hown, that in ca&longs;e the little Gla&longs;s
Ve&longs;&longs;el that held the Water, of which a
part a&longs;cended into the flender Pipe, were
&longs;o clo&longs;'d, that a Man might with his mouth
&longs;uck the Air out of it, the Water would
immediately &longs;ub&longs;ide in the &longs;mall Pipe.

And this would indeed infer, that it a&longs;-
cended before onely by the pre&longs;&longs;ure of
the incumbent Air: But that it may
(how ju&longs;tly I know not) be objected,
that preadventure this would not hap-
pen, in ca&longs;e the upper ende of the Pipe
were in a Vacuum: And that 'tis very
probable the Water may &longs;ub&longs;ide, not
becau&longs;e the pre&longs;&longs;ure of the internal Air
is taken off by Ex&longs;uction, but by rea&longs;on
of the Spring of the external Air,
which impels the Water it findes in its
way to the Cavity de&longs;erted by the
other Air, and would as well impell
the &longs;ame Water upwards, as make it
&longs;ub&longs;ide, if it were not now lei&longs;ure to exa-
mine any further this Matter, I &longs;hall
onely minde Your Lord&longs;hip, that if
You will pro&longs;ecute this Speculation,
it will be pertinent to finde out likewi&longs;e,
Why the &longs;urface of Water /as is manife&longs;t
in Pipes) u&longs;es to be concave, being de-
pre&longs;&longs;'d in the middle, and higher on eve-
ry side? and Why in Quick-&longs;ilver on the
contrary, not onely the &longs;urface is wont

der Pipe in it, the &longs;urface of the Li-
quor (as 'tis call'd) will be lower within

Which Phaeno-
mena, whether, and how far, they may
be deduc'd from the Figure of the Mer-
curial Corpu&longs;cles, and the Shape of the
Springy Particles of the Air, I willingly
leave to be con&longs;ider'd.

SEveral ways we have met with pro-
po&longs;'d, partly by the excellent Galileo,
and partly by other ingenious Writers,
to manife&longs;t that the Air is not devoid of
weight; &longs;ome of the&longs;e, require the previ-
ous ab&longs;ence of the Air to be weighed;
and others, the violent conden&longs;ation of it.

But if we could lift a pair of Scales above
the Atmo&longs;phere, or place them in a Va-
cuum, we might there weigh a parcel of
Air it &longs;elf, as here we do other Bodies in
the Air, becau&longs;e it would there be heavi-
er then that which &longs;urrounds it, as are
gro&longs;&longs;er Bodies we commonly weigh, then
the medium or ambient Air.

Where-
fore, though we have above declin'd to
affirm, that our Receiver, when empty-
ed, de&longs;erves the name of a true Vacuum,
and though we cannot yet perfectly free
it from Air it &longs;elf, yet we thought fit to
try how far the Air would manife&longs;t its
gravity in &longs;o thin a medium, as we could
make in our Receiver, by evacuating it.

We cau&longs;'d then to be blown at the Flame
of a Lamp, a Gla&longs;s-bubble of about
the bigne&longs;s of a small Hen egge, and of
an Oval form, &longs;ave that at one end there
was drawn out an exceeding flender Pipe,
that the Bubble might be &longs;eal'd up, with
as little rarifaction as might be, of the
Air included in the great or ovall Cavi-
ty of it.

This Gla&longs;s being &longs;eal'd, was fa-
&longs;tened to one of the Scales of the exact
pair of Ballances formerly mention'd;
and being counterpoi&longs;'d with a weight of
Lead, was convey'd into the Receiver,
and clo&longs;'d up in it.

The Beam appearing
to continue Horizontal, the Pump was &longs;et
awork, and there &longs;carce pa&longs;t above two
or three Ex&longs;uctions of the Air, before
the Ballance lo&longs;t its Aequilibrium, and
began to incline to that &longs;ide on which
the Bubble was; which, as the Air was
further and further drawn out, did mani-
fe&longs;tly more and more preponderate, till
he that pump'd began to grow weary of
his Imployment: after which the aire be-
ing lea&longs;urely let in againe, the &longs;cales by
degrees returned to their former Aequili-
brium.

After that we tooke them out, and
ca&longs;ting into that &longs;cale to which the lead
belong'd three quarters of a grain, we
convey'd the ballance into the Recei-
ver, which being clo&longs;ed up, and exhau-
&longs;ted as before, we ob&longs;erv'd, that as the
aire was drawne out more and more, &longs;o
the gla&longs;&longs;e bubble came neerer and neer-
er to an Aequilibrium with the other
weight, till at length the beame was
drawne to hang horizontall; which (as
we had found by another tryall) wee
could not bring it to do, when a quar-
ter of a Graine more was added to
the &longs;cale, to which the lead belong'd:
though it &longs;eem'd que&longs;tionle&longs;&longs;e, that if
wee could have perfectly empty'd the
Receiver of the contain'd aire, that in-
cluded, in the bubble would have weigh-
ed above a grain, notwith&longs;tanding its
having been probably &longs;omewhat Rari-
fy'd by the flame by the help of which,
the bubble was &longs;eald up.

Let us adde,
that on the regre&longs;&longs;e of the excluded
air, the Lead, and the weight ca&longs;t into the
&longs;ame &longs;cale, did againe very much pre-
ponderate.

Experi-
ment 36.

We likewi&longs;e convey'd into the Re-
ceiver, the &longs;ame bubble, open'd at
the end of the flender pipe above men-
tioned, but having drawne out the aire,
after the accu&longs;tomed manner, we found
not as before, the bubble to out-weigh
the oppo&longs;ite lead, &longs;o that by the help
of our Engine, we can weigh the Aire,
as we weigh other Bodies, in its na-
turall or ordinary con&longs;i&longs;tence, without
at all conden&longs;ing it: Nay, which is re-
markable, having convey'd a Lamb's
bladder about halfe full of Aire into the
Receiver, wee ob&longs;erved, that though
upon the drawing out of the ambient
aire the impri&longs;oned Air &longs;o expended
it &longs;elf, as to di&longs;tend the Bladder &longs;o, as to
&longs;eem ready to break it, yet this rarified
Air did manife&longs;tly depre&longs;s the Scale
whereunto it was annexed.

Another thing, we mu&longs;t not forget to
mention, that happend to us, whil'&longs;t we were
making tryals concerning the weight of the
Air; namely, That having once cau&longs;'d the
Pump to be &longs;omewhat ob&longs;tinately ply'd,
to di&longs;cover the better what may be ex-
pected from the thinne&longs;s of the medium
in this Experiment; the Impri&longs;on'd Air
broke its brittle Pri&longs;on, and throwing the
greate&longs;t part of it again&longs;t the &longs;ide of the
Receiver, da&longs;h'd it again&longs;t that thick Gla&longs;s
into a multitude of pieces.

Which Acci-
dent I mention, partly that it may con-
firm what we deliver'd in our Reflections,
upon the fir&longs;t Experiment, where we con-
&longs;ider'd what would probably be done by
the Spring of Air Impri&longs;on'd in &longs;uch
Gla&longs;&longs;es, in ca&longs;e the ballancing pre&longs;&longs;ure of
the ambient Air were withdrawn; and
partly, that we may thence di&longs;cern of how
clo&longs;e a Texture Gla&longs;s is, &longs;ince &longs;o very
thin a film of Gla&longs;s (if I may &longs;o call it)
prov'd &longs;o impervious to the Air, that it
could not get away through the Pores,
but was forc'd to break the gla&longs;s in pieces
to free it &longs;elf; and this, notwith&longs;tanding
the time and advantage it had to try to
get out at the Pores.

And this I mention,
that neitherour Experiments, nor tho&longs;e
of divers Learned Men, might receive
any prejudice from an Experiment which
I happen'd to make divers years ago, and,
which having been &longs;o much taken notice
of by curious Men, may be drawn to
countenance their erroneous Opinion, who
would fain per&longs;wade us, That Gla&longs;s is
penetrable by Air properly &longs;o called.

Our
Experiment was briefly this: We were
di&longs;tilling a certain &longs;ub&longs;tance, that much a-
bounded with &longs;ubtle Spirits and volatile
Salt, in a &longs;trong Earthen-ve&longs;&longs;el of an un-
u&longs;ual &longs;hape, to which was luted a large
Receiver, made of the cour&longs;er &longs;ort of
Gla&longs;s, (which the Trades-men are wont
to call Green-gla&longs;s) but in our ab&longs;ence,
the Fire, though it were to be very &longs;trong,
was by the negligence or mi&longs;take of tho&longs;e
we appointed to attend it, &longs;o exce&longs;&longs;ively
increa&longs;'d, that when we came back to the
Fornace we found the Spirituous and Sa-
line Corpu&longs;cles pour'd out (if I may &longs;o
call it) &longs;o hot, and &longs;o copiou&longs;ly into the
Receiver, that they made it all opacous,
and more likely to flie in pieces, then fit
to be touch'd.

Yet, being curious to ob-
&longs;erve the effects of a Di&longs;tillation, pr&longs;e-
cuted with &longs;o inten&longs;e and unu&longs;ual degree
of heat, we ventur'd to come near, and
ob&longs;erv'd among other things, that on the
out-&longs;ide of the Receiver, at a great di-
&longs;tance from the juncture, there was &longs;etled
a round whiti&longs;h Spot or two, which at
fir&longs;t we thought might be &longs;ome &longs;tain up­
on the Gla&longs;s; but after, finding it to
be in divers Qualities like the Oyl,
and Salt of the Concrete we were Di­
&longs;tilling, we began to &longs;u&longs;pect that the
mo&longs;t &longs;ubtle and fugitive parts of the im­
petuou&longs;ly a&longs;cending Steams, had pene­
trated the &longs;ub&longs;tance (as they &longs;peak) of
the Gla&longs;s, and by the cold of the am­
bient Air were conden&longs;'d on the &longs;ur­
face of it.

And though we were ve­
ry backward to credit this &longs;u&longs;pition, and
therefore call'd in an Ingenious Per&longs;on
or two, both to a&longs;&longs;i&longs;t us in the Ob­
&longs;ervation, and have Witne&longs;s of its e­
vent, we continued a while longer to
watch the e&longs;cape of &longs;uch unctuous Fumes,
and upon the whole matter unanimou&longs;ly
concluded, That all things con&longs;ider'd,
the &longs;ubtle parts of the di&longs;till'd matter
being violently agitated, by the exce&longs;­
&longs;ive heat had pa&longs;&longs;'d through the Pores
of the Gla&longs;s, widen'd by the &longs;ame heat.

But this having never happen'd but
once in any of the Di&longs;tillations we have
either made or &longs;een, though the&longs;e be
not a few, it is much more rea&longs;onable
to &longs;uppo&longs;e, that the perviou&longs;ne&longs;s of
our Receiver to a Body much more
&longs;ubtle then Air, proceeded partly from
the loo&longs;er Texture of that particular
parcel of Gla&longs;s the Receiver was made
of (for Experience has taught us, that
all Gla&longs;s is not of the &longs;ame compact­
ne&longs;s and &longs;olidity) and partly from the
enormous heat, which, together with
the vehement agitation of the pene­
trant Spirits, open'd the Pores of the
Gla&longs;s; then to imagine that &longs;uch a
&longs;ub&longs;tance as Air, &longs;hould be able to per­
meate the Body of Gla&longs;s contrary to
the te&longs;timony of a thou&longs;and Chymical
and Mechanical Experiments, and of
many of tho&longs;e made in our Engine, e­
&longs;pecially that newly recited: Nay, by
our fifth Experiment it appears, that
a thin Bladder will not at its Pores
give pa&longs;&longs;age even to rarified Air.

And
on this occa&longs;ion we will annex an Ex­
periment, which has made &longs;ome of
tho&longs;e we have acquainted with it,
doubt, whether the Corpu&longs;cles of the
Air be not le&longs;&longs;e &longs;ubtle then tho&longs;e of
Water.

But without examining here the
rea&longs;onablene&longs;&longs;e of that doubt, we will
proceed to recite the Experiment it &longs;elf,
which &longs;eems to teach, That though Air,
when &longs;ufficiently compre&longs;&longs;'d, may per­
chance get entrance into narrower holes
and crannies then Water; yet unle&longs;s the
Air be forc'd in at &longs;uch very little holes,
it will not get in at them, though they
may be big enough to let Water pa&longs;s
through them.

The Experiment then was this: I took
a fair Gla&longs;s Siphon, the lower end of
who&longs;e longe&longs;t Leg was drawn by degrees
to &longs;uch a &longs;lenderne&longs;s, that the Orifice, at
which the Water was to fall out, would
hardly admit a very &longs;mall Pin: This Si­
phon being inverted, the matter was &longs;o
order'd, that a little Bubble of Air was
intercepted in the &longs;lendere&longs;t part of the
Siphon, betwixt the little hole newly men­
tion'd, and the incumbent Water, upon
which, it came to pa&longs;s, that the Air be­
ing not to be forc'd through &longs;o narrow a
pa&longs;&longs;age, by &longs;o light a Cylinder of Water,
though amounting to the length of divers
Inches, as lean'd upon it, hinder'd the
further Efflux of the Water, as long as I
plea&longs;'d to let it &longs;tay in that narrow place:
whereas, when by blowing a little at the
wider end of the Siphon, that little par­
cel of Air was forc'd out with &longs;ome Wa­
ter, the remaining Water, that before
continu'd &longs;u&longs;pended, began freely to drop
down again as formerly.

And if you
take a Gla&longs;s Pipe, whether it be in the
form of a Siphon, or no, that being for
the mo&longs;t part of the thickne&longs;s of a Mans
Finger, is yet towards one end &longs;o &longs;len­
der, as to terminate in a hole almo&longs;t as
&longs;mall as a Hor&longs;e-hair; and if you fill this
Pipe with Water, you will finde that Li­
quor to drop down freely enough tho­
row the &longs;lender Extream: But if you then
invert the Pipe, you will finde that the
Air will not ea&longs;ily get in at the &longs;ame hole
through which the Water pa&longs;&longs;'d.

For in
the &longs;harp end of the Pipe, &longs;ome Inches
of Water will remain &longs;u&longs;pended, which
'tis probable would not happen, if the
Air could get in to &longs;ucceed it, &longs;ince if the
hole were a little wider, the Water would
immediatly &longs;ub&longs;ide.

And though it be
true, that if the Pipe be of the length of
many Inches, a great part of the Wa­
ter will run down at the wider Orifice, yet
that &longs;eems to happen for &longs;ome other rea­
&longs;on, then becau&longs;e the Air &longs;ucceeds it at
the upper and narrow Orifice, &longs;ince all the
&longs;lender part of the Pipe, and perhaps
&longs;ome Inches more, will continue full of
Water.

And on this occa&longs;ion I remember, that
whereas it appears by our fifth Experi­
ment, That the Aërial Corpu&longs;cles (ex­
cept perhaps &longs;ome that are extraordinari­
ly fine) will not pa&longs;&longs;e thorow the Pores
of a Lambs Bladder, yet Particles of Wa­
ter will, as we have long &longs;ince ob&longs;erv'd,
and as may be ea&longs;ily try'd, by very clo&longs;e­
ly tying a little Alcalizate Salt (we u&longs;'d
the Calx of Tartar, made with Nitre)
in a fine Bladder, and dipping the lower
end of the Bladder in Water; for if you
hold it there for a competent while, you
will finde that there will &longs;train thorow the
Pores of the Bladder Water enough to
di&longs;&longs;olve the Salt into a Liquor.

But I &longs;ee I am &longs;lipt into a Digre&longs;&longs;ion,
wherefore I will not examine, whether,
the Experiment I have related, proceed­
ed from hence, That the &longs;pringy Texture
of the Corpu&longs;cles of the Air, makes
them le&longs;s apt to yield and accommodate
them&longs;elves ea&longs;ily to the narrow Pores of
Bodies, then the more flexible Particles
of Water; or whether it may more pro­
babiy be a&longs;crib'd to &longs;ome other Cau&longs;e.

Nor will I &longs;tay to con&longs;ider how far we may
hence be a&longs;&longs;i&longs;ted to ghe&longs;s at the cau&longs;e of
the a&longs;cen&longs;ion of Water in the &longs;lender
Pipes and Siphons formerly mention'd,
but will return to our Bubble; and take
notice, That we thought fit al&longs;o to en­
deavor to mea&longs;ure the capacity of the
Bubble we had made u&longs;e of, by filling
it with Water, that we might the better
know how much Water an&longs;wered in
weight to 3/4 of a Grain of Air, but not­
with&longs;tanding all the diligence that was
u&longs;ed to pre&longs;erve &longs;o brittle a Ve&longs;&longs;el, it
broke before we could perfect what we
were about, and we were not then pro­
vided of another Bubble fit for our
turn.

The ha&longs;te I was in, My Lord, when I
&longs;ent away the la&longs;t Sheet, made me forget
to take notice to you of a Problem that
occurr'd to my thoughts, upon the oc­
ca&longs;ion of the &longs;low breaking of the Gla&longs;s
Bubble in our evacuated Receiver.

For
it may &longs;eem &longs;trange, &longs;ince by our &longs;ixth
Experiment it appears, that the Air, when
permitted, will by its own internal Spring
expand it &longs;elfe twice as much as Mer­
&longs;ennus was able to expand it, by the
heat even of a candent Æolipile: Yet
the Elater of the Air was &longs;carce able to
break a very thin Gla&longs;s Bubble, and ut-
terly unable to break one &longs;omewhat thic­
ker, within who&longs;e cavity it was impri­
&longs;on'd; whereas Air pent up and agitated
by heat is able to perform &longs;o much more
con&longs;iderable effects, that (not to mention
tho&longs;e of Rarefaction that are more obvi­
ous) the Learned Je&longs;uit Cabæus (he that
writ of the Load-&longs;tone) relates, That he
&longs;aw a Marble Pillar (&longs;o va&longs;t, that three
men together with di&longs;play'd arms could
not imbrace it, and that 1000 Yoke of
Oxen drawing it &longs;everal ways with all
their &longs;trength, could not have torn it
a&longs;&longs;under) quite broken off in the mid&longs;t,
by rea&longs;on of &longs;ome Wood, which hap­
pening to be burnt ju&longs;t by the Pillar, the
heat proceeding from the neighboring
Fire, &longs;o rarified &longs;ome Air or Spirituous
Matter which was &longs;hut up in the cavities
of the Marble, that it broke through the
&longs;olid Body of the Stone to obtain room
to expand it &longs;elf.

Meteo A­

I remember I have taken notice that
probably the rea&longs;on why the included Air
did not break the hermetically &longs;eal'd Bub­
bles that remain'd intire in our emptyed
Receiver, was, That the Air, being &longs;ome­
what rarefied by the Flame imploy'd to
clo&longs;e the Gla&longs;s, its Spring, upon the re-
ce&longs;s of the heat, grew weaker then before.

But though we reject not that ghe&longs;s, yet
it will not in the pre&longs;ent ca&longs;e &longs;erve the
turn, becau&longs;e that much &longs;maller Gla&longs;s
bubbles exactly clo&longs;'d, will, by the in­
cluded Air (though agitated but by the
heat of a very moderate Fire) be made
to fly in pieces.

Whether we may be
a&longs;&longs;i&longs;ted to &longs;alve this Problem, by con&longs;i­
dering that the heat does from within ve­
hemently agitate the Corpu&longs;cles of the
Air, and adde its a&longs;&longs;i&longs;tance to the Spring
they had before, I &longs;hall not now examine:
&longs;ince I here but propo&longs;e a Problem, and
that chiefly that by this memorable Story
of Cabæus, notice may be taken of the
prodigious power of Rarefaction, which
hereby appears capable of performing
&longs;tranger things then any of our Experi­
ments have hitherto a&longs;crib'd to it.

We &longs;hould hence, My Lord, imme­
diatly proceed to the next Experiment,
but that we think it fit, on this occa&longs;ion,
to acquaint You with what &longs;ome former
tryals (though not made in our Engine)
have taught us, concerning what we
would have di&longs;cover'd by the newly
mention'd Bubble that broke.

And this
the rather, becau&longs;e (a great part of this
letter &longs;uppo&longs;ing the gravity of the Aire)
it will not be impertinent to determine
more particularly then hitherto we have
done, what gravity we a&longs;cribe to it.

We tooke then an Æolipile made of
copper, weighing &longs;ix ounces, five drachms,
and eight and forty graines: this being
made as hot as we dur&longs;t make it, (for feare
of melting the mettle, or at lea&longs;t the So­
dar) was removed from the fire and im­
mediately &longs;topped with hard wax that no
Aire at all might get in at the little
hole wont to be left in Æolipiles for the
fumes to i&longs;&longs;ue out at: Then the Æolipile
being &longs;uffer'd lea&longs;urely to coole was again
weighed together with the wax that &longs;topt
it, and was found to weigh (by rea&longs;on of
the additionall weight of the wax) &longs;ix
ounces, &longs;ixe drachmes, and 39 graines.

La&longs;tly, the wax being perforated without
taking any of it out of the Scale, the
externall Aire was &longs;uffered to ru&longs;h in
(which it did with &longs;ome noy&longs;e) and then
the Æolipile and wax, being againe
weighed amounted to &longs;ix ounces, &longs;ix
drachmes, and 50. graines.

So that the
Æolipile freed as farre as our fire could
free it, from it's Aire, weighed le&longs;&longs;e then
it &longs;elfe when repleni&longs;hed with Air, full
eleven graines.

That is, the Air contain­
able within the cavity of the Æolipile a­
mounted to eleven graines and &longs;omewhat
more; I &longs;ay &longs;omewhat more, becau&longs;e of
the particles of the Air, that were not
driven by the fire out of the Æolipile.
And by the way (if there be no mi&longs;take
in the ob&longs;ervations of the diligent Mer­
&longs;ennus) it may &longs;eeme &longs;trange that it &longs;hould
&longs;o much differ from 2. or 3. of ours; in
none of which we could rarifie the Air in
our Æolipile (though made red hot almo&longs;t
all over, and &longs;o immediately plung'd into
cold water) to halfe that degree which he
mentions, namely to 70. times it's natu­
rall extent, unle&longs;&longs;e it were that the Æo­
lipile he imploy'd was able to &longs;u&longs;taine
a more vehement heat then ours (which
yet we kept in &longs;o great an one, that once
the &longs;oder melting, it fell a&longs;under into the
two Hemi&longs;pheres it con&longs;i&longs;ts of.)

The fore-mentioned way of weighing
the Air by the help of an Æolipile, &longs;eems
&longs;omewhat more exact then that which
Mer&longs;ennus u&longs;ed, In that in ours the Æoli­
pile was not weighed, till it was cold;
whereas in his, being weighed red hot, it
&longs;ubject to loo&longs;e of it's &longs;nb&longs;tance in the
cooling, for (as we have el&longs;ewhere noted
on another occa&longs;ion) Copper heated red
hot is wont in the cooling to throw off
little thin &longs;cales in &longs;uch plenty, that having
purpo&longs;ely watcht a Copper Æolipile du­
ring its refrigeration, we have &longs;een the
place round about it almo&longs;t covered with
tho&longs;e little &longs;cales it had every way &longs;cat­
ter'd: which, however they amount not
to much, ought not to be over-looked,
when 'tis &longs;o light a body as Air, that is
to be weighed.

We will not examine,
whether the Æolipile in cooling may not
receive &longs;ome little increment of weight,
either from the vapid or &longs;aline Steames
that wander up and downe in the Air: But
we will rather mention, that (for the grea­
ter exactne&longs;&longs;e) we imployed to weigh our
Æolipile, both when fill'd onely with Air
and when repleni&longs;ht with Water, a paire
of &longs;cales that would turne (as they &longs;peak)
with the fourth part of a grain.

As to the proportion of weight be­
twixt Air and Water, &longs;ome learned men
have attempted it by wayes &longs;o unaccurate
that they &longs;eeme to have much mi&longs;taken
it.

For (not to mention the improbable
accounts of Kepler and others.) The lear-
ned and diligent Ricciolus, having pur­
po&longs;ely endeavoured to inve&longs;tigate this
proportion by meanes of a thin blad­
der, e&longs;timates the weight of the Air to
that of the Water to be as one to ten
thou&longs;and, or thereabouts.

And indeed I re­
member that having formerly, on a cer­
tain occa&longs;ion, weighed a large bladder full
of Air, and found it when the Air was all
&longs;quee&longs;ed out, to have contained fourteen
graines of Air.

I found the &longs;ame bladder
afterwards fill'd with water to containe
very neer 14. pound of that liquor: accor­
ding to which account, the proportion of
Air to Water was almo&longs;t as a graine to a
pound, that is, as one to above 7600. To
this we may adde, that on the other &longs;ide,
Galileo him&longs;elfe u&longs;ing another, but an un­
accurate way too, defined the Air to be
in weight to Water, but as one to 4. hun­
dred.

But the way formerly propo&longs;ed of
weighing the Air by an Æolipile, &longs;eemes
by great oddes more exact; and (as farre
as we could ghe&longs;&longs;e) &longs;eemed to agree well
enough with the experiment made in our
Receiver.

Wherefore it will be be&longs;t to
tru&longs;t our Æolipile in the enquiry we are a­
bout, and according to our ob&longs;ervations
the water it contained amounting to one
and twenty ounces and an halfe, and as
much Air as was requi&longs;ite to fill it weigh­
ing eleven graines, the proportion in gra­
vity of Air to Water of the &longs;ame bulk
will be as one to 938. And though we
could not fill the Æolipile with water, &longs;o
exactly as we would, yet in regard we
could not either as perfectly as we would,
drive the Air out of it by heat; we think
the proportion may well enough hold:
but tho&longs;e that are delighted with round
numbers (as the phra&longs;e is) will not be
much mi&longs;taken if they reckon water to be
neere a thou&longs;and times heavier than Air.

And (for further proof that we have made
the proportion betwixt the&longs;e two bodies
rather greater then le&longs;&longs;er then indeed it is;
and al&longs;o to confirme our former ob&longs;erva­
tion of the weight of the Air) we will adde,
That, having another time put &longs;ome Wa­
ter into the Æolipile before we &longs;et it on
the fire, that the copious vapours of the
rarefied liquor might the better drive out
the Air, we found, upon try all carefully
made, that when the Æolipile was refrige­
rated, and the included vapours were by
the cold turned againe into water (which
could not have happen'd to the Air, that
the preceeding Steams expell'd) the Air,
when it was let in, increa&longs;'d the weight of
the Æolipile as much as before, namely,
Eleven Grains; though there were alrea­
dy in it twelve Drachmes and a half, be­
&longs;ides a couple of Grains of Water, which
remain'd of that we had formerly put in­
to it to drive out the Air.

Mer&longs;ennus indeed tells us, that by his
account Air is in weight to Water, as 1 to
1356. And adds, that we may, without
any danger, believe that the gravity of
Water to that of Air of a like bulk, is
not le&longs;s then of 1300 to 1. And con&longs;e­
quently, that the quantity of Air to a
quantity of Water equiponderant there­
to, is as 1300 to 1. But why we &longs;hould
relinqui&longs;h our own carefully repeated try­
als, I &longs;ee not.

Yet I am unwilling to re­
ject tho&longs;e of &longs;o accurate and u&longs;eful a Wri­
ter: And therefore &longs;hall propo&longs;e a way
of reconciling our differing Ob&longs;ervations,
by pre&longs;enting, that the di&longs;crepance be­
tween them may probably ari&longs;e from the
differing con&longs;i&longs;tence of the Air at London
and at Paris: For our Air being more cold
and moi&longs;t, then that which Your Lord­
&longs;hip now breaths, may be &longs;uppo&longs;'d al&longs;o
to be a fourth or fifth part more heavy.

I
leave it to be con&longs;ider'd, whether it be of
any moment that our Ob&longs;ervations were
made in the mid&longs;t of Winter, whereas his
were perhaps made in &longs;ome warmer time
of the Year.

But I think it were not a­
mi&longs;s that, by the method formerly pro­
po&longs;'d, the gravity of the Air were ob­
&longs;erv'd both in &longs;everal Countries, and in
the &longs;ame Country, in the &longs;everal Sea&longs;ons
of the Year and differing Temperatures of
the Weather.

And I would give &longs;ome­
thing of value to know the weight of &longs;uch
an Æolipile as ours full of air in the mid&longs;t
of Winter in Nova Zembla, if that be
true which we formerly took notice of,
namely, That the Hollanders, who Win­
tered there, found that Air &longs;o thick that
their Clock would not go.

If Your Lord&longs;hip &longs;hould now ask me,
if I could not by the help of the&longs;e, and
our other Ob&longs;ervations, decide the Con­
trover&longs;ies of our Modern Mathematici­
ans about the height of the Air or Atmo­
&longs;phere, by determining how high it doth
indeed reach: I &longs;hould an&longs;wer, That
though it &longs;eems ea&longs;ie enough to &longs;hew that
divers Famous and Applauded Writers
have been mi&longs;taken in a&longs;&longs;igning the heigth
of the Atmo&longs;phere: Yet it &longs;eems very
difficult preci&longs;ely to define of what height
it is.

And becau&longs;e we have hitherto but
lightly touch'd upon a matter of &longs;uch im­
portance, we pre&longs;ume it wil not be thought
impertinent, upon this occa&longs;ion, to annex
&longs;omething towards the Elucidation of
it.

What we have already try'd and newly
&longs;et down, allows us to take it for granted,
that (at lea&longs;t about London) the propor­
tion of gravity betwixt Water and Air,
of equal bulk, is as of a thou&longs;and to
one.

The next thing therefore that we are
to enquire after, in order to our pre&longs;ent
de&longs;ign, is the difference in weight betwixt
Water and Quick-&longs;ilver: And though
this hath been defin'd already by the Il­
lu&longs;trious Verulam, and &longs;ome other inqui­
&longs;itive Per&longs;ons, that have compar'd the
weight of &longs;everal Bodies, and ca&longs;t their
Ob&longs;ervations into Tables, yet we &longs;hall
not &longs;cruple to annex our own tryals about
it: Partly, becau&longs;e we finde Authors
con&longs;iderably to di&longs;-agree; partly, becau&longs;e
we u&longs;'d exacter Scales, and a &longs;omewhat
more wary method then others &longs;eem to
have done: And partly al&longs;o, becau&longs;e ha­
ving pro&longs;ecuted our inquiry by two or
three &longs;everal ways; the &longs;mall difference
between the events may a&longs;&longs;ure us that we
were not much mi&longs;taken.

We took then a Gla&longs;s Pipe, of the
form of an inverted Siphon, who&longs;e &longs;hape
is delineated in the &longs;ixteenth Figure: And
pouring into it a quantity of Quick &longs;ilver,

Liquor, both in the longer and &longs;horter

the Scheme by the prick'd Line EF; then
pouring Water into the longer Leg of the

&longs;erv'd the &longs;urface of the Quick-&longs;ilver in
that leg to be, by the weight of the Wa­

the &longs;horter leg, to be as much impell'd
upward as from F to G: Whereupon ha­
ving formerly &longs;tuck marks, as well at the

mealur d both the di&longs;tance DC to have

in the other leg) by the weight of the Wa­

So
that the di&longs;tance DC amounting to (2 12/54)
Inches, and the height of the Water a­
mounting (30 45/50) Inches; and the whole
numbers on both &longs;ides, which the annex­
ed Fractions being reduc'd to improper
Fractions of the &longs;ame denomination, the
proportion appear'd to be (the denomi­
nators beng left out as equal on both &longs;ides)
as 121 to 1665; or by reduction, as one
to (13 92/121).

Be&longs;ides this unu&longs;ual way of determi­
ning the gravity of &longs;ome things, we mea­
&longs;ur'd the proportion betwixt Quick-&longs;ilver
and Water, by the help of &longs;o exact a bal­
lance, as loo&longs;es its Æquilibrium by the
hundredth part of a Grain.

But becau&longs;e
there is wont to be committed an over­
&longs;ight in weighing Quick-&longs;ilver and Wa­
ter, e&longs;pecially if the Orifice of the Ve&longs;&longs;el
wherein they are put be any thing wide, in
regard that men heed not that the &longs;urface
of Water in Ve&longs;&longs;els will be concave,
but that of Quick-&longs;ilver, notably convex
or protuberant: To avoid this u&longs;ual over­
&longs;ight (I &longs;ay) we made u&longs;e of a gla&longs;s bubble,
blown very thin at the Flame of a Lamp,
that it might not be too heavy for the
Ballance, and terminating in a very &longs;lender
neck, wherein the concavity or convexity
of a Liquor could not be con&longs;iderable:
This Gla&longs;s weighing 23 1/2 Grains, we fill'd
almo&longs;t with Quick-&longs;ilver, and fa&longs;tning a
mark over again&longs;t the middle of the pro­
tuberant Superficies as near as our Eyes
could judge, we found that the Quick­
&longs;ilver alone weighed 299 1/32 Grains: Then
the Quick-&longs;ilver being pour'd out, and
the &longs;ame Gla&longs;s being fill'd as full of com­
mon Water, we found the Liquor to
weigh 21 7/8 Grains.

Whereby it appear'd
that the weight of Water to Quick­
&longs;ilver, is as one to (13 19/28): Though our Il­
lu&longs;trious Verulam (que&longs;tionle&longs;s not for
want of Judgement or Care, but of ex­
act In&longs;truments) makes the proportion
betwixt tho&longs;e two Liquors to be greater
then of 1 to 17. And to adde, that up­
on the by, &longs;ince Quick-&longs;ilver and well
rectified Spirit of Wine, are (how ju&longs;tly
I &longs;ay not) accounted, the one the hea­
vie&longs;t, and the other the lighte&longs;t of Li­
quors; we thought to fill in the &longs;ame
Gla&longs;s, and with the &longs;ame Scales to ob­
&longs;erve the difference betwixt them, which
we found to be as of 1 to (16 641/1084); where­
by it appear'd, That the difference be­
twixt Spirit of Wine, that may be made
to burn all away, (&longs;uch as was ours) and
common Water, is as betwixt 1 and (1 44/171)

We might here take occa&longs;ion to ad­
mire, that though Water (as appear'd by
the Experiment formerly mention'd of
the Pewter Ve&longs;&longs;el) &longs;eems not capable of
any con&longs;iderable conden&longs;ation, and &longs;eems
not to have inter&longs;per&longs;'d in it any &longs;tore of
Air; yet Quick-&longs;ilver, of no greater bulk
then Water, &longs;hould weigh near fourteen
times as much.

But having onely point­
ed at this as a thing worthy of con&longs;idera­
tion, we will proceed in our inquiry after
the heigth of the Atmo&longs;phere: And to
avoid the trouble of Fractions, we will
a&longs;&longs;ume that Quick-&longs;ilver is fourteen times
as heavy as Water, &longs;ince it wants &longs;o little
of being &longs;o.

Wherefore having now given us the
proportion of Air to Water, and Water
to Quick-&longs;ilver, it will be very ea&longs;ie to
finde the proportion betwixt Air and
Quick-&longs;ilver, in ca&longs;e we will &longs;uppo&longs;e the
Atmo&longs;phere to be uniformly of &longs;uch a
con&longs;i&longs;tence as the Air we weighed here
below.

For &longs;ince our Engine hath &longs;uffi­
ciently manife&longs;ted that 'tis the Æquili­
brium with the external Air, that in the
Torricellian Experiment keeps the Quick­
&longs;ilver from &longs;ub&longs;iding; And &longs;ince, by our
accurate Experiment formerly mention'd,
it appears that a Cylinder of Mercury,
able to ballance a Cylinder of the whole
Atmo&longs;phere, amounted to near about
thirty Inches; and &longs;ince, con&longs;equently
we may a&longs;&longs;ume the proportion of Quick­
&longs;ilver to Air to be as fourteen thou&longs;and to
one; it will follow, that a Cylinder of
Air, capable to maintain an Æquilibrium,
with a Mercurial Cylinder of two Foot
and an half in height, mu&longs;t amount to
35000 Feet of our Engli&longs;h Mea&longs;ure;
and con&longs;equently (reckoning five Foot
to a Geometrical Pace, and one thou&longs;and
&longs;uch Paces to a Mile) to &longs;even full
Miles.

But this (as we lately intimated) pro­
ceeds upon the &longs;uppo&longs;ition, that the Air
is every where of the &longs;ame con&longs;i&longs;tence
that we found it near the &longs;urface of the
Earth; but that cannot with any &longs;afety
be concluded, not onely for the rea&longs;on I
finde to have been taken notice of by the
Antients, and thus expre&longs;t in Seneca:
Omnis Aër (&longs;ays he) quo propior e&longs;t terris
hoc cra&longs;sior; quemadmodum in aqua & in
omni humore fæx ima e&longs;t, it a in Aëre &longs;pi&longs;­
&longs;ißima quæ&queacute; de&longs;idunt; but much more,
becau&longs;e the &longs;pringy Texture of the Aërial
Corpu&longs;cles, makes them capable of a
very great compre&longs;&longs;ion, which the weight
of the incumbent part of the Atmo­
&longs;phere is very &longs;ufficient to give tho&longs;e that
be undermo&longs;t and near the &longs;urface of the
Earth.

And if we recall to minde tho&longs;e
former Experiments, whereby we have
manife&longs;ted, That Air, much rarefied with­
out heat, may ea&longs;ily admit a further ra­
refaction from heat; and that the Air, even
without being expanded by heat, is capa­
ble of being rarefied to above one hundred
and fifty times the extent it u&longs;ually po&longs;­
&longs;e&longs;&longs;es here below; How can it be demon­
&longs;trated that the Atmo&longs;phere may not, for
ought we know, or at lea&longs;t for ought can
be determin'd by our Statical and Mecha­
nical Experiments, ri&longs;e to the height of
Five and twenty German Leagues, if not
of &longs;ome hundred of common Miles?

And this conjecture it &longs;elf may appear
very injurious to the height whereunto
Exhalations may a&longs;cend, if we will allow
that there was no mi&longs;take in that &longs;trange
Ob&longs;ervation made at Tolous in a clear
Night in Augu&longs;t, by the diligent Ma­
thematician Emanuel Magnan, and thus
Recorded by Ricciolus, (for I have not at
hand the Authors own Book) Vidit (&longs;ays
he) ab hor a undecima po&longs;t meridiem u&longs;&queacute; ad
mediam noctem Lunâ infra horizontem
po&longs;itâ, nubeculam quandam lucidam prope
Meridianum fere u&longs;que ad Zenith diffu&longs;am
quæ con&longs;ider at is omnibus non poter at ni&longs;i à
&longs;ole illuminari; ideoque altior e&longs;&longs;e debuit
tota umbr a terræ.

Addit (continues Ricci­
olus) &longs;imile quid eveni&longs;&longs;e Michaeli Angelo
Riccio apud Sabinos ver&longs;anti nempe viro
in Mathe&longs;i eruditi&longs;simo.

Various Ob&longs;ervations made at the
feet, tops, and interjacent parts of high
Mountains, might perchance &longs;omewhat
a&longs;&longs;i&longs;t us to make an e&longs;timate in what pro­
portion, if in any certain one, the higher
Air is thicker then the lower, and ghe&longs;s
at the di&longs;-form con&longs;i&longs;tence, as to laxity
and compactne&longs;s of the Air at &longs;everal
di&longs;tances from us.

And if the difficul­
ties about the refractions of the Cele&longs;tial
Lights, were &longs;atisfactorily determin'd,
that might al&longs;o much conduce to the pla­
cing due limits to the Atmo&longs;phere (who&longs;e
Dimen&longs;ions tho&longs;e Ob&longs;ervations about
Refractions &longs;eem hitherto much to con­
tract.) But for the pre&longs;ent we dare not
pronounce any thing peremptorily con­
cerning the height of it, but leave it to
further inquiry: contenting our &longs;elves to
have manife&longs;ted the mi&longs;take of divers
eminent Modern Writers, who will not
allow the Atmo&longs;phere to exceed above
two or three Miles in height (as the Fa­
mous Kepler will not the Aër refractivus)
and to have rendred a rea&longs;on why in the
mention we made in the Notes upon the
fir&longs;t Experiment, touching the height of
the Atmo&longs;phere, we &longs;crupled not to &longs;peak
of it, as if it might be many Miles high.

WE will now proceed to recite a
Phænomenon, which, though
made among&longs;t the fir&longs;t, we thought fit
not to mention till after many others, that
we might have the opportunity to ob­
&longs;erve as many Circum&longs;tances of it as we
could, and &longs;o pre&longs;ent Your Lord&longs;hip at
once, mo&longs;t of what we at &longs;everal times
have taken notice of concerning &longs;o odde
a Phænomenon.

Experi­
ment 37.

Our Engine had not been long fini&longs;h'd,
when, at the fir&longs;t lea&longs;ure we could &longs;teal
from our occa&longs;ions to make tryal of it,
we cau&longs;'d the Air to be pump'd out of
the Receiver; and whil'&longs;t I was bu&longs;ied in
entertaining a Learned Friend that ju&longs;t
then came to vi&longs;it me, an Ingenious By-
&longs;tander, thought he perceiv'd &longs;ome new
kind of Light in the Receiver, of which
giving me ha&longs;tily notice, my Friend and
I pre&longs;ently ob&longs;erv'd, that when the Suc­
ker was drawn down, immediately upon
the turning of the Key, there appear'd
a kinde of Light in the Receiver, almo&longs;t
like a faint fla&longs;h of Lightening in the
Day-time, and almo&longs;t as &longs;uddenly did it
appear and vani&longs;h.

Having, not with­
out &longs;ome amazement, ob&longs;erv'd divers
of the&longs;e Apparitions of Light, we took
notice that the Day was clear, the hour
about ten in the Morning, that the onely
Window in the Room fac'd the North;
and al&longs;o, that by interpo&longs;ing a Cloak, or
any opacous Body between the Receiver
and the Window, though the re&longs;t of the
Room were &longs;ufficiently enlightned, yet

But not being able on all the&longs;e Circum­
&longs;tances to ground any firm Conjecture

the Pump, as in the Morning, we could

lea&longs;t glimmering of Light; whence we

Receiver, did not proceed from any new

&longs;hould proceed, it po&longs;'d us to conje­

Wherefore the next Morning, ho­
ping to inform our &longs;elves better, we

but though we could as well as former­

place wherein we made the tryal was the
very &longs;ame; and though other Circum­
&longs;tances were re&longs;embling, yet we could

Light all that Day, nor on divers o­
thers on which tryal was again fruitle&longs;­

be &longs;ure a Day before hand that the&longs;e
Fla&longs;hes will be to be &longs;een in our great
Receiver.

Nay, having once found the
Engine in a good humour (if I may
&longs;o &longs;peak) to &longs;hew this trick, and &longs;ent
notice of it to our Learned Friend
Doctor Wallis, who expre&longs;&longs;'d a great

And this un&longs;ucce&longs;sfulne&longs;s whereto our

Fir&longs;t then we ob&longs;erv'd, that the Appa­
