Next, we noted that the fla&longs;h appears
immediately upon the turning of the
Key, to let the Air out of the Receiver
into the empty'd Cylinder, in &longs;o much
that I remember not that when at any
time in our great Receiver, the Stop-cock
was open'd before the Cylinder was ex­
hau&longs;ted (whereby it came to pa&longs;s that the
Air did rather de&longs;cend, then ru&longs;h into the
Cylinder) the often mention'd fla&longs;h ap­
pear'd to our eyes.

Yet, we further ob&longs;erv'd, that when in­
&longs;tead of the great Receiver we made u&longs;e
of a &longs;mall Gla&longs;s, not containing above a
pound and a half of Water, the Phæno­
menon might be exhibited though the
Stop-cock were open, provided the
Sucker were drawn nimbly down.

We noted too, that when we began to
empty the Receiver, the appearances of
Light were much more con&longs;picuous
then towards the latter end, when little
Air at a time could pa&longs;s out of the Re­
ceiver.

We ob&longs;erv'd al&longs;o, that when the Suc­
ker had not been long before well Oyl'd,
and in&longs;tead of the great Receiver, the
&longs;maller Ve&longs;&longs;el above-mention'd was em­
ploy'd; We ob&longs;erv'd, I &longs;ay, that then,
upon the opening of the Stop-cock, as
the Air de&longs;cended out of the Gla&longs;s in­
to the empty'd Cylinder, &longs;o at the &longs;ame
time there a&longs;cended out of the Cylinder
into the Ve&longs;&longs;el a certain Steam, which
&longs;eem'd to con&longs;i&longs;t of very little Bubbles,
or other minute Corpu&longs;cles thrown up
from the Oyl, rarefied by the attrition it
&longs;uffered in the Cylinder.

For at the
&longs;ame time that the&longs;e Steams a&longs;cended
into the Gla&longs;s, &longs;ome of the &longs;ame kinde
manife&longs;tly i&longs;&longs;ued out like a little Pillar of
Smoke at the Orifice of the Valve, when
that was occa&longs;ionally open'd.

And the&longs;e
Steams frequently enough pre&longs;enting
them&longs;elves to our view, we found, by
expo&longs;ing the Gla&longs;s to a clear Light, that
they were wont to play up and down
in it, and &longs;o by their whitei&longs;hne&longs;s, to e­
mulate in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure the apparition of
Light.

For we likewi&longs;e &longs;ometimes found, by
watchful ob&longs;ervation, that when the
Fla&longs;h was great, not onely at the very
in&longs;tant the Receiver lo&longs;t of its tran&longs;pa­
rency, by appearing full of &longs;ome kinde
of whiti&longs;h &longs;ub&longs;tance; but that for &longs;ome
&longs;hort time after the &longs;ides of the Gla&longs;s
continued &longs;omewhat opacous, and
&longs;eem'd to be darken'd, as if &longs;ome
whiti&longs;h Steam adher'd to the in&longs;ide of
them.

He that would render a Rea&longs;on of
the Phænomenon, whereof all the&longs;e are
not all the Circum&longs;tances, mu&longs;t doe
two things; whereof the one is diffi­
cult, and the other little le&longs;s then im­
po&longs;&longs;ible: For he mu&longs;t give an Ac­
count not onely whence the appearing
whitene&longs;s proceeds, but wherefore that
whitene&longs;s does &longs;ometimes appear and
&longs;ometimes not.

For our part, we freely confe&longs;&longs;e
our &longs;elves at a lo&longs;&longs;e about rendering
a Rea&longs;on of the le&longs;s difficult part of the
Problem: And though Your Lord­
&longs;hip &longs;hould ev'n pre&longs;s us to declare what
Conjecture it was, that the above-recited
Circum&longs;tances &longs;ugge&longs;ted to us, we &longs;hould
propo&longs;e the thoughts we then had, no o­
therwi&longs;e then as bare Conjectures.

In ca&longs;e then our Phænomenon had con­
&longs;tantly and uniformly appear'd, we &longs;hould
have &longs;u&longs;pected it to have been produc'd
after &longs;ome &longs;uch manner as follows.

Fir&longs;t, we ob&longs;erv'd that, though that
which we &longs;aw in our Receiver &longs;eem'd to
be &longs;ome kinde of Light, yet it was indeed
but a whitene&longs;s which did (as hath alrea­
dy been noted) opacate (as &longs;ome &longs;peak)
the in&longs;ide of the Gla&longs;s.

Next we con&longs;ider'd, that our com­
mon Air abounds with Particles or little
Bodies, capable to reflect the Beams of
Light.

Of this we might ea&longs;ily give di­
vers proofs, but we &longs;hall name but two:
The one, that vulgar ob&longs;ervation of the
Motes that appear in Multitudes &longs;wim­
ming up and down in the Air, when the
Sun-beams &longs;hooting into a Room, or any
other &longs;hady Place di&longs;cover them, though
otherwi&longs;e the eye cannot di&longs;tingui&longs;h them
from the re&longs;t of the Air: The other proof
we will take from what we (and no doubt
very many others) have ob&longs;erv'd, touch­
ing the Illumination of the Air in the
Night.

And we particularly remember,
that, being at &longs;ome di&longs;tance from London
one Night, that the People, upon a very
well-come Occa&longs;ion, te&longs;tified their Joy
by numerous Bon-fires; though, by rea­
&longs;on of the Interpo&longs;ition of the Hou&longs;es,
we could not &longs;ee the Fires them&longs;elves, yet
we could plainly &longs;ee the Air all enlighten'd
over and near the City; which argu'd,
that the lucid Beams &longs;hot upwards from
the Fires, met in the Air with Corpu&longs;cles
opacous enough to reflect them to our
Eyes.

A third thing that we con&longs;idered, was,
That white may be produc'd (without
excluding other ways, or denying invi&longs;i­
ble Pores in the &longs;olide&longs;t Bodies) when
the continuity of a Diaphanous Body
happens to be interrupted by a great num­
ber of Surfaces, which, like &longs;o many
little Looking-gla&longs;&longs;es, do confu&longs;edly re­
pre&longs;ent a multitude of little and &longs;eeming­
ly contiguous Images of the elucid Body.

We &longs;hall not in&longs;i&longs;t on the explanation of
this, but refer You for it to what we have
&longs;aid in another Paper (touching Co­
lours.) But the In&longs;tances that &longs;eem to
prove it are obvious: For Water or whites
of Eggs beaten to froth, do lo&longs;e their
tran&longs;parency and appear white.

And ha­
ving out of one of our le&longs;&longs;er Receivers
carefully drawn out the Air, and &longs;o order'd
it, that the hole by which the Water was
to get in, was exceeding &longs;mall, that the
Liquor might be the more broken in its
pa&longs;&longs;age thorow it, we ob&longs;erv'd with plea­
&longs;ure, That, the Neck being held under
Water, and the little hole newly men­
tion'd being open'd, the Water that ru&longs;h'd
in was &longs;o broken, and acquired &longs;uch a mul­
titude of new Surfaces, that the Receiver
&longs;eem'd to be full rather of Milk then Wa­
ter.

We have likewi&longs;e found out, That
by heating a lump of Cry&longs;tal to a certain
degree, and quenching it in fair Water, it
would be di&longs;continu'd by &longs;uch a multi­
tude of Cracks, (which created new Sur­
faces within it) that though it would not
fall a&longs;under, but retain its former &longs;hape,
yet it would lo&longs;e its tran&longs;parency, and ap­
pear white.

Upon the&longs;e Con&longs;iderations, My Lord,
and &longs;ome others, it &longs;eem'd not ab&longs;ur'd to
imagine, That upon the ru&longs;hing of the Air
out of the Receiver into the empty'd Cy­
linder, the Air in the Receiver being &longs;ud­
denly and vehemently expanded, the Tex­
ture of it was as &longs;uddenly alter'd, and the
parts made &longs;o to &longs;hift places (and perhaps
&longs;ome of them to change po&longs;tures) as du­
ring their new and vehement Motion and
their varied Scituation, to di&longs;turb the
wonted continuity and &longs;o the Diapha­
neity of the Air; which (as we have alrea­
dy noted) upon its cea&longs;ing to be a tran­
&longs;parent Body, without the interpo&longs;ition
of colour'd things, mu&longs;t ea&longs;ily degene­
rate into white.

Several things there were that made
this Conjecture &longs;eem the le&longs;s improba­
ble.

As fir&longs;t, That the whitene&longs;s al­
ways appear'd greater when the Ex&longs;ucti­
on began to be made, whil'&longs;t there was
&longs;tore of Air in the Receiver, then when
the Air was in great part drawn out.

And
next, That, having exhau&longs;ted the Re­
ceiver, and apply'd to the hole in the
Stop-cock a large bubble of clear Gla&longs;s, in
&longs;uch a manner, that we could at plea&longs;ure let
the Air pa&longs;s out at the &longs;mall Gla&longs;s into the
great one, and ea&longs;ily fill the &longs;mall one with
Air again, We ob&longs;erv'd with plea&longs;ure,
That upon the opening the pa&longs;&longs;age be­
twixt the two Gla&longs;&longs;es, the Air in the
&longs;maller having &longs;o much room in the great­
er to receive it, the Di&longs;&longs;ilition of that
Air was &longs;o great, that the &longs;mall Viol
&longs;eem'd to be full of Milk; and this Expe­
riment we repeated &longs;everal times.

To
which we may adde, That, having pro­
vided a &longs;mall Receiver, who&longs;e upper Ori­
fice was &longs;o narrow that I could &longs;top it with
my Thumb, I ob&longs;erv'd, that when upon
the Ex&longs;uction of the Air the capacity of
the Gla&longs;s appear'd white, if by a &longs;udden
removal of my Thumb I let in the out­
ward Air, that whitene&longs;s would imme­
diately vani&longs;h.

And whereas it may be
objected, That in the In&longs;tance formerly
mention'd, Water turning from per&longs;pi­
cuous to white, there intervenes the Air,
which is a Body of a Heterogeneous na­
ture, and mu&longs;t turn it into Bubbles to
make it lo&longs;e its tran&longs;parency.

We may
borrow an An&longs;wer from an Experiment
we deliver in another Treati&longs;e, where we
teach how to make two very volatile Li­
quors, which being gently put together
are clear as Rock-water, and yet will al­
mo&longs;t in a moment, without the &longs;ub-ingre&longs;­
&longs;ion of Air to turn them into Bubbles, &longs;o
alter the di&longs;po&longs;ition of their in&longs;en&longs;ible
parts, as to become a white and con&longs;i&longs;tent
Body.

And this happens not as in the
precipitation of Benjamin, and &longs;ome o­
ther Re&longs;inous Bodies, which being di&longs;­
&longs;olv'd in Spirit of Wine, may, by the effu­
&longs;ion of fair Water, be turn'd into a &longs;eem­
ingly Milky &longs;ub&longs;tance.

For this white­
ne&longs;s belongs not to the whole Liquor, but
to the Corpu&longs;cles of the di&longs;&longs;olv'd Gum,
which after a while &longs;ub&longs;iding leave the Li­
quor tran&longs;parent, them&longs;elves onely re­
maining white: Whereas in our ca&longs;e, 'tis
from the vary'd texture of the whole for­
merly tran&longs;parent fluid Body, and not
from this or that part that this whitene&longs;&longs;e
re&longs;ults: For the Body is white thorowout,
and will long continue &longs;o; and yet may,
in proce&longs;s of time, without any addition,
be totally reduc'd into a tran&longs;parent Bo­
dy as before.

But be&longs;ides the Conjecture in&longs;i&longs;ted on
all this while, we grounded another upon
the following Ob&longs;ervation, which was,
That having convey'd &longs;ome &longs;moke into
our Receiver plac'd again&longs;t a Window, we
ob&longs;erv'd, that upon the ex&longs;uction of the
Air, the Corpu&longs;cles that were &longs;wimming
in it, did manife&longs;tly enough make the Re-
ceiver &longs;eem more opacous at the very
moment of the ru&longs;hing out of the Air:
For con&longs;idering that the whitene&longs;s, who&longs;e
cau&longs;e we enquire of, did but &longs;ometimes ap­
pear, it &longs;eem'd not impo&longs;&longs;ible but that at
&longs;uch times the Air in the Receiver might
abound with Particles, capable of re­
flecting the Light in the manner requi&longs;ite
to exhibit a white colour, by their being
put into a certain unu&longs;ual Motion.

As
may be in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure illu&longs;trated by
this, That the new motion of the fre&longs;hly
mention'd Fumes, made the in&longs;ide of the
Receiver appear &longs;omewhat darker then
before: And partly by the nature of our
formerly mention'd &longs;moking Liquor,
who&longs;e parts though they &longs;eem'd tran&longs;pa­
rent whil'&longs;t they compo&longs;'d a Liquor, yet
when the &longs;ame Corpu&longs;cles, upon the un­
&longs;topping of the Gla&longs;s, were put into a
new motion, and di&longs;po&longs;'d after a new
manner, they did opacate that part of the
Air they mov'd in, and exhibited a great­
er whitene&longs;s then that which &longs;ometimes
appears in our Pneumatical Ve&longs;&longs;el.

Nor
&longs;hould we content our &longs;elves with this &longs;in­
gle In&longs;tance, to manife&longs;t, That little Bo­
dies, which being rang'd after one manner,
are Diaphanous and Colourle&longs;s, may, by
being barely agitated, di&longs;per&longs;'d, and con­
&longs;equently otherways rang'd, exhibite a
colour, if we were not unwilling to rob
our Collection of Experiments concern­
ing Colours.

But, My Lord, I fore&longs;ee You may
make &longs;ome Objections again&longs;t our pro­
po&longs;ed ghe&longs;s, which perhaps I &longs;hall &longs;carce
be able to an&longs;wer, e&longs;pecially, if You in­
&longs;i&longs;t upon having me render a Rea&longs;on why
our Phænomenon appears not con&longs;tant­
ly.

I might indeed an&longs;wer, that probably
it would do &longs;o, if in&longs;tead of our great
Receiver we u&longs;e &longs;uch a &longs;mall Viol as we
have lately mention'd, wherein the Di&longs;&longs;i­
lition of the Air being much greater, is
like to be the more con&longs;picuous: Since I
remember not that we ever made our try­
al with &longs;uch &longs;mall Ve&longs;&longs;els, without find­
ing the expected whitene&longs;s to appear.

But
it would remain to be explicated, why in
our great Receiver the Phænomenon &longs;hould
&longs;ometimes be &longs;een, and oftentimes not ap­
pear.

And though that Conjecture which
we la&longs;t made &longs;hould not be rejected, yet if
we were further pre&longs;&longs;'d to a&longs;&longs;ign a rea&longs;on
why the Air &longs;hould abound with &longs;uch Par­
ticles, as we there &longs;uppo&longs;e, more at one
time then another, we are not yet pro­
vided of any better An&longs;wer, then this
general one, That the Air about us,
and much more that within the Receiver,
may be much alter'd by &longs;uch cau&longs;es as few
are aware of: For, not to repeat tho&longs;e
probable Arguments of this A&longs;&longs;ertion
which we have occa&longs;ionally mention'd
here and there in the former part of this
Epi&longs;tle, we will here &longs;et down two or
three In&longs;tances to verifie the &longs;ame Propo­
&longs;ition.

Fir&longs;t, I finde that the Learned
Fo&longs;ephus Aco&longs;ta, among other Judicious
Ob&longs;ervations he made in America, hath
this concerning the Effects of &longs;ome
Winds; There are (&longs;ays he) Winds which
naturally trouble the Water of the Sea, and
make it green, and black; others, clear as
Cry&longs;tal.

Next, we have ob&longs;erv'd, That
though we conveyd into the Receiver our
Scales, and the Pendula formerly men­
tion'd, clean and bright; yet after the Re­
ceiver had been empty'd, and the Air let in
again, the glo&longs;s or lu&longs;tre both of the one,
and of the other, appear'd tarni&longs;h'd by a
beginning ru&longs;t.

And in the la&longs;t place, we
will &longs;ubjoyn an Ob&longs;ervation we made
&longs;ome Years ago, which hath been heard
of by divers Ingenious Men, and &longs;een
by &longs;ome of them: We had, with pure
Spirit of Wine, drawn a Tincture out of
a certain Concrete which u&longs;es to be rec­
koned among Mineral Bodies; And this
Tincture being very pure and tran&longs;parent,
we did, becau&longs;e we put a great value upon
it, put into a Cry&longs;tal Viol which we care­
fully &longs;topp'd, and lock'd up in a Pre&longs;s a­
mong &longs;ome other things that we &longs;pecial­
ly priz'd.

This Liquor being a Chy­
mical Rarity, and be&longs;ides, very defecate
and of a plea&longs;ing Golden Colour; we
had often occa&longs;ion to look upon it, and
&longs;o to take notice, that one time it &longs;eem'd
to be very much troubled, and not clear
as it was wont to be: Whereupon we ima­
gined, that though it would be &longs;omething
&longs;trange, yet it was not impo&longs;&longs;ible that
&longs;ome Precipitation of the Mineral Cor­
pu&longs;cles was then happening, and that
thence the Liquor was opacated; but,
finding after &longs;ome days that though the
expected Precipitation had not been
made, yet the Liquor, retaining its for­
mer vivid Colour, was grown clear again
as before; we &longs;omewhat wondered at it,
and locking it up again in the &longs;ame Pre&longs;s,
we re&longs;olved to ob&longs;erve, both whether
the like changes would again appear in
our Tincture; and whether in ca&longs;e they
&longs;hould appear, they would be a&longs;cribable
to the alterations of the Weather.

But
though, during the greate&longs;t part of a Win­
ter and a Spring, we took plea&longs;ure to ob­
&longs;erve, how the Liquor would often grow
turbid, and after a while clear again: Yet
we could not finde that the&longs;e Mutations
depended upon any that were manife&longs;t in
the Air, whieh would be often dark and
clouded, when the Tincture was clear and
tran&longs;parent; as on the other &longs;ide, in clear
Weather the Liquor would appear &longs;ome­
times troubled, and more opacous.

So
that being unable to give an account of
the&longs;e odde changes in our Tincture (which
we &longs;uppo&longs;e we have not yet lo&longs;t, though
we know not whether it have lo&longs;t its fickle
Nature) either by tho&longs;e of the Air, or
any thing el&longs;e that occurr'd to our
thoughts; we could not but &longs;u&longs;pect that
there may be in divers Bodies, as it were
Spontaneous Mutations, that is, &longs;uch
changes as depend not upon manife&longs;t
Cau&longs;es.

But, My Lord, what has been
all this while &longs;aid concerning our Phæno­
menon, is offer'd to You, not as contain­
ing a &longs;atisfactory Account of it, but to
a&longs;&longs;i&longs;t You to give Your&longs;elf one.

WE took a Gla&longs;s Ve&longs;&longs;el, open
at the top, and into it we put
a mixture of Snow and common Salt
(&longs;uch a mixture as we have in another
Treati&longs;e largely di&longs;cour&longs;ed of) and in­
to the mid&longs;t of this mixture we &longs;et a
Gla&longs;&longs;e, of a Cylindrical form, clo&longs;ely
&longs;topp'd at the lower end with Plai&longs;ter,
and open at the upper, at which we
fill'd it with common Water.

The&longs;e
things being let down into the Recei­
ver, and the Pump being &longs;et awork,
the Snow began to melt &longs;omewhat fa­
&longs;ter then we expected; whether upon
the account of the Ex&longs;uction of the
Air, or becau&longs;e there was but little of
the Snow, or whether for any other
Rea&longs;on, it appeared doubtfull.

But
however, by that time the Receiver
had been con&longs;iderably exhau&longs;ted, which
was done in le&longs;&longs;e then 1/4 of an hour,
we perceived the Water near the bot­
tom of the Gla&longs;s Cylinder to Freeze,
and the Ice by a little longer &longs;tay, &longs;eem'd
to encrea&longs;e, and to ri&longs;e &longs;omewhat higher
then the &longs;urface of the &longs;urrounding Li­
quor, where into almo&longs;t all the Snow and
Salt were re&longs;olv'd.

The Gla&longs;s being ta­
ken out, it appear'd that the Ice was as
thick as the in&longs;ide of the Gla&longs;s it fill'd,
though into that I could put my Thumb.

The upper &longs;urface of the Ice was very
concave, which whether it were due to
any unheeded accident, or to the ex&longs;u­
ction of the Air, we leave to be deter­
min'd by further tryal.

And la&longs;tly, the
Ice held again&longs;t the Light, appear'd not
de&longs;titute of Bubbles, though &longs;ome By­
&longs;tanders thought they were fewer then
would have been found if the Water had
been frozen in the open Air.

The like
Experiment we try'd al&longs;o another time in
one of our &longs;mall Receivers, with not un­
like &longs;ucce&longs;s.

Experi­
ment 38.

And on this occa&longs;ion, My Lord, give
me leave to propo&longs;e a Problem, which
&longs;hall be this: Whence proceeds that
&longs;trange force that we may &longs;ometimes ob­
&longs;erve in frozen Water, to break the Bo­
dies that Impri&longs;on it, though hard and &longs;o­
lid?

That there is &longs;uch a force in Wa­
ter expo&longs;'d to Congelation, may be ga­
ther'd not onely from what may be often
ob&longs;erv'd in Winter, of the bur&longs;ting of
Gla&longs;&longs;es too clo&longs;e &longs;topp'd, fill'd with Wa­
ter or aqueous Liquors, but by In&longs;tances
as much more con&longs;iderable as le&longs;s obvi­
ous.

For I remember, that an Ingenious
Stone-cutter not long &longs;ince complain'd to
me, That &longs;ometimes, through the negli­
gence of Servants, the Rain being &longs;uffer­
ed to &longs;oak into Marble Stones, the &longs;uper­
vening violent Fro&longs;ts would bur&longs;t the
Stones, to the Profe&longs;&longs;ors no &longs;mall dam­
age.

And I remember another Trades­
man, in who&longs;e Hou&longs;e I had Lodgings, was
la&longs;t Winter complaining, that even Im­
plements made of Bell-metal, being care­
le&longs;ly expo&longs;'d to the wet, have been broken
and &longs;poil'd by the Water, which, having
gotten into the little Cavities and Cran­
nies of the Metal, was there afterwards
frozen and expanded into Ice.

And to
the&longs;e Relations, we can adde one of the
formerly mention'd Cabæus's, whereby
they not onely may be confirm'd, but are
&longs;urpa&longs;&longs;'d: For he tells us, That he &longs;aw a
huge Ve&longs;&longs;el of exceeding hard Marble,
&longs;plit a&longs;under by congel'd Water, who&longs;e
Rarefaction, &longs;ays our Author, prov'd &longs;o
vehement, that the hardne&longs;s of the Stone
yielded to it; and &longs;o a Ve&longs;&longs;el was broken,
which would not have been &longs;o by 100
Yoke of Oxen drawing it &longs;everal ways.

I
know, My Lord, that to &longs;olve this Pro­
blem, it will be &longs;aid, That Congelation

And I have el&longs;ewhere
prov'd by particular Experiments, That

able) it may be &longs;aid to take up more room

But though we grant that freezing makes

In . 4.

WE took an Oval Gla&longs;s, clear and
(lea&longs;t it &longs;hould break) pretty
&longs;trong, with a &longs;hort Neck at the obtu&longs;er

clo&longs;ely Cemented to the newly mention'd

the Air in that.

Gla&longs;s Egge might be the
more con&longs;picuous; Then there was con­

above-mention'd &longs;lender part of the Pipe,
&longs;o that the Water was interpo&longs;'d between

This Weather-gla&longs;s (delineated

&longs;mall Receivers, that onely the &longs;lender

Experi­
ment 39.

The Pump being &longs;et a work, upon
the Ex&longs;uction of the Air, the Water in

ther-gla&longs;s, &longs;ince upon the bare applica­

&longs;ing upon the &longs;ubjacent Water, to impel

For if it be demanded what then could
cau&longs;e the fore-mention'd &longs;ub&longs;iding of the
Water?

it may be an&longs;wered, That pro­
bably it was the reaching of the Gla&longs;s

&longs;eem'd probable, as well by what was a­

cum&longs;tance (which we divers times ob­
&longs;erv'd) That when by drawing the Air out

&longs;urface of the Egge, the Water was pre­
&longs;ently re-impell'd to its former height:

ther Treati&longs;e concerning the Spring that

&longs;teem'd.

And in the mean while it may
&longs;erve the turn to cau&longs;e a Gla&longs;s Egge to be

&longs;tate or po&longs;ture.

But to return to our
Experiment, From thence it &longs;eems pro­

So that

We try'd al&longs;o what Operation the

IT may &longs;eem well worth trying, whether

But though we ea&longs;ily

&longs;uch an Experiment; yet not to omit our

We al&longs;o another time &longs;hut into a great

&longs;trong and lively, though we had rather

&longs;ide of the Gla&longs;s whereon &longs;he

dle of Flowers, which re­

But whether this fall of the Bee,

Experi­
ment 40.

TO &longs;atisfie our &longs;elves in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure,

&longs;tanding this hurt, the Lark was very

The Ve&longs;&longs;el being ha&longs;tily, but

&longs;uction of the Air, &longs;he began manife&longs;tly

And
though upon the appearing of the&longs;e Con-

Soon after we got a Hen-&longs;par­

Experi­
ment 41.

Whereupon, ha&longs;tily turning the Key, we

The&longs;e Experiments &longs;eem'd the more

&longs;iderable quantity; as may appear by what

I forgot to mention, that having cau&longs;'d

Having proceeded thus far, though (as

&longs;topp'd for the ex&longs;uction of the Air then

The Experiment had this event, that

Nor was I content with this, but for
Your Lord&longs;hips further &longs;atisfaction, and

And this care
&longs;ucceeded &longs;o well, that the next Morning

live, but had devour'd a good part of the

And
having thus kept him alive full twelve
hours, or better, we did, by &longs;ucking out

to appear &longs;well'd; and by letting in the

A Digre&longs;sion containing &longs;ome
Doubts touching Re&longs;pi­
ration.

I Fear Your Lord&longs;hip will now expect,
that to the&longs;e Experiments I &longs;hould add

by their a&longs;&longs;i&longs;tance, to re&longs;olve the Diffi­
culties that occur about Re&longs;piration; &longs;ince
at the beginning I acknowledg'd a further

But I have yet, becau&longs;e of the inconve­
nient Sea&longs;on of the Year, made &longs;o few

tisfied by tho&longs;e I have been able to make,

My&longs;terious thing, then it did before.

But
yet, &longs;ince they have furni&longs;h'd me with
&longs;ome &longs;uch new Con&longs;iderations, concern­
ing the u&longs;e of the Air, as confirms me in

commonly believ'd touching that matter;
That I may not appear &longs;ullen or lazy, I
am content not to decline employing a
few hours in &longs;etting down my Doubts, in

And this, My Lord, being all my pre­
&longs;ent De&longs;ign, I &longs;uppo&longs;e You will not ex­
pect that (as if You knew not, or had for­
gotten what Anatomi&longs;ts are wont to
teach) I &longs;hould entertain You with a need­
le&longs;s Di&longs;cour&longs;e of the Organs of Re&longs;pira­
tion, and the variety of their Structure in
&longs;everal Animals; though if it were ne­
ce&longs;&longs;ary, and had not been perform'd by o­
thers, I &longs;hould think, with Galen, that by
treating of the Fabricks of living Bodies,
I might compo&longs;e Hymns to the wi&longs;e Au­
thor of Nature, who, in the excellent con­
trivance of the Lungs, and other parts of
(tho&longs;e admirable Engines) Animals, ma­
nife&longs;ts him&longs;elf to be indeed what the Elo­
quent Prophet mo&longs;t ju&longs;tly &longs;peaks him,
Wonderful in Counsel, and excellent in
working.

Galenus de
, Part:
lib. 3.

Nor &longs;hall we any further meddle with
tho&longs;e Controver&longs;ies &longs;o much agitated a­
mong the Moderns, namely, Whether the
motion of the Lungs in Re&longs;piration be their
own, or but con&longs;equent to the motion of the
Thorax, Diaphragme, and (as &longs;ome Learn­
ed Men would have it) the Abdomen; And,
Whence it is that the Air &longs;wells the Lungs
in In&longs;piration any further then they may
receive light from our Engine: But that
it may appear what kinde of &longs;ervice it is
that may be expected from it on this oc­
ca&longs;ion, we mu&longs;t premi&longs;e a few Words to
&longs;hew wherein the &longs;trength of the Obje­
ction we are to an&longs;wer, lies.

In favor then
of tho&longs;e that would have the Lungs ra­
ther pa&longs;&longs;ive then active in the bu&longs;ine&longs;s of
Re&longs;piration, it may again&longs;t the common
opinion be alledg'd, That as the Lungs be­
ing de&longs;titute of Mu&longs;cles and of Fibres,
are unfit to dilate them&longs;elves; &longs;o it ap­
pears, that without the motion of the
Thorax they would not be fill'd with Air.

Since as our Learned Friend Dr. High­
more has well (and congruou&longs;ly, to what
our &longs;elves have purpo&longs;ely try'd) ob­
&longs;erv'd, if a live Dog have a great wound
made in his Che&longs;t, the Lobes of the
Lungs on that &longs;ide of the Media&longs;ti­
num will &longs;ub&longs;ide and lie &longs;till; the Tho­
rax and the Lobes on the other &longs;ide
of the Media&longs;tinum, continuing their
former motion.

And if &longs;uddenly at once
the Mu&longs;cles of the Che&longs;t be on both
&longs;ides di&longs;&longs;ected, upon the Ingre&longs;s of the
Air, the whole Lungs, though untouch'd,
will remain movele&longs;s, at lea&longs;t, as to any ex­
pan&longs;ion or contraction of their &longs;ub&longs;tance.

To which we may adde the Ob&longs;ervati­
on of the diligent Bartholinus, who af­
firms the like of the Diaphragme al­
&longs;o, namely, That it being wounded, the
Lungs will fall together, and the Re&longs;pi­
ration cea&longs;e, which my Experiments op­
po&longs;e not, provided the Wound be any
thing great.

And indeed the Diaphragme
&longs;eems the principal In&longs;trument of ordina­
ry and gentle Re&longs;piration, although to
re&longs;train'd Re&longs;piration (if I may &longs;o call
it) the interco&longs;tal Mu&longs;cles, and perhaps
&longs;ome others may be allowed eminently to
concur.

But the chief of the Contro­
ver&longs;ies formerly pointed at, is not yet de­
cided, namely, what it is that conveys the
Air into the Lungs.

For when, to coun­
terballance all that has been alledg'd, tho&longs;e
that plead for the Lungs, demand what it
is that &longs;hould bring the Air into the
Lungs, if them&longs;elves do not attract it,
their Antagoni&longs;ts di&longs;agree about the Re­
ply.

For when to this que&longs;tion &longs;ome of
the be&longs;t Modern Philo&longs;ophers an&longs;wer,
that by the dilatation of the Che&longs;t the
contiguous Air is thru&longs;t away, and that
pre&longs;&longs;ing upon the next Air to it, and &longs;o
onwards, the Propul&longs;ion is continued till
the Air be driven into the Lungs, and &longs;o
dilate them: When this (I &longs;ay) is an­
&longs;wered, it is Objected even by Bartholine
him&longs;elf, as a convincing Reply, that, ac­
cording to this Doctrine, a Man could not
fetch his Breath from a great Ve&longs;&longs;el full of
Air, with a &longs;lender Neck, becau&longs;e, that
when his Mouth covers the Orifice of the
Neck, the dilatation of his Thorax could
not propell the Air in the Ve&longs;&longs;el into his
Lungs, by rea&longs;on of its being &longs;eparated
by the inclo&longs;ing Ve&longs;&longs;el from the ambient
Air; and yet, &longs;ay they, Experience wit­
ne&longs;&longs;es that out of &longs;uch a Ve&longs;&longs;el a Man may
&longs;uck Air.

But of this difficulty our Engine
furni&longs;hes us with an ea&longs;ie Solution, &longs;ince
many of the former Experiments have ma­
nife&longs;ted, That in the ca&longs;e propo&longs;ed, there
needs not be made any (though 'tis true
that in ordinary Re&longs;piration there is wont
to be made &longs;ome) propul&longs;ion of the Air by
the &longs;welling Thorax or Abdomen into the
Lungs; &longs;ince upon the bare Dilatation of
the Thorax, the Spring of that internal
Air, or halituous &longs;ub&longs;tance that is wont
to po&longs;&longs;e&longs;s as much of the Cavity of the
Che&longs;t as the Lungs fill not up, being much
weaken'd, the external and contiguous
Air mu&longs;t nece&longs;&longs;arily pre&longs;s in at the open
Winde-Pipe into the Lungs, as finding
there le&longs;s re&longs;i&longs;tance then any where el&longs;e a­
bout it.

And hence (by the way) we may derive
a new a&longs;&longs;i&longs;tance to judge of that famous
Controver&longs;ie di&longs;puted among Naturali&longs;ts
and Phy&longs;itians, ever &longs;ince Galens time,
&longs;ome maintaining that the Che&longs;t, with the
contained Lungs, may be re&longs;embled to a
pair of Bellows, which comes therefore
to be fill'd becau&longs;e it was dilated: And o­
thers pleading to have the compari&longs;on
made to a Bladder, which is therefore di­
lated becau&longs;e it is fill'd.

For as to the
Thorax, it &longs;eems evident from what has
been lately &longs;aid, that it, like a pair of Bel­
lows, happens to be partly fill'd with Air,
but becau&longs;e it was dilated: But as for the
Lungs them&longs;elves, who want Fibres to
di&longs;tend them, they may fitly enough be
compar'd to a Bladder; &longs;ince they are di­
lated by being fill'd, namely, by that Air
which ru&longs;hes into them upon the dilatation
of the Che&longs;t, in who&longs;e increa&longs;ed Cavity
it findes (as we fre&longs;hly noted) le&longs;s re&longs;i&longs;t-
ance to its Spring then el&longs;ewhere.

And
this brings into my minde that &longs;trange
Ob&longs;ervation of Nicolaus Fontanus, a Phy­
&longs;itian at Am&longs;terdam, who te&longs;tifies, That
in a Boy of the &longs;ame Town, four years
old, there was found, in&longs;tead of Lungs, a
certain Membranous Bladder; which be­
ing fill'd with Wind, and furni&longs;h'd with
little Veins, had its origination from the
Wind-Pipe it &longs;elf; which being &longs;uppo&longs;'d
true, how well it will agree with mo&longs;t of
the Opinions touching Re&longs;piration, I leave
to be con&longs;idered.

And thus may the grand Objection of
Bartholine, and others, be an&longs;wered: But
I leave to Anatomi&longs;ts to con&longs;ider what is
to be &longs;aid to &longs;ome Ob&longs;ervations that &longs;eem
to contradict tho&longs;e Anatomical Experi­
ments already mention'd: Such was par­
ticularly that which I remember I have
read in Sennertus (from the ob&longs;ervation of
his Father-in-law Schato) of a Melancho­
ly Student, who having &longs;tabb'd him&longs;elf,
and pierced the Diaphragme in the thinner
or tendonous part (call'd by many the
Nervous Circle) lived &longs;even Moneths af­
ter he had &longs;o wounded him&longs;elf, though af­
ter his death (preceded by violent Vomit-
ings) the Wound (perchance dilated by
tho&longs;e &longs;trainings) appear'd &longs;o great, that
the whole Stomack was found to have got
in by it into the left &longs;ide of the Thorax.
And &longs;uch al&longs;o was the accident that hap­
pen'd to a Noble Man, whom I remem­
ber I have &longs;een, and who is yet alive, in
who&longs;e Che&longs;t there has, for the&longs;e many
years, remain'd a hole &longs;o great, that the
motion of his Heart may be perceiv'd by
it.

The&longs;e (I &longs;ay) and &longs;ome other Ob&longs;er­
vations, I &longs;hall now forbear to in&longs;i&longs;t on,
becau&longs;e I hold it not unfit, before we
come to con&longs;ider the u&longs;e of Re&longs;piration,
that we acquaint Your Lord&longs;hip with an
Ingenious Conjecture, that was made at
the cau&longs;e of the ha&longs;ty death of the Ani­
mals our Engine kill'd: namely, That it
was not the want of Air that de&longs;troy'd
them, but the Pre&longs;&longs;ure of the innate Air
in the cavity of the Che&longs;t; as if the
Spring of this Air being no longer coun­
terballanc'd by the ambient Air, was there­
by become &longs;o &longs;trong, that it kept the
Thorax forcibly di&longs;tended, and hinder'd its
wonted contraction; and &longs;o compre&longs;&longs;'d
the Lungs and their Ve&longs;&longs;els, as to ob&longs;truct
the Circulation of the Blood.

And this
Conjecture, as it is &longs;pecious enough, &longs;o I
might have admitted it for true; but that
I con&longs;ider'd, that (not to mention that
one, e&longs;pecially of the Animals kill'd in
our Engine, &longs;eem'd manife&longs;tly for a pret­
ty while, and not long before he dy'd, to
move his Thorax, as if he exerci&longs;'d Re&longs;pi­
ration) the diligent Wallæus relates, That
he divers times ob&longs;erv'd, in the Di&longs;&longs;ecti­
on of live Bodies, that the Membrane
that inve&longs;ts the Lungs, had Pores in it
as big as the larger &longs;ort of Peas, which a­
grees with the Ob&longs;ervations of Chyrur­
gions and Phy&longs;itians, viz.

That matter
collected in the Thorax, has penetrated in­
to the Lungs, and been di&longs;charged by
coughing.

And I remember too, that mo&longs;t
of the Animals we kill'd in our Engine
were Birds, of who&longs;e Lungs Harvey
&longs;omewhere informs us, That he ob­
&longs;erv'd them very manife&longs;tly to open at
their Extremities into the Abdomen.
And by &longs;uch Perforations we may well
&longs;uppo&longs;e the pa&longs;&longs;age free betwixt the exter­
nal Air and that in the Abdomen: But this
Conjecture may be further con&longs;ider'd.

Be&longs;ides, to &longs;how that the Animals that
died in our Gla&longs;&longs;es, need not be &longs;uppo&longs;'d
to have been kill'd by the want of Air, we
fore&longs;ee another Argument that we mu&longs;t
deal &longs;o ingeniou&longs;ly with Your Lord&longs;hip,
as not to conceal.

You very well know,
that be&longs;ides the generality of the
Schools, there are many new Philo&longs;ophers
who, though they di&longs;&longs;ent from the old
Peripateticks in other things, do, as they,
deny the po&longs;&longs;ibility of a Vacuum; and
hold, that tho&longs;e &longs;paces which are devoid
of Air, and other gro&longs;&longs;er Bodies, are all
of them exactly repleni&longs;hed with a certain
Etherial Matter, &longs;o thin and &longs;ubtle, that
it can freely permeate the Pores of the
compacted&longs;t and clo&longs;e&longs;t Bodies, and ev'n
of Gla&longs;s it &longs;elf.

Now &longs;ome of tho&longs;e Na­
turali&longs;ts that are of this per&longs;wa&longs;ion may
object, That the Animals that died in our
Receivers, did &longs;o, not &longs;o much for lack of
Air, as by rea&longs;on that the Air that was
pump'd out was nece&longs;&longs;arily &longs;ucceeded by
an Etherial Sub&longs;tance; which con&longs;i&longs;ting of
parts vehemently agitated, and &longs;o very
&longs;mall, as without re&longs;i&longs;tance to pa&longs;s in and
out through the very Pores of Gla&longs;s; it
may well be &longs;uppo&longs;'d, that a con&longs;iderable
quantity of this re&longs;tle&longs;s and &longs;ubtle Mat­
ter, meeting together in the Receiver,
with the exce&longs;&longs;ive heat of it, may be
quickly able to de&longs;troy a little Animal, or
at lea&longs;t, make the Air too intemperately
hot to be fit for Re&longs;piration.

But though this be a Difficulty not &longs;o
ea&longs;ily to be re&longs;olv'd without the a&longs;&longs;i&longs;tance
of our Engine, yet I &longs;uppo&longs;e we have al­
ready an&longs;wer'd the Objection by our 38th
and 39th Experiments; which though we
made partly for other purpo&longs;es, yet we
premi&longs;'d them onely to clear up the diffi­
culty propo&longs;'d.

Another &longs;u&longs;pition we &longs;hould have en­
tertain'd concerning the death of our Ani­
mals, namely, That upon the &longs;udden re­
moval of the wonted pre&longs;&longs;ure of the am­
bient Air, the warm Blood of tho&longs;e Ani­
mals was brought to an Efferve&longs;cence or
Ebullition, or at lea&longs;t &longs;o vehemently ex­
panded, as to di&longs;turb the Circulation of
the Blood, and &longs;o di&longs;order the whole Oe­
conomy of the Body. (This (I &longs;ay) I
&longs;hould have had &longs;ome &longs;u&longs;pition of) but
that Animals of a hot Con&longs;titution are
not the &longs;ole ones that cannot in our ex­
hau&longs;ted Engine exerci&longs;e the Function of
Life.

But I mu&longs;t not now dwell upon
matters of this nature, becau&longs;e I think
it high time to proceed to the con&longs;iderati-
on of the principal &longs;ubject of our Engine,
namely, The u&longs;e of Re&longs;piration; or ra­
ther, The u&longs;e of the Air in Re&longs;piration.

For whereas of the divers u&longs;es of it men­
tion'd by Anatomi&longs;ts the mo&longs;t, &longs;uch as
the Production and Modulation of the
Voice by the Eli&longs;ion of the Air, the La­
rynx &c.

the expul&longs;ion of Excrements
by Coughing, the conveying in of Odours
by In&longs;piration, and &longs;ome others, rather
convenient for the well being of an Ani­
mal, then ab&longs;olutely nece&longs;&longs;ary to his Life:
Whereas (I &longs;ay) the other u&longs;es are &longs;uch as
we have &longs;aid, The great Hippocrates him­
&longs;elf gives this notable Te&longs;timony to the
u&longs;e of the Air, as to Animals endow'd
with Lungs, Mortalibus (&longs;ays he) hic (&longs;pi­
ritus) tum vitæ, tum morborum ægrotis cau­
&longs;a e&longs;t.

Tantáque corporibus omnibus &longs;pi­
ritûs ine&longs;t neceßitas, ut &longs;iquidem aliis om­
nibus & cibis & potionibus, quis ab&longs;tineat,
duos tamen aut tres, vel plures dies poßit vi­
tam ducere: At &longs;i quis &longs;piritus in corpus
vias intercipiat, vel exiguâ diei parte, ho­
mini pereundum &longs;it; Adeo nece&longs;&longs;arius e&longs;t
u&longs;us &longs;piritûs in corpore.

Ad hæc quo&queacute;,
quum omnibus aliis actionibus homines qui­
e&longs;cant, quod mutationibus innumer is vita
&longs;it expo&longs;ita, ab hâc tamen &longs;olâ actione nun-
quam de&longs;i&longs;tant animantia, quin aut &longs;piritum
adducant, aut reddant.

But touching the account upon which
the In&longs;piration and Ex&longs;piration of Air
(both which are comprehended in a)gapno,
Re&longs;piration) is &longs;o nece&longs;&longs;ary to Life, both
Naturali&longs;ts and Phy&longs;itians do &longs;o di&longs;agree,
that it will be very difficult either to re­
concile their Opinions, or determine their
Controver&longs;ies.

For fir&longs;t, Many there are who think
the chief (if not &longs;ole) u&longs;e of Re&longs;piration
to be the Cooling and tempering of that
Heat in the Heart and Blood, which other­
wi&longs;e would be immoderate: And this O­
pinion, not onely &longs;eems to be mo&longs;t recei­
ved among&longs;t Schola&longs;tick Writers, but di­
vers of the new Philo&longs;ophers, Carte&longs;ians,
and others, admitted with &longs;ome variation;
teaching, That the Air is nece&longs;&longs;ary, by its
coldne&longs;s, to conden&longs;e the Blood that pa&longs;­
&longs;es out of the right Ventricle of the
Heart into the Lungs, that thereby it may
obtain &longs;uch a con&longs;i&longs;tence, as is requi&longs;ite
to make it fit Fewel for the vital Fire or
Flame, in the left Ventricle of the heart.

And this Opinion &longs;eems favor'd by this,
That Fi&longs;hes, and other cold Creatures,
who&longs;e Hearts have but one cavity, are al-
&longs;o unprovided of Lungs, and by &longs;ome o­
ther con&longs;iderations.

But though it need
not be deny'd, that the in&longs;pir'd Air may
&longs;ometimes be of u&longs;e by refrigerating the
Heart; yet (again&longs;t the Opinion that makes
this Refrigeration, the mo&longs;t genuine and
con&longs;tant u&longs;e of the Air) it may be Obje­
cted, That divers cold Creatures (&longs;ome
of which, as particularly Frogs, live in
the Water) have yet need of Re&longs;piration,
which &longs;eems not likely to be needed for
Refrigeration by them that are de&longs;titute of
any &longs;en&longs;ible heat, and be&longs;ides, live in the
cold Water: That even decrepid old
Men, who&longs;e natural heat is made very
languid, and almo&longs;t extingui&longs;h'd by rea­
&longs;on of age, have yet a nece&longs;&longs;ity of fre­
quent Re&longs;piration: That a temperate Air
is fitte&longs;t for the generality of breathing
Creatures; and as an Air too hot, &longs;o al­
&longs;o an Air too cold, may be inconvenient
for them (e&longs;pecially, if they be troubled
with an immoderate degree of the &longs;ame
Quality which is predominant in the Air:)
That in &longs;ome Di&longs;ea&longs;es the natural heat is
&longs;o weaken'd, that in ca&longs;e the u&longs;e of Re&longs;pi­
ration were to cool, it would be more
hurtful then beneficial to breath; and the
&longs;u&longs;pending of the Re&longs;piration, may &longs;up-
ply the place of tho&longs;e very hot Medicines
that are wont to be employ'd in &longs;uch Di­
&longs;tempers: That Nature might much bet­
ter have given the Heart but a moderate
heat, then &longs;uch an exce&longs;&longs;ive one, as needs
to be perpetually cool'd, to keep it from
growing de&longs;tructive; which the gentle,
and not the burning heat of an Animals
Heart, &longs;eems not inten&longs;e enough &longs;o indi­
&longs;pen&longs;ably to require.

The&longs;e, and other
Objections, might be oppo&longs;'d, and pre&longs;&longs;'d
again&longs;t the recited Opinion: But we &longs;hall
not in&longs;i&longs;t on them, but onely adde to
them, That it appears not by our fore­
going Experiments (I mean the 38th and
39th) that in our exhau&longs;ted Receiver,
where yet Animals die &longs;o &longs;uddenly for
want of Re&longs;piration, the ambient Body is
&longs;en&longs;ibly hotter then the common Air.

Other Learned Men there are, who will
have the very &longs;ub&longs;tance of the Air to get
in by the Ve&longs;&longs;els of the Lungs, to the
left Ventricle of the Heart, not onely to
temper its heat, but to provide for the
generation of Spirits.

And the&longs;e alledge
for them&longs;elves the Authority of the An­
tients, among whom Hippocrates &longs;eems
manife&longs;tly to favor their Opinion; and
both Ari&longs;totle and Galen do &longs;ometimes
(for methinks they &longs;peak doubtfully e­
nough) appear inclinable to it.

But for
ought ever I could &longs;ee in Di&longs;&longs;ections, it is
very difficult to make out, how the Air is
convey'd into the left Ventricle of the
Heart, e&longs;pecially the Sy&longs;tole and Dia&longs;tole
of the Heart and Lungs, being very far
from being Synchronical: Be&longs;ides, that
the Spirits &longs;eeming to be but the mo&longs;t
&longs;ubtle and unctuous Particles of the
Blood, appear to be of a very differing
Nature from that of the lean and incom­
bu&longs;tible Corpu&longs;cles of Air.

Other Ob­
jections again&longs;t this Opinion have been
propo&longs;'d, and pre&longs;t by that excellent Ana­
tomi&longs;t, and my Indu&longs;trious Friend, Dr.
Highmore, to whom I &longs;hall therefore refer
you.

Another Opinion there is touching Re­
&longs;piration, which makes the genuine u&longs;e of
it to be Ventilation (not of the Heart,
but) of the Blood, in its pa&longs;&longs;age thorow
the Lungs; in which pa&longs;&longs;age, it is di&longs;­
burthened of tho&longs;e Excrementitious
Steams, proceeding, for the mo&longs;t part,
from the &longs;uperfluous Sero&longs;ities of the
Blood, (we may adde) and of the Chyle
too, which (by tho&longs;e new Conduits of
late very happily detected by the famous
Pecquet) hath been newly mix'd with it in
the Heart.) And this Opinion is that of
the Indu&longs;trious Mœbius, and is &longs;aid to
have been that of that excellent Philo&longs;o­
pher Ga&longs;&longs;endus; and hath been in part an
Opinion almo&longs;t vulgar: But this Hypo­
the&longs;is may be explicated two ways: For
fir&longs;t, The nece&longs;&longs;ity of the Air in Re&longs;pi­
ration, may be &longs;uppo&longs;'d to proceed from
hence; That as a Flame cannot long burn
in a narrow and clo&longs;e place, becau&longs;e the
Fuliginous Steams it unce&longs;&longs;antly throws
out, cannot be long receiv'd into the am­
bient Body; which after a while growing
too full of them, to admit any more, &longs;ti­
fles the flame, &longs;o that the vital Fire in the
Heart requires an ambient Body, of a
yielding nature, to receive into it the &longs;u­
perfluous Sero&longs;ities and other Recrements
of the Blood, who&longs;e &longs;ea&longs;onable Expul&longs;i­
on is requi&longs;ite to depurate the Ma&longs;s of
Blood, and make it fit both to Circulate;
and to maintain the vital heat re&longs;iding in
the Heart.

The other way of explicating
the above-mention'd Hypothe&longs;is, is, by
&longs;uppo&longs;ing, that the Air does not onely, as
a Receptacle, admit into its Pores the Ex­
crementitious vapors of the Blood, when
they are expell'd through the Wind-Pipe,
but does al&longs;o convey them out of the
Lungs, in regard that the in&longs;pired Air,
reaching to all the ends of the A&longs;pera Ar­
teria, does there a&longs;&longs;ociate it &longs;elf with the
Exhalations of the circulating Blood, and
when tis exploded, carrys them away with
it &longs;elf, as we &longs;ee that winds &longs;peedily dry up
the &longs;urfaces of wet Bodies, not to &longs;ay any
thing of what we formerly ob&longs;ervd touch­
ing our Liquor, who&longs;e fumes were &longs;trange­
ly elevated upon the Ingre&longs;s of the Air.

Now of the&longs;e two ways of explicating
the u&longs;e of Re&longs;piration, our Engine af­
fords us this Objection again&longs;t the fir&longs;t;
That upon the Ex&longs;uction of the Air, the
Animals die a great deal &longs;ooner then if it
were left in the Ve&longs;&longs;el; though by that
Ex&longs;uction the ambient &longs;pace is left much
more free to receive the &longs;teams that are ei­
ther breathed out of the Lungs of the
Animal, or di&longs;charg'd by in&longs;en&longs;ible Tran­
&longs;piration through the Pores of his
Skin.

But if the Hypothe&longs;is propo&longs;'d, be taken
in the other &longs;en&longs;e, it &longs;eems congruous e­
nough to that grand ob&longs;ervation, which
partly the Phænomena of our Engine, and
partly the relations of Travellers, have
&longs;ugge&longs;ted to us, namely, That there is a
certain con&longs;i&longs;tence of Air requi&longs;ite to Re­
&longs;piration; &longs;o that if it be too thick, and
already over-charged with vapors, it will
be unfit to unite with, and carry off tho&longs;e
of the Blood, as Water will di&longs;&longs;olve, and
a&longs;&longs;ociate to it &longs;elf but a certain proportion
of &longs;aline Corpu&longs;cles; and if it be too
thin or rarefied, the number or &longs;ize of the
Aërial Particles is too &longs;mall to be able to
a&longs;&longs;ume and carry off the halituous Excre­
ments of the Blood, in &longs;uch plenty as is
requi&longs;ite.

Now that Air too much thicken'd (and
as it were clogg'd) with Steams, is unfit
for Re&longs;piration, may appear by what is
wont to happen in the Lead-Mines of De­
von&longs;hire, (and, for ought I know, in tho&longs;e
too of other Countrys, though I have
&longs;een Mines where no &longs;uch thing was com­
plain'd of) for I have been inform'd by
more then one credible Per&longs;on (and parti­
cularly by an Ingenious Man, that has of­
ten, for curio&longs;ity, digg'd in tho&longs;e Mines,
and been imploy'd about them) that there
often ri&longs;es Damps, as retaining the Ger­
mane Word by which they call them)
which does &longs;o thicken the Air, that unle&longs;s
the Work-men &longs;peedily make &longs;igns to
them that are above, they would (which
al&longs;o &longs;ometimes happens) be pre&longs;ently
&longs;tifled for want of Breath; and though
their Companions do make ha&longs;te to draw
them up, yet frequently, by that time
they come to the free Air, they are, as it
were, in a &longs;woon, and are a good while be­
fore they come to them&longs;elves again.

And
that this &longs;wooning &longs;eems not to proceed
from any Ar&longs;enical or Poy&longs;onous Exhala­
tion contain'd in the Damp, as from its
over-much conden&longs;ing the Air, &longs;eems pro­
bable from hence; That the &longs;ame Damps
